fields.headline: Henry and Kanu to do the Lyon's share
fields.trailText: Arsene Wenger is hoping that frustration among his forwards will reap handsome dividends, with Thierry Henry and Nwankwo Kanu likely to get the nod tonight.
fields.body:
Given that Arsène Wenger has been publicly criticised by Dennis Bergkamp, Nwankwo Kanu and Sylvain Wiltord in the past week, it would be understandable if the Arsenal manager was panicking about an internal revolt. Instead he seems to be rubbing his hands.

Keeping four top-class strikers happy is near impossible but Wenger knows a little frustration can go a long way. How easily a whingeing run can feed a winning run was plain to see against Chelsea on Sunday.

No sooner had Wiltord complained that being left out in Lyon had "stuck in his throat" and that he did not "always understand the choices of the coach" than he came off the bench to give a match-winning performance. As Wenger planned for tonight's crucial return leg he sounded unconcerned by his forwards' comments.

"I can understand that the strikers want to play but I know as well that if you don't have four strikers you have no chance," he said. "As long as their frustration has positive consequences on the results of the team I'm OK. A champion shows how strong he is on the field."

Six successive wins show that the players are performing. Wenger senses the old consis tency and mental strength are returning and knows three points tonight will go a long way to earning a quarter-final place. A further victory at home to Spartak Moscow on March 6 would make certain.

The fact that Thierry Henry has partnered Kanu in every Champions League game so far hints at this evening's unhappy couple. Ray Parlour will return for Arsenal after suspension, as should Tony Adams. Gilles Grimandi or Oleg Luzhny will fill in for the ineligible Igor Stepanovs.

Arsenal (possible, 4-4-2): Seaman; Dixon, Grimandi, Adams, Cole; Lauren, Parlour, Vieira, Pires; Henry, Kanu.

fields.headline: Counter culture costs Reds dear
fields.standfirst:
Minute-by-minute match report
David Lacey's match report
fields.trailText: Richard Williams on how the removal of Ryan Giggs changed the entire complexion of Manchester United's performance.
fields.body:
For the opening quarter of an hour of last night's match at Old Trafford, Sven-Goran Eriksson must have been hugging himself with pleasurable anticipation. There were six Englishmen in the Manchester United side - two defenders, two midfielders and two forwards - and every one appeared to be worth a place not just in the squad he will announce on Friday morning, but in his starting line-up against Spain next week. Facing a very good Valencia team, they looked magisterial.

Unfortunately the removal of one Welshman changed the entire complexion of the performance. After making the opening goal for Andy Cole, Ryan Giggs went straight to the touchline and spoke to United's physiotherapist. Five minutes later he was putting on his jacket, and Nicky Butt was taking his place.

With Giggs went the shape and coherence that had shaken the visitors in the opening 15 minutes. As Butt joined Roy Keane and Paul Scholes in patrolling the central areas, gone was the priceless width that had stretched Valencia to breaking point.

From that moment United seemed strangely content to sit on their lead, allowing Valencia to come at them and at times living dangerously. For a while this concentration on defence allowed Wes Brown and Gary Neville to demonstrate their competence, the former producing another composed display alongside Jaap Stam at the heart of the rearguard until, with less than five minutes to play, he threw himself at Vicente Rodriguez's low cross from the left and turned the ball inside the near post to give Valencia a thoroughly deserved equaliser.

One mistake under pressure ought not to be enough to damage the good opinion which Eriksson will have formed of the young defender's precocious talent, although it may make him think twice about putting Brown on the fast track to a place in the team for the forthcoming World Cup qualifying matches.

England's new manager was given another slightly puzzling message by the performance of David Beckham, whose creative contribution waned as his aggression came to the fore in the second half - leading to a booking for a foul on Kily Gonzalez and then, perilously, a ticking-off for a further offence against Ruben Baraja. Bringing his temper under control, Beckham subsequently attracted fouls by Baraja and Amedeo Carboni, both booked for their efforts.

Whatever role Eriksson may have mind for Beckham, Sir Alex Ferguson appears in little doubt about his most effective position in United's formation. The No7 started the match in his accustomed place on the right wing, and announced himself with three fine touches in the first five minutes - a silky glance inside, a sumptuous volleyed backheel to Cole, and a ball driven from one touchline to the other which set Mickael Silvestre off on a dribble that provided the first indication of vulnerability in the right flank of the Valencia defence.

It was from there United's goal originated, when Giggs made the most of the combined failure of a mix-up between Jocelyn Angloma and Miguel Angel Angulo. The Welshman's reaction to the opportunity was swift and deadly, but Eriksson would have been more interested in the cool aplomb with which Cole put the chance away. Cole's record of no goals in 10 England appearances would appear to put him some way down the queue for a place against Spain, but he looked perfectly comfortable against this opposition.

These two sides, equally dedicated to attacking football, will always produce an entertaining match, but whereas Ferguson is reaping the reward of more than a decade of team-building, Hector Cuper has been struggling to replace the attack that took the club to last season's European Cup final. So far the lanky John Carew looks nothing like an adequate replacement for Adrian Ilie, although the 21-year-old Pablo Aimar, acquired this month from River Plate, looks more than promising.

Resembling a cross between Georgi Kinkladze and Juninho, the diminutive Aimar saw Kily waste his brilliant first-time flick with a shot over the bar after five minutes, but was as culpable himself 20 minutes later when he sidefooted wide of the far post with only Fabien Barthez to beat.

United's inability to hold on to their advantage can be put down to an uncharacteristic willingness to fall into a reliance on counter-attacks, seemingly founded on a belief in their capacity to hold Valencia at bay for more than an hour. The Spanish team are too richly talented to justify such a risk, and it was Brown's misfortune to be the scapegoat for what was, in the end, a collective failure.

fields.headline: Anderlecht 1 - 4 Leeds
fields.trailText: Teams
fields.body:
Teams

Anderlecht 23-Zvonko Milojevic; 16-Bertrand Crasson, 2-Aleksander Ilic, 5-Glen De Broek, 9-Didier Dheedene; 4-Yves Vanderhaeghe, 10-Walter Baseggio, 11-Alin Stoica, 7-Bart Goor; 8-Jan Koller, 13-Tomasz Radzinski

Leeds 1-Nigel Martin; 29-Rio Ferdinand, 5-Lucas Redebe, 21-Dominic Matteo; 19-Eirik Bakke, 4-Olivier Dacourt, 23-David Batty, 18-Danny Mills, 3-Ian Harte; 9-Mark Viduka, 17-Alan Smith.

Referee Rune Pedersen (Norway).

1 Leeds kick off on a cool evening in the Belgian capital. Anderlecht take up early residence in the Leeds half before Smith is able to clear for Viduka to chase to the Anderlecht area.
2 Anderlecht corner on the right; Leeds caught napping when Dheedene plays it short but David O'Leary's men eventually clear.
4 Leeds free-kick just shy of the centre circle, Harte only manages to drift the ball into Anderlecht keeper Milojevic.
5 Stoica charges into the gap on the edge of the Leeds area, but good running by Matteo marshals the ball away for a throw.
7 Leeds free-kick 20 yards out; Harte takes it and a wicked deflection sends the ball over for a corner. Comes to nothing.
8 Smith's lay off set up Bakke for a snap shot from the edge of the area that Milojevic tips over the bar. Good movement early on by Smith and Viduka shows Leeds are not going to be intimidated by Anderlecht's formidable home record of 20 wins out of 20.
11 Stoica and Radzinski combine for Stoica to fire in a shot from wide on the left; Martyn claims.
12 Stoica lays it off for Radzinski to shoot wide from the edge of the area.
13 GOAL: Anderlecht 0 - 1 Leeds Made by Viduka when gets to the by-line, looks up and pulls it back for Smith fire home from 10 yards.
17 Leeds free-kick just inside the Anderlecht half. Another floater in the box by Harte, but this time at least Ferdinand manages to glance it on (straight to the keeper). The Leeds contingent are providing all the noise in the Constant Van Den Stock stadium as the home fans try to come to grips with the possibility of a home defeat.
22 Leeds with their tails up as Radebe cuts off a Stoica pass to Radzinski on the edge of the area.
25 Smith has an unecessary dig at Ilic and spills him over the by-line. Gets away with it.
27 Viduka muscled off the ball before he can wriggle through in the Anderlecht area; just fails to set up Bakke as he is floored.
28 Booking Danny Mills for having a pop at Radzinski. Radebe clears the free-kick.
29 Good vision by Ferdinand when he delivers a cross-field pass to Viduka racing away on the right - shame the ball raced away from Viduka.
31 Viduka wins a corner on the left.
33 Ferdinand tussles with man-mountain Koller and comes off better.
34 GOAL: Anderlecht 0 - 2 Leeds Matteo's ball to the far post finds Viduka, and the Australian - on his back foot - gets up to loop a header over Milojevic for Leeds's second.
38 GOAL: Anderlecht 0 - 3 Leeds Great composure from Smith as he lifts the ball over Milojevic with his right foot from bang on 18 yards.
39 Substitution Dindane on for Ilic.
41 Stoica blows a chance to pull one back as he fires over from just outside the area.
44 Anderlecht free-kick a few yards outside the Leeds area. Dindane tries to bend it in but he can't even hit the target.
45 Leeds free-kick from 25 yards. Played short for Mills to fire wide. Half-time Great half for Leeds. Anderlecht's midfield have barely been allowed to move and Smith and Viduka have been inspired up front - Smith for constantly harrassing the back line, Viduka for fine touches, and both for goals.

46 Anderlecht get the second half underway.
47 Booking Harte for sliding on Dindane as the Anderlecht player got away on the right.
48 Anderlecht knock the ball around on the edge of the Leeds area; possession ends when Vanderhaeghe's shot is deflected away from goal.
50 More urgency to Anderlecht's play, not surprisingly, as Dindane probes repeatedly down the right.
52 Dindane makes the mistake of not sticking to runs down the flank when delivers a shockingly inaccurate deep pass upfield.
55 Baseggio finds Dindane on the edge of the area but his shot carries all the weight of a flying powder-puff.
57 Leeds corner, taken by Harte, comes to nothing. Harte wins another after the ball is played back to him from the clearance. Ferdinand smacks this one through the crowd from 10 yards and beats Milojevic only to see his effort cleared off the line by Koller, with a suspicion of handball.
60 Despite Anderlecht's urgency Leeds are still in control and have had easily the best chance of the last 15 minutes.
65 Goor gets through from a knock-on by Stoica but Martyn charges out to save the resulting left-foot shot. Corner comes to nothing.
72 Another chance goes begging for Goor, who must have been on the end of a rocket at half-time as he barely featured in the first half. He shoots wide at the far post from six yards after everyone misses a free-kick into the area.
76 GOAL: Anderlecht 1 - 3 Leeds Martyn comes to meet a free-kick, misses it and Koller heads in from 10 yards.
78 Goor does well to pull the ball back from the by-line as Koller fires in another; Martyn saves superbly to tip over.
79 Leeds on the back foot at the moment as Anderlecht pile on the pressure, full of confidence after pulling one back.
81 GOAL: Anderlecht 1 - 4 Leeds De Broek gets a bit over-confident when he climbs all over Viduka in the area and floors him - penalty . Harte steps up to ensure victory for Leeds with a well-struck spot-kick to the left of Milojevic.
83 Substitution Kewell on for Viduka.
89 Anderlecht know the game is up as things become scrappy in the final minutes. Leeds still chasing and closing down however.
90 Leeds have a last crack at a fifth when Harte drifts the ball in to the far post. Full-time.
Anderlecht 1 - 4 Leeds Leeds through to the quarter-finals after Real Madrid hold Lazio to a 2-2 draw.

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Sam
fields.trailText: You'll have to excuse Simon, he's obviously an Aussie. Why do they feel the need to denigrate New Zealand? Perhaps it's insecurity...
fields.body:
Dear Milly,

You'll have to excuse Simon, he's obviously an Aussie. Why do they feel the need to denigrate New Zealand? Perhaps it's insecurity... Has he not seen the sky explode with colour as the sun sets over Mount Cook? Has he not dived into a crystal clear mountain lake after a hard days hiking through the Southern Alps? Has he not overdosed on adrenalin in Queenstown? New Zealand is an extraordinary and diverse place. It's just a pity about the neighbours...

Enjoy it!

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Michael
fields.trailText: When are you leaving Australia? There's so much to see. I guess NZ is tempting to move on to but I'd a least go to Byron Bay while you are there; you could rent out surf boards for a week and camp on the beach. If you don't, you'll miss out on the surfer bum thing and all the other crazies that live in Byron.
fields.body:
Hi Milly, how are you?

When are you leaving Australia? There's so much to see. Sydney is a beautiful city but it's in a world of its own. Sometimes I thought I could have been in any country in the world, apart from the sun and beaches.

I guess NZ is tempting to move on to but I'd a least go to Byron Bay while you are there; you could rent out surf boards for a week and camp on the beach. If you don't, you'll miss out on the surfer bum thing and all the other crazies that live in Byron. Also a trip to Nimbin, just next door, is essential.

Are you flying out of Sydney? Brisbane is just as easy. Money is a constraint but you could get a petrol share up the coast for $30...

Good luck with whatever you do,

Michael.

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Tony and Elaine
fields.trailText: How does it feel to be responsible for all the people you have inspired to travel? Thought you might like to know that you have done it again - my wife and I have decided to sell up, move to a smaller house with NO MORTAGE and finance a trip around the world! Reading your diaries has given us a taste for adventure.
fields.body:
Hi Sue,

How does it feel to be responsible for all the people you have inspired to travel? I have been reading your diaries since the first week and I have just read all the emails people have sent you. I, too, am in education, 45 years old (I am a beginner - only in my third year!) and have made some life changing decisions in my time (university as a mature student and a change of career - I used to be a joiner!), but you are doing the ultimate challenge and I salute you!

Thought you might like to know that you have done it again - my wife and I have decided to sell up, move to a smaller house with NO MORTAGE and finance a trip around the world! Reading your diaries has given us a taste for adventure. It still feels like a massive step to take, especially the first bit - actually being on your own in a foreign world, culture, language etc. etc. In your diaries you come across as being without fear and you sound very confident ( you also sound as if you are having a great time which is really bloody annoying to us in dear old Blighty!). Is this how it was for you?

I would love to hear from you if you can afford the time - I will understand if you can't - sorry I haven't got any tips for you, just admiration!

Good luck for the rest of your travels

Tony Hall, teacher of English (please don't find anything wrong with my grammar), Macclesfield, Cheshire.

webTitle: European cruise ship runs aground off island of Nevis

fields.headline: European cruise ship runs aground off island of Nevis
fields.trailText: A cruise ship carrying more than 1,000 European passengers ran aground yesterday off the south coast of the Caribbean island of Nevis.
fields.body:
A cruise ship carrying more than 1,000 European passengers ran aground yesterday off the south coast of the Caribbean island of Nevis.

The MS Mistral, operated by the Greek line Festival Cruises, became stuck on a sand bank around 3 am, about 900 feet off shore, according to St. Kitts and Nevis government spokesman Erasmus Williams. The ship was carrying 530 crew and 1,130 passengers, mainly French, German, British and Italian. No passengers were injured.

Crews were working to refloat the vessel and the passengers would stay aboard until divers were able to determine how extensive the damage was, said Major Pat Wallace of the coast guard. If the damage was not extensive, the ship was expected to continue on its journey to Antigua. Although the front of the ship was taking in some water, the leak was located in a watertight bulkhead and was therefore no cause for concern.

The ship was on a weeklong cruise, heading from Dominica to the French island of St. Barthelemy, when it ran aground.

webTitle: Week 12: Byron Bay to Frazer Island

fields.headline: Far from the madding crowd
fields.standfirst: Deciding it's time to move on from Byron Bay when he finds that  meeting an Australian has become an exciting event, Sam heads up the coast to take a tour of  Frazer Island, an experience marred only by the guide's inability to remember his name
fields.trailText: Week 12, Byron Bay to Frazer Island Deciding it's time to move on from Byron Bay when he finds that meeting an Australian has become an exciting event, Sam heads up the coast to take a tour of Frazer Island, an experience marred only by the guide's inability to remember his name
fields.body:
My week started with an uncomfortable 11-hour bus ride along Australia's east coast. The air conditioning was broken, I had a screaming child behind me, and the driver was almost as grumpy as the Greyhound bus drivers in the US.

This one had a ridiculous number of rules and regulations that he laboriously repeated at each stop. These included no food, no drinks, no closing the ventilators (particularly pointless, since they weren't working) and no stretching. Ok, I made that last one up but it might as well have been a rule since the seats were so cramped you could scarcely move a toe.

After an eternity, I reached Byron Bay. This is a centre for all things alternative and everywhere you went there were wind chimes for sale and adverts for yoga lessons or discussion groups on Buddhism. The town also has some glorious beaches and there were usually plenty of surfers out riding the waves.

I was considering getting some surfing lessons, so thought I would have an exploratory dip first - to test the water as it were. The breakers were huge and it was a real struggle to fight my way beyond them to the calmer sea. I bobbed up and down on the swell for a while before having a go at bodysurfing. I saw a biggish wave coming up behind me, swam hard and managed to catch it. I had a brief glorious sensation of being swept along. Then everything turned upside down as the wave broke and I was pulled under. I could only have been down for a short while but by the time I escaped, I was left flapping about in the shallows gasping for breath.

Not one to give up that easily, I went out for another go. This time the force of the wave almost ripped my shorts off. I just managed to cling onto them but with my hands down by my side, I couldn't direct my approach through the white turmoil. I ended up headfirst in the sand. Enough was enough and I decided to avoid any further embarrassment by sticking to sunbathing.

Byron Bay is one of Australia's top holiday spots and in the evening there was a real buzz about the place, with plenty of bars and restaurants and the usual naff clubs you find in coastal resorts. It was also full of English teenagers. The UK must be a rather quiet place at the moment as everyone seems to be over here. I thought this was good at first as I always had plenty in common with the people I met, but it begins to get you down after a while. I realised it was time to move on after I got over-excited when the guy next to me at the bar turned out to be an authentic Australian.

I got back on the bus, zipped through a dreary-looking Brisbane, and on up to Hervey Bay, the launch pad for trips to Frazer Island.

Frazer Island is the world's largest sandbar (120km by 15km). It has huge drifting sand dunes; crystal clear lakes, and rainforest with an amazing variety of trees and plants. As such, it is on the world heritage list and the northern part is protected by National Park status. There are no paved roads so the only way to explore the island is by four-wheel drive. There are a variety of operators in Hervey Bay itching to help you do this and relieve you of your cash.

The two main options are self-drive (where you basically make up a group out of whoever's booked in for that day) or a guided trip where you get taken round in a huge bus with a commentary on the wildlife. I had booked with Frazer Escape who offer something in between. You get to share the driving but a guide comes along to show the way. At A$220, this all-inclusive three-day trip was pretty good value.

I was in a group of 20, split between two Toyota land cruisers. We were shown a sobering video of newsclips of some horrific accidents that have happened on the island when trucks have rolled over or crashed into each other. There was also a brief explanation of how to drive the vehicles. Then we packed our food and rucksacks onto the vehicles and set off for the ferry.

There were storm winds forecast for that night so the first thing we did on reaching the island was to grab a good campsite. This was where the benefits of having a guide. He knew the best places and we quickly found a sheltered spot off the beach. After setting up our tents, the afternoon was spent at nearby Lake Wabby. This deep little lake was surrounded by dunes on one side and eucalyptus forest on the other. We all sunbathed or splashed about and played frisbee.

After dinner we made a fire and sat around chatting and playing drinking games into the night. The key to these sort of trips being successful is the people who are on them. I was lucky enough to be with a really good bunch who all mucked in and had a laugh at the same time.

The following days were spent in much the same vein. We drove along the endless, windswept beach past rusting shipwrecks. We swam in more warm, clear lakes. We walked up steep sand dunes and then rolled back down them. We went for hikes in the rainforest and floated down streams back to the beach. We climbed up headlands and tried to spot the man-eating sharks, which make swimming in the sea a no go.

The land cruisers were great vehicles and could go anywhere. We would rev down narrow, bumpy tracks, rocking from side to side, everyone in the back hanging on and shouting helpful instructions to the driver. We got stuck in soft sand a couple of times and everybody had to jump out and push but it was all part of the fun.

Our guide certainly knew his way round the island but he could have done with learning a thing or two about customer relations. He didn't, for example, bother to try to learn our names. When something needed to be done he would just point and say "you!". The company also let themselves down a bit with the accommodation on our return to Hervey Bay. Little things like broken bunk beds and being charged a non-refundable A$1.50 for sheets that you don't need are rather annoying.

However, these were only minor complaints and all in all, it was a really good trip to an amazing place with an excellent group of people.

Thanks for your emails. I'm glad to see the mystery of my missing duck has been solved. I'd been wondering where he'd flown off to. It's good to know he's enjoying himself back in New York.

Next week I'm going on another camping trip, this time into the heart of the outback to see Uluru (Ayers Rock) and then a brief stopover in Perth before reaching Africa. Over the last few days, I've decided to change my route through Africa slightly, so I'll tell you more about that in my next report.

fields.headline: Yelland defends Bulger stance
fields.trailText: 6.45pm: David Yelland has defended his decision to publish letters that purport to be from James Bulger's killer. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Sun editor David Yelland has defended his paper's decision to publish "menacing" letters that purport to be from James Bulger's killer Robert Thompson.

The letters were published in spite of the controversial court order to protect Thompson's identity and whereabouts.

"We have to be responsible and check facts and we have to ensure that we're not breaching what the court has said in terms of identifying where [they] are," said Mr Yelland.

"But there is a huge well of public interest about what's happened and no matter what the authorities do, newspapers will continue asking questions," he said.

"If ever there was a public interest defence for the press to ask questions it's a case like this.

"We're not going to follow these boys, we're not going to be able to anyway.

"The Home Office has misjudged us.

"They think we're out to identify these boys and we're not."

"What we're out to do is tell the story," insisted Mr Yelland.

The letters emerged just days after the toddler's father Ralph Bulger lost his bid to have the court order guaranteeing Mr Thompson and his cohort, Jon Venables, anonymity.

Although there is no legal reason not to publish the letters, the publication of them exposes the limitations of the court order.

webTitle: Foot-and-mouth outbreak: government bans animal exports

fields.headline: Foot-and-mouth outbreak: government bans animal exports
fields.standfirst: Special report: what's wrong with our food?
fields.trailText: The government this evening moved to contain the outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease by banning exports of live animals, meat, milk and other animal products as the European Union, Ireland and the United States banned animal imports from the UK.
fields.body:
The government this evening moved to contain the outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease by banning exports of live animals, meat, milk and other animal products as the European Union, Ireland and the United States banned animal imports from the UK.

The agriculture minister, Nick Brown, said that extra resources were being deployed to act swiftly and firmly against the disease and put the nation's farming industry back on track.

He urged farmers to play their part in stamping out the disease which, if not controlled, could see thousands of animals slaughtered without profit. The UK ban came shortly after the Irish government banned imports of animal and dairy products from this country because of the foot-and-mouth outbreak. The United States has banned the import of live pigs and pork products from the UK.

The ban came on the day veterinary inspectors had investigated a suspected outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease at a fourth British farm, sparking fears that it may be spreading.

The Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food said a team of inspectors had been sent to Stroud, Gloucestershire, to assess whether the disease was present. A five-mile animal exclusion zone had been placed around the farm as a precaution.

A spokesman said: "We can confirm that a farm near Stroud, Gloucestershire, is under investigation. We do not have any more details than that at this time."

The first indication of the outbreak came yesterday when 27 infected pigs were discovered at Cheale Meats abattoir in Little Warley, Essex. These were the first cases of the disease in Britain for 20 years.

The two farms which delivered the pigs to the abattoir last Friday - one in the Isle of Wight, the other in Buckinghamshire - are also being tested for the presence of foot-and-mouth among livestock.

The cases were confirmed by the chief veterinary officer, Jim Scudamore, a Maff spokeswoman said. The ministry said a routine veterinary inspection of animals at the premises had proved "highly suspicious", with suspected symptoms of foot-and-mouth found in 27 pigs.

Maff said it was working with local authorities to contact farmers within the exclusion limits who were being warned to look out for animals either lame or off their feed.

A spokeswoman said: "We need the assistance of the farming community to check their stock and report any potential symptoms, because this does spread very rapidly." She said there was no threat to humans.

Exclusions were placed around the farms yesterday, but Maff said there had been no confirmation of an outbreak of the disease at either of the farms.

The movement restriction zones apply to all cloven hoof animals, including pigs, sheep, goats and cattle, and will remain in place pending further investigation.

Foot-and-mouth is a highly infectious viral disease which can affect cattle, pigs, sheep and goats. Symptoms include the development of blisters in the mouth causing increased salivation and lameness.

It is not usually fatal, but animals cease gaining weight and production in dairy cattle falls.

The last major outbreak in Britain was 20 years ago, while the most recent outbreak in the EU took place in Greece last year. An outbreak in 1967 led to the slaughter of more than 400,000 animals.

The food standards agency said yesterday that the cases had no implications for the human food chain.

fields.headline: First among equals
fields.standfirst: Daphne Obang, trailblazing social services director
fields.trailText: Profile: Daphne Obang, trailblazing social services director
fields.body:
Bracknell Forest, seen by some as the belly button of the south-east's own silicon valley, has not had much in the way of celebrity status to cheer about. It may be home to IT giants Panasonic, Dell computers and 3M, but most people would be hard-pressed to point out the unitary council on a map. Yet it has made history by appointing Britain's first black woman social services director, Daphne Obang.

Obang, whose brief also includes housing, will be expected to sort out the council's social services department, which, just days before her appointment, was severely criticised for failing local people in a joint review report from the social services inspectorate and audit commission.

It is a challenge she relishes. Obang, currently assistant director for community care at Camden council, north London, says: "I'm fascinated with what goes wrong and with what goes on inside people's thinking - the little glitches that can happen in people's communication between the internal and external world."

An avid Ruth Rendell fan, Obang is expecting to take an analytical approach of the "whydunnit" variety, rather than the "whodunnit", to address the problems highlighted in the joint review. "It's the social and economic factors which have created a dysfunctional situation," she insists. "And the 'why' is just fascinating."

There have been only four black directors of social services in the past - all men and none still in post - and one Asian director still serving. So why would a Conservative-run borough, with an ethnic minority population of just 2.7%, want to employ a black woman director? And why would an up-and-coming professional with a history of working in complex London boroughs - assistant area team manager in Croydon, resource manager at Tower Hamlets and head of adult services for Newham - want to work there? Simple, says Brack nell Forest chief executive Gordon Mitchell: Obang is the best person for the job. "Her personal qualities include the fact that she is someone who can pull people together and encourage people to work better together and handle change sensitively and effectively," he explains.

For her part, Obang, says she was taken with the common ground she shared with council leaders in the borough's plan of the way forward. "I was really impressed when I met the recruitment panel and they seemed to me to have their hearts and heads in the right places in terms of delivering good social health care for their area," she says.

Bracknell, then in Berkshire, was built in 1949 as one of the last new towns. Together with its surrounding area, it has grown from some 30,000 people in the 1950s to 111,500 today. As the region has matured - it became Bracknell Forest in 1988 - so have its people; a 20% surge in the number of older people is expected in the next 10 to 15 years.

Voters twice returned a full house of 40 Conservative councillors, in 1983 and 1987, and the Tories currently account for 30 of the 40 seats. But council leaders have accepted radical change is necessary since the first warning signs of poor social services, from an internal review, prompted the resignation last August of the former director, Trevor Farmer.

When she takes up her post in May, Obang will inherit a department with staff vacancy rates of 16%, a perceived lack of direction and huge challenges in terms of commissioning services and inter-agency partnerships, particularly with the voluntary sector.

Multi-partnership working is the future for social care, says Obang, who credits herself with having helped set up one of the earliest community mental health teams in London's east end, while at Newham. A student of the government's modernisation agenda, she professes herself to have been thrilled on first reading the NHS plan, which she took to the top of a famous landmark near her home to pore over on a sunny Sunday.

"It was very exciting - almost as exciting as reading one of my thrillers," she says. "It's a plan which tries to give a lot of control and power back to people when they are using public services, and that can only be right . We really have to get shot forever of the notion that people who make you better are somehow from a different stratosphere than the patient."

Obang trained as a psychiatric nurse; her first job was as a mental health social worker in Lewisham, south London, and she has had close links with health throughout her career - she is currently a non-executive director of her local community health trust. "I'm passionate about public service and the social health care system, just wanting to make things better," she says.

She admits there are problems with the image of social work and would like to see the Association of Directors of Social Services take more of a lead role in repackaging the profession's image to tackle long-running staff recruitment and retention difficulties. She is adamant that frontline staff can, with proper training and support, be empowered to be full partners in the brave new world of social care.

But Farmer's early departure was a salutary lesson. And with a chill wind gusting across the social care sector, Obang's view of the meteorological office headquarters from her new Bracknell base could prove a useful reminder of how the political climate can blow hot and cold.

How a mentoring scheme aims to ensure that Daphne Obang won't be the only black social services director: www.SocietyGuardian.co.uk/socialcare/

"It was very exciting - almost as exciting as reading one of my thrillers," she says. "It's a plan which tries to give a lot of control and power back to people when they are using public services, and that can only be right . We really have to get shot forever of the notion that people who make you better are somehow from a different stratosphere than the patient." Obang trained as a psychiatric nurse; her first job was as a mental health social worker in Lewisham, south London, and she has had close links with health throughout her career - she is currently a non-executive director of her local community health trust. "I'm passionate about public service and the social health care system, just wanting to make things better," she says. She admits there are problems with the image of social work and would like to see the Association of Directors of Social Services take more of a lead role in repackaging the profession's image to tackle long-running staff recruitment and retention difficulties. She is adamant that frontline staff can, with proper training and support, be empowered to be full partners in the brave new world of social care. But Farmer's early departure was a salutary lesson. And with a chill wind gusting across the social care sector, Obang's view of the meteorological office headquarters from her new Bracknell base could prove a useful reminder of how the political climate can blow hot and cold. How a mentoring scheme aims to ensure that Daphne Obang won't be the only black social services director: www.SocietyGuardian.co.uk/socialcare/

webTitle: Public sector forced to tackle racism

fields.headline: Public sector forced to tackle racism
fields.trailText: Jack Straw, the home secretary, will tomorrow announce new powers giving statutory force to the official campaign to tackle institutional racism in schools, hospitals, universities and across the whole public sector, including the police and prisons. Alan Travis reports
fields.body:
Jack Straw, the home secretary, will tomorrow announce new powers giving statutory force to the official campaign to tackle institutional racism in schools, hospitals, universities and across the whole public sector, including the police and prisons.

From April a positive legal duty to promote good race relations and equality of opportunity will be imposed on every public body, including ministries, Whitehall departments and local government.

They will have to monitor the ethnic composition of their workforce to ensure it reflects the minority ethnic make-up of their local community.

Public bodies will have a duty to assess the impact on racial equality of proposed policies and new services. For example, if an NHS trust proposes to close, or open, a hospital it would have to publish an assessment of what impact it would have on local minority ethnic communities.

The announcement is being made by Mr Straw in a 60-page consultation paper as part of his attempt to maintain the momentum behind the government's anti-racist campaign. This weekend marks the second anniversary of the official inquiry report into the murder of the black teenager Stephen Lawrence. Mr Straw will tomorrow announce the latest progress report on the 70 recommendations by Sir William Macpherson.

Attempts by the police to tackle institutional racism have already provoked a backlash from some officers who have received the backing of William Hague and some newspapers. The decision to extend the fight right across the public sector, backed by "legal teeth", is likely to intensify the debate.

The statutory duty to combat institutional racism will mean public organisations will have to monitor the impact of existing policies on race equality. So far public debate on this has centred on such questions as the use by police of stop and search tactics, or practices inside the prison service.

The way councils or housing associations allocate homes, or the way schools operate their exclusion policies towards troublesome pupils, will also come under scrutiny.

The new duty will mean that an education authority or a university will have to publish an annual assessment which would not only detail the minority ethnic composition of teaching staff and others but specify levels of achievement by different ethnic groups and incidents of racial harassment.

The measures will be legally enforceable by the commission for racial equality. Official inspection bodies such as Ofsted, HM inspector of police, the chief inspector of prisons, the audit commission and the national audit office will also beable to order compliance.

The consultation paper will leave open the question of whether individual schools or the local education authority will be made the legally responsible body for tackling institutional racism. Ministers are anxious not to create a new bureaucratic paperwork burden on head teachers, or hospital administrators.

fields.headline: About The Whiff
fields.trailText: The Spread Eagle public house on Norfolk Road plays a prominent part in the history of Reading Football Club. So close to the Tilehurst End of the club's long time, and still spiritual, home, Elm Park, that you could fart in the public bar and be heard on the terrace, the pub has catered for both solace and celebration many times over the years. Its most famous patron was the mercurial Robin Friday, who predilection for a pre-match pint was frowned upon even in the Seventies. Despite the move to the modern concrete temple just by the M4, the Spread will always be synonymous with Reading Football Club.
fields.body:
The Spread Eagle public house on Norfolk Road plays a prominent part in the history of Reading Football Club. So close to the Tilehurst End of the club's long time, and still spiritual, home, Elm Park, that you could fart in the public bar and be heard on the terrace, the pub has catered for both solace and celebration many times over the years. Its most famous patron was the mercurial Robin Friday, who predilection for a pre-match pint was frowned upon even in the Seventies. Despite the move to the modern concrete temple just by the M4, the Spread will always be synonymous with Reading Football Club.

There is, however, one stain on its otherwise impeccable reputation: the Spread must take a large part of the blame for the formation of The Whiff. Denied the chance to drink copious amounts of alcohol a very short time after the game, The Whiff might well have merely remained an "I could do that" notion in the back of the editors' minds. After five pints, two spicy pepperamis and a bag of Wheat Crunchies, however, that notion quickly becomes "well, why don't we then?" There's only a short step, about three pints worth, from here to commitment.

The demise of Elm Park and the move to the Mad House provided the final impetus: Reading have a new stadium and so, as the crowds swell beyond 15,000, why not a new fanzine to go with it? OK, you need at least eight pints or a frontal lobotomy (preferably both) to see the logic of that argument but, hey, this is a football fanzine and not the Tractatus Logico-Philosophicus.

Why, "The Whiff"? "Is it because you smell?" asked some knuckle-headed Birmingham fan just before we tonked them at Elm Park. In those strange days before we moved out beyond Smallmead Stadium, there did appear the very real possibility that our spanking new ground would be tainted with that other great feature of our fêted town: the Whitley Whiff. Whatever, there is no disputing that the Madejski Stadium itself is built on the rubble and the rubbish of millions of forgotten inhabitants of the town. The Fanzine would thus be a celebration of the contradiction that is Reading FC: a shiny new stadium set in a stinking wasteland.

All fanzine editors will tell you that they're an independent publication, trying to reflect the voice of the fan. Whilst this is no doubt true, it is also the case that any fanzine is an indulgence, since we are asking you to part with a fraction of your hard-earned merely to read our own prejudices and small-minded opinions. You could, of course, respond, as some have, by sending us opinions of your own to print and for these we are always grateful: they make the content more representative and we have to do less work, which means more time in the pub (not that we're alcoholics or anything).

Ultimately, the Whiff's mission is to entertain. Many fanzines are filled with long and detailed match reports, page after page of opinion about who should be in the side and very little in the way of originality. We like to think the Whiff is a little different. We hope you agree.

webTitle: Politics: Devolution could threaten the election

fields.headline: Pulling the party down
fields.standfirst: Success, and failure, in Scotland and Wales could undermine Labour when it comes to the election
fields.trailText: Jonathan Freedland: Success, and failure, in Scotland and Wales could undermine Labour when it comes to the election.
fields.body:
They're playing "guess the majority" over at Millbank Tower. Not publicly, of course, since complacency is a capital crime on Planet New Labour, but in private all is confidence. The election, whether it comes on April 5 or May 3, belongs to them.

You can understand their swagger. Every possible sign points their way every light is turning green. They look at yesterday's Guardian/ICM poll and see a lead stretching into the distance: a 15-point margin at a time when most governments are lucky to be in the low single digits.

Or they can glance at the "poll of polls" produced by that veteran number-cruncher, Ivor Crewe. His latest average of the competing surveys shows Labour with an even fatter 17-point lead - enough to swell Labour's majority from 179 seats to 229.

The Millbankers can slice it whichever way they like, it's still the same story. Labour are more trusted than the Conservatives to handle education, health and transport - and even traditional Tory strong suits like the economy and law and order. On every measure, they win. No postwar government has enjoyed a command like it even Margaret Thatcher's post-Falklands surge in 1983 was not as strong.

The private polling, where Labour might tell itself some unwelcome truths, is just as encouraging. Voters still associate the Tories with the bad old days of the early 90s - sky-high interest rates, repossessions, negative equity. Black Wednesday has become the Tories' Winter of Discontent: Labour only has to mention it to scare voters on to their side. Reporters may be bored rigid by hearing Gordon Brown chant "No return to boom and bust", but the polls show it works. Yesterday the Halifax did their bit to help, too: their cut in base rates, and the general price war in the mortgage business, all add to the pre-election, feelgood mood.

As if Labour's advantage was not great enough already, it has two more weapons at the ready. First, the Millbank crew have had a recent lesson in how not to do it. They watched Al Gore's narrow defeat last year, realising that even a party presiding over economic good times can lose. Gore's mistake, they concluded, was to treat America's prosperity as a given, thereby denying the Democrats credit for their achievement. That's why the Blairite soundbite du jour is that Britain's economic health - record lows in both inflation and unemployment - is the fruit of "choice, not chance". Labour refuses to let this election become a debate with the Tories on how to spend it - they want credit for generating the surplus cash in the first place. And, so far, they're getting it.

Labour's second nuclear device is William Hague. Polls show the British have warmed to him about as much as they did to Neil Kinnock: they simply do not see him as a plausible prime minister. Indeed, Blair's personal lead over Hague is a whopping 20 points.

No blot, it seems, can muddy this landscape. The Tory boomlet of September's fuel protests went as fast as it came. Peter Mandelson's resignation excited the natterers and chatterers of the Westminster village but made no dent on the polls. The Derry Irvine, cash-for-wigs affair adds to the widespread impression of an arrogant Labour administration - but it seems unlikely to shift many votes. Tony Blair must reckon that his is the Teflon government: both the Mandy and Derry episodes would have unravelled John Major, but they seem to wash right off him.

Can anything darken this blue sky for Labour? Only one thing: turnout. If Labour's supporters stay at home, confident that victory is theirs, and Conservatives head out, energised by their determination to keep the pound, a gap that should have been a mile-wide could suddenly narrow. That's why Blair's last two big speeches were so blatantly aimed at waking up and motivating Labour voters.

In this context there are a couple of distant clouds which, even if they don't threaten to ruin Labour's spring day, could certainly cause the odd unwanted shower. The irony is that both are of the government's own making. Indeed, the source of the trouble is one of Labour's most radical first-term achievements: devolution.

It is in Wales that the problem is most obvious. Labour figures there warn that the party could lose between seven and 10 of the 34 Welsh seats they now hold. They cite the 1999 elections for the new Welsh assembly, when Labour lost the iconic strongholds of the Rhondda, Islwyn (Kinnock's old seat) and Llanelli.

The explanation is simple. "You ask people here what they would prefer to have, the national assembly or bubonic plague, and most of them would opt for the latter," says one Labour sceptic. He believes the government is now blamed for creating a body - following the narrowest of referendum victories in 1997 - which nobody wants. One recent poll found two-thirds of Welsh voters disapproved of the assembly, with Labour taking the rap. A recent council byelection in Wrexham saw Labour's total vote slump to just 50 - in a seat where its previous majority had been 654.

Activists are still smarting over the Alun Michael episode - when Millbank sought to impose its own man as Welsh Labour leader over the people's choice, Rhodri Morgan - and have struggled to recover ever since. Now installed as first minister, Morgan has missed the odd political trick, too: he let himself announce the Corus steel closure in Llanwern, but allowed one of his Liberal Democrat coalition partners to get the glory of revealing that the FA Cup was coming to Cardiff. "Naff politics," sniffs one critic. Punishment could come on polling day, when Welsh voters either defect to Plaid Cymru again - or stay home.

In Scotland, Labour has the reverse problem - not that devolution has failed to bed down, but that it has bedded down too comfortably. While the Welsh still doubt the purpose of their assembly, Scots have grown entirely used to their new parliament in Edinburgh: "It's as if it was always there," says one fulltime observer.

The result is that a general election for Westminster could feel a very faraway affair. Now that so many key decisions are taken at Holyrood, Labour will have an uphill struggle explaining why the coming poll is even relevant to Scotland. After all, the key Blair themes - education, health and crime - are no longer decided in Westminster at all, but in Edinburgh. If anything, the new dispensation helps the Tories: at least their core issues - Europe and asylum, for example - remain Westminster matters. The one crumb of comfort for Labour is that if the remoteness of the House of Commons hurts them, imagine what it does to the Scottish National party: how on earth will they get their vote out?

For wholly opposite reasons - the success of devolution in Scotland, its struggle to take root in Wales - two Labour bastions threaten to spoil the party this spring. It won't be enough to change the final outcome, but it could alter the scale of victory. Any of those Millbank workers, about to place their bet in the office sweepstake, take note.

fields.headline: Lord chancellor has no regrets
fields.standfirst: Labour in power
fields.trailText: February 21 2001: The under-fire Lord chancellor Derry Irvine has rejected criticism of his fund-raising role for the Labour party  and even claimed he would do the same thing again.
fields.body:
The under-fire Lord chancellor Derry Irvine has rejected criticism of his fund-raising role for the Labour party  and even claimed he would do the same thing again.

In his first public comment on the controversy that has engulfed him since Sunday's revelation that he asked Labour-supporting lawyers to pledge at least £200 to the government, Lord Irvine of Lairg said: "I do not believe that I have done anything wrong nor do I believe I have broken any current rules. If I did I would be the first to apologise.

"I would certainly consider doing it again."

The political wrangle  which has dominated headlines during the "phony election" war  was sparked when it was revealed he had hosted a fundraising dinner at London's Atlantic Bar and Grill and asked lawyers to donate money for a Labour second term.

Tory and Liberal-Democrat critics of the Lord chancellor dubbed it the "cash for wigs" scandal as one of Derry Irvine's roles is to appoint QCs, and had called for his resignation.

But replying to questions in the House of Lords, the lord chancellor said he was no different to any other cabinet minister and would consider fundraising again.

A spokeswoman for prime minister Tony Blair said the lord chancellor retained the full confidence of the prime minister and the accusations would be treated with the contempt they deserved. Liberal Democrat Lord McNally, who tabled a question asking whether "the role of lord chancellor is compatible with that of a party fundraiser", said he was disappointed that Lord Irvine did not apologise for the affair.

Although the lord chancellor refused to apologise, he did conceed that the row had created negative publicity for the government.

He said: "Whether or not [doing it again] would attract a furore of this kind would be a consideration I would take into account.

"I believe this furore has distracted attention of country from the real issues."

The fuss centred on the probity of the Lord Chancellor acting a partisan political fund raiser whilst simultaneously being head of the judiciary  in addition to his Cabinet post and legislative role in the Lords.

In an age-old tradition, Lord Irvine was required to take a step away from his seat on the woolsack before answering to demonstrate that he was stepping away from his role as speaker of the Lords and was replying to questions as a cabinet minister.

However the lord chancellor did announce that he would favour an independent commissioner to look into judicial appointments.

fields.headline: Extracts from Lord Irvine's speech
fields.standfirst: Edited highlights of the Lord Chancellor's 15-minute rebuttal of the "cash-for-wigs" affair in the House of Lords this morning. A full transcript will be available at Hansard at 9am on Thursday.
fields.trailText: Liberal Democrat peer Lord McNally, asked the lord chancellor, "whether the role of lord chancellor is compatible with that of a party fundraiser?"
fields.body:
Liberal Democrat peer Lord McNally, asked the lord chancellor, "whether the role of lord chancellor is compatible with that of a party fundraiser?"

Lord Irvine responded: "I do not believe anyone who attended the dinner in question could conceivably have thought that a donation could have bought an appointment advantage."

Every minister from the prime minister downwards was involved in fund raising for the party, he said.

Lord McNally asked Lord Irvine what precedent he thought his behaviour had set, and called on him to apologise.

"There's a blurring by your behaviour of your responsibilities as a minister and your responsibilities as a politician," he said . Lord Irvine insisted he had done nothing wrong nor broken any rules.

"If I did, I would be the first to apologise. There's no real difference between party political campaigning and fundraising because I believe that fundraising is an inherent part of party political campaigning."

He pointed to the example of other lord chancellors who had been involved in campaigning - Tory Lord Hailsham who toured the country at the age of 79 in 1987, Lord Kilmuir who had been on the campaign trail and Lord Mackay who had taken a "high profile" role against Scottish devolution.

"Unless and until the rules are changed a lord chancellor is no different from any other cabinet minister," Lord Irvine argued.

Lord Strathclyde, leader of the opposition in the Lords, asked: "Would you do it again?" Lord Irvine replied that unless the rules were changed, he would consider doing it again. But he went on to say he would also have to consider the furore which the issue had caused.

"This furore is distracting the attention of the country from the real issues facing it," he said.

Lord Irvine said the same rules about fundraising applied to the lord chancellor as to other ministers, and he pointed out that 26,000 public appointments were direct ministerial appointments.

Lord Howe of Aberavon, the Tory former deputy prime minister, said there was a difference between political campaigning and fundraising.

He insisted that Lord Irvine's predecessors would have recognised the difference "intuitively and instinctively", and been "bound by the unwritten rule".

Lord Irvine said: "I would be very surprised if Tory lord chancellors had not attended fundraising dinners.

"It would have been completely unobjectionable for them to have done so and it would have aided fundraising by their attendance."

Lord Irvine added he was about to appoint the first commissioner for judicial appointments, and had not closed his mind to the idea of a commission for judicial appointments.

"It is a very controversial proposition and you know well there are many who are really opposed to that proposition because of the dangers which it is said to pose to appointments on merit only as distinct from appointments which make compromises. "But I take this opportunity to say again I have not closed my mind to this and after the new commissioner for judicial appointments has presented his first annual report to parliament it will be time for us to sit back, take stock, and to see if it is a sensible course to go out to consultation on the possibility of an appointments commission."

webTitle: Lord Mackay dies on way to Lords

fields.headline: Lord Mackay dies on way to Lords
fields.trailText: Former Tory minister Lord Mackay of Ardbrecknish died today after collapsing on his way to the House of Lords.
fields.body:
Former Tory minister Lord Mackay of Ardbrecknish died today after collapsing on his way to the House of Lords.

Peers were told by Baroness Jay, the Labour leader in the Lords, that the 62-year-old was taken to hospital but did not survive the journey. Peers will have the opportunity to pay tribute to him on Monday.

Lord Mackay had been on duty on the Woolsack when the House rose after a 13-hour sitting at 3.32am this morning. The former MP for Argyll and Bute was taken to St George's hospital, Tooting, following a suspected heart attack.

The peer's political career spanned more than 40 years. He was social security minister in John Major's government from 1994 to 1997 and became deputy leader of the opposition in the Lords before recently joining the crossbenches on his appointment as chairman of the Lords committees.

He led a Lords revolt last year against the Labour government's efforts to push through a freedom of information bill, saying it was still far too secretive.

In a brief statement, Baroness Jay told peers: "The noble Lord Mackay of Ardbrecknish, the chairman of committees has died.

"I understand that he collapsed on his way to the House this morning, was taken by ambulance to St George's hospital in south London but sadly did not survive the journey. "I know that many of us will wish to take the chance to pay proper tribute to him and that will be done on Monday afternoon when the House resumes after the brief recess."

Tory peer Lord Luke said: "It's a shock to hear the awful news this morning but one thing our friend would have said is: Tthe show must go on'."

Michael Ancram, chairman of the Conservative party, said: "John Mackay was a great servant of the party. "From his victory in Argyll in 1979 which led the Tory revival in Scotland at that election, until very recently when he took on his new non-political role in the House of Lords, he was a tireless advocate and promoter of conservatism north of the border. "He was a courageous and dynamic minister in the Scottish Office at a very difficult time in the 1980s.

"Over the last 10 years, he became a major figure in the House of Lords respected on all sides."

Born in 1938, John Jackson MacKay was educated at Campbeltown grammar school and Glasgow University.

After becoming a maths teacher in Oban, he joined the Commons as Conservative MP for Argyll in 1979.

He joined the Lords in 1991, listing fishing and sailing as his hobbies, and leaves a widow Sheena.

webTitle: Moratorium sought on DU shell testing

fields.headline: Moratorium sought on DU shell testing
fields.standfirst: Special report: depleted uranium
fields.trailText: Campaigners have demanded a moratorium on the testing of depleted uranium shells after the Ministry of Defence resumed test-firing at a military base in Scotland yesterday.
fields.body:
Campaigners have demanded a moratorium on the testing of depleted uranium shells after the Ministry of Defence resumed test-firing at a military base in Scotland yesterday.

It is the first time the weapons have been tested since fears over the shells were heightened by a UN report in January. Locals are opposed to the firing amid growing concerns about health risks which have also been highlighted by veterans of the Gulf war.

Since 1982 more than 7000 DU shells have been fired from the range at the south-western tip of Scotland into the Solway Firth. Most of the shells, some 20 tonnes worth, are still lying on the seabed. Only one has ever been retrieved. Yesterday, 12 DU shells were fired, according to the MoD.

The testing is carried out by the defence evaluation and research agency (Dera) and is due to stop this October. The MoD says it is done under strictly controlled conditions and monitoring has shown only very low levels of DU contamination at the base, well below anything that could be considered a health hazard.

The defence minister, Lewis Mooney, said people in the south-west of Scotland had been subjected to scare stories about the dangers posed by the shells. He said every batch of shells had to be tested to ensure that they met the necessary standards.

"There is no known threat to health from the shells that have been fired into the Solway," said Dr Mooney. "We monitor continuously to ensure there is no effect on background radiation. You have to remember that there is uranium present in the sea naturally and that these shells have never been shown to alter that level."

However, campaigners say the renewed test firing is unacceptable in light of growing concern.

Local MP and MSP Alasdair Morgan said the test programme must be stopped. "I think local feeling is growing," he said. "This is a quiet area where people don't go on protest marches, but concern has hardened over the last few years with the realisation of the nature of the DU weapons.

"The MoD's attitude is that they are right and everyone else is wrong, and how dare anyone question what they are doing if they want to test these shells? I don't think littering the area in that fashion is any way to be carrying on in this day and age."

Locals say there have been misfirings on the 4,500-acre range, and there are reports of traces of beryllium, which is a component of depleted uranium, being found up to 30 miles away from Dundrennan.

Kathleen Glass, a local community councillor, said it was negligent for testing to continue until more was known about the effects. "We are looking for health screening to be offered to civilians employed on the range so they can have that extra reassurance." Tony Duff, a Gulf veteran who ran a support group for ex-service personnel, said the community around Dundrennan was right to be concerned. He said the average 120mm DU shell produces between 1kg and 3kg of DU dust when it strikes a target. "Imagine that much being mixed in the water or ending up on the beaches or flying around in the air," he said. "To say the tests are not as dangerous as in a combat zone is at best sheer folly, at worst complete disinformation."

A spokeswoman for Dera said that a total of 60 DU shells would be fired between now and October at the range. "This is a routine testing programme which was planned before any of the recent scares," she said. "We are test ing the accuracy of the shells by firing them against soft targets, and the alleged health risks occur when the shells are fired at hard targets, like tanks."

A total of 12 DU shells were fired during yesterday's test session.

fields.headline: BBC Online picks up Hitchhiker
fields.trailText: 1.15pm: The BBC will host the official website for Douglas Adams' Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
The BBC is hoping to tap into the obsessive fanbase of Douglas Adams' Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy by hosting the official website, h2g2.com, on its public service website.

The cult site has been temporarily closed while it is stripped of all commercial references and links.

It will be relaunched at bbc.co.uk/h2g2 at the beginning of March.

Hardcore Hitchhiker anoraks have surprisingly given their support to the move.

One fan on the Hitchhiker message board called it "top stuff".

"Obviously the beeb has spotted a thriving community and it's about the only corporation in the UK that isn't trying to put a pound sign on everything.

"This is also certain to ensure the future of h2g2 for as long as anyone cares to mention," he said.

A core of 150,000 fans regularly use h2g2, generating some 3m page impressions each month.

The deal builds on Mr Adams' existing long-term relationship with the BBC. According to BBC Online, the move was initiated by Mr Adams himself.

Mr Adams, said: "The BBC is where Hitchhiker's first started and I am delighted - in the words of the hot new pop combo we've been hearing so much about recently - to get back to where I once belonged."

The site will become a forum for ideas, comments and guides to life.

Ashley Highfield, director of new media at the BBC, said: "H2g2 on BBC Online is a significant step towards engaging with, rather than broadcasting to, our consumers."

webTitle: Letters: More evidence against Derry Irvine

fields.headline: More evidence against Derry Irvine
fields.trailText: Whilst one expects government ministers to defend the lord chancellor after his lack of discretion in asking fellow lawyers for donations to the Labour party (Verdict goes against lord chancellor, February 20), I could not believe Paul Boateng when he said what a great reforming lord chancellor Derry Irvine has been.
fields.body:
Whilst one expects government ministers to defend the lord chancellor after his lack of discretion in asking fellow lawyers for donations to the Labour party (Verdict goes against lord chancellor, February 20), I could not believe Paul Boateng when he said what a great reforming lord chancellor Derry Irvine has been. Boateng claimed the changes in legal aid had improved poor people's access to the legal system.

In fact, the changes will deny legal aid to those whom the legal commission judges to have only a 50-50 chance of success.
Dan Draper
Cowes, Isle of Wight

 Derry Irvine's fault is compounded by his signing off with the phrase: "Yours ever." This is surely more usually associated with Essex girls writing to their sweethearts in the forces, is it not?

Jeff Fendall
Broadstairs, Kent

 My partner, a lawyer and life-long Labour supporter, did not receive a "yours ever, Derry" letter. Will this affect her career?

Neil Grant
London

 Do you think that if I were to offer more than £200, say £300, I might get a guided tour of the famed wallpaper as well as dinner?

Constantine Goulimis
London
cng@greycon.com

fields.headline: No 6. Reading
fields.standfirst: Jeff Kirkpatrick, co-editor of Reading fanzine The Whiff, introduces us to the Royals. Or is it the Biscuitmen?
fields.trailText: What makes us different?
fields.body:
What makes us different?

Where to start? The fanatical belief in our own innate superiority, perhaps, or maybe the unique status accorded us by the footballing Gods, who for some reason decided long ago to mark us out for particularly inequitable treatment? Or is it just that we know we epitomise that old football cliché, the Sleeping Giant? In truth, none of these attributes can be uniquely applied to the Royals as we share each and every one with the myriad of other small clubs who populate the lower reaches of English professional football.

What we also share with many of them is a history steeped in mediocrity and under-achievement. Not qualities you may be inclined to shout about but worn like a veritable badge of pride when confronted with many "modern" football fans, whose sudden interest in the game in the last few years extends no further than Sky TV, the Premiership and almost certainly either Man Utd, Arsenal or Chelsea. Not that we think we're special but it's surely a paradox that whilst the Premiership receives most of the attention, the real hotbed of English football support lies in the Nationwide and Conference leagues.

As for the Royals (or the Biscuitmen, as a few of us Oldies still prefer), the last few years have seen unprecedented change, not of all of which could be considered for the better. Our fabulous new 25,000-seater stadium may seem totally incongruous in a Second-Division setting but surely hints at potential as yet unfulfilled. The catchment area for both fans and players is enormous, with the nearest other League clubs (Oxford, Swindon, Wycombe, Bournemouth) all at least thirty miles away.

And yet, thanks to the pernicious influence of the capital, our fan base has leaked away over the years, principally to Chelsea, Arsenal and Spurs. This may also be because of our own lamentable history of failure but it's frustrating none the less.

The high points

Almost all of Reading's success as a League club has come in the last twenty years or so. Success, of course, is a relative term, as in the last couple of seasons an away win at, say, Chesterfield, would be seized upon as a glorious achievement. When you get used to a diet of unremitting misery, even the merest glimmer can seem like a whole Fort Knox full of gold.

Our victory over Luton in the Simod Cup final at Wembley in 1988 is the biggest single success and enough to make us attempt to rig the result of Observer Sport Monthly's recent poll to find the country's top 100 sporting moments. History is never kind to these events as beating Luton today is hardly climbing football's Everest but, in 1988, Luton were a First Division side who recovered from the 4-1 mauling at our hands to beat Arsenal in the final of the League Cup and also reached the semi-finals of the FA Cup.

Others include the 13 wins in a row at the start of the 1985-86 season (that Fulham failed to equal this year) and the record clean sheets kept by Steve Death back in the 70s.

The low points

So much to choose from, so little time. Any relegation leaves a bitter taste and a gnawing, empty feeling in the pit of the stomach until the new season starts but at least hope is always there somewhere, however fleeting her appearance may prove to be. The real disasters are those financial crisis that threaten the whole future of the club.

For Reading and Oxford fans, the lowest of the low has to be Captain Bob's (Robert Maxwell to the uninitiated) attempt to amalgamate the two clubs under the new banner of the Thames Valley Royals. This all seems like ancient history now but only a few will remember how close the megalomaniac pension thief came to achieving his vile scheme. When will these petty despots realise that messing about with a football club is a dangerous business? The locals, wherever they are, will not go quietly.

High point and low point

Of course, the most dramatic achievement and the most savage disappointment came in one and the same game. The 4-3 defeat by Bolton in the 1995 play-off final came with the Royals on the verge of our first-ever season in the top flight, courtesy of a 2-0 half-time lead and a dominating performance. We also, as if any Royals' fan needed reminding, missed a bloody penalty. In fact, I can't write about this any more - what did I do with that bottle of scotch?

Current position

Scrapping like crazy for at least a play-off position in the Second Division, the Royals are still managing to frustrate their loyal supporters. Brilliant one moment, terrible the next, we are the division's answer to Chelsea - a collection of talented individuals who don't quite function as a team when it matters.

Last fixture

As if to prove a point, a stinker of a home draw against Peterborough. English lower-division football at its worst: all misplaced passes, crunching tackles and defensive cock-ups.

Next fixtures

Oldham away, Swansea away, then Rotherham at home. What a glamorous life we lead! As play-off rivals, the Rotherham game will be crucial although as The Whiff is sponsoring the match ball that day, we'll probably be too full of "free" Bucks Fizz to notice.

Sore point

With the team performing better than for some years, the protracted (not to say bizarre) contract negotiations with our best player, Darren Caskey, seem odd, to say the very least. Having offered him a deal he was about to accept, the club withdrew having just signed a new player (don't ask). Caskey now apparently wants too much money but is out of contract in June so we'll probably lose him on a Bosman.

The chairman

What can we say? A man who almost single-handedly rescued the club from near financial oblivion and certainly penury, funded the building of an extraordinary new stadium and turned traditional small timers Reading into one of the Second Division's "big" clubs. John Madejski may not be much of a football fan but that makes his contribution all the more remarkable.

Of course, it's not very fashionable to praise the chairman, and many in Reading feel that he could and should have committed far more of his vast financial resources. His mistake was in not investing when we were near the top of the First Division, a mistake he has paid very dearly for. Fact is, without him, we'd have nowhere near the resources (he's also funded the Academy), very little hope and possibly not much of a future.

Rivals

Younger Reading fans will expend a great deal of energy spitting bile and venom at Swindon but, if the truth be known, it's all a bit artificial. Swindon don't give a damn about us and can't understand the fuss. Until they folded, our real rivals were Aldershot but unless we fluke a meeting in the cup, that rivalry is unlikely to be renewed.

Kit

Despite what QPR fans might say, the Blue and White Hoops belong to us. Why? Quite simply because we got there first. We may have experimented with various abominations during the 80s but our hearts are in the hoops.

Mascot

The club mascot is a big furry lion called Kingsley. Some time ago, The Whiff uncovered the shocking revelation that it is not, in fact, a real lion but a bloke dressed up in a comedy lion suit. Several of Reading's younger fans had to have the week off school to recover from this news. The faux feline still parades around shamelessly at every game.

Popular players

The most popular and notorious player in Reading's history is the one and only Robin Friday. Both genius and villain, here was a man who spent the build up to the game in the pub, produced moments of extraordinary vision and skill on the pitch and would then flatten the opposition centre-half following one heavy challenge too many. A real 70s man, if you took Stan Bowles, Rodney Marsh and Alan Hudson, rolled them into one and added a liberal dose of wild Romany, you might get something approaching Robin Friday.

With his story already covered in the book The Greatest Footballer You Never Saw, a film is apparently in the offing. Unfortunately, we will never see his like again.

Unpopular players

For some reason, it seems necessary to pick on one player in every squad and single them out for particular vitriol whenever they appear. Current incumbent of this unfortunate position is Keith Jones whose crime has apparently been to have, er, a couple of bad games.

Most ridiculous signing

One Boris Mikhailov, the bewigged Bulgarian World Cup goalkeeper, who joined us the season after our glorious failure to reach the Premiership. Now this may be a myth, but he apparently saw the play-off final and thought we played all our home games at Wembley. Elm Park (our old ground) must have been something of a shock to him.

Worst-ever manager

This category could prove rather contentious. Some may opt for Terry "the Taxi" Bullivant, whose one season in charge saw us relegated after losing thirteen of the last fifteen games. Some may go for his replacement, the high-profile Tommy Burns, who tried to turn Reading into a suburb of Glasgow and frittered away millions whilst achieving precisely bugger all. My own vote goes to Ian Porterfield who, in the early 90s, managed to produce a side of such mind-numbing tedium that I had to leave the country for a while just to avoid going to matches.

Celebrity fans

None, fortunately, since the demise of Israeli spoonbender and all-round arse wipe, Uri Geller. Having embarrassed us with stunts involving telepathy and magic crystals, Geller had the bare-faced cheek to claim that any success we had was down to him and failure was the result of booting him out of the club.

The ground

Nuff said already. Simply the best outside the Premiership. Possibly.

Atmosphere

With the home fans still settling in, the crowd can seem quiet and the stadium acoustics do not help. In my personal opinion the lack of nearby boozers does not help - we need a bit more alcohol-fuelled chanting.

Local knowledge

The stadium might be great, but stuck on industrial park near the motorway, it's not going to win any awards for aesthetic qualities. Indeed, the name of our fanzine, The Whiff, comes from the proximity of the nearby sewage works. The advice has to be: drink in town and get a bus/taxi to the ground. Oh, and don't eat the stadium "food", as cooking is an art that hasn't quite yet penetrated the nether reaches of the modern-day concrete bowl.

Fanzines

With Reading set in the heart of the UK's answer to Silicon Valley, the fanzine community is now almost entirely on the internet. Some of these are very good, especially Hob Nob Anyone?, Offateleven and 1871.

The Whiff is now the only paper-based 'zine in existence at Reading, but testimony to the fact that people still want to hold a newspaper or similar in their hands rather than rush home and read it on the net. However, despite our resolutely Luddite approach, we also have a web site at www.thewhiff.com.
