In truth, none of these attributes can be uniquely applied to the Royals as we share each and every one with the myriad of other small clubs who populate the lower reaches of English professional football. What we also share with many of them is a history steeped in mediocrity and under-achievement. Not qualities you may be inclined to shout about but worn like a veritable badge of pride when confronted with many "modern" football fans, whose sudden interest in the game in the last few years extends no further than Sky TV, the Premiership and almost certainly either Man Utd, Arsenal or Chelsea. Not that we think we're special but it's surely a paradox that whilst the Premiership receives most of the attention, the real hotbed of English football support lies in the Nationwide and Conference leagues. As for the Royals (or the Biscuitmen, as a few of us Oldies still prefer), the last few years have seen unprecedented change, not of all of which could be considered for the better. Our fabulous new 25,000-seater stadium may seem totally incongruous in a Second-Division setting but surely hints at potential as yet unfulfilled. The catchment area for both fans and players is enormous, with the nearest other League clubs (Oxford, Swindon, Wycombe, Bournemouth) all at least thirty miles away. And yet, thanks to the pernicious influence of the capital, our fan base has leaked away over the years, principally to Chelsea, Arsenal and Spurs. This may also be because of our own lamentable history of failure but it's frustrating none the less. Success, of course, is a relative term, as in the last couple of seasons an away win at, say, Chesterfield, would be seized upon as a glorious achievement. When you get used to a diet of unremitting misery, even the merest glimmer can seem like a whole Fort Knox full of gold. Our victory over Luton in the Simod Cup final at Wembley in 1988 is the biggest single success and enough to make us attempt to rig the result of Observer Sport Monthly's recent poll to find the country's top 100 sporting moments. webTitle: Plan for schools wins wide support

fields.headline: Plan for schools wins wide support
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Nearly two-thirds of Labour voters back Tony Blair's plans to reintroduce partial selection to up to half of all state secondary schools in England, according to the results of this month's Guardian/ICM opinion poll.
fields.body:
Nearly two-thirds of Labour voters back Tony Blair's plans to reintroduce partial selection to up to half of all state secondary schools in England, according to the results of this month's Guardian/ICM opinion poll.

The survey shows that while the principle of comprehensive education remains staunchly supported by 72% of all voters - rising to 80% of Labour voters - they are prepared to back the government's scheme for a new generation of "specialist" comprehensives.

But the poll also shows that a significant minority - one in three of all voters - do not approve of the government's plan, which could see the development by 2006 of a two-tier system of "bog standard" schools, as the prime minister's spokesman, Alastair Campbell, described them, alongside the new schools specialising in subjects such as technology, the arts, media and sport.

Twenty-nine per cent of Labour voters and nearly 40% of Liberal Democrat voters who support the principle of comprehensive education disapprove of the plan.

Mr Blair will be surprised by such strong support - 63% of Labour voters - for his consultative "green paper" plan to introduce a measure of selection by aptitude into half the state secondary sector in England. Under the scheme pupils would be selected according to their aptitude for the school's specialist area, unlike the old grammar schools which demanded academic ability.

The poll result is all the more interesting in the light of the attacks at the weekend on Mr Campbell's use of the phrase "bog standard" by the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, and the education secretary, David Blunkett.

Ministers in particular will latch on to the ICM finding that it is voters in social classes DE, the unskilled and the unemployed, who most approve of the plan to drive up educational standards by introducing specialist secondary schools.

The survey shows that support for the principle of com prehensive education is strongest among the 25 to 34 age group, where it rises to 85% of all voters, and second strongest at 80% among 18- to 24-year-olds, the voters with the most recent experience of going to secondary school.

Support for comprehensive schools is weakest among the over 65s, of whom only 60% approve of the principle.

The ICM poll also underlines how the debate over grammar schools and the reintroduction of selection by ability rather than by aptitude is politically dead. Even among Conservative voters 65% say they approve of the idea of comprehensive secondary education and only 31% are willing to declare themselves opposed.

Among Labour voters only 8% are against the principle of comprehensive education. Slightly more men (76%) favour comprehensive education than women (69%).

The question asked by the survey was: "The government has said it plans to turn half of all state secondary schools, including comprehensive schools, into partly selective schools specialising in areas such as technology, the arts, media or sport. Do you approve or disapprove of this plan?"

 ICM interviewed a random sample of 1,000 adults aged over 18 by telephone between February 16 and 18. Interviews were conducted across the country and the results have been weighted to the profile of all adults.

webTitle: Milburn pushes on with consultant plan

fields.headline: Milburn pushes on with consultant plan
fields.trailText: The health secretary, Alan Milburn, put the government on a collision course with the medical profession today after pressing ahead with controversial proposals to reform the NHS consultant contract.
fields.body:
The health secretary, Alan Milburn, put the government on a collision course with the medical profession today after pressing ahead with controversial proposals to reform the NHS consultant contract.

Mr Milburn promised that the UK's 24,000 senior hospital doctors would get salary rises worth up to £20,000 over 10 years in return for limits on the amount of private work they carry out.

His most radical proposal, to force newly qualified consultants to work exclusively for the NHS for a period of up to seven years, was be fiercely resisted by consultant leaders, who saw it as an infringement of professional freedom.

BMA consultant's committee chairman Peter Hawker said:"The government's insistence on proposing to ban newly qualified consultants from working outside the NHS is completely unacceptable and insulting to the profession.

"It is not supported by any cogent arguments. At a time when the secretary of state is encouraging more NHS patients to be treated in the private sector, such a ban would be illogical, unworkable and probably illegal. It will not help consultants treat any more patients, and could work against the interests of the NHS."

Mr Milburn's progress on reforming the contract - which has remained largely unchanged since 1948, will be seen as a major test of the government's NHS modernisation credentials.

Critics of the contract say it is outdated and open to abuse by consultants who seek to maximise their private fee income by neglecting NHS work and creating long NHS waiting lists.

Mr Milburn said: "Since 1948 the whole assumption in the NHS has been that the only way for consultants to get on is by doing more private work. That cannot be right either for NHS consultants or for NHS patients.

"Under these plans NHS patients will get the full benefit of senior doctors' unrivalled skills while the hard work of NHS consultants will be better rewarded."

He added: "These proposals will provide a clear career structure for consultants and more incentives for doing NHS work."

The Tory health spokesman, Dr Liam Fox, said the Conservatives would reverse any plans by Labour to restrict consultants' contracts.

He said: "This policy smacks of the centralising, authoritarian tendency of the secretary of state, who increasingly wants to control the whole of the NHS from behind his desk in Whitehall."

NHS confederation policy director Andrew Foster welcomed the proposals as an important step in making NHS consultants more accountable.

He said: "The new contract must address all of the weaknesses of the 1948 version so that we are able to achieve higher productivity, greater flexibility and better quality of care in return for fair and generous reward".

fields.headline: Whatever happened to Third Lanark?
fields.standfirst: Send your questions to the.boss@guardian.co.uk and we'll do our best to answer them.
fields.trailText: THE THIRD WAY
fields.body:
THE THIRD WAY

I was idly leafing through a reference book the other day and came across a reference to Third Lanark doing something (getting relegated, I think) in 1965. This surprised me as I had always taken that name to be rather like The Wanderers in England - a name in the early records, but long out of existence. What happened to them? asks Alan Cooper

What happened to them indeed. As you suspected, Third Lanark were relegated at the end of the 1964-65 Scottish First Division campaign, losing a spectacular 30 of their 34 matches and ending up with seven points. Sadly, within two years, the club was declared bankrupt, thrown out of the league, and dissolved in the courts.

Just how the club ended up like that was never properly ascertained - fans still claim boardroom corruption to this day - but the net result was plain enough, and the death knell sounded after a 2-2 draw away to Stranraer in 1967. Thirty-four years on, they're still the last Scottish club to go under - let's hope Airdrie don't join them.

It was a sorry end to the scarlet-shirted Glasgow club, which had enjoyed no little success in the early years of Scottish football. The Third Lanarkshire Volunteers - also known as Third Lanark, Thirds, the Warriors, and the Hi-Hi - were founder members of the Scottish League, and won the championship in 1904 and the Scottish Cup in 1889 and 1905 (beating Celtic and Rangers respectively).

Their odd nickname of the Hi-Hi can, we think, be attributed to the fact that their ground, Cathkin Park, enjoyed spectacular views of Glasgow, situated as it was on a rocky knoll in the southside of the city. The site of the ground is now a municipal park, and some of the terracing still exists. Frankly, it's a bit eerie.

LITTLE BROTHERS TRYING TO MAKE IT BIG

At the moment in Italy, Christian Vieri's little brother Massimiliano and Roberto Baggio's little bro' Eddy are playing together for Serie B side Ancona. Are there any other younger brothers of big name players attempting to do likewise? asked Martin Casey.

Don't worry Martin, there are plenty more brothers around. Joseph Vess points out that Youssouf Hadji (younger brother of Coventry's Mustapha) and Egutu Oliseh (same of Borussia Dortmund's Sunday) play for the French Second Division side AS Nancy Lorraine.

Meanwhile, closer to home, Matthew Pike is convinced that Darren Huckerby's younger brother was last seen playing for Telford United. And Paul Gorman reckons that David Winters, the younger brother of Aberdeen forward (and occasional Scotland international) Robbie Winters is in the youth squad of Dundee United. "Does this count?" he asks. Well, why not?

DRAWS, DRAWS, DRAWS

Is there any evidence that awarding three points for a win has made the game more exciting? Are there less draws than before the change? Would any English championships have been decided differently under the old system? asks Stuart McGill

In 1980-1, the final year the English league used the old two-point system, there were 118 draws in the old First Division. The next year, with the new system introduced, there were 121.

Perhaps they just needed to get used to it. What about the 1994-95 Premiership table, the last time the same number of matches were played? Er, 134 draws.

Whether this is more exciting or not is entirely up to you. But changing the points system made no difference to the destination of any championships post 1982.

However in the 1974-75 season three points for a win would have made a difference. That season Derby County came top with 53 points, ahead of Liverpool and Ipswich with 51. But as Neil Emms points out, Ipswich won 23 games, compared to 21 for Derby and 20 to Liverpool, and under the three points for a win system Bobby Robson's men would have won the title on goal difference, after finishing level on 74 points with Derby.

WHY DO WATFORD HAVE A MOOSE ON THEIR BADGE?

Why, if their nickname is The Hornets, do Watford have a moose on their club badge? asked Martyn Amos.

"The moose is actually a hart - a male deer - which represents the hart part of Hertfordshire," says Tim Beesley, from Berkhamsted, Herts.

"I've no idea why the spelling is different, lost in the mists of time no doubt," he continues. "But I do know it is on the badge to represent the fact that for a very long time Watford were the only league club in Hertfordshire. Of course, this is no longer the case as Watford have been joined by Barnet.

"This is a relatively recent badge, as I think I'm right in saying the Watford badges of the 60's and 70's had a hornet on them," he adds.

And the reason why Watford are called the Hornets? As Alan Brydon points out, that's because of their distinctive yellow and black kit.

GOALS, GOALS, GOALS - BUT STILL RELEGATED

Which (old) First Division team scored more goals than the other 21 but still ended up relegated? asks Eric Diver.

You're talking about Manchester City - who else? - who were relegated in 1937-38, despite scoring 80 goals in 42 matches, three more than champions Arsenal.

CAN YOU HELP?

"Bristol Rovers haven't yet won at home in the league this season. I know various teams have gone a whole season without winning away, but has a team ever gone a whole season without winning a home game?" asks Andy Birbeck.

"France's Ligne magique of Thuram, Desailly, Blanc, Lizarazu, with Barthez in goal, have never been on the losing side as a unit, and has carted off the World Cup and European Championship to boot. Has there ever been a more successful international back line?" asks Tom Paternoster.

"Is it true that veteran striker Roddy Grant (formerly of St Johnstone, Dunfermline Athletic, Partick Thistle, Cowdenbeath, Ayr United and currently with Brechin City) has scored against every team in the Scottish Premier, First, Second and Third Divisions? And if so, presumably this is a unique feat and would justify Grant's nickname The Legend?" asks Patrick Laughlin.

"With Manchester United now packing over 67,000 per home league game, will their average home league attendance this season be an English League record?" asks Vic Ardern.

As you suspected, Third Lanark were relegated at the end of the 1964-65 Scottish First Division campaign, losing a spectacular 30 of their 34 matches and ending up with seven points. Sadly, within two years, the club was declared bankrupt, thrown out of the league, and dissolved in the courts. Just how the club ended up like that was never properly ascertained - fans still claim boardroom corruption to this day - but the net result was plain enough, and the death knell sounded after a 2-2 draw away to Stranraer in 1967. Thirty-four years on, they're still the last Scottish club to go under - let's hope Airdrie don't join them. It was a sorry end to the scarlet-shirted Glasgow club, which had enjoyed no little success in the early years of Scottish football. The Third Lanarkshire Volunteers - also known as Third Lanark, Thirds, the Warriors, and the Hi-Hi - were founder members of the Scottish League, and won the championship in 1904 and the Scottish Cup in 1889 and 1905 (beating Celtic and Rangers respectively). Their odd nickname of the Hi-Hi can, we think, be attributed to the fact that their ground, Cathkin Park, enjoyed spectacular views of Glasgow, situated as it was on a rocky knoll in the southside of the city. The site of the ground is now a municipal park, and some of the terracing still exists. Frankly, it's a bit eerie. LITTLE BROTHERS TRYING TO MAKE IT BIG At the moment in Italy, Christian Vieri's little brother Massimiliano and Roberto Baggio's little bro' Eddy are playing together for Serie B side Ancona. Are there any other younger brothers of big name players attempting to do likewise? asked Martin Casey. Don't worry Martin, there are plenty more brothers around. Joseph Vess points out that Youssouf Hadji (younger brother of Coventry's Mustapha) and Egutu Oliseh (same of Borussia Dortmund's Sunday) play for the French Second Division side AS Nancy Lorraine. Meanwhile, closer to home, Matthew Pike is convinced that Darren Huckerby's younger brother was last seen playing for Telford United. And Paul Gorman reckons that David Winters, the younger brother of Aberdeen forward (and occasional Scotland international) Robbie Winters is in the youth squad of Dundee United. "Does this count?" he asks. Well, why not? DRAWS, DRAWS, DRAWS Is there any evidence that awarding three points for a win has made the game more exciting? Are there less draws than before the change? Would any English championships have been decided differently under the old system? asks Stuart McGill In 1980-1, the final year the English league used the old two-point system, there were 118 draws in the old First Division. The next year, with the new system introduced, there were 121. Perhaps they just needed to get used to it. What about the 1994-95 Premiership table, the last time the same number of matches were played? Er, 134 draws. Whether this is more exciting or not is entirely up to you. But changing the points system made no difference to the destination of any championships post 1982. However in the 1974-75 season three points for a win would have made a difference. That season Derby County came top with 53 points, ahead of Liverpool and Ipswich with 51. But as Neil Emms points out, Ipswich won 23 games, compared to 21 for Derby and 20 to Liverpool, and under the three points for a win system Bobby Robson's men would have won the title on goal difference, after finishing level on 74 points with Derby. WHY DO WATFORD HAVE A MOOSE ON THEIR BADGE? Why, if their nickname is The Hornets, do Watford have a moose on their club badge? asked Martyn Amos. "The moose is actually a hart - a male deer - which represents the hart part of Hertfordshire," says Tim Beesley, from Berkhamsted, Herts. "I've no idea why the spelling is different, lost in the mists of time no doubt," he continues. "But I do know it is on the badge to represent the fact that for a very long time Watford were the only league club in Hertfordshire. Of course, this is no longer the case as Watford have been joined by Barnet. "This is a relatively recent badge, as I think I'm right in saying the Watford badges of the 60's and 70's had a hornet on them," he adds. And the reason why Watford are called the Hornets? As Alan Brydon points out, that's because of their distinctive yellow and black kit. GOALS, GOALS, GOALS - BUT STILL RELEGATED Which (old) First Division team scored more goals than the other 21 but still ended up relegated? asks Eric Diver. You're talking about Manchester City - who else? - who were relegated in 1937-38, despite scoring 80 goals in 42 matches, three more than champions Arsenal. CAN YOU HELP? "Bristol Rovers haven't yet won at home in the league this season. I know various teams have gone a whole season without winning away, but has a team ever gone a whole season without winning a home game?" asks Andy Birbeck. "France's Ligne magique of Thuram, Desailly, Blanc, Lizarazu, with Barthez in goal, have never been on the losing side as a unit, and has carted off the World Cup and European Championship to boot. Has there ever been a more successful international back line?" asks Tom Paternoster. "Is it true that veteran striker Roddy Grant (formerly of St Johnstone, Dunfermline Athletic, Partick Thistle, Cowdenbeath, Ayr United and currently with Brechin City) has scored against every team in the Scottish Premier, First, Second and Third Divisions? And if so, presumably this is a unique feat and would justify Grant's nickname The Legend?" asks Patrick Laughlin. "With Manchester United now packing over 67,000 per home league game, will their average home league attendance this season be an English League record?" asks Vic Ardern.

webTitle: Are the Tories right on marriage?

fields.headline: Are the Tories right on marriage?
fields.standfirst:
Tory proposals which would benefit married couples by £1,000 are part of a finely tuned set of tax policies, writes political correspondent Nicholas Watt

Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: William Hague has unsettled Labour leaders in recent weeks by unveiling a series of tax cuts aimed at middle income earners who flocked to Tony Blair in 1997.
fields.body:
William Hague has unsettled Labour leaders in recent weeks by unveiling a series of tax cuts aimed at middle income earners who flocked to Tony Blair in 1997.

The Tory leader today proposes his most ambitious plan when he pledges a tax cut of up to £1,000 a year for married couples if one parent stays at home with young children.

Labour was quick to condemn the plan, saying that the Tories had failed to live up to their commitment to restore the married couple tax allowance in full. It also pointed out that the latest measure would be of no benefit to 80% of married couples.

Despite their rhetoric, Labour strategists know that the Tory tax cuts are carefully targeted to help parents with young children and middle income earners. Unlike Mr Hague's outbursts on law and order last year, which were easily characterised as extremist, it is difficult for Labour to portray the Tories' tax plans in the same light.

The Tories are only pledging £8bn of tax cuts - a modest figure overall - but they have all been drawn up with great care. Michael Portillo, the shadow chancellor, moved onto Gordon Brown's home turf earlier this week when he pledged an extra £200 a year for parents of children under the age of five.

Although the Tory tax cuts have been planned with care, Labour does have one trump card. Mr Portillo's cuts all depend on him taking the knife to £8bn of the government's spending plans within three years of the election. Most economic observers believe that the Tories will struggle to achieve the cuts in the light of Mr Hague's pledge to match Labour spending in five key areas, including health and education.

The Tory leader also has a habit of stating his case in overblown language which presents Labour with an easy target. In an article in today's Daily Mail, in which he launched his latest tax cut, Mr Hague launched a foolish attack on Tony Blairs view of marriage.

"When Tony Blair talks about loving the institution of marriage, like he said he loved the pound before the last election, he means it in the same way as a female praying mantis does: I love you but now I am going to destroy you," the Tory leader wrote.

Why undermine a clever announcement with such language? Even the prime minister's sharpest critics have no doubt that he is a devoted family man. And therein lies William Hague's problem.

webTitle: Little England comes out to play

fields.headline: Little England comes out to play
fields.standfirst: The Whiff's take on Sven-Goran Eriksson
fields.trailText: The Whiff's take on Sven-Goran Eriksson.
fields.body:
It's the end of the world as we know it. England, inventors of the game of football and a dominant force for much of the last century, have finally admitted total inadequacy and appointed a foreign coach to manage the national side. Sven-Goran Eriksson, the Swede whose predecessors included the badger and the turnip, will take over the poisoned chalice next June, providing Lazio don't lose patience with their departing coach before then.

The furore this appointment has caused amongst the press and, in this case it appears, the public at large, says a great deal about the current national English psyche. Predictably, the Daily Mail has launched the offensive already, as if a Swedish football coach is somehow the straw breaking the camel's back of the British Empire, which now, finally, lies in ruins around our feet. This, of course, from the newspaper that paid Zola Budd to turn "British" in a vain attempt to win Britain some Olympic gold medals.

Of rather more import is the reaction of Gordon Taylor, chairman of the Professional Footballers' Association, who has effectively already informed the players he represents that Eriksson is the wrong man for the job. Some of these players will have to work with the man for the next few years and yet their union representative has already begun a campaign of vitriolic abuse against him.

If various phone-in polls are to be believed, much of the English public are also against the very idea of a foreigner coaching the national side. Rather like the Daily Mail and Gordon Taylor, the rationale for this view seems to be nothing more than hurt national pride combined with an unhealthy dose of xenophobia. In other words, we're English, we invented the game, how can anyone be better at coaching it than we are? The stereotyping of the Swedes as a nation of skiers and hammer throwers is irrelevant; any foreign coach would have been subjected to the same kind of bile.

Of course, there is a perfectly good football case for arguing that Eriksson should not get the job. With no experience of English football and little knowledge of the current England players beyond Beckham and a handful of others, how can he be better qualified than, say, Terry Venables? On the other hand, who else, apart from El Tel, is a qualified English option? Peter Taylor, with less than half a season of top flight experience? Bryan Robson, who's spent £70m in taking Middlesborough into the bottom four?

Although this lack of knowledge will be a hindrance in the short term, Eriksson's tactical appreciation and experience of the game outside of these shores will be a welcome change from Keegan's gung-ho naivety. Indeed, those crying out for a home grown coach may well be victims of that other great myth of English football: that our up-and-at-em, kick-and-chase style would be successful at international level, if only we had the guts to play it in its purest form. In other words, if we could only forget the fannying around possession game and give it to Johnny Foreigner where he doesn't like it, we'd be World and European Champions instead of the Frogs. Unfortunately it is lost on many that this argument can be rebutted in just two words: Graham Taylor.

Indeed, it seems odd that, given our abysmal international record in the last three decades when we have had exclusively English managers with English back-up teams, that a change of approach is not more welcome. The stick-our-heads-in-the-sand method has got us precisely nowhere; why not try something different?

Of course, some will say, the French success was all achieved with home grown coaching talent. Even ignoring the fact that they have something like 50,000 qualified coaches to our 2,000, this is not strictly true. The great French side of the early eighties (cheated out of the World Cup final in 1982 by the German goalkeeper and winners of the 1984 European Championship) was coached by Michel Hidalgo, a native Frenchman. Hidalgo, however, been an assistant in the set-up that forged this success when the French national side was coached by one Stefan Kovacs, a Romanian.

Not only is the appointment of a non-national coach not unique to England, it is not even unique within English sport. There weren't too many calling for the removal of Steve Redgrave's coach, despite the fact that he has the very un-English name of Jurgen Grobbler. Likewise, was our cricket team's long-overdue victory over the West Indies this summer the less welcome because the coach, Duncan Fletcher, happens to be from Zimbabwe?

Unfortunately, these arguments will cut little ice and almost no slack for Eriksson. Failure, even in his first game, will probably result in more vitriol than that heaped on Robson, Taylor and Hoddle combined. He is used to criticism of his tactics from the Italian media, who pride themselves on their knowledge of the game. What he won't be used to is the extraordinary level of personal abuse that will come his way, as well as that of his family and friends.

The truly ridiculous part of this whole scenario is that most of those loudly proclaiming doom and disaster will be fully back behind the team as soon as it starts winning, whoever the coach happens to be. In other words, all Eriksson has to do to win back the hearts and minds of the public is to create a successful side. His problem is that he has precisely zero time in which to achieve it.

Of course, there will be some that stick to their line no matter what. However, such died-in-the-wool nationalists are likely to be of a similar ilk to those who argued that England's 2 - 0 victory over Brazil in the mid-eighties was really only 1 - 0 as one of the goals was scored by the black John Barnes. Being black, they argued, he evidently couldn't be English and so could not have scored a goal for England. The fact that he also created the other obviously passed them by but then such people have never been noted for their appreciation of logic.

In truth, though, the whole debate has been tainted by a nasty under-current of what might be termed racism. The major arguments given against Eriksson have had nothing to do with football and everything to do with his nationality, in other words, prejudice based on where he was born. It seems extraordinary that, in the year 2000, a multi-cultural society such as our own, should be having a public debate in such terms. If nothing else, it shows that much of our footballing sub-culture is still rooted in the nineteenth century.

This is surely not how we want the rest of the world to perceive us. Whatever passport Eriksson happens to carry should not be a criterion for considering him for the job. As a nation, we ought to be grown up enough to accept two things: firstly, that the appointment of the national football coach is not a barometer of our success as a nation as a whole and secondly, that it should go the right man, wherever he happens to have been born.

webTitle: Bescot Orange - The away day that went like Clockwork

fields.headline: Bescot Orange - The away day that went like Clockwork
fields.standfirst: A slightly unusual match report from The Whiff's visit to Walsall
fields.trailText: A slightly unusual match report from The Whiff's visit to Walsall.
fields.body:
There was me, that is Alex, and my four droogs, that is Pete, Jeff, Neil and Stretchdontcallmedim. We sat in Stretchdontcallmedim's motor as he played hog of the road, trying to make up our rassoodocks why so many of the Reading fans are such miserable nazzes. Oh my brothers one thing I could never stand is to see a filthy old drunky howling away at the filthy songs of his fathers and going Blerp Blerp in between as it might be a filthy old orchestra in his stinking rotten guts. I could never stand to see anyone like that, and often it is I'm feeling bolnoy to slooshy all the starry bratchyies spouting their chepooka all the time while I am trying to viddy the beautiful Reading. Some of them would appear to be in want of a little of the old ultra-violence to sort their gullivers out.

It had been a real horrorshow day; the old surprise visit to the Korova Milk bar before the eegra set us up nicely. Five milk pluses for less than ten dengs is almost as good as the old in-out-in-out! Soon we were at the Bescot and then it happened: it was like for a moment, O my brothers, some great bird had flown into the world and I felt all the malenky little hairs on my plott standing endwise and the shivers crawling up like slow malenky lizards and then down again- for the Reading ran onto the pitch.

And so begins the old-ultra-violence by proxy; shots, saves, tackles, horrowshow horning, offsides, chicken-balti pies, goals disallowed, goals allowed, an injury time strike by McIntyre while I was in the vaysay. All great value for your pretty polly. And now this is the real weepy and tragic part of the story, O my brothers and only friends, the beautiful Reading came second! The shock sent my Dada beating his gulliver and rookas against unfair bog in his heaven and my mom, boo hoo hooing in her grief. But did your friend and humble narrator snuff himself? Of course not, otherwise how could he tell the story?

No instead I knew I'll be as right as dodgers; but some of the fellow Urzy they had a trial with judge and a jury and some very hard words spoken against your friend and humble underpaid referee- he was sentenced to fourteen years in Stargent number 84-F among smelly perverts and hardened crustoodniks. These are the lewdies I'm govoreeting about: always moaning about something; we've got the best squad, the most cutter and the best stadium in the division- but no divine right to win every week. The Wallsall won the bitva of the day and good luck to them, they're the best team I've seen us try to filly with this season & I hope they come secondways at the end so we can have the balti pies again next year. So lets us have less of the unhappy chumble from the baboochkas, it's going to be a choodessny season- a long hard drat but we'll be smecking when we go upwise. So horn gromky for the Urz and put a smile on your litso or I'll cut your yarbles off. Right, right?

Doobidoob. A bit tired, may be best not to say more. Bedways is rigthways now, so best we go homeways and get a bit of spatchka. Right, right!

Alex

Municipal flat block 18-A Linear North

webTitle: Ministers dismiss NHS plea for cash

fields.headline: Ministers dismiss NHS plea for cash
fields.trailText: Ministers have dismissed as a "bargaining ploy" a leaked letter from health service finance directors which claims that the NHS does not have the resources to meet government targets. Patrick Butler reports
fields.body:
Ministers have dismissed as a "bargaining ploy" a leaked letter from health service finance directors which claims that the NHS does not have the resources to meet government targets.

Heads of finance from Britain's main teaching hospitals voiced their concerns in a memo to the NHS chief executive, Nigel Crisp, which warns that the NHS reform programme is over-ambitious.

The memo reinforces wider concerns in the service, first reported by SocietyGuardian.co.uk earlier this month, that despite record funding increases, the NHS will struggle to balance the books in 2001-02.

The memo, from the main university hospitals finance directors group says: "The level of ambition set out for next year is beyond the resources available. We will not be able to deliver the key targets required. We feel obliged to alert you to our professional concerns."

It adds: "We are resolute in our belief that the financial gaps we are now facing cannot be closed by normal measures."

The health secretary, Alan Milburn, dismissed the warning as a bargaining bid ahead of the next NHS funding round.

He told Channel 4 news: "There is a negotiation going on and there will be noise around the negotiations."

He added: "Since that letter has been written I have just put out an extra 11% on training budgets into the National Health Service, a lot of which will benefit precisely the teaching hospitals that are complaining.

"It is normal at this time of year. Every year there is a negotiation between the providers on the one side, the teaching hospitals and indeed other hospitals, and those commissioning the care."

There was an extra £400m going into research and development and £140m into mainstream budgets, he said.

The chancellor, Gordon Brown, announced in March 2000 a 6.1% average annual real terms increase for the NHS worth around £19bn over four years, a move dubbed the biggest-ever increase in health service history.

Ministers claimed they had moved the debate away from finance and onto reform - reform that was subsequently spelled out in last summer's NHS plan. But managers are privately describing negotiations for 2001-02 as the "toughest ever".

fields.headline: Peak Practice makes perfect
fields.trailText: 4.45pm TV overnights: BBC1's two-part crime drama In Deep proved no match for Peak Practice last night, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
BBC1's two-part crime drama In Deep proved no match for Peak Practice last night, in spite of a cast that included the usually bankable stars Nick Berry and Stephen Tompkinson.

And the viewing figures for the second part of the show dropped off by more than 1m since Monday night to just 6.3m.

ITV pulled in 7.4m viewers eager to see whether doctors Kate Preston and Will Preston can mend their broken relationship in Peak Practice, broadcast in the same 9pm slot.

Also competing for viewers at 9pm was BBC2's cult Louis Theroux-fronted documentary.

This time it was magician Paul Daniels and his assistant/wife Debbie McGee who got the Theroux treatment and 3.8m viewers tuned in to give the channel a highly respectable 16% share.

On Channel 4, the revamped Big Breakfast fell to a new low of just 200,000 viewers and a 6% share.

Even Donna Air's charms won't keep people watching.

The show now has the same viewing figures as BBC2's highly niche Open University programming, broadcast in the graveyard slot of 11.45pm.

Channel 5 achieved its best ratings figures of the day with a 9pm showing of Robocop director Paul Verhoeven's Starship Troopers.

The film, a satirical sci-fi adventure involving giant arachnids, notched up 2.3m viewers to give it a 13% share.

webTitle: Business: CSFB seeks to have race case struck out

fields.headline: CSFB seeks to have race case struck out
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: CSFB, the American investment bank, today will seek to have allegations of racial discrimination brought by former trader Philip Karam, struck out at an employment tribunal.
fields.body:
CSFB, the American investment bank, today will seek to have allegations of racial discrimination brought by former trader Philip Karam, struck out at an employment tribunal.

Mr Karam, from Wandsworth, south London, insists he was the victim of institutionalised racism at the bank where he began working as a desk assistant in June 1998.

He was signed off from work with stress and related symptoms last March and claims he had been discriminated against and was the victim of bullying and harassment.

His allegations, which have been aired at preliminary hearings over the past few months, include that he was warned not to complain otherwise he would end up like murdered black teenager Stephen Lawrence.

Although Mr Karam, 32, was employed as a desk assistant, he insists he was doing the job of a junior trader and earned a salary, including bonuses, of almost £44,000.

An earlier hearing heard that Mr Karam was told in December 1999 he was no longer allowed to do any trading and was being transferred to operations work.

A spokeswoman for CSFB said the bank totally rejected the allegations brought against it and would vigorously defend itself at the tribunal. It was, she insisted, an equal opportunities employer and "did not tolerate discrimination in any form".

CSFB has applied to have the claims against it struck out because it believes the way the case has been conducted by Mr Karam and his legal advisers have led to an abuse of process.

A two-day hearing is scheduled to start tomorrow in Stratford, east London.

webTitle: Public sector forced to tackle racism

fields.headline: Public sector forced to tackle racism
fields.standfirst:
Straw tackles 'official' racism
Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: Jack Straw, the home secretary, will tomorrow announce new powers giving statutory force to the official campaign to tackle institutional racism in schools, hospitals, universities and across the whole public sector, including the police and prisons, the Guardian has learned.
fields.body:
Jack Straw, the home secretary, will tomorrow announce new powers giving statutory force to the official campaign to tackle institutional racism in schools, hospitals, universities and across the whole public sector, including the police and prisons, the Guardian has learned.

From April a positive legal duty to promote good race relations and equality of opportunity will be imposed on every public body, including ministries, Whitehall departments and local government.

They will have to monitor the ethnic composition of their workforce to ensure it reflects the minority ethnic make-up of their local community.

Public bodies will have a duty to assess the impact on racial equality of proposed policies and new services. For example, if an NHS trust proposes to close, or open, a hospital it would have to publish an assessment of what impact it would have on local minority ethnic communities.

The announcement is being made by Mr Straw in a 60-page consultation paper as part of his attempt to maintain the momentum behind the government's anti-racist campaign. This weekend marks the second anniversary of the official inquiry report into the murder of the black teenager Stephen Lawrence. Mr Straw will tomorrow announce the latest progress report on the 70 recommendations by Sir William Macpherson.

Attempts by the police to tackle institutional racism have already provoked a backlash from some officers who have received the backing of William Hague and some newspapers. The decision to extend the fight right across the public sector, backed by "legal teeth", is likely to intensify the debate.

The statutory duty to combat institutional racism will mean public organisations will have to monitor the impact of existing policies on race equality. So far public debate on this has centred on such questions as the use by police of stop and search tactics, or practices inside the prison service.

The way councils or housing associations allocate homes, or the way schools operate their exclusion policies towards troublesome pupils, will also come under scrutiny.

The new duty will mean that an education authority or a university will have to publish an annual assessment which would not only detail the minority ethnic composition of teaching staff and others but specify levels of achievement by different ethnic groups and incidents of racial harassment.

The measures will be legally enforceable by the commission for racial equality. Official inspection bodies such as Ofsted, HM inspector of police, the chief inspector of prisons, the audit commission and the national audit office will also beable to order compliance.

The consultation paper will leave open the question of whether individual schools or the local education authority will be made the legally responsible body for tackling institutional racism. Ministers are anxious not to create a new bureaucratic paperwork burden on head teachers, or hospital administrators.

fields.headline: Premier League to negotiate sponsorships
fields.trailText: 4.45pm: The Premier League will negotiate second-tier sponsorship deals once the title sponsor, thought to be Sony, is announced, reports Julia Day.
fields.body:
The Premier League is to negotiate nine second-tier sponsorship deals as soon as the title sponsor, thought to be Sony, is announced.

Premier League chief executive Richard Scudamore will meet the league's 20 club chairmen in London on Thursday to discuss the title sponsor, the buyer of the its overseas TV rights and its pay-per-view rights.

The next stage of sponsorship negotiations will centre around the league's "official partners".

Nine brands have been official partners this season.

These are Sony PlayStation, Siemens, the Daily Telegraph, Nestle's Yorkie, McDonald's, npower, CIS, Procter & Gamble's Wash & Go and Glaxo SmithKline Beecham's Lucozade Sport.

All the one-year agreements will expire at the end of this season.

The sponsorships give each company a commercial relationship with the league's clubs.

Each sponsor's budget is divided between the clubs - the individual club and sponsor decide how it is spent.

The deals span areas such as advertising, product, equipment or knowledge supply.

This year, Lucozade Sport provided nutritional and rehydration advice to the clubs.

Siemens marketing manager Sue Rowe said her company was keen to renegotiate its deal for next season.

But she said problems would arise if the league's title sponsor were a rival mobile phone manufacturer.

Sony does make mobile phones.

The electronics giant is believed to be the frontrunner to seal the title sponsorship deal.

Budweiser, Pepsi and Coke have all stepped back from the sponsorship.

Last week, the Premier League said two companies were left in the running.

A deal with Sony would give the Premier League what it wants - a global company that is not an alcohol brand and that fits in with the league's global marketing strategy.

Current title sponsor Carling is thought to have reentered talks with the Premier League.

It had left the negotiating table claiming the league was dragging its feet.

Carling's four-year deal cost it around £27m a year.

The new deal is thought to be worth at least £45m annually.

webTitle: Moscow dispatch: the imprisonment of Pavel Borodin

fields.headline: Pavel the just
fields.standfirst:
The Russian official held in America on corruption charges is being improbably recast as a martyr back in his home country, writes Amelia Gentleman

Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: The Russian official held in America on corruption charges is being improbably recast as a martyr back in his home country, writes Amelia Gentleman in Moscow.
fields.body:
As former presidential aide Pavel Borodin begins his second month of incarceration inside a New York jail awaiting extradition to Switzerland on money laundering charges, Russian efforts to secure his release have been renewed.

Until now the "energetic measures" which Russian foreign minister Igor Ivanov promised would be taken to secure his "immediate and unconditional release" have proved futile, and the once-powerful Kremlin insider remains behind bars - humiliatingly reduced from his past role as head of the Kremlin property department (responsible for some $600bn [£416bn] worth of assets), to a more modest position as inmate 55217-053 in a Brooklyn detention centre.

The Duma's international affairs committee yesterday prepared a new appeal to the American state department, urging officials not to agree to the extradition request from the Swiss who intend to prosecute Mr Borodin for bribe-taking and laundering a sum of around $25m [£17m].

Pleading for clemency, the draft document stresses the national importance of Mr Borodin's current job as State Secretary of the Union of Belarus and Russia (a nebulous position granted by Vladimir Putin after Mr Borodin was dismissed from the Kremlin property department last year). The seniority of his post as coordinator of a future union between the two countries, meant his arrest and extradition had a serious impact on "Russia's state interests", the statement concludes.

It seems unlikely that this appeal will succeed where personal appeals from Mr Putin to Mr Bush have failed. Bernard Bertossa, the Swiss prosecutor in charge of the case, insisted yesterday that the extradition process would not be abandoned.

Mr Borodin was detained on January 18 at New York airport, after unwisely accepting an invitation to one of George Bush's inauguration celebrations in Washington - despite the existence of an international warrant for his arrest. The warrant was issued after a probe into alleged multi-million dollar kickback scams involving government officials who commissioned the Swiss construction firms, Mabetex and Mercata, to refurbish the Kremlin and other Russian public buildings in the last year's of Boris Yeltsin's presidency.

As Mr Borodin gazes wistfully at the Statue of Liberty (just visible from his cell window), supporters in Moscow are working hard to generate support for his cause. It has not been an easy task to remodel the official as a suffering martyr in the eyes of a nation long-embittered by the extravagance of Yeltsin's circle. Jowly, smug and once fond of boasting about the wealth of the luxury dachas, limousines, jets and Tsarist palaces in his gift for the favoured elite, Mr Borodin is a most unlikely popular hero.

But fuelled by nationalist anger at the snub perceived in America's decision to implement the arrest warrant of a serving Russian official, Mr Borodin's supporters have worked hard to reclaim him as the wronged victim of international hostility to Russia.

Their efforts have met with a receptive audience. "We might not approve of him, but the American's decision to arrest him is deeply insulting to our country. It's a sign of how weak Russia has become in the eyes of the world," a retired soldier from Vladivostok commented.

Even those Moscow newspapers most critical of Mr Borodin in the past have begun to question whether the case against him will stand up. Citing documents procured from the Swiss prosecutors, Novaya Gazeta claimed this week that the Swiss had no proof that Mr Borodin had received any of the laundered funds.

The most surreal manifestation of the rebranding campaign came last week when an exhibition of children's drawings opened in Moscow, dedicated to the plight of "Our Pavel".

Organised - with a healthy sense of the absurd - by activists from the extreme nationalist Liberal Democratic Party, most of the teachers and school children who took part were participating in good faith. Crayoned pictures of a despondent Mr Borodin, weeping because fellow prisoners had stolen his food, were on display alongside felt tip depictions of Mr Yeltsin, mourning the loss of his friend. Some children had composed poems lamenting the arrest, others prepared a care parcel containing vodka and Russian bread to boost the official's spirits.

fields.headline: Rage at rush hour
fields.standfirst: Once South Africa's rail travellers feared for their lives. Now they burn down the station, says Chris McGreal
fields.trailText: Once South Africa's rail travellers feared for their lives. Now they burn down the station, says Chris McGreal.
fields.body:
Riding the trains has never been much fun for South Africa's weary commuters. The first thing they have to contend with is whether or not the trains actually go.

On Monday night they didn't, so enraged passengers burned down a good part of Pretoria's magnificent railway station. But there was a time when late arrivals were the least of commuters' problems.

Rail passengers around the world, not least in Britain, complain of being treated as cattle. But in South Africa that was precisely the thinking behind the design of entire sections of the railway system.

Trains were not there to carry passengers as such but workers herded each day from the sprawling black townships around Johannesburg, Pretoria and Cape Town into the factories that thrived on cheap labour.

Comfort was not a consideration. Time keeping was only an issue because late workers were bad for business. Service existed only to the extent of checking tickets and beating back people from the doors of overcrowded trains.

The railways were famous under apartheid as a last refuge for white men unable to find jobs elsewhere. Black travellers suffered as a result.

But it was in the early 1990s that travelling the trains around Johannesburg took on a new dimension - terror. The commuters packed into crowded carriages were easy targets for slaughter in the political killings that swept the Reef townships.

Hundreds died on the trains. Men with automatic weapons and machetes marched on to the platforms of stations such as New Canada in Soweto and fired at random into the carriages or hacked at those who tried to run.

There is one telling photograph taken from the front of a train. On the platform side, a group of armed men can be seen moving toward the doors. On the other side, commuters are pouring out of the windows and onto the track to escape the looming slaughter.

A simple journey to work was to run the gauntlet of death. Some people travelled later, when the trains were emptier and less of a target. But most took their life into their hands to hang onto their jobs.

Those days are past but while commuters are no longer afraid they are just as angry.

Years of chronic under investment and poor service make the journey to work from outlying townships to jobs in the major cities a grind that can take almost as long as the hours spent at work on a bad day.

Pent up frustration, and no one to direct it at, burst out on Monday evening after a signal failure forced the cancellation of trains from Pretoria station at rush hour.

Several thousand people stormed the passenger services office. A handful lit fires. The flames quickly shot up to the roof and within minutes the 91 year-old historic station was engulfed.

The near destruction of the classic building - its shell may yet be saved but some of its most outstanding features cannot be restored - only brought more grief for commuters as the government called the army out to keep order the next day for fear of another riot after the station was closed.

There was no more trouble but there was a grim satisfaction among many travellers that at last they had hit back, even if it was at their own expense.

Inevitably, train travel is not like that for everyone in South Africa. The country is also home to the world's most luxurious train - the Blue Train. It plies across the country and up to Victoria Falls in Zimbabwe at a sedate 50 miles per hour.

Delays are not common and the passengers would hardly care if they were. They travel in sound proofed cabins with private bathrooms and air conditioning. And they dress for dinner while the commuters on Pretoria station consider themselves lucky to get home in time for supper.

Years of chronic under investment and poor service make the journey to work from outlying townships to jobs in the major cities a grind that can take almost as long as the hours spent at work on a bad day. Pent up frustration, and no one to direct it at, burst out on Monday evening after a signal failure forced the cancellation of trains from Pretoria station at rush hour. Several thousand people stormed the passenger services office. A handful lit fires. The flames quickly shot up to the roof and within minutes the 91 year-old historic station was engulfed. The near destruction of the classic building - its shell may yet be saved but some of its most outstanding features cannot be restored - only brought more grief for commuters as the government called the army out to keep order the next day for fear of another riot after the station was closed. There was no more trouble but there was a grim satisfaction among many travellers that at last they had hit back, even if it was at their own expense. Inevitably, train travel is not like that for everyone in South Africa. The country is also home to the world's most luxurious train - the Blue Train. It plies across the country and up to Victoria Falls in Zimbabwe at a sedate 50 miles per hour. Delays are not common and the passengers would hardly care if they were. They travel in sound proofed cabins with private bathrooms and air conditioning. And they dress for dinner while the commuters on Pretoria station consider themselves lucky to get home in time for supper. webTitle: Consumer: How much can you pay for ... a charm bracelet

fields.headline: How much can you pay for ... a charm bracelet
fields.trailText: Charm, they say is priceless, but a charm bracelet - that's another story. For £1500, Links of London has created a 18ct bracelet with five solid gold charms representing the sights of London. There's the traditional phone box, the taxi, the trusty double-decker bus, the Queens' Guard complete with bearskin and of course, the good old pillar box. Additional charms including a policeman's helmet, can be purchased for an extra £140-£240 depending on weight.
fields.body:
Charm, they say is priceless, but a charm bracelet - that's another story. For £1500, Links of London has created a 18ct bracelet with five solid gold charms representing the sights of London. There's the traditional phone box, the taxi, the trusty double-decker bus, the Queens' Guard complete with bearskin and of course, the good old pillar box. Additional charms including a policeman's helmet, can be purchased for an extra £140-£240 depending on weight.

So who would buy such a thing? Government spin-doctors on a charm offensive? Wealthy tourists wanting a holiday souvenir with a difference? The Queen, perhaps, as a pressie for her mum? Oh no, they're much trendier than that, a representative informed me.

With the current fad for ironic T-shirts and name chains, fashion victims have been snapping them up. In keeping with the spirit of irony, I wondered if Links did a gold Millennium Dome or perhaps a pigeon, but the response was sadly negative. However, should you feel the urge to deviate from the London theme, the company will make to order any of their more traditional range from a lucky horseshoe to a black cat. In the meantime, watch that space on anglophile Madonna's wrist.

 Available from Links of London branches

fields.headline: Attack of the seven-foot children
fields.standfirst: Kids' TV favourites the Tweenies are coming to a town near you. Hide your wallet, says Catherine Bennett
fields.trailText: Kids' TV favourites the Tweenies are coming to a town near you. Hide your wallet, says Catherine Bennett.
fields.body:
What are they? Any non-parents reading this page for kicks may need an introduction. The Tweenies are four adult-sized creatures: two male, two female, with big feet and a blobby head resembling a cross between a tyrannosaurus rex and a moppet.

What do they do? They provide "a thought provoking, enriching and enjoyable experience" for the under-fives. Or that's what the BBC Tweenies website claims. Every morning, on BBC2, the four little monster-toddlers hang out in an other-worldly playgroup, where they are cared for by a pair of older Tweenies, a faintly sinister Tweenie-geezer called Max and a more matronly minder, Judy. There is also a dog called Doodles. In squeaky, pretend-childish voices, they sing and play, dance and learn things about the world.

Fizz and Bella, Jake and Milo have awoken profound passions in the pre-school generation. Where three-year-olds meet and exchange views, Tweenie-preference is now considered quite as revealing of character as favourite colour. The selection of, say, Fizz, would generally held to be a more promising indicator than that of the unspeakable Bella; while any child opting for Max would be, one feels, as much a source of perplexity to her peers as if she had expressed a preference for mud-brown.

Although the programme may strike more sensitive viewers as repellently raucous, the improving content and overall harmlessness of the Tweenie world has converted many parents, who were therefore the softest of touches when it was announced that the Tweenies would be touring "live", all round the country. If the show was related to the enriching BBC programmes then it could not be wholly meretricious. And even if it was at Wembley, Tweenies Live! was, like chickenpox, the sort of childhood affliction that would only have to be lived through once. Off we went.

The show did turn out to be quite stimulating, mathematically. It was extraordinary how the figures added up. You started with the price of the ticket: say, £11.50 for a not very good seat (minus booking fee), like ours. Then, with the merchandising stalls everywhere, you had to spend at least £4 on a programme (a folded promotional poster) and £5 on the cheapest possible flashing wand (luxury versions £9). To say nothing of the popcorn and T-shirts, rucksacks and scarves. So if you took £20 as a conservative average cost per child, multiplied it by, say, 5,000 (Wembley Arena holds 11,000), then that's £100,000 made just from the children in the audience, without even beginning to include the costs of their escorts. At Wembley, they were doing up to three Tweenies Live! shows a day, so that's £300,000 a day, from the children alone. Which added up to a mystery: where had all the money gone?

Not, manifestly, on the show, which amounted to little more than the six Tweenie costumes plus dog costume, each containing an unknown actor, strutting and squeaking through a few song-and-dance routines. The mainstay of the production was a triptych of giant screens, whose crude inserts and graphics were presumably meant to compensate for the shortage of props, economy of cast and a catastrophic sound system that rendered even the most rudimentary dialogue unintelligible.

In the absence of a narrative, the principal dramatic device was to remove the Tweenies from view, so that all the tinies began asking anxiously where they had gone, then, after a while, to make them come back. The greedy cynics who threw this shambles together seem to have decided, no doubt correctly, that adulation of the Tweenies is now so far advanced that the mere sight of the foursome in various permutations will satisfy their audience. So the sight of the foursome - albeit from a great distance - was what they offered. To be fair, the Tweenies did occasionally invite their audience to dance along with them: a form of participation which was not, alas, possible, for anyone except children sitting within nappy-throwing distance of the stage and would have been positively suicidal for many others sitting higher up.

For most of the tots, glued to their parents' laps, or half trapped in the grip of an adult-size folding seat, the spectacle of the remote, squawking Tweenies going up and down through holes in an empty stage was considered excitement enough. Or too much excitement by half.

Other impresarios may be heartened to hear that, if your stars are big enough, you can entertain the audience of Wembley Arena with nothing more than the promise of a story and a few dressing-up clothes.

The highlight was the massed singing of the Colchester classic, Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star (waving any flashing wands that had not already broken), though it seemed a shame this was one of the episodes of Tweenie-rationing, so we had to sing along with creepy old Max. Those who like loud bangs were rewarded at the end of the show, when the Tweenies disappeared in the one prop that must have set them back more than a tenner: the Green Tweenie rocket, on which, of a morning, they soar into view. Pure, theatrical Calpol.

The parents in my party conceded that the children had enjoyed it, in a notably muted kind of way. Then again, as one of the mothers said, "They would like anything." The presentation of various bits of Tweenie junk probably added to the children's enjoyment. Among the adults in our row, the mood was less benign. It is not altogether comfortable to sit and watch tiny children having their trust and intelligence insulted. And anyway, we were bored. For all its enormous profits and its claims to be "improving", Tweenies Live! contrived to offer less than any other children's spectacle we could think of, from the local pantomime to the travelling circus, from the humblest puppet theatre to the elaborate stunts of Disney on Ice - even, someone muttered, to the acrobatics at the Dome. Making money from Tweenie lovers is as easy as taking candy from a baby. And, as BBC Worldwide is still discovering, so much more rewarding.

For more information, contact the box office (0870 7898830) or visit www.tweenieslive.com

webTitle: Parents: Life as a paranoid parent

fields.headline: Fear of everything
fields.standfirst: It started with aeroplanes, but soon spread to dogs, water, rashes . . .  Julie Myerson on life as a paranoid parent
fields.trailText: It started with aeroplanes, but soon spread to dogs, water, rashes . . . Julie Myerson on life as a paranoid parent.
fields.body:
My friend Jackie - capable, sane, outgoing mother of two - is flying to America tomorrow. She's terrified. Especially since she and the kids have to do the return journey without her husband. "I'd rather we all died together," she says. "I know it's stupid, but I just would."

Meanwhile, Lou can barely bring herself to fly at all these days. The first time she got on a plane after having Ellie, now 18 months, she had a panic attack - "shaking, crying, clutching on to the seats" - and is scared of repeating it.

I can fly, I do fly and, ironically, I'm marginally braver with children in tow. But otherwise I tend to clutch my magazine and wait to die. It's never a good start to a holiday.

The most unnerving thing of all about Jackie, Lou and me - and so many of the mothers I know - is that none of us used to be like that. As teenagers, as students, as young, single women, we flew all over the place without a second thought.

So what happened? Why does motherhood make us all so anxious? And it's not only aeroplanes, but motorways, rashes, dog poo, strangers, deep water. It's partly rational, of course - suddenly there's so much to lose. Few would deny that the sheer, awesome responsibility of parenthood permanently alters you. But we're not just talking useful anxiety here, but something sneakier and jumpier and, I suspect, more hormonal. How many fathers do you know who go to pieces on jumbo jets?

For me, it all reached a terrible crescendo after our third baby. Maybe it wasn't so surprising. I'd conceived, carried and given birth to three children in less than four years. If ever a person was drowning in hormones, I was.

But once Raphael was a few months old, I developed blinding headaches - flashing lights, the lot. I became tense, self-absorbed. Even a walk to the swings with the double buggy seemed a feat. Few who knew me seemed to notice - people are endlessly forgiving to tired new mothers - but the GP sent me to see a neurologist who banged my knees with a hammer and shone lights in my eyes. Raphael watched, grave-faced and milky-lipped, from his carry-cot. "Nice baby," the neurologist commented.

"But I can't see him," I said. "When I get the headaches, he goes all blurred."

Instead of telling me I had a brain tumour, the neurologist laughed. "Poor chap. That won't do at all."

I was amazed when he told me I was fine. "But the headaches?"

He patted my arm. "I think they'll go away now."

"I'm OK!" I told my partner when I got home.

"Of course you are," he grunted, as he scraped dried Play-Doh from the kitchen table. And I was.

Hypochondriac? I can see why you might think so. But it was only a year or so later, when I was my normal, bouncy self again, that I realised that I had been depressed. Anxiety can be a symptom of depression and I'd had it in spades. In fact, it was only when I got my sense of humour back that I saw how utterly loopy I had been.

And though I suppose I'm glad I wasn't diagnosed, and (maybe) offered tranquillisers, I do wonder how many new mothers out there are unwittingly suffering. Motherhood makes you frantic, makes you edgy, makes you anxious - all of us to some extent and some more than others. I know that, you know that - so why do none of the books or experts tell us how to deal with it?

These days, I'm not exactly laid back but - thanks to a strong, loving partner and a life-saving book called Manage Your Mind (Gillian Butler and Tony Hope, Oxford University Press, £9.99), I do have the wild, panting hound that is my imagination on a firmer leash. Sometimes it still pulls where I don't want to go, but a sharp tug in the opposite direction is usually all I need to remain calm and sane.

This morning in the playground, I pressed this invaluable tome on Jackie. She took it. "But you know, I've been lying listening to all those planes taking off all morning," she said brightly. "And not one has crashed."

"That's right," I agreed firmly. "You'll be fine."

And as we walked off across the asphalt with our gaggle of kids, we probably looked like we believed it.

More or less.

webTitle: Parents: 'Hyper-parenting' and why it could be endangering your child's health

fields.headline: 'Raising the next Tiger Woods is now more important than raising a happy, well-balanced child'
fields.standfirst: Polly Ghazi on the phenomenon of 'hyper-parenting' and why it could be endangering your child's health
fields.trailText: Polly Ghazi on the phenomenon of 'hyper-parenting' and why it could be endangering your child's health.
fields.body:
Life for Cathy Hagner and her three young children is set to permanent fast-forward. Their full school day and her 9am-2pm job as a paralegal are busy enough. But it's at 4pm that the pace really quickens.

Cathy frantically ferries Brendan, 12, and Matthew, 10, from soccer field to hockey pitch to basketball court while dropping off eight-year-old Julie at piano lessons or Girl Scouts club. Often, the exhausted family doesn't get home until 7pm - just in time for a quick supper before homework. Julie, though barely old enough to tie her own shoelaces, is studying for tests in Spanish and religion and reading a book on which she has to give a seminar-style presentation to her class. She also practises piano every day and often nods off over her night-time paperwork.

"One evening recently, I spent four solid hours in the car driving them from one activity to another," says Cathy, who lives in a small town outside Buffalo in New York State. "We were all pretty stressed and it did make me stop and think whether this was any kind of normal life. But then, we know lots of families whose kids do even more than mine do!"

Welcome to the world of hyper-parenting. A world in which middle-class American - and, increasingly, British - parents treat their children as if they are competitors eternally racing for some undefined finishing line. A world in which the people-carrier becomes a second home as children are hustled from activity to activity in or der to make their future CVs as impressive as possible. A world in which raising the next Tiger Woods or Venus Williams has apparently become a more important goal than raising a happy, well-balanced child.

"It is the child-rearing issue of our time, at least for middle and upper-class families, across most of the western world," says US child psychiatrist Dr Alvin Rosenfeld, co-author of Hyper-Parenting: Are You Hurting Your Child by Trying Too Hard?

"Parents have been led to believe that they can somehow programme their children for success if only they do all the right things. It starts even before they are born, when pregnant women are warned of dire consequences if they don't eat the right foods. Then they are told that playing a baby Mozart could speed its development, so they play Mozart and it just goes on from there. It's a very fascistic, winner-takes-all view of society and it's making a lot of parents - and children - very unhappy."

Rosenfeld's book has caused a media furore in the US, where hyper-parenting is pretty much the norm for all but the poorest parents. Its real-life case studies, including a father who sought human growth hormone treatment for his 10-year-old son in the belief that short people are seen as losers, have shocked Americans. And his criticisms have been taken up by paediatricians and psychiatrists alarmed at the physical and mental toll that "over-scheduling" is taking on young lives.

"Doctors across the country are reporting a growing trend in children suffering from stomach ulcers and frequent headaches due to exhaustion and stress," says childhood expert William Doherty of the University of Minnesota. "Teachers are dealing with exhausted kids in the classroom. It's a very serious problem." Doherty is helping dismayed parents in a handful of American suburbs to set up Family Lives First! groups, which request local sports and youth clubs to cut back on required games and classes.

In the UK, too, GPs and child experts are reporting similar symptoms of stress among overtired and overstimulated middle-class children. With two working parents now the norm, many children are attending after-school clubs through necessity. But competitive pressures are also fuelling an explosion of private-sector extracurricular activities, including sports, language, music and maths classes for children as young as four.

"There is definitely a new parenting trend under way which says that you have to uncork all your child's potential at a young age, otherwise you will let them down," says Terri Apter, a Cambridge-based child and adolescent psychiatrist. "It isn't entirely new: there have always been pushy parents. But what was previously seen as eccentric behaviour is now much more the norm. Mothers see their children's friends doing lots of outside activities and they believe they have to follow suit. It all becomes very competitive."

Dee Knox, a mother of three in an affluent south London neighbourhood, knows all about such pressures. "I know a lot of families where parenting became a competitive thing from a very young age," she says resignedly. "It starts off when they are toddlers, with mothers comparing how many social out ings their children are having to friends' houses, and then it progresses to doing gym or judo classes at five and Spanish lessons at six. It's just crazy."

She and her husband have so far resisted such pressures for sons Tom, seven, Patrick, four, and two-year-old Charlie. Tom does one after-hours club at his private school and plays mini-rugby on winter Sundays. "He sometimes asks to do more but I say no," says Dee. "He asked to learn to play a musical instrument the other day, for example, but I said I would rather he just came home and mucked around with his family. So far, it hasn't caused a problem, although other children at his school do much more than he does."

Terri Apter has seen at first hand the harmful effects of hyper-parenting. She is currently studying a group of British and American 18-year-olds, many of whom are having enormous difficulty adjusting to the freedom of college life. "A lot of them are so used to having their time filled up chock-a-block by their parents that, when they leave home, they are totally bewildered by these large swathes of unstructured time in their daily lives. They lack the most basic self-management skills and simply don't know what to do with themselves."

The answer, she says, is for parents to lighten up and take a sensible middle road - allowing for lots of time for free play with family, as well as structured activity. "Everyone wants their child to shine, but going to art or jazz classes are not necessarily any more beneficial than giving young children time and freedom to play by themselves. Or just to sit and think."

Are you hyper?

Want to avoid falling into the Hyper-Parenting Trap? US child psychiatrist Alvin Rosenfeld, co-author of Hyper-Parenting, suggests the following "fundamental principles":

 Limit activities. Signing your child up for too many will stress out the whole family.

 Resist peer pressure to overdo it. Some parents make firm rules such as one sport per child per season.

 Develop healthy scepticism. Be discriminating in taking advice from ubiquitous parenting "experts"in the media, and don't follow every fad promising to boost a child's immune system or brainpower.

 Make family a priority. Fostering proper relationships with your children is more important than ferrying them to activities - don't imbalance or overload family life with outside commitments.
