fields.bodyText: Life for Cathy Hagner and her three young children is set to permanent fast-forward. Their full school day and her 9am-2pm job as a paralegal are busy enough. But it's at 4pm that the pace really quickens. Cathy frantically ferries Brendan, 12, and Matthew, 10, from soccer field to hockey pitch to basketball court while dropping off eight-year-old Julie at piano lessons or Girl Scouts club. Often, the exhausted family doesn't get home until 7pm - just in time for a quick supper before homework. Julie, though barely old enough to tie her own shoelaces, is studying for tests in Spanish and religion and reading a book on which she has to give a seminar-style presentation to her class. She also practises piano every day and often nods off over her night-time paperwork. "One evening recently, I spent four solid hours in the car driving them from one activity to another," says Cathy, who lives in a small town outside Buffalo in New York State. "We were all pretty stressed and it did make me stop and think whether this was any kind of normal life. But then, we know lots of families whose kids do even more than mine do!" Welcome to the world of hyper-parenting. A world in which middle-class American - and, increasingly, British - parents treat their children as if they are competitors eternally racing for some undefined finishing line. A world in which the people-carrier becomes a second home as children are hustled from activity to activity in or der to make their future CVs as impressive as possible. A world in which raising the next Tiger Woods or Venus Williams has apparently become a more important goal than raising a happy, well-balanced child. "It is the child-rearing issue of our time, at least for middle and upper-class families, across most of the western world," says US child psychiatrist Dr Alvin Rosenfeld, co-author of Hyper-Parenting: Are You Hurting Your Child by Trying Too Hard? "Parents have been led to believe that they can somehow programme their children for success if only they do all the right things. It starts even before they are born, when pregnant women are warned of dire consequences if they don't eat the right foods. Then they are told that playing a baby Mozart could speed its development, so they play Mozart and it just goes on from there. It's a very fascistic, winner-takes-all view of society and it's making a lot of parents - and children - very unhappy." Rosenfeld's book has caused a media furore in the US, where hyper-parenting is pretty much the norm for all but the poorest parents. Its real-life case studies, including a father who sought human growth hormone treatment for his 10-year-old son in the belief that short people are seen as losers, have shocked Americans. And his criticisms have been taken up by paediatricians and psychiatrists alarmed at the physical and mental toll that "over-scheduling" is taking on young lives. "Doctors across the country are reporting a growing trend in children suffering from stomach ulcers and frequent headaches due to exhaustion and stress," says childhood expert William Doherty of the University of Minnesota. "Teachers are dealing with exhausted kids in the classroom. It's a very serious problem." Doherty is helping dismayed parents in a handful of American suburbs to set up Family Lives First! groups, which request local sports and youth clubs to cut back on required games and classes. In the UK, too, GPs and child experts are reporting similar symptoms of stress among overtired and overstimulated middle-class children. With two working parents now the norm, many children are attending after-school clubs through necessity. But competitive pressures are also fuelling an explosion of private-sector extracurricular activities, including sports, language, music and maths classes for children as young as four. "There is definitely a new parenting trend under way which says that you have to uncork all your child's potential at a young age, otherwise you will let them down," says Terri Apter, a Cambridge-based child and adolescent psychiatrist. "It isn't entirely new: there have always been pushy parents. But what was previously seen as eccentric behaviour is now much more the norm. Mothers see their children's friends doing lots of outside activities and they believe they have to follow suit. It all becomes very competitive." Dee Knox, a mother of three in an affluent south London neighbourhood, knows all about such pressures. "I know a lot of families where parenting became a competitive thing from a very young age," she says resignedly. "It starts off when they are toddlers, with mothers comparing how many social out ings their children are having to friends' houses, and then it progresses to doing gym or judo classes at five and Spanish lessons at six. It's just crazy." She and her husband have so far resisted such pressures for sons Tom, seven, Patrick, four, and two-year-old Charlie. Tom does one after-hours club at his private school and plays mini-rugby on winter Sundays. "He sometimes asks to do more but I say no," says Dee. "He asked to learn to play a musical instrument the other day, for example, but I said I would rather he just came home and mucked around with his family. So far, it hasn't caused a problem, although other children at his school do much more than he does." Terri Apter has seen at first hand the harmful effects of hyper-parenting. She is currently studying a group of British and American 18-year-olds, many of whom are having enormous difficulty adjusting to the freedom of college life. "A lot of them are so used to having their time filled up chock-a-block by their parents that, when they leave home, they are totally bewildered by these large swathes of unstructured time in their daily lives. They lack the most basic self-management skills and simply don't know what to do with themselves." The answer, she says, is for parents to lighten up and take a sensible middle road - allowing for lots of time for free play with family, as well as structured activity. "Everyone wants their child to shine, but going to art or jazz classes are not necessarily any more beneficial than giving young children time and freedom to play by themselves. Or just to sit and think." Are you hyper? Want to avoid falling into the Hyper-Parenting Trap? US child psychiatrist Alvin Rosenfeld, co-author of Hyper-Parenting, suggests the following "fundamental principles":  Limit activities. Signing your child up for too many will stress out the whole family.  Resist peer pressure to overdo it. Some parents make firm rules such as one sport per child per season.  Develop healthy scepticism. Be discriminating in taking advice from ubiquitous parenting "experts"in the media, and don't follow every fad promising to boost a child's immune system or brainpower.  Make family a priority. Fostering proper relationships with your children is more important than ferrying them to activities - don't imbalance or overload family life with outside commitments.  Be unproductive. An adult life of endless activity from 6am to 9pm sets a bad example, suggesting to our children that they should be hyperactive workaholics too. Show your children you enjoy their company with no apparent goal - nothing will bolster their self-esteem more effectively.  Treat childhood as a preparation, not a performance. Children should not be judged on every aspect of their performance in life - from school to sports. It puts too much pressure on them and us; resist pressure to push your child to excel early.  Leave empty spaces in your diary. Parents worry about kids being bored and so tend to "over-schedule" their lives. Empty hours are important - they teach children to use their imaginations and create their own happiness.

fields.headline: Life after Havel
fields.standfirst: The Czech president's persistent health problems are prompting questions about his replacement, says Kate Connolly
fields.trailText: The Czech president's persistent health problems are prompting questions about his replacement, says Kate Connolly.
fields.body:
In mid-1998, as he was recovering from a life-threatening perforation of the colon, Czech president Vaclav Havel approached his friend Madeleine Albright to ask her if she would consider taking over the presidency when his term of office ends in January 2003.

"I'm very flattered by the speculation that I might be considered a serious candidate," the Czech-born former US secretary of state said when the news came to light a year ago.

Commentators and Havel aides had a field day with the idea. "She would be supremely qualified," said Jiri Pehe, Havel's former chief adviser. "She has all of the experience you could imagine."

The people warmed to the idea: after all, anything was possible in a country where a playwright had become president, Shirley Temple an ambassador and Frank Zappa cultural envoy.

Mrs Albright generously allowed the fairytale-loving nation a few days to mull over the far fetched but pleasurable notion, before issuing a statement which well and truly quashed all rumours.

"I am not and will not be a candidate for that high office," she said, "for which I am sure there will be no shortage of highly qualified Czech men and women."

"If only," mused Prague Castle officials, while newspaper commentators speculated as to who made up this supposed wealth of candidates, producing just a handful of mainly highly eccentric possibilities: the chief of a commercial TV station, a catholic priest, a silver haired travel agent-cum-senator, and the country's former Thatcherite prime minister whose government fell from grace after a succession of corruption scandals.

No, the prospects were not looking bright. (Even when he'd run for re-election two years ago, Havel's only opponents were an astrophysicist from the communist party and a far right wing leader who was unable to attend the parliamentary vote because he was behind bars.) The debate was shelved, but has arisen once again in the past few days after the 64 year-old was forced to cut short a visit to Kuwait and was whisked back home to Prague military hospital with blocked lungs and bronchitis.

On Sunday, doctors announced he was suffering from a new complication and the notoriously difficult patient is now into his second week under close medical observation.

It is the ninth life threatening illness of the former playwright president since December 1996 when he had a 15 millimetre cancerous tumour removed along with half his right lung. Doctors say he is paying the price for years in and out of prison under communism, combined with a lifetime of chain smoking.

The Czech populace has graduated considerably from being so disinterested and naive about the details of the health of its head of state that doctors once fobbed them off with x-rays of his bodyguard, claiming they were the president's.

Now they are a nation of walking medical dictionaries who familiarise themselves with details of his procedures like colostomy removals, tracheotomies and his bronchopneumonial and arrhythmial conditions.

And with this latest illness they have come of age, say commentators, after finally beginning to confront the taboo topic of life after Havel, the man who has like no other Czech politician, shaped his country's post-communist image and been key to securing places at the negotiating tables of both the EU and Nato (which the Czech Republic joined two years ago).

It will be hard to find a replacement for a man who, despite his flagging popularity at home, is on the world stage one of the most popular politicians, credited with helping to overthrow communism in eastern Europe, who has been described as a better Czech export than even Skoda cars or beer.

But asked recently by the daily Mlada Fronta Dnes whether Vaclav Havel should consider stepping down due to his health, 66 per cent of pollsters responded in favour of him doing so.

Jiri Leschtina writing in the same paper, said if he resigns now, Havel would be betraying himself.

But others say if he doesn't, Havel - around which there is a growing air of irreplaceability - is in danger of allowing the post to fall to some highly controversial figures.

Now, say an increasing number, would be the time to pass the baton to the sturdy yet uncharismatic former dissident, Petr Pithardt, leader of the senate, thus blocking the attempts of the opposition Civic Democratic Party (ODS) to place its ruthlessly pro-capitalist leader and former prime minister, Vaclav Klaus, in the post. Or even - as has been suggested this week - the lacklustre current Social Democrat prime minister Milos Zeman.

It was Klaus who helped Havel found the civic forum, the group of dissidents that led the Velvet Revolution that toppled the communists.

Now, in a true illustration of how the country has split since 1989, the two men are public enemies - one a fervent advocate of capitalism, the other inclining toward more welfare-conscious politicking - prompting Klaus to say in a recent interview of his former friend: "I don't believe what he says, what he stands for, what he does ... I am a normal person, he is not."

What Mr Klaus probably finds hard to stomach is that only one Vaclav will lodge in the memory and it won't be him.

Havel dismisses as "tabloid speculation" the idea that he might resign before his term of office is over, but he has strongly indicated that he will not rue the day when it comes.

A few months ago he said he was looking to "introduce a little slowness" into his life, and wished to drive through the streets of Prague without the regulation blue flashing light on his official car.

"I might neglect a great number of my presidential obligations," he said, "but I will have time to think and look into other cars and watch people."

They sounded just like the words of a man who in 13 years has never felt comfortable with the trappings of power and may no longer have the energy to drive his scooter down the corridors of Prague Castle, but has plenty of mental vigour - and a wealth of material - to return to writing absurdist plays.

fields.headline: Marketing Week
fields.standfirst: Publication date: February 22
fields.trailText: February 22: Jan Ahrenbring, Ericsson's veteran global marketing chief, has quit.
fields.body:
Jan Ahrenbring, Ericsson's global veteran global marketing chief, has quit the company.

Mattel has appointed Eugene Murtha as its managing director following the unexplained departure of Richard Sanderson.

Volkswagen is seeking a UK marketing chief following the promotion of Chris Craft to the new role of director of group service.

Air Miles has appointed Mary Thomas from British Airways to replace Amanda MacKenzie as its marketing director.

Argos has poached Comet marketing director Paul Geddes to be its new marketing chief.

AOL Time Warner has chosen Coca-Cola to be its sole global marketing partner for the release of the forthcoming Harry Potter film, in a deal worth £95m.

fields.headline: Marketing
fields.standfirst: Publication date: February 22
fields.trailText: February 22: The Central Office of Information is set to put more than £100m worth of government advertising business up for grabs.
fields.body:
The Central Office of Information is to put more than £100m of government advertising business up for grabs.

Excite has drafted in IPC Media commercial director Rebecca Miskin to be its first dedicated UK general manager.

Air Miles has hired British Airways marketeer Mary Thomas to fill its top marketing post.

Jan Ahrenbring, Ericsson Mobile Communications' top marketeer, has quit two weeks after hiring Bartle Bogle Hegarty to handle the company's £100m global account.

Ex-beeb.com and Tango marketing chief David Atter has emerged as chief executive and co-founder of new website Talking Families.

BT is to call a review of its consumer direct marketing business, worth up to £20m.

Scottish Courage has handed its £5m Beck's creative account to M&C Saatchi.

fields.headline: Arab rulers undertake reform
fields.standfirst: In the Middle East, constitutional change isn't being demanded by the masses, but handed down from above, writes Brian Whitaker
fields.trailText: In the Middle East, constitutional change isn't being demanded by the masses, but handed down from above, writes Brian Whitaker.
fields.body:
Most parents in Britain would, I'm sure, balk at the idea of naming a child "Referendum" or "New Labour". But in the Middle East, where people take their politics seriously, it's different.

Palestinian refugees, for instance, often express their family's aspirations by giving children names like "Return". And in Bahrain last week the fashionable name for babies was Mithaq, meaning "Charter".

The charter in question is Bahrain's National Charter, proposed by the progressive new ruler, which promises wide-ranging reforms including an elected parliament, a constitutional monarchy and an independent judiciary. In a two-day referendum, Bahrainis gave it their approval with obvious enthusiasm.

In Yemen yesterday, people were voting in the first local government elections since the northern and southern parts of the country were unified in 1990. Yemen has previously held two reasonably competitive multi party elections for parliament and one less successful presidential election in which the sitting president resoundingly defeated his opponent - a nonentity from his own party.

Elsewhere in the Arabian peninsula, Kuwait has an elected parliament, though political parties are banned and women (as well as substantial numbers of men) do not have the right to vote. These are modest but encouraging signs in a region which has, historically, been noted for its rule by autocratic monarchs or the military.

One of the striking features of the Middle East today is that the initiative for reform usually comes from the top - unlike Europe, where constitutional change in the past was generally achieved through popular struggle, sometimes including the drastic step, as in Britain and France, of chopping a king's head off.

One reason for this difference, perhaps, is the traditional Arab respect for authority which means that people look to the head of their family, their local sheikh or their ruler, for guidance.

Another is that the Middle East now has a growing number of new-generation leaders - all at least partly western-educated - who have modern ideas and recognise that their countries will not prosper in the global economy unless they adopt more open systems of government.

Among these are King Mohammed of Morocco and Abdullah of Jordan, President Bashar al-Assad of Syria and Sheikh Hamad al-Khalifa of Bahrain. We should, perhaps, also include the Emir of Qatar, who did great service to the whole region a few years ago by setting up the Arab world's most free-speaking television channel, al-Jazeera.

One of the problems with this is that it's very difficult to turn a country round single-handed. Government ministers and officials are often nervous about making the slightest reforms without approval from the top. In Morocco, which is theoretically a constitutional monarchy with a socialist government, virtually nothing happens unless the king says so.

Surprisingly for Europeans, resistance to change sometimes comes from the masses. Last year, a demonstration in favour of women's rights, organised by Morocco's educated elite, was completely overwhelmed by a huge counter-demonstration of conservative Islamists.

Other resistance comes from entrenched elements in the establishment who have a parochial outlook and less experience of the outside world than their rulers. Many make a comfortable living through corruption and so have a financial interest in preserving the status quo.

A more cynical view is that many of the countries that embark on democratisation are not really interested in democracy but feel obliged to meet certain minimal standards in order to qualify for western aid and to stop human rights organisations from frightening away investors.

This may be a factor in some of the poorer Arab countries, but western dependence on oil and the prospect of lucrative arms sales tends to over-ride principles when it comes to dealing with the rich Gulf states. For that reason, it is possible that some of the richest countries in the Gulf will be the last to democratise.

A further motive behind reform from the top is that it can provide a safety valve for internal conflicts. Bahrain's long-standing problem is that it has Sunni Muslim rulers while the Shi'a population, who are in the majority, have little political power.

Shi'ite frustration boiled up into riots, bombings and arson attacks in the mid-1990s, and hundreds of activists were brutally suppressed by the previous emir, with more than a little help from a retired British colonel called Ian Henderson.

The new emir's proposals, which grant equality to all Bahrainis, regardless of their religious sect, signal a more enlightened approach to the grievances of the Shi'ite majority. The hope is that in future these problems can be resolved through democratic channels.

Something similar happened in Yemen back in 1990 when the two parts of the country were unified. The south had been governed by Marxists, while the north had a much more traditional tribal system. In an absence of agreement about who should run the unified country, the two governments set up a temporary coalition, to be followed by multi-party elections. With their very different backgrounds, the coalition partners soon fell out and by 1994 resorted to war, which resulted in a victory for the north.

The basic problem in Yemen was that the multi-party system became an excuse to avoid confronting the underlying disagreements. Instead of using democratic processes to resolve these differences, they institutionalised them in the name of democracy.

Eleven years on, the idea of accepting majority decisions (even when you disagree with them), and of not harassing opposing candidates, has still not fully taken hold in Yemen.

In yesterday's elections, 10 people were reportedly killed and more than 20 wounded. In one district, tribesmen fired at a helicopter carrying ballot boxes, complaining that the government had forced their candidates to withdraw from the contest.

With their very different backgrounds, the coalition partners soon fell out and by 1994 resorted to war, which resulted in a victory for the north. The basic problem in Yemen was that the multi-party system became an excuse to avoid confronting the underlying disagreements. Instead of using democratic processes to resolve these differences, they institutionalised them in the name of democracy. Eleven years on, the idea of accepting majority decisions (even when you disagree with them), and of not harassing opposing candidates, has still not fully taken hold in Yemen. In yesterday's elections, 10 people were reportedly killed and more than 20 wounded. In one district, tribesmen fired at a helicopter carrying ballot boxes, complaining that the government had forced their candidates to withdraw from the contest. webTitle: Extract from Did Things Get Better? (III)

fields.headline: A pale sort of green
fields.standfirst:
Our third extract from a new book assessing Labour's performance in government finds that growth consistently trumped environment
Extract one: Well, did things get better?
Extract two: social justice
Extract four: crime
Extract five: health
Polly Toynbee and David Walker pick their top 10 politics books
fields.trailText: Our third extract from a new book assessing Labour's performance in government finds that growth consistently trumped environment.
fields.body:
Never mind things, did the planet's prospects improve under Tony Blair? Measured against indices of global warming and environmental degradation, Labour barely twitched the dial. But assessed against other countries' efforts and taking into account the public's lust for burning fuel and turning on lights, Labour might win a prize in the every-little-helps stakes.

Gordon Brown grasped the nettle of taxing industry to cut energy consumption though he also fulfilled the manifesto promise to cut VAT on domestic fuel to 5%, hardly likely to encourage homeowners to use less. Motorists were pillaged through the fuel price escalator - until they rebelled last year.

All the talk about sustainability - John Prescott did produce a "sustainable development strategy" in 1999 but little has been heard of it since - cannot mask a fundamental point. When it came to the rural and urban white papers, jobs and prosperity were Labour's foremost concerns. If they could be accommodated on brown rather than green fields, well and good. But in the language of priorities, growth trumped environment every time.

As Labour strove to reconcile business interests with the welfare of the planet, a series of uncomfortable compromises were made. The bid to cut carbon emissions (20% by 2010 was the promise) was never going to involve a serious effort to substitute non-fossil fuels in producing energy. Tiny support was offered wind farms and solar cells - Tony Blair's promise to finance research on renewables turned out to be based on £50m not even from the government but the national lottery's new opportunities fund. Still, the chart shows what will happen if Labour's package of measures to cut greenhouses gases are put into effect, cutting total output of such gases by 23% by 2010, carbon dioxide by 19%.

Those reductions depend on Labour's greatest environmental achievement, the climate change levy starting in April, despite the Confederation of British Industry's protests. The trouble was, the green message was never consistently delivered. If domestic fuel was made cheaper, VAT was cut on insulation and poorer households were helped to lag roofs and seal windows. In contradiction, restrictions were lifted on gas-fired power stations and Labour tried to help what is left of the UK's deep-mined coal industry, old sentiment tugging against new green imperatives. On the sustainability side of the ledger a new tax on aggregates - gravel for building - is payable from next year and landfill taxes were raised.

Fuel duty escalator was invented by the Tories to fill the Treasury's coffers and Labour used it to pump up revenues it could not get because it had promised not to raise income tax. Between May 1997 and the end of last year the pump price of unleaded rose by 42% of which 22 percentage points were due to tax. Had it been linked from the start with improved public transport motorists might just have been persuaded (the aggregate real costs of motoring having fallen over the long term). But the 10-year plan for transport launched last year, even before the September protests, showed Labour's reluctance to attack the car culture. After all, Longbridge is the epicentre of Midlands electoral marginalism. No congestion charges, so far. Bike lanes have largely been left to a charity, Sustrans, to build.

Some greenery had sprouted round the edges of transport policy, excise duty cut to encourage cleaner engines and less powerful cars, car tax allowances linked to carbon output. But road building also expanded.

When countryside dwellers invade London on March 18, it will be worth asking whether things really did get worse for them. Labour, true to its postwar traditions, proved as much the farmers' sugar daddy as the Tories. Agricultural interests were excused the harsh competitiveness prescribed by the prime minister and chancellor for other industries. No effort equivalent to what is now happening in Germany was made to rebase agricultural production on sustainable, animal-friendly principles. No heads rolled as a result of the BSE inquiries.

Frightened by the marches in 1997, the government rushed to throw in ad hoc hush money for rural transport and housing and safeguards for village shops. Having prevaricated on hunting until recently, Labour made more progress on a statutory right to roam. The Countryside Act will open up 4m acres, though "local forums" in which landowners are unlikely to be reticent will be set up to discuss access. Labour did establish new national parks with strong planning regimes covering the New Forest and parts of the South Downs and "countryside" was itself extended as 30,000 hectares were newly classified as green belt.

But this has been a growth government and growth means extra pressure on green fields and extra emissions of greenhouse gases, especially from transport. The government did little to prepare people for a future of more expensive, less plentiful energy. The sight, last November, of fuel-protesting hauliers trying to drive their lorries through flooded York was a potent sign of how little the public connected energy consumption with environmental catastrophe.

fields.body:
The liquidator for Fashionfile.com is hoping to find buyers for the trading exchange's assets in the hope of recouping some of the cash owed to creditors.

Sports content company Sportal is to launch a broadband and 3G wireless video service to enable users to bet on live sporting events.

ZapItOver has run out of funding and is to cease trading.

Property giant British Land is launching a site that can be tailored to users' shopping tastes.

Virgin Mobile is to introduce a service that will alert subscribers to late deals and discounts via SMS text, WAP and voice messaging.

Wellbeing.com, the joint venture between Boots and Granada Media, has bought some of the assets of failed parenting site WebBaby.

webTitle: £1m project gives travellers easier access to healthcare

fields.headline: £1m project gives travellers easier access to healthcare
fields.trailText: Going to see the doctor can be a daunting experience for Britain's travelling families.
fields.body:
Going to see the doctor can be a daunting experience for Britain's travelling families.

People who live in a caravan with no bath or shower, whose clothes permanently smell of ingrained wood-smoke, and whose boots and trousers are more often than not covered in mud, don't always get the reception they want.

Now, in a pioneering pilot scheme aimed at solving these access and other problems, travelling families in Herefordshire are to get their own mobile health service.

The £1m project, which is being funded by the Department of Health, will bring health care to around 1,200 travellers in a scheme that will run for the next three years.

The project was put together after extensive research to pinpoint the exact needs of travellers. Initially, the mobile health team - a GP, lead nurse, health visitor and practice manager - will take the service to the families wherever they are in the county via a mobile health centre in a former bus. Longer-term plans are for the to have facilities for a surgery on a permanent site.

Karen Henson, lead nurse on the project, said months of research and planning have gone into the setting up of the scheme, including meeting with travellers.

"The sort of health problems that they have are what you would get at a general surgery. The problems may be more severe or they might be presenting with problems earlier, but what is vital is to make the service accessible," she said.

"Travellers don't present as your average member of the public. For many of them, going to see the doctor may be intimidating because they feel sensitive about being seen as being different, and they are sensitive to prejudice.

"One of the major aims of the project is really to encourage them to present for the services that we offer irrespective of whether or not they have mud on their boots, or if they haven't had a bath for some time. We want to make sure that when they come to see us they don't feel uncomfortable simply because of the way they choose to live their lives."

The project aims to meet the needs of both new and traditional travellers. According to the health professionals involved, the two groups are likely to have differing health needs and to take a different approach to accessing care. In the case of the traditional travellers, many of whom have led an itinerant lifestyle since birth, there may be problems with literacy that mean that health promotion campaigns are less effective than for the general population.

Many new travellers may have adopted the lifestyle as adults and are often drawn to alternative forms of medicine, although Ms Henson says it is important to avoid generalisations.

"The project will be needs-led, and at first the bus will be kitted out with basic equipment like a mini-health centre, but as we find out exactly what is needed then we can refine what we have to offer," said Ms Henson.

Travellers were involved in interviewing the workers on the project - and that is seen as an important move by the travellers. Many of the travellers believe the idea will help because the health professionals involved will have a special understanding of their nomadic lifestyle and culture.

"It was important because we were able to make sure that the people involved really understand what travelling is like. It can be a really stressful lifestyle when you get evicted and have to move on. There are problems, like getting the results of tests when you may be spending some time in Scotland then travelling to Wales and then maybe Herefordshire,'' said Lily Horseman, who has been a traveller for seven years.

"When a family take a sick child to a surgery they don't want to be harassed by being asked to take off their boots before going in and this has happened to people I know. With this project there is a kind of shorthand, the doctor or nurse already understands the lifestyle, you don't have to explain that your clothes smell of wood-smoke or that you may not have access to running water.

"I know that a lot of travellers will use this service instead of just waiting until things get really bad and then having to go to the local accident and emergency department because they feel so out of place at an ordinary surgery."

fields.headline: Pig farmers penned in
fields.standfirst:
Foot and mouth disease is the latest body blow to an industry already reeling from senseless economic pressures, says Derek Brown

Special report: What's wrong with our food?
fields.trailText: Foot and mouth disease is the latest body blow to an industry already reeling from senseless economic pressures, says Derek Brown.
fields.body:
For more than a decade, Britain's battered livestock industries have been swirling in a turgid sea of grim initials.

First it was BSE and the ghastly phenomenon of mad cows. Then came the passionate debate over GM food - genetically modified for beasts to eat, as well as humans. Last year brought CSF, the horrible classical swine fever. Now there is FMD, the worst of the lot.

Foot and mouth disease spreads with deadly speed. It affects pigs, sheep, goats and cattle. The only way to deal with it is by the most drastic of scorched-earth campaigns. The last big outbreak, in 1967-68, saw the slaughter of nearly 450,000 animals.

For big breeders in particular, the FMD outbreak could not have been worse timed. Their industry has been hammered by tough new animal welfare regulation, by supermarket demands for GM feeds to be eliminated and by a flood of cheap imports, notably from Denmark and the Netherlands.

In spite of all that, market prices for home-produced pork and bacon have risen smartly in recent weeks. Blue sky was reappearing over the pig business. Now the darkest cloud envelopes it again.

Little wonder then about the shrieks of outrage coming from the industry. Digby Scott, commenting today on the estimable national pig association website, puts down the FMD outbreak to "supermarket greed and the drive for globalisation at all costs [which] has turned this country into a cesspit for the world's cheapest meat and meat products".

He has a point. The vast bulk of food consumed in Britain - imported or otherwise - is transported ridiculous distances to reach the supermarket shelves. It has to be collected, processed, labelled, wrapped, stored and distributed. Even small farmers who want to market meat products locally, are increasingly forced to sent their animals many miles to the nearest abattoir - and then bring it back again.

This article is being written in Oxfordshire. In the whole county, just one slaughterhouse has survived the torrent of British and EU hygiene regulation. In our small market town, remarkably, we have two traditional butchers, both offering high quality and value. But the pressure on prices is remorseless: one of the butchers buys in Danish pork, to compete with the supermarkets.

No wonder that the thriving outdoor pig farms around about the town have dwindled and, in at least one case, gone out of production altogether. Now the remaining producers have to live with the grisly fear of a disease for which there is no answer save wholesale slaughter.

webTitle: BBC staff to work to rule

fields.headline: BBC staff to work to rule
fields.trailText:
8.30am: BBC staff will begin working to rule in protest at a new expenses policy from next Monday, writes Jason Deans.
Feb 15: Expenses policy sparks BBC work to rule
fields.body:
BBC staff will begin working to rule in protest at a new expenses policy from next Monday, in a move that will hit location drama shoots and outside broadcast sports coverage.

The work to rule follows a ballot by broadcasting union Bectu of more than 6,000 BBC staff members last week.

In the vote, 85% opted in favour of a work to rule, which will commence on Monday February 26.

In a potentially disruptive move made to drive the union's point home, BBC staff will return to their office for lunch if they are working on location less than five miles away.

This is a protest against staff being told they cannot claim more than £6 for lunches away.

In London, this could involve journeys of two hours or more if staff have to cross central London to get from a location shoot back to TV centre in White City.

In a protest against the ban on the use of private cars, staff will also only use BBC cabs, rather than their own cars, for late-night and early-morning shifts.

In addition, Bectu has recommended members only use hotels booked by the BBC.

Under the new rules, staff can only stay at hotels that cost up to £55 a night.

A Bectu spokesman said the work to rule would continue "indefinitely".

"As the days get longer, the impact will become greater, hitting longer sporting events and drama shoots," the spokesman added.

fields.headline: Pigs
fields.standfirst: After a 20-year hiatus, the first outbreak of foot-and-mouth has been found in Britain's pig population. Here's our guide to the best porky sites
fields.trailText: After a 20-year hiatus, the first outbreak of foot-and-mouth has been found in Britain's pig population. Here's our guide to the best porky sites
fields.body:
1. Worringly for the rural community, an outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease among pigs was confirmed at an Essex farm today, the first for 20 years.

2. Foot-and-mouth ain't pretty. First, the pigs smacks its lips as the virus is excreted in its saliva, then fluid-filled blisters form around its mouth (and other areas with thin tissues, like the feet).

3. These blisters eventually burst and naturally, the pig (or any other cloven-footed animal, most of which are also susceptible) isn't too hot on its food by this stage.

4. So many animals starve to death. The mortality rate is about 5%, but this can rise to as much as 50% with variant strains - detrimental for pig farmers.

5. It's another blow to pigs' long running PR problem after August's outbreak of swine fever.

6. Despite periodic lapses into hideous disease and their rumoured predilection for wallowing in their own excrement, pigs are actually clean animals. They don't sweat very much and only lounge around in mud because, like, there's no water around.

7. And, to make things worse, if they're not being berated for their personal hygiene, they're being cast as cigar chomping farmyard megalomaniacs in, erm, ham fisted Stalinism allegories or murderous, rampaging brutes in second rate camp horror cash-ins.

8. But despite revulsion in some quarters, pigs have many proponents, including George Clooney, whose pot bellied friend, Max, seems to exert a Svengali-like influence over his life. He vets Clooney's girlfriends, for one.

9. The animals have many noble qualities, which anyone born in the Year of the Pig will of course reflect in abundance - Ravel, Spielberg, Hitchcock and Hemingway were all porcine people.

10. And if you porkers out there are looking for your perfect animal mate, then it's all go with rats, rabbits, goats and, eye-wateringly, dragons.

fields.body:
February 19:
The weather suddenly deteriorated today, and it has been cold and raining most of the day. The wind was howling around the guesthouse blowing windows open, and then the rain started just as I set off to pick up Latifa at 8.30am.

We had planned to meet up with Stuart who was trying to continue doing his distribution of pots and pans, so we decided to brave the rain and proceed to the camps. It is good to see the rain, and a lot more is needed to make up the short-fall of the past three years, but it will prevent the final shelters being finished by next week as we had hoped. The roofs are made of wood with plastic sheeting and then mud on top of that, and the mud needs the sun to dry.

The plan was to try to monitor the first quilt-making project in Mazlagh in which 200 women had signed (with thumbprints) as having received wheat for their sewing and finishing of the quilts. We looked for the man who had looked after the tailoring tent, but were told that he had returned to his village to see how things are there. His brother helped us to identify some of the women, but it was not an easy task wandering around haphazard tents and houses, no address system at all, 8,000 families and the ground becoming muddier and slippier as the rain continued to fall.

As we move families into the new Ockenden shelters we are able to carry out more detailed registrations and will target female-headed households and large families for work in the future. There are now 350 families living in these shelters, and they have been promised some stoves from the Norwegian government through the United Nations Office for Coordinating Humanitarian Affairs (UNOCHA), firewood from the Iranian government and the International Committe of the Red Cross are thinking of giving even more stoves. This is all a good indication of the cooperation among some of the agencies.

By lunch time we all felt exhausted from trekking around in the mud, squatting in smoke-filled huts and being shouted at by women saying we are not doing enough to help them.

But I did have a really good meeting with two African women at UNICEF in the afternoon. We discussed giving some of the tailors I had seen in the villages work making baby clothes as an income generation programme.

We have very little electricity at the moment - I have been told the city generator is very old and dying, so I am writing this in the dark and getting a headache. Enough for today!

fields.headline: Christie quits TBWA
fields.trailText: 2.30pm: Neil Christie, TBWA\London's chief operating officer, has resigned unexpectedly, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
The chief operating officer of London's second biggest advertising agency, TBWA\London, has resigned unexpectedly.

Neil Christie has quit the agency - which has been his home for eight years - following a management restructure.

But Mr Christie denies he has been squeezed out.

Gary Lace and Johnny Hornby were recently appointed joint managing directors and Mr Christie was appointed chief operating officer under chairman Paul Bainsfair.

Mr Bainsfair said: "We have a too-many-cooks situation here.

"We promoted a couple of guys to joint managing directors and Neil to chief operating officer and hoped there would be enough management responsibility to cover between them.

"But it has not worked very well and Neil was the first to put his hand up and say he wasn't enjoying it.

"We talked about other positions here but he felt he wanted to help run an agency and that job had been diluted at TBWA.

"So he decided to ply his trade elsewhere," said Mr Bainsfair.

Mr Christie said that, having survived the upheaval of four mergers at the agency over the past eight years, he does not feel he has been forced out.

"I've been here long enough not to have to worry about things like being squeezed out," he claimed.

He plays down the suggestion he may start his own agency.

"I wouldn't discount that but at the moment I am going to take time out, have a holiday and then start looking for a new job."

Before joining TBWA, Mr Christie spent two years at Bartle Bogle Hegarty.

He started his advertising career at Yellowhammer.

webTitle: Trimble calls for Good Friday review

fields.headline: Trimble calls for Good Friday review
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText:
The Northern Ireland first minister says republicans need to break the deadlock over policing, militarisation and disarmament
Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.body:
Following a meeting today at Downing Street, the Northern Ireland first minister and leader of the Ulster Unionist party, David Trimble, said the Good Friday peace agreement is moving toward a review while deputy first minister Seamus Mallon said the agreement could break down within a week.

Mr Trimble warned that republicans needed to make "hard decisions" to break the deadlock over policing, demilitarisation and IRA disarmament. Speaking after a meeting with the prime minister, Tony Blair, Mr Trimble added: "If there is failure to deal with these issues then obviously we have to take stock and a review is an obvious way of taking stock."

Mr Trimble spent an hour in talks with Mr Blair but declined to say whether the meeting had left him more optimistic about the possibility of a breakthrough. Mr Blair also met today with nationalist Social Democratic and Labour party member Seamus Mallon, who urged the prime minister to call a round table meeting of all pro-agreement parties in a bid to end deadlocked discussions.

Mr Trimble said: "I very much hope there is a progress as a result of these meetings but we are as yet uncertain." He appealed to republican leaders to show the "moral courage" displayed by unionists.

Mr Trimble added: "It is time for people to shoulder their obligations and I think that is true of republicans as well as nationalists."

Mr Mallon told the prime minister that with talks on decommissioning, policing and demilitarisation still deadlocked, there was about a week left to get an agreement.

The meeting came as Sinn Fein considered legal action to stop chief constable Sir Ronnie Flanagan from starting a recruitment campaign for the new policing service. In Belfast, Sinn Fein's Martin McGuinness warned that without the establishment of a policing board, the decision to go ahead would be illegal.

Ahead of the today's meeting at Number 10, the Democratic Unionist party leader, the Reverend Ian Paisley, claimed the Northern Ireland peace process was now "shattered". Mr Paisley, a staunch critic of the Good Friday agreement, said Mr Trimble's recent warnings that the peace process could be heading for a review have dealt the process a critical blow. He said: "It has been shattered by what Mr Trimble has said - that they now need to devise new workable democratic structures for the agreement."

However, the Northern Ireland minister, John Reid, insisted he had been encouraged by the constructive tone of today's discussions.

"I think the positive nature of this morning's meetings means we will be able to carry through the process," he said.

He said all the suggestions put forward would be discussed with the Irish government on his trip to Dublin.

webTitle: Eidos/Nokia team to create WAP games

fields.headline: Eidos/Nokia team to create WAP games
fields.trailText: 1pm: Computer games company Eidos is teaming up with Nokia to provide games for WAP phones, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Eidos, the troubled creator of the Tomb Raider gaming series, has moved into the mobile phone market in a bid to counter the non-appearance of the PlayStation 2 console.

The UK company has teamed up with handset maker Nokia to provide games for internet-friendly WAP phones over the next two years.

"It is the first step on the way to mobile games, which is potentially a very big market.

"The introduction of third generation mobile phones over the next few years will make it possible to receive even more content," said Simon Protheroe, technical director of Eidos.

Eidos has been hit hard by delays in delivering the much-hyped PS2.

Game buyers have held back from buying new software until the latest console is available.

This resulted in a series of profit warnings and top-level management resignations in the second half of last year.

The PS2 consoles will begin to arrive in Europe over the next few months.

But Mr Protheroe said the advent of third-generation mobile phones could provide an important revenue stream for Eidos.

"Today, our core business remains PlayStation 2 consoles and PCs, and that will be the case for the next couple of years.

"But mobile phones will become an increasingly important market," he said.

Eidos will soon release its Gangsters game on Nokia phones and is developing WAP versions of its other games.

The company's products include a highly successful tie-in with the Who Wants to be a Millionaire? quiz show.

fields.headline: Wallpaper inspires Selfridges
fields.trailText: 12.15pm: Selfridges has hired Wallpaper's contract publishing arm to produce an in-store magazine. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Selfridges department store is hoping to shed its dowdy image.

It has recruited hyper-trendy Wallpaper founder Tyler Brule's publishing company to produce an in-store magazine.

The magazine will come out of Wallpaper Group's contract publishing and brand agency subsidiary Wink Media and will be published twice a year from March.

It will cover fashion, food, interior decoration and home appliances.

It promises to be "the dawn of a cool new era in the genre of retail publications".

Canadian-born Mr Brule broke new ground in the publishing world when he launched Wallpaper, the style bible covering design architecture and interiors.

The first issue is to feature Wallpaper's trademark designers, editors and photographers, with contributions from photographers Tim Bret Day and Rebecca Pierce.

Contract publishing has been revitalised over the past five years, attracting high-profile journalists from a style magazines.

Former Arena editor Ekow Eshun is now a consultant editor on Virgin Airways' in-flight magazine Hot Air.

fields.headline: Napster offers £690m to settle copyright case
fields.trailText:
12pm: Online music swapshop Napster is offering £690m over five years to settle the copyright case it has recently lost, reports Amy Vickers.
Feb 21: Napster plays the wooing game
Feb 20: Napster backers tackle Fifa
Feb 12: Napster loses appeal
fields.body:
Beleaguered online music swapshop Napster has offered a potentially crippling £690m over five years to settle the copyright infringement lawsuit that threatens to shut it down.

The offer was announced in San Francisco last night, a week after a federal appeals court gave the clearest indication to date that Napster would lose its court battle.

Instead of putting up a further fight and spending another year in the appeal court, Napster has offered an olive branch to record companies in a bid to find a beneficial solution to the high-profile spat.

But record companies gave a muted reaction to the Napster's proposals.

Insiders are doubtful the recording industry will fall for this proposed deal.

Record companies are loathe to allow Napster and its parent company Bertelsmann to control the online distribution of their music.

Critics have been quick to point out the proposals are little more than a PR exercise.

Napster's settlement proposal does not even come close to the money the record companies believe they are owed for copyright infringement.

Under the proposal, £104m would be paid annually for the first five years to Sony, Warner, BMG, EMI and Universal.

An additional £35m has been allocated to cover the annual costs of dealing in music from independent labels.

To cover these huge costs, Napster believes it will be able to generate hundreds of millions of dollars through its plan to introduce monthly subscriptions by July.

The limited monthly download service is to cost users around £3, while the unlimited download service will be priced at around £6.

Napster has desperately tried to reach agreements with record companies since the lawsuit began last year.

So far it has only managed to bring BMG on-side.

Napster interim CEO Hank Barry urged a peace with the record companies.

"We all ought to sit down and settle this thing. This community ought to be allowed to stay together," he said.

webTitle: Coke banks on Harry's magic touch

fields.headline: Coke banks on Harry's magic touch
fields.standfirst: Leader: Coke must not choke the magic of Harry
fields.trailText: Bespectacled boy wizard Harry Potter has conjured $150m (£103m) out of Coca-Cola, the world's leading soft drink group, which yesterday won the global marketing rights for the first film version of the popular children's novels.
fields.body:
Bespectacled boy wizard Harry Potter has conjured $150m (£103m) out of Coca-Cola, the world's leading soft drink group, which yesterday won the global marketing rights for the first film version of the popular children's novels.

The deal, which includes a promise to fund community-based reading schemes, is one of the biggest agreed to promote a film. The cost is said to be on par with the company's funding of last year's Olympic Games.

JK Rowling, whose stories about the young wizard have made her one of the wealthiest writers in Britain, insisted on having the final say on the way the books were marketed, especially in the UK. Her dislike of action figures and other aspects of Hollywood commercialisation was understood to have given Coca-Cola the edge over fast-food companies such as McDonald's.

Both Coca-Cola and Warner Bros, the film studio making Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone, stressed their plans for literacy and reading initiatives in announcing the agreement.

John Chandler, a spokesman for Coca-Cola, said: "This is going to be about the Harry Potter ethos as opposed to a buy-one-get-one-free type of thing."

The deal will allow the soft drink company to plaster images of the boy wizard over its cans of Coke, Minute Maid and Hi-C drinks. But the film will not show Harry and his friends swigging the drinks when it is released in November.

The deal comes as Coca-Cola is trying to boost sales after a wave of bad publicity including the European contamination scare last year.

Shrewd marketing has already characterised the sale of the books themselves. When Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire was released last year, books were sent out in armoured vans and eager fans started queuing at midnight to buy their copies at special launch parties.

More than 66m Harry Potter books have been sold in 200 languages so far. Warner Bros plans to turn the other three books in the series into movies if Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone is a success.

Royalties from merchandising could quadruple the £20m Rowling, who wrote the first volume as a single mother living on social security, is said to have earned from the books.

Paul Flett, vice-president of marketing for Warner Bros UK, said: "Our attitude to Harry Potter is extremely judicious and prudent."

The film studio, which is owned by AOL Time Warner, has signed several merchandising agreements with retailers. Everything from Harry Potter children's clothes to duvet covers and back-to-school stationery will be sold in stores such as Marks & Spencer.

fields.headline: Barak's last 'zigzag'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Ehud Barak's abrupt throwing in of the political towel happened too late to allow this morning's papers anything but the most cursory coverage.
fields.body:
Ehud Barak's abrupt throwing in of the political towel happened too late to allow this morning's papers anything but the most cursory coverage.

An instant analysis by Sarah Honig in the Jerusalem Post starts crisply: "When we all thought that Ehud Barak had zigged all the zags possible, he zigged yet another late last night. This, it is assumed, is his last."

The piece goes on to suggest that the prime minister's political career is well and truly over: "Barak made two incredible blunders after the election.

"First he announced impetuously that he was quitting and then he withdrew that decision. This coming on top of the unprecedented beating at the polls and the fact that, previously, his one-man rule in Labor had alienated nearly every higher-up in the party left him with no allies. No one in Labor wanted him and some feared he wouldn't even give up the party leadership."

The Tel Aviv daily, Ha'aretz, looks ahead to a new - and in all likelihood bitter - contest for the heart and mind of the sorely divided Israeli Labour party: "[Barak's] letter to Sharon paves the way for a leadership struggle inside Labor. The first items on the party agenda is for the central committee on Monday to determine not only which of its members will serve in the presumed national unity government, but who will fill Barak's place as chairman of the party."

Ha'aretz also has an eyecatchingly angry commentary targeting Israelis who always cast themselves as the victims. Writer Amira Hass finds a fine irony in predictions, from within the security establishment, that the Palestinian National Authority is on the point of collapse, and suggests that if that is so, it may have something to do with Israel's continued occupation tactics, and its own view of itself.

"Those who yield to the victim mindset that is daily fed by Israeli occupation mechanisms; those who count their own dead and wounded while remaining indifferent to the huge number of dead and wounded on the other side, are making no attempt to understand the meaning of the experiment that began in the last decade of the 20th century.

"The Oslo lab experiment [the peace process] must be judged, not on the basis of the promises and declarations of its architects, but on the basis of the Israeli policy implemented on the ground. In short, the experiment tried to examine the possibility of continuing the rule over the Palestinians by shutting them into autonomous bordered-off areas, and taking over as much as possible of their water and land resources."

The theme is taken up in the letters column by a Ha'aretz reader in New York, who dismisses the idea that the current intifada is an expression of Palestinian immaturity: "It is rather an expression of pent-up frustration from a population that has been living for almost 35 years under military rule who simply cannot take it any more and are no longer willing to tolerate the likes of Sharon and his settler supporters dictating to them the terms of their national future."

In short, the experiment tried to examine the possibility of continuing the rule over the Palestinians by shutting them into autonomous bordered-off areas, and taking over as much as possible of their water and land resources." The theme is taken up in the letters column by a Ha'aretz reader in New York, who dismisses the idea that the current intifada is an expression of Palestinian immaturity: "It is rather an expression of pent-up frustration from a population that has been living for almost 35 years under military rule who simply cannot take it any more and are no longer willing to tolerate the likes of Sharon and his settler supporters dictating to them the terms of their national future." Jack Straw, the home secretary, is to announce new powers to tackle racism across the public sector.

webTitle: Hague pledges tax breaks for married couples

fields.headline: Hague pledges tax breaks for married couples
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Tories in opposition
Nicholas Watt: are the Tories right on marriage?
fields.trailText: William Hague will reinforce Conservative claims to represent traditional, family values by unveiling tax breaks for married couples today.
fields.body:
William Hague will reinforce Conservative claims to represent traditional, family values by unveiling tax breaks for married couples today.

He will promise that a Tory government would cut up to £1,000 from wedded couples' annual tax bill. But the offer is only open to couples where one partner stays at home to look after a child under 11.

Mr Hague has long pledged bring back a version of the married couple's allowance. The last Tory government began phasing it out and before it was abolished by chancellor Gordon Brown in 1999.

The decision to limit it to married couples with children under 11 is seen as a victory for senior Tories like shadow chancellor Michael Portillo. Mr Portillo and shadow social security secretary David Willetts are among those who have argued that Conservatives must help young families.

The new benefit would be limited to basic rate tax relief and take effect from 2003-4. Costing £1bn, it means the Conservatives have used up £5.5 billion of the £8 billion savings they say they have identified to fund tax cuts announced in the run up to the general election.

Mr Hague's promise follows Tory pledges of tax breaks to help savers, pensioners, families with young children and Michael Portillo's announcement last night that widowed parents will also benefit.

However, Treasury Chief Secretary Andrew Smith was scathing about the transferable tax credit. The majority of married couples and couples with children would not be eligible, Mr Smith said. And the move fell far short of the Tory leaders pledge to bring back the married couples allowance, he claimed. "The Tories have broken their own promise to reintroduce the married couples allowance, he said.

"This measure will be of absolutely no benefit to around 80% of married couples. "Of the 10m married couples who are taxpayers over eight million will not benefit because they do not fall into the categories chosen by the Tories."

These included married couples without children, those with children over 11 or those where both partners worked, Mr Smith said. "What is more, the Tories are penalising children in certain families - six million of the 7.5 million families with children will not benefit," he added.

Earlier, Mr Portillo said a Tory government would scrap tax on both the widowed parent's allowance and any stake their partner had in the Government-operated SERPS bonus pension scheme.

About 50,000 families would benefit, according to the shadow chancellor. Those earning £15,000 a year and receiving £15 a week from SERPS would be more than £1,000 better off.

The proposal was a "significant" boost for widowed parents and part of the Tories' commitment to helping families with children, he said.

"Our approach is to help people, often at their time of greatest need, by leaving them more of their own money to support themselves and their families," said Mr Portillo. "We believe in supporting people who have responsibilities and who take on responsibilities."

The widowed mother's allowance is set at the same rate as the basic state pension and will be worth £72.50 from April, when it becomes the widowed parent's allowance.

The benefit is currently taxed for those who work, as are payments from SERPS - the State Earnings-Related Pension Scheme. That means an annual bill of £2,112.70 for someone earning £15,000 and receiving SERPS contributions of £15 a week. Under the Tory plans that would drop to £1,111.70, Mr Portillo said.

fields.headline: Schmeichel retires from Danish team
fields.trailText: Peter Schmeichel has announced his retirement from international football. The former Manchester United captain has decided to quit after 128 appearances for his country.
fields.body:
Peter Schmeichel has announced his retirement from international football. The former Manchester United captain has decided to quit after 128 appearances for his country.

Schmeichel, who captained United to their 1999 European Cup final win over Bayern Munich, was also the star performer when Denmark produced their stunning European Championship triumph in 1992.

Schmeichel left Old Trafford for Sporting Lisbon, and immediately helped the Portuguese side win their first league title for 18 years.

"After nearly 14 fantastic and eventful years as a Danish international, I have sadly taken the decision to end my international career," he said.

The Denmark coach Morten Olsen has included several England-based players in his squad to face Ireland in Dublin at the end of the month. In the absence of Schmeichel, the Sunderland keeper Thomas Sorensen is likely to start. Also included are Fulham's Bjarne Goldbaek, Everton's Thomas Gravesen, the Charlton midfielder Claus Jensen and Chelsea's winger Jesper Gronkjaer.

Denmark: Sorensen (Sunderland), Christiansen (Rangers); Albrechtsen (AB/Den), Heintze (PSV Eindhoven/Neth), Henriksen (Panathinaikos/Gr), Helveg (Milan/It), Laursen (Verona/It); Goldbaek (Fulham), Gravesen (Everton), Jensen (Charlton), Jorgensen (Udinese/It), Tofting (Hamburg/Ger), Nielsen (AB/Den); Gronkjaer (Chelsea), Michaelsen (AB), Rommedahl (PSV Eindhoven/Neth), Sand (Schalke/Ger), Tomasson (Feyenoord/Neth).

fields.headline: What is a personal loan?
fields.trailText: Taking out a personal loan is a way of borrowing money from a bank, building society or other financial service provider. You can usually borrow up to £15,000 for a period that can range from six months to 10 years. Generally speaking, the more you borrow, the lower the interest, but rates vary from around 8% to 20%, so you'll need to shop around. This is made more difficult by the fact that it is not easy to compare personal loan rates because different lenders calculate the total cost of the loan (known as the APR or annual percentage rate) in different ways.
fields.body:
Taking out a personal loan is a way of borrowing money from a bank, building society or other financial service provider. You can usually borrow up to £15,000 for a period that can range from six months to 10 years. Generally speaking, the more you borrow, the lower the interest, but rates vary from around 8% to 20%, so you'll need to shop around. This is made more difficult by the fact that it is not easy to compare personal loan rates because different lenders calculate the total cost of the loan (known as the APR or annual percentage rate) in different ways.

Loans can be secured or unsecured. Secured loans are usually tied to your house - which means if you default, you may need to sell your house to repay the loan. Unsecured loans are not tied into anything, but if you don't make the repayments, the bank will blacklist you and you may find it difficult to take out other financial products, such as credit cards or a mortgage. Loans for specific items such as new cars are also available, often with lower interest rates. If you're taking out a loan for a car, tell your lender.

Most loans are re-paid by monthly instalments and the repayment period will be agreed before you get the money. This is usually a fixed period and you will have to pay a redemption penalty - an example being two months interest - if you want to pay it off sooner. The longer the repayment period, the more interest you will be paying, so go for the shortest one you can manage. Flexible loans, which let you borrow and pay back at will, are becoming more common, but the interest rate charged is often significantly higher.

fields.headline: Cardinals in
fields.standfirst: Does today's record number of appointees mean the Pope is looking for a successor? asks Rory Carroll
fields.trailText: Does today's record number of appointees mean the Pope is looking for a successor? asks Rory Carroll
fields.body:
Records may be made to be broken but the Pope today breaks the rules with the creation of 44 new cardinals in Rome.

Clad in cassocks, blood red jerkins, capes, sashes and three cornered hats called birettas, appointees recite oaths of loyalty in Latin before a packed St Peter's square.

Pope John Paul II's message to them: "Be ready to spill blood if need be to spread the faith."

An impressive display of historic continuity. And, indeed, many of the new cardinals reflect their boss's conservatism. But churning beneath the solemnity of the ceremony, called a consistory, is the tension of a church entering a new era.

The Pope himself has signalled that something is up by appointing a record number of cardinals, bringing the total to 184.

Excluding those aged over 80 - and thus no longer eligible to vote for their successor - means that 135 cardinals are entitled to file into the Sistine Chapel at the next conclave.

Not so long ago Pope Paul VI fixed the number at 120, but John Paul has rarely been constrained by precedent. Several reasons motivated this breach, but perhaps the most compelling is the likelihood that this - his eighth - will be the Pope's last consistory.

He turns 81 in May. Not so old for the sport fanatic once dubbed God's athlete, were it not for Parkinson's disease and the legacy of the 1981 assassination attempt.

The charisma and intellect endure but he is now a trembling, slurring invalid who needs to be pushed around on a trolley. His health is believed to have stabilised in recent months and he may well be around for years to come, but appointing so many cardinals made one thing clear: he's urgently consolidating his legacy.

At the apex of an institution with around 1bn members, cardinals are busy men: theologians, diplomats, pastors, administrators, their duties range widely. Their most important task for 1,000 years is the one most of the current bunch have yet to do: elect a Pope, from their own ranks.

John Paul is thought to want someone just like him: doctrinally conservative, passionate about social justice and with theatrical flair. Thanks to his longevity - 22 years in the job - from today have he will have appointed 93% of the current voters. He regularly dines with those expected to be kingmakers to try to guide their choice.

He may spectacularly fail. Cardinals are loyal during a pontiff's lifetime but are liberated by his death. They can be their own men.

Theoretically suffused with the Holy Ghost, conclaves are believed to host cynical horse trading: vote for me and you'll get your new cathedral.

Most voters, however, take their duty extremely seriously. With an average age of 71, they know it is probably the only chance they'll get. They listen to their conscience and their flock.

First they will construct an identikit of an ideal Pope: his age, origin, personality and position on the issues. Once that's agreed they look around for who fits the bill.

Despite huge love for this Pope - who may yet become known as John Paul II the Great - restlessness has grown in recent years, especially among liberals.

An older successor is favoured so he will not reign as long. Fluency in several languages - especially Italian, English and Spanish - would be nice, if not essential. So, too, is an ability to harness mass media and ensure doctrinal consistency without alienating more people.

The crunch is likely to be origin. The Italians, 24-strong, want one of their own. Before the election of the Polish archbishop in 1978, Italy held the papacy for more than 450 years. Time to reclaim it, they reckon.

They'll have a fight on their hands and may turn out to be too divided. After Europeans the largest grouping is of Latin Americans, with 27 of voting age. A strong case, since they minister to 40% of the world's Catholics.

Peering closely at today's intake, the next Vicar of Christ could well be peering back from beneath a new biretta.

webTitle: Users warn schoolchildren of drug dangers

fields.headline: Users warn schoolchildren of drug dangers
fields.trailText: People who have become mentally ill through drug use are to tell schoolchildren about the dangers of drugs in a new charity initiative.
fields.body:
People who have become mentally ill through drug use are to tell schoolchildren about the dangers of drugs in a new charity initiative.

The Kent User Forum launched the scheme earlier this month when it became worried about the number of people entering the mental health system as a result of drug abuse.

This is an idea other charities may want to adopt following a report published this week, which shows British teenagers are more likely to use drugs, drink or cigarettes than their European counterparts.

Phillip Newhouse, spokesman for Kent User Forum, said: "I flippantly remarked to someone who is mentally ill as a result of a drugs problem that he could talk to schoolchildren. He was receptive to the idea, so I thought we would give it a go."

The forum asked the local press to run articles inviting schools to arrange sessions with a guest speaker. Mr Newhouse said: "One school in Canterbury did, it worked well, and they have invited us back."

The charity is looking for further schools to take up the offer but also thinks other charities could promote the idea around the country.

Mr Newhouse says: "Teachers I have spoken to hate teaching personal and social education (PSE) because they feel that they have no experience of the subjects. We could take over the drugs sections of PSE and citizenship courses."

fields.headline: Mail dismisses Express threat
fields.trailText:
12.15pm update: The Mail has poured scorn on the Express's attempts to drive away its readers, writes Jessica Hodgson.
10am: Express blasts Harmsworths
fields.body:
The Daily Mail has dismissed the Express's attempts to drive readers away by suggesting owner Richard Desmond simply isn't up to playing with the big boys.

The circulation director for the Daily Mail and the Mail on Sunday claims the Express lacks the resources to retaliate in the next round of the promotions war.

Mike Newman, who manages promotions and circulation for the two papers, said he doubted the Express had the "people on the ground" to put its new promotional drive into practice.

Mr Newman spoke to MediaGuardian.co.uk following reports the Express plans to offer Express readers £10 for converting their subscriptions to the Daily Mail.

"One of the reasons Associated Newspapers can offer these schemes is that we have lots of people out there who can visit shops.

"I frankly doubt whether Express Newspapers has the people on the ground to put this scheme into place," he says.

And he confirmed Associated would be offering newsagents £5 for each Express to Mail conversion.

He noted the Express had just made a number of cuts to its circulation department.

He also rebuffed suggestions the two newspaper groups were "at war", saying the tactics were just "standard news trade practice".

"I can think of at least four occasions in the past four years when we've done this," he said.

He said Associated had identified "a way of rolling out circulation by capturing readers from the Express - it is in a weak position because it has a new owner".

Last week the Express circulation director Nigel Lomas defected to News International.

This morning the Express published a searing piece identifying the Rothermere family - the proprietors of Associated Newspapers - as "dysfunctional".

The Express is trying to establish itself as the paper for family values in place of the Daily Mail.
