webTitle: Russia turns its back on young Aids generation

fields.headline: Russia turns its back on young Aids generation
fields.trailText: The bones of dead Aids victims have been ground to powder and mixed with heroin by Chechen drug dealers to spread the virus through Russia and debilitate the nation, Sasha, a young HIV-sufferer in St Petersburg, insisted.
fields.body:
The bones of dead Aids victims have been ground to powder and mixed with heroin by Chechen drug dealers to spread the virus through Russia and debilitate the nation, Sasha, a young HIV-sufferer in St Petersburg, insisted.

This is the reason for the dramatic explosion of HIV infections in the city, he said, and very possibly how he contracted the disease. Either that or by using a needle borrowed from a friend. 'Most of them are already infected. I know about 40 people who've tested positive in the last few months. There's no way of escaping it now,' he said.

Waiting for check-up results in a cold corner of the city's main HIV hospital, he made an effort to look cheerful. 'As soon as I've got over my heroin addiction, I'm going to go back to college and get a job in the timber industry where I can work in the fresh air,' he said.

His doctor assessed his prospects with less optimism. 'In a few years, when he contracts Aids, neither he nor the government will be able to afford the necessary drugs and he will die,' she said.

The seeds of a catastrophe are germinating in St Petersburg, largely ignored by local and central government. Over the past two years, Russia has been experiencing the world's swiftest rate of growth in HIV cases, with the crisis intensifying more rapidly than in any African country. Russia's northern capital is in the grip of a severe epidemic - progressing faster than in any other city throughout the federation. Two years ago there were no more than around 200 cases of HIV registered in St Petersburg, but last January local doctors became concerned by a sudden surge in infections. A year later, some 7,000 people are infected with about 1,200 new cases emerging every month.

The government has been slow to tackle the problem. As a result, among the group most at risk - people between the ages of 17 and 23 - understanding of the illness remains primitive. There is uncertainty about how the disease can be transmitted and the pulverised bone theory is widely believed.

Specialists know how the situation will progress. Over the next year the disease will be passed from drug users, prostitutes and the gay community and begin to spread through the rest of the community, pushing the number up further. 'It's only then that the local authorities will start paying attention. But of course by then it will be too late,' commented Vladimir Musatov, a doctor with Médécins du Monde, one of the independent organisations trying to combat the outbreak.

Late into the night, six days a week, he sits on a bus travelling between the main prostitute highways and the high-rise suburbs where drug use is most intensive. The bus has clean needles, facilities for testing and photocopied information on the transmission of the disease. Even when the temperature outside drops to minus 22 degrees, people queue in the snow to talk to the doctors in the bus.

Sveta, 24, broke off from her five-hour shift by the roadside, for which she earns about 400 roubles (£9.75), to pick up new needles. 'I'm very frightened about the disease,' she said, looking old and tired beneath her cheerful make-up. 'A few years ago we hardly knew what Aids was, and now we all know someone who's infected.'

St Petersburg has a heroin problem. About four years ago, it stopped being just a transit point on the drug route between Central Asia and West Europe and became an important market in its own right. Large quantities of very cheap heroin appeared, costing around 70 roubles (£1.70) a hit, and drug consumption soared tenfold among the young population.

About 98 per cent of those infected by HIV are intravenous drug users. But the 70 people who turn up every night at the bus are but a fraction of the 100,000 intravenous drug users in the city. 'The government needs to implement a series of campaigns, targeting prostitutes, drug users, schoolchildren and the general public on the risks,' Musatov said. 'Do I expect them to do this? No.'

Ingrained distaste for drug addiction among the Soviet generation has allowed many officials to suggest that those infected have only themselves to blame. 'We need to see real political desire to combat the epidemic, but the government is much better at hiding problems than at resolving them,' Alexander Tskhanovitch, director of the Médécins du Monde programme, said.

The head of the government-run centre for the fight against Aids, Vadim Pokrovsky, said: 'Many officials still don't believe we have an Aids problem.' This belief is fed by the much-quoted statistic that there are currently only 125 people in Russia suffering from the disease, with only 780 deaths registered.

Across the country some 86,000 people have been registered with HIV, which officials believe to be only 20 per cent of the real figure. Pokrovsky believes that by the end of the year, the actual number of HIV-infected Russians will rise to about a million, increasing to four million by 2005. Set against Russia's shrinking population of 145 million, the figure is disturbing.

Pokrovsky wants the government to set up a single anti-Aids co-ordinating body, headed by members of Russia's powerful Security Council, to oversee the battle against the disease. He too is doubtful about the likelihood of this happening. 'Last year the government gave us less than $2 million (£1.4m) to buy medicines, to pay for information campaigns and for testing, and this year the same amount has been allocated. To work effectively, we need no less than $100 million,' he said.

Doctors at Russia's only HIV maternity ward, on the edge of St Petersburg, treat pregnant HIV mothers to reduce the risk of passing the disease on to their unborn babies. In a clean ward upstairs, abandoned HIV-positive babies lie in neat rows of cots. Until 1997 only 20 babies had been born in Russia with the infection; since then 1,147 more have arrived - most of them the children of drug-using mothers. The future for these babies is not bright.

With the most effective Western drug treatment priced at around $800 (£544) a month per patient - and no Russian equivalent on the horizon - the doctors know that they will be unable to treat the children when they become ill.

fields.headline: Kenneth Clarke
fields.standfirst:
Rushcliffe (1970- )

Ask Aristotle about Kenneth Clarke
fields.trailText: Labour's second landslide victory has given Ken Clarke one last opportunity to shake off the title of "the leader the Tories most miss."   His popularity with the public at large is seen as his best card.  This reputation was only enhanced in the last parliament when his punchy backbench speeches showed him to be the Tories' best weapon.
fields.body:
Labour's second landslide victory has given Ken Clarke one last opportunity to shake off the title of "the leader the Tories most miss." His popularity with the public at large is seen as his best card. This reputation was only enhanced in the last parliament when his punchy backbench speeches showed him to be the Tories' best weapon.

His Labour opponents thanked heaven they were fighting William Hague - they might not be so happy he if becomes the next Tory leader.

As a former chancellor he has prospered as the chairman of Unichem (£120,000 a year) and deputy chairman of BAT (£50,000 a year).

Though he used his time in parliament to fight for his version of "one nation" pro-European Toryism, and he was very unlikely to defect to another party. His 60s-style Toryism is too deeply rooted.

Mr Clarke not only knows where all the Tory bodies are buried, he buried a few himself. He was no liberal under Mrs Thatcher, first as health secretary 1988-90, imposing Tory "reforms" as "Thatcherism with a human face", and then as education secretary 1990-92, trying to force teachers back into old-fashioned teaching techniques.

His stubbornness belies his background. His maternal grandfather was a Raleigh bicycle toolroom engineer and communist. His other grandfather was a pacifist who sold the Daily Herald at union rallies. His own father, a wartime collier electrician, turned against unions and became the owner of a jewellery business. His mother, a highly intelligent woman, died an alcoholic.

He decided at seven that he wanted to become an MP. Upon reaching Cambridge he joined both the Bow group and the moderate-Labour campaign for social democracy. He backed Macmillan's failed 1960 attempt to join the EEC and was elected chairman of the Cambridge University Conservative association which embraced John Gummer, Norman Fowler and Michael Howard.

After starting his career as a barrister, he fought hopeless Mansfield in 1964 and 1966, and then retook Rushcliffe from Labour in 1970. He began his climb as parliamentary private secretary to fellow barrister and "one nation" Europhile Geoffrey Howe and was unhappy when Margaret Thatcher defeated Mr Howe for the Tory leadership in 1975.

Mr Clarke started his ministerial life in 1979, when his Cambridge chum Norman Fowler asked for him as parliamentary secretary for transport. He then became minister for health under Mr Fowler in 1982. There he fought the unions and claimed that £6m could be recovered from overseas visitors. In 1985 he reached the cabinet as paymaster general, as No 2 to Lord Young.

He showed his continuing liberal streak by opposing hanging and supporting abortion. In 1990 he voted for Mrs Thatcher in the first round and Douglas Hurd in the second, although Europhobe Alan Clark thought "that podgy puffball" might stand himself.

Mr Clarke was a member of the government throughout the Conservatives' 18 years in power. His staying power marks him out from most of his colleagues and few doubt that they have heard the last of him yet.

webTitle: At the mercy of drug giants

fields.headline: At the mercy of drug giants
fields.trailText: Refilwe is a spectral figure, so thin that the light from the huge hospital window at her back seems to pass through her. She sits as straight as a knife, all bone, white robe, and huge eyes gazing at nothing, breathing shallowly through an open mouth. She is 30 and has a son of seven. She has tuberculosis and her mouth is covered with the telltale white spots of a common infection she cannot fight off, because HIV is destroying her body's resistance.
fields.body:
Refilwe is a spectral figure, so thin that the light from the huge hospital window at her back seems to pass through her. She sits as straight as a knife, all bone, white robe, and huge eyes gazing at nothing, breathing shallowly through an open mouth. She is 30 and has a son of seven. She has tuberculosis and her mouth is covered with the telltale white spots of a common infection she cannot fight off, because HIV is destroying her body's resistance.

Ask her how she is and she slowly turns her entire body towards you. "I'm feeling better," she whispers. It is a fiction maintained by the plump and jolly nurses at the Natalspruit hospital outside Johannesburg who have dozens more like her on drips in wards 13 and 16, where anybody with any strength resists going because if you have HIV, you have no future.

Refilwe, impossibly, gets to her feet and makes her way with pitiful steps and the arm of a nurse to the door, a walking wraith. She is going to the TB clinic. They will sort out the TB but then they will send her home to die. She is fatally weakened and there are no antiretroviral drugs to take on HIV here.

Nokuthula, 23, is also under a death sentence, for all that she appears robust with health. So is her 18-month-old son Sipho, whose name means a gift. The young mother has put herself and her child in the care of the traditional healer in the township outside Natalspruit hospital who gives them herb and bark infusions to make them strong. But traditional medicine could not save Nokuthula's husband, who died of Aids last September.

At an age when women in the west are embarking on families and careers, Refilwe and Nokuthula have begun the business of dying. They live in the East Rand suburbs of Johannesburg, South Africa, where one in five is estimated to be harbouring the virus that will kill them.

Across Africa and the developing world millions more will die of diseases that are treatable in the west, such as diarrhoea, meningitis, malaria, TB and Aids. The hospitals do what they can, but their best efforts are a sticking plaster on a haemorrhage. The western drugs they need are unaffordable. Life is priced too high.

Thirty-five miles away in Pretoria, a legal battle critical to the fate of many more women like Refilwe and Nokuthula, their men and their children, is about to begin. Case number 4183/98 in the South African high court is an action brought by 42 pharmaceutical companies, including the British giant GlaxoSmithKline, against the South African government.

The case is an attempt to block South Africa from importing cheap medicines. The drug companies have spent three years and millions of pounds preparing the case.

They have retained virtually every patent lawyer in South Africa. On March 5 their barristers will try to stop the South African government from buying the medicines its people so badly need from countries where the prices are lowest, on the grounds that it is infringing world trade agreements.

The rest of Africa will be closely watching the outcome of the trial. So will developing countries on other continents. With the death toll from infectious diseases inexorably rising, especially in Africa, a tide of outrage is swelling among local activists and international aid organisations who see medicines denied to the sick in the name of commerce.

More than 2.5m people die every year from Aids-related illnesses. More than 13m children have lost one or both parents to the condition. There are more than 32m men, women and children infected by HIV in developing countries. AZT and 3TC, the basic antiretroviral drugs in the west, would keep them alive and well, but the price tag is $10,000 (£7,000) to $15,000 per patient a year. The majority of employed people in South Africa, with whole families to support, earn less than $3,000 a year, and by comparison with most of the rest of the continent, they are rich.

But there are now alternatives - cheap copies of life-saving medicines called generics, made mainly in Brazil, India and Thailand whose national laws allow them to ignore drug patents in cases of dire human need. Thailand believes it could reduce the cost to $200 a year per patient. It is a price the South African government might be able to pay for the life of Refilwe and Nokuthula, but the drug companies, in Case 4183/98, afraid of the potential worldwide consequences if their prices start to be undercut, say no.

Today in Cape Town at least 5,000 supporters of the successful grassroots Treatment Action Campaign will march on parliament to demand the medicines. At the same time in London, Oxfam is launching an international campaign demanding help for developing countries who want to use legitimate measures to buy or make their own cheap drugs, but who are bullied into submission by the lawyers working for drug companies and by the western governments who support them.

The pharmaceutical companies argue that they need 20 years of patent protection to recoup the vast sum it costs to research and develop drugs. They say it takes $1bn and at least 12 years to get a new medicine to market.

But, their accusers say, 90% of those new medicines are designed for 10% of the world's population in rich countries who can pay for them. The companies argue they already sell to developing countries at prices lower than in the west and that, with the approval of UNAids, the joint UN programme on HIV/Aids, five major companies have offered 85% discounts on drugs that are badly needed.

That could bring antiretrovirals down to $1,500 a patient, low enough for poor countries to hand them out to a chosen few but, say critics, millions would still have to die.

The Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association of South Africa, which is bringing the case with the international companies, says it supports any country's right to buy supplies of drugs that are cheaper abroad "in exceptional circumstances". But it argues that section 15c of the Medicines Act, passed by the South African government in 1997 to allow it to import cheap copies of western medicines, would give the health minister "unfettered discretion to override patent rights for medicines in this country". And it was appalled when the South African delegation told a World Health Organisation meeting in January 1999 that the new legislation was a model which the rest of Africa should follow.

It is not just Africa that worries the big pharmaceuticals. On behalf of the industry the US government is taking the offensive to Brazil, which has had dramatic success in manufacturing its own cheap copies of patented drugs and now exports generics. Its price for an AZT equivalent is down from $15,000 a year to $4,000. There are now 60,000 people with HIV in Brazil who get free treatment.

At the heart of the growing legal battles directed against South Africa, Brazil and several other developing countries lies a little known international agreement called Trips - trade related intellectual property rights. It was agreed within the World Trade Organisation in order to ensure patent rights were respected around the world. The poorest countries have until 2006 to comply with Trips by passing their own patent laws. Under Trips, signatory states can pass clauses, as South Africa has tried to do, to bypass patents and make or buy cheaper drugs in cases of "dire emergency", and few could argue Aids is less than that.

But the west's sharp legal minds, backed by vast drug company wealth, are willing and able to mount expensive challenges in the courts to uphold their patent rights - and thus the price of their drugs - as is about to happen in Pretoria.

For the first time, there is also about to be a challenge in the WTO itself. Last month the new US administration, which accepted substantial election funding from the pharmaceutical industry, asked for a WTO disputes hearing where it will claim Brazil is in breach of Trips. Oxfam and others fear the offensive against Brazil and South Africa marks a new determination by the drugs companies to resist the flouting of their patents by poor countries.

GlaxoSmithKline has recently threatened legal action against the Indian generics company Cipla, blocking its plans to bring a cheap version of Combivir - AZT and 3TC in one pill - into Uganda and Ghana. "The implementation of WTO patent rules is taking place against the backdrop of a sustained campaign led by the pharmaceutical industry which may well erode the public health protection provided by safeguard provisions," says an Oxfam report published today.

In Khayelitsha, a shanty town that sprawls over a vast plain near Cape Town's airport, the Nobel prize-winning volunteer doctors are raising the stakes. They pioneered the use of nevirapine, a drug that stops pregnant women transmitting HIV to their babies. Now the government is rolling out the programme to the entire country.

After the period of apostasy, when President Thabo Mbeki upset the medical world by doubting that HIV caused Aids, the government seems willing to seek out and use cheap drugs if it is allowed to.

Last year it opened an infectious diseases clinic - code for HIV - where people are offered counselling and treatment for the "opportunistic infections" that can kill. They use fluconazole, a strong antibiotic most hospitals lack because of its price, to treat cryptococcal meningitis and thrush.

In May, they will take the most radical step of all and start 150 adults and 30 children who are at death's door on antiretrovirals - the very medication that keeps people in the west with HIV alive. They live in the East Rand suburbs of Johannesburg, South Africa, where one in five is estimated to be harbouring the virus that will kill them. Across Africa and the developing world millions more will die of diseases that are treatable in the west, such as diarrhoea, meningitis, malaria, TB and Aids. The hospitals do what they can, but their best efforts are a sticking plaster on a haemorrhage. The western drugs they need are unaffordable. Life is priced too high. Thirty-five miles away in Pretoria, a legal battle critical to the fate of many more women like Refilwe and Nokuthula, their men and their children, is about to begin. Case number 4183/98 in the South African high court is an action brought by 42 pharmaceutical companies, including the British giant GlaxoSmithKline, against the South African government. The case is an attempt to block South Africa from importing cheap medicines. The drug companies have spent three years and millions of pounds preparing the case. But there are now alternatives - cheap copies of life-saving medicines called generics, made mainly in Brazil, India and Thailand whose national laws allow them to ignore drug patents in cases of dire human need. Thailand believes it could reduce the cost to $200 a year per patient. It is a price the South African government might be able to pay for the life of Refilwe and Nokuthula, but the drug companies, in Case 4183/98, afraid of the potential worldwide consequences if their prices start to be undercut, say no. Today in Cape Town at least 5,000 supporters of the successful grassroots Treatment Action Campaign will march on parliament to demand the medicines. At the same time in London, Oxfam is launching an international campaign demanding help for developing countries who want to use legitimate measures to buy or make their own cheap drugs, but who are bullied into submission by the lawyers working for drug companies and by the western governments who support them. The pharmaceutical companies argue that they need 20 years of patent protection to recoup the vast sum it costs to research and develop drugs. They say it takes $1bn and at least 12 years to get a new medicine to market. fields.headline: Champions League round-up
fields.trailText: Austrian minnows Sturm Graz were surprise qualifiers for the second stage of the Champions League. They could yet be surprise qualifiers for the quarter-finals too.
fields.body:
Austrian minnows Sturm Graz were surprise qualifiers for the second stage of the Champions League. They could yet be surprise qualifiers for the quarter-finals too.

After losing their first two Group A games to Manchester United and Valencia, Sturm have now beaten Panathinaikos twice in a week. They followed up last week's 2-0 home victory by winning the return in Athens 2-1.

First-half goals from Markus Schopp and Mario Haas put Graz into a commanding position, and Ioannis Goumas's 73rd-minute header for the home side was too little, too late.

Sturm Graz coach Ivica Osim was in ebullient mood after the game, claiming: "Everyone thought Sturm would be easy opponents. That has not happened - and it will not happen in the next game."

But he admitted that next game - against Valencia in Graz on March 7 - wouldn't be easy. "Miracles don't happen every day," he said.

Gala suffer pain in Spain

Galatasaray suffered their first defeat in Group B, going down 2-0 away at Deportivo La Coruna.

Deportivo went into the game on the back of two successive Group B defeats, and despite enjoying most of the early possession looked nervous in front of goal. But those nerves were settled on 40 minutes when Victor fired home after Djalminha's shot was deflected to him at the far post.

Galatasaray were reduced to ten men on 58 minutes when Vedat Inceefe was sent off for a tackle from behind on Victor that brought him his second yellow card. Fifteen minutes later, Djalminha made the game safe for La Coruna with a well-taken penalty.

"The referee was very strict with the sending-off of Vedat but just after he didn't follow the same criterion with Mauro Silva [of Deportivo]," claimed Galatasaray coach Mircea Lucescu after the game. "The penalty was non-existent. The crowd refereed the game. Deportivo played at a high level, though," he added.

"The group is very even now," Lucescu continued. "Whoever qualifies will go through in the last minute of the last game."

Deportivo coach Javier Irureta said he expected his side to make it through to the last eight, providing they beat PSG in their next game. "Winning the next game at home to PSG should be enough," he said. "We were the better side tonight. We took the initiative, although we lacked a bit of composure on the key chances."

Late goal earns Milan a draw

A last-minute goal from substitute Jose Mari gave AC Milan a 1-1 draw at Paris St-Germain.

PSG took the lead with a 25-yard free-kick from Laurent Robert after 75 minutes, but Jose Mari scrambled an injury-time equaliser through a mishit a shot that dribbled over the line as the wrong-footed PSG keeper Lionel Letizi scrambled after the ball.

The result means that Galatasaray lead the group with seven points, followed by AC Milan and Deportivo Coruna on six and PSG on two.

However, PSG coach Luis Fernandez has refused to concede the club's Champions League campaign is over. "It's not all over yet," Fernandez said. "We've got two matches left and we've got to win them both. It's as simple as that."

But the maths are against him: PSG need to win their last two matches and hope Milan do the same to go through.

Leonardo, who was playing against his former club, admitted his side's goal was "a bit lucky".

"Even though we are unbeaten in this phase it won't be easy for us in the last two games," he said.

webTitle: Coke and P&G form joint marketing company

fields.headline: Coke and P&G form joint marketing company
fields.trailText: 11.30am: Coca-Cola and Procter & Gamble are to create a global company to develop and market drinks and snack products, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
With a pack of Pringles in one hand and a can of Coke in the other, the two biggest marketing forces in the world are forming a £2.7bn joint venture.

Coca-Cola and Procter & Gamble are to create a standalone company to develop and market new juice drinks and snack products on a global basis.

But the new, as yet unnamed, company will also bring together existing brands from each company.

P&G's Pringles, Sunny Delight and Punica brands will sit alongside Coke's Minute Maid, Hi-C, Five Alive, Fruitopia, Cappy, Kapo, Sonfil and Qoo products.

Coke and P&G will each own 50% of the limited liability company, which will have immediate annual sales of £2.6bn from the existing brands.

The new company combines Coke's worldwide distribution, merchandising and customer marketing expertise with P&G's research and development capabilities.

Don Short, a Coke veteran of 24 years, has been named chief executive of the new company.

A management team and board of directors composed of two Coke and two P&G executives will be named soon.

"This new company will focus all of its resources on becoming the global leader in innovative snacks and nutritional beverages," said Coke chairman and chief executive Doug Daft and P&G president and chief executive AG Lafley in a joint statement.

"It multiplies our respective strengths, creating something better than either of our companies could do alone - it's the perfect combination."

The companies expect sales of the new company to grow from £2.7bn to £3.5bn within two years.

It will have its own research and development capability in juice and "better for you" beverages, 15 manufacturing facilities and 6,000 employees.

It will manufacture, distribute and market brands in the £34.7bn global snacks category and the £23.6bn global juice and juice-drinks category.

The company will begin operations following regulatory approvals.

Until then, the two companies will continue to operate independently.

The new company is expected to generate revenue enhancements and cost savings that will offset transition costs.

There will be massively expanded distribution for existing brands such as Pringles and Sunny Delight.

webTitle: Aids vaccine gives Africa ray of hope

fields.headline: Aids vaccine gives Africa ray of hope
fields.trailText: An Anglo-Kenyan team will begin trials in Nairobi this week of the first Aids vaccine specifically designed for Africa, where 90 per cent of Aids victims live.
fields.body:
An Anglo-Kenyan team will begin trials in Nairobi this week of the first Aids vaccine specifically designed for Africa, where 90 per cent of Aids victims live.

The radical new vaccine is the result of a partnership between scientists from the universities of Oxford and Nairobi, which nearly came unstuck over a patent war last year. Parallel trials have already begun on 18 volunteers in Britain to see if the vaccine has any toxic effects.

The vaccine stems from the discovery that 60 prostitutes in Nairobi's Majengo slum - around 5 per cent of the total - were immune to HIV despite massive exposure to it. The women had between five and 10 sexual partners every day, and rarely used condoms. Up to 25 per cent of Kenyans are estimated to be HIV positive, and in Nairobi's slums even more.

'They didn't have the virus or the antibodies. So they must have been getting rid of the virus so quickly that it couldn't get established,' said Dr Job Bwayo, leader of the Kenyan team, yesterday.

Nairobi scientists discovered the women's immune systems were utilising an aggressive cell against the virus. The instant other cells became infected these 'killer T-cells' destroyed them.

'We took the HIV virus and white blood cells from the prostitutes, put them in a test-tube and - bang! - they reacted. The cells killed the virus,' said Bwayo.

The discovery spawned similar studies around the world. A team from Oxford's Institute of Molecular Medicine found the same phenomenon in prostitutes in the Gambia. In 1995 the Oxford and Nairobi teams joined forces. Backed by the New York-based International Aids Vaccine Initiative, their efforts have so far cost $4.5 million - a comparative snip.

The idea of a vaccine is to train the body's immune system to recognise characteristics of an enemy virus in advance, so that it will tell foe from friend when the attack comes. Traditionally, that has meant injecting people with a weakened or killed version of the virus itself, triggering antibodies.

Around 25 experimental Aids vaccines based on this principle are on trial globally. All except one have failed to get past the preliminary test stage. The new vaccine aims to trigger a different kind of immuno-response, producing not antibodies but cells - killer T-cells. Results in animals have been encouraging. Around 30 per cent of monkeys injected with the vaccine proved immune to extremely high doses of Simian Immunodeficiency Virus, HIV's close cousin.

Professor Andrew Mc-Michael, leader of the Oxford team, said yesterday: 'I believe we have a really good chance of this thing working; somewhere in the region of 70 per cent.'

McMichael confirmed that the trialists in Britain, himself included, had suffered no side-effects. 'We didn't expect any and we're very happy,' he said.

If the Kenyan trials go as well , the vaccine will be tried on a large, high-risk population in 18 months. Kenya will be the perfect testing ground because the vaccine is designed for subtype A of the virus, the predominant strain in East Africa. All existing vaccines target subtype B, predominating in Europe, Asia and America. 'As a vaccine for people in the UK this would not be optimal, though we believe we could adapt it quite easily,' said McMichael.

The best case scenario would see manufacturers called in after two years of population trials, and the vaccine widely available in another two years: around six years from now. Bwayo said: 'This vaccine may not prove to be the one. But we have hopes that, if not, one of the modifications currently being produced in Oxford will be.'

Three months ago, such co-operation briefly seemed a distant dream. The radical new vaccine is the result of a partnership between scientists from the universities of Oxford and Nairobi, which nearly came unstuck over a patent war last year. Parallel trials have already begun on 18 volunteers in Britain to see if the vaccine has any toxic effects. The vaccine stems from the discovery that 60 prostitutes in Nairobi's Majengo slum - around 5 per cent of the total - were immune to HIV despite massive exposure to it. The women had between five and 10 sexual partners every day, and rarely used condoms. Up to 25 per cent of Kenyans are estimated to be HIV positive, and in Nairobi's slums even more. 'They didn't have the virus or the antibodies. So they must have been getting rid of the virus so quickly that it couldn't get established,' said Dr Job Bwayo, leader of the Kenyan team, yesterday. Nairobi scientists discovered the women's immune systems were utilising an aggressive cell against the virus. The instant other cells became infected these 'killer T-cells' destroyed them. 'We took the HIV virus and white blood cells from the prostitutes, put them in a test-tube and - bang! - they reacted. The cells killed the virus,' said Bwayo. The discovery spawned similar studies around the world. A team from Oxford's Institute of Molecular Medicine found the same phenomenon in prostitutes in the Gambia. In 1995 the Oxford and Nairobi teams joined forces. Backed by the New York-based International Aids Vaccine Initiative, their efforts have so far cost $4.5 million - a comparative snip. The idea of a vaccine is to train the body's immune system to recognise characteristics of an enemy virus in advance, so that it will tell foe from friend when the attack comes. Traditionally, that has meant injecting people with a weakened or killed version of the virus itself, triggering antibodies. Around 25 experimental Aids vaccines based on this principle are on trial globally. All except one have failed to get past the preliminary test stage. The new vaccine aims to trigger a different kind of immuno-response, producing not antibodies but cells - killer T-cells. Results in animals have been encouraging. Around 30 per cent of monkeys injected with the vaccine proved immune to extremely high doses of Simian Immunodeficiency Virus, HIV's close cousin. Professor Andrew Mc-Michael, leader of the Oxford team, said yesterday: 'I believe we have a really good chance of this thing working; somewhere in the region of 70 per cent.' McMichael confirmed that the trialists in Britain, himself included, had suffered no side-effects. 'We didn't expect any and we're very happy,' he said. If the Kenyan trials go as well , the vaccine will be tried on a large, high-risk population in 18 months. Kenya will be the perfect testing ground because the vaccine is designed for subtype A of the virus, the predominant strain in East Africa. All existing vaccines target subtype B, predominating in Europe, Asia and America. 'As a vaccine for people in the UK this would not be optimal, though we believe we could adapt it quite easily,' said McMichael. The best case scenario would see manufacturers called in after two years of population trials, and the vaccine widely available in another two years: around six years from now. fields.headline: Ryanair announces seven new destinations
fields.trailText: Low-cost carrier Ryanair announced today that from April 5 it will offer daily flights to seven new destinations from Stansted airport, including the first services by the airline to Austria and Belgium.
fields.body:
Low-cost carrier Ryanair announced today that from April 5 it will offer daily flights to seven new destinations from Stansted airport, including the first services by the airline to Austria and Belgium.

The new routes to be operated from Stansted are Brussels, Salzburg, Esbjerg in Denmark, Pescara and Trieste in Italy and Gothenburg and Stockholm in Sweden. Return fares will start at £49 to Brussels, where there will be six flights daily. On its new Austrian and Belgian routes, Ryanair will be competing directly with British Airways, Germany's Lufthansa and Belgium's Sabena.

Ryanair also announced today that it will be increasing the frequency of flights on some of its existing routes from Stansted, with additional daily services to Dublin and Shannon in Ireland and Prestwick in Scotland.

"This will undoubtedly be Ryanair's most successful summer schedule ever," said chief executive Michael O'Leary. He added that Ryanair was continuing its policy of increasing competitive pressure on European airlines and their "rip-off" fares. This summer Ryanair will fly on 52 routes to 47 destinations around Europe.

webTitle: Theologian used web to lure boy

fields.headline: Theologian used web to lure boy
fields.trailText: An evangelical Christian lecturer who helped run his local church youth club was convicted yesterday of sexually assaulting a schoolboy he befriended through an internet gay chatroom.
fields.body:
An evangelical Christian lecturer who helped run his local church youth club was convicted yesterday of sexually assaulting a schoolboy he befriended through an internet gay chatroom.

Judge David Morris told Anthony Gray, 30, of Bicester, Oxfordshire, that it was inevitable that he would receive a lengthy custodial sentence.

He added: "I have come to the view you came to Cardiff with deceit in your heart and lust in your loins."

He remanded Gray in custody for reports and ordered him to register as a sex offender.

The jury heard how Gray, who studied theology at Exeter and Oxford universities, met the 14-year-old boy after logging on to Gay.com and they chatted online about 20 times before meeting in Cardiff.

Gray, now the father of a six-month-old daughter, was due to go to the city on a business meeting in April last year. The meeting was cancelled but he made the 200-mile round trip and met the boy at the city's central railway station. They went to a cinema and then booked into a hotel.

Gray, who denied the charges, said that in the hotel room they had only chatted about the boy's struggle with his sexuality. But the judge said it had been "pre-planned" and that he had "wreaked his sexual satisfaction on a young and vulnerable boy knowing full well he was under age".

Gray admitted he had told the schoolboy during their on-line chats that he was a 22-year-old openly gay man and said he wanted to advise the boy about his sexuality.

Gray, now a lecturer for the Universities and Colleges of Christian Fellowship, said he had started struggling with his sexuality five years ago after seeing images of gay pornography on a borrowed computer.

He described his home life as "happy and content" but found that he was excited by the gay pornography.

The court heard that he bought gay porn magazines and videos on trips to London and Oxford and hid them from his wife in the attic. When police raided the house after his arrest in August they found 33 gay videos, hundreds of magazine cuttings and 3,000 gay images of teenage boys downloaded on to his computer.

Prosecutor Greg Bull described Gray as a "Jekyll and Hyde" character who appeared to be a respectable citizen. "But he had deeper, darker motives for seeking out young boys," he said.

The court heard that the boy told of the meeting when, three months later, his parents questioned him about his internet phone bill. In evidence, the boy, who had been given the computer with a dedicated phone line to help with his homework, said he was "confused" because he thought he might be gay. "I confided in my friends but not my parents. I was trying to speak to people of my own age who would understand me. I gave [Gray] my telephone number."

After the hearing, the boy's mother said: "I would warn other parents to watch what their children are doing on the computer."

The case comes after seven men were jailed for their part in the Wonderland internet paedophile ring.

Michele Elliott, director of Kidscape, said recent cases showed the urgent need for restrictions on the internet.

fields.headline: BBC staff lambast Dyke
fields.trailText:
11.45am update: Women at the BBC are furious with Greg Dyke's comments that they should "pop down the pub" instead of going out on lunches, writes Jessica Hodgson.
8.30am: BBC staff to work to rule
fields.body:
Women at the BBC are furious with Greg Dyke's comments that they should "pop down the pub" instead of going out on expesnses-paid lunches.

A letter in this week's Ariel lambasts the director-general after his new policy on expenses stated BBC staff lunches should not exceed £6.

The letter, from a female producer in Specialist Factual, says: "Greg Dyke might be happy sitting in a strange pub in a strange place on his own for the evening.

"But it would be irresponsible and unfair, bordering on dangerous, to expect a young female researcher to do the same."

The letter continues: "such glib comments show extraordinary lack of awareness".

It argues also the new policy banning staff from booking cabs in advance is also dangerous.

"A researcher or AP on their own in an isolated or alien place after dark should never be asked to stand on the street alone to hail a cab."

The letter comes as BBC staff have adopted work to rule in protest at the new expenses rules.

webTitle: Casting news: Samantha Morton cast in Spielberg's new movie

fields.headline: Samantha Morton cast in Spielberg's new movie
fields.standfirst: Plus: Billy Bob Thornton finds love on death row; Hilary gets swanky in the Chambermaid; Ricky Martin a dead cert in movie debut; German stars sell their souls for Faust
fields.trailText: Plus: Billy Bob Thornton finds love on death row; Hilary gets swanky in the Chambermaid; Ricky Martin a dead cert in movie debut; German stars sell their souls for Faust
fields.body:
 British actress Samantha Morton has landed the role of Tom Cruise's love interest in the Steven Spielberg thriller Minority Report. Based on a Philip K Dick short story, the film stars Cruise as a detective forced to solve a crime that has not yet been committed. Morton, who reportedly beat out the likes of Cate Blanchett for the role, was Oscar-nominated last year for her role in Woody Allen's Sweet and Lowdown.

 Billy Bob Thornton and Wes Bentley are to play a father-son team of prison workers in Monster's Ball. Directed by Marc Foster, the gritty saga will star Thornton as a backwoods labourer from a racist family who falls for the black wife of an inmate on death row. Monster's Ball begins shooting in the spring.

 Last year's Oscar winner for Best Actress Hilary Swank has signed on to play the title role in The Chambermaid, to be directed by Brat Pack guru John Hughes in his first stint behind the camera since 1991's Curly Sue. The film sounds pure popcorny Hughes fare, with Swank playing a wrong-side-of-the-tracks Chicago domestic who falls bonnet over heels for an English aristocrat. What's the betting they're currently trying to secure Hugh Grant to play the aristo?

 Latino singer Ricky Martin looks set to make his film debut as a sexy revolutionary in The Assassination, a thriller based on the slaying of Dominican Republic dictator Rafael Trujilo. The film will also star Ed Harris and James Coburn. Ricky - fans will be pleased to note - will double up on his acting duties to sing the title song.

 Carrying us still further into bizarre casting territory comes the news that the blue-eyed trio of tennis star Boris Becker, racing star Michael Schumacher and model Claudia Schiffer are to cameo in a German version of the Faust story. Directed by Rainer Matsutani, the film will tell the tale of a lowly taxi driver who sells his soul to the devil.

webTitle: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner

fields.headline: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.trailText: Name game
fields.body:
Name game

Eighteen months ago we reported the fate of a reader, Joe Arkley, who entrusted his belongings to a removals company called Cargo Forwarding (UK). The goods never arrived and the company, which specialises in moving students overseas, went into liquidation before he could recover his losses. Soon afterwards he noticed a removals company called Cargo Forwarding (International) trading under the same logo from the same address with the same director. He was unable to claim against this new incarnation because the business was registered under a different company number at Companies House and therefore counted as a new firm.

Arkley will be interested to hear what's happened since, courtesy of an ex-employee of Cargo Forwarding International who is still waiting for his wages to be paid. "I gather that the depot in Manchester still contains cargo which I left there six months ago," says our source, who prefers to remain anonymous. He fears the firm may fold again, leaving customers out of pocket, then resurface under an adjusted name. "It's my understanding that the new incarnation is likely to be CFI Movers Ltd or CFI International Movers," he warns.

The trail starts at the London office where calls to Cargo Forwarding's provincial depots are diverted. No reply. Next stop the Imex Business Park in Manchester where customers' goods are allegedly languishing. A spokeswoman for the park is hesitant. "They're still here and will be as far as I know, but their status is not something I'd comment on."

Meadows International, an Edinburgh removals company, which allowed Cargo to include its (Meadows) number on its advertising literature provided Cargo shipped some of its customers goods in return, says it has received a number of complaints from worried customers. "I've been told they're restructuring," says the spokesman. "Some of our customers' stuff is in their warehouse and it's leaving people in a state of panic."

A search at Companies House reveals that the business began life in 1983 as Cargo Forwarding (UK) Ltd, which was compulsorily liquidated in 1998 after failing to file accounts and returns. The present incarnation, Cargo Forwarding International, had one of Cargo Forwarding UK's directors as its company secretary and second director, and is now two years overdue with its returns and accounts. Both its directors and the company secretary have resigned in the last three months, which means the business is in breach of company regulations.

Two new companies, CFI Movers Ltd and CFI International Movers Ltd, were incorporated last November with no registered directors or secretary, an omission which also breaches company regulations.

Behind Cargo's guises are brothers Anthony and Steven Bird, Steven being one of the ex-directors of Cargo Forwarding International. When Consumer surprises him on his mobile phone, he insists that the firm has been bought out and blames the chaos on a third party.

"The accounting isn't straight, but I was only director of marketing so I didn't realise what was going on," says Bird, who resigns as director two weeks after we speak. Nor, he says, did he realise that some goods had been holed up at the depots since August. CFI Movers Ltd has, he claims, taken on Cargo Forwarding's liability. He won't disclose the name of the new firm's directors but promises that one will give us a call.

Lo and behold we are rung by smooth-talking Tony Bird, who claims that he has stepped in to sort out the mess and is attempting to ship the trapped goods to their destinations. "I set up CFI to continue Cargo's trade and have taken on all its assets and liabilities, but I'm having second thoughts now because there are too many problems," he says. "If you publish this, I shall lose income and won't be able to move the goods." He insists that he is a director of CFI Movers, although his name is not registered. Asked about the long-lost Cargo Forwarding (UK) Ltd, of which he claims he was the "owner", he insists he "got rid of it" because he was divorcing his wife and says he has no recollection of the accounts being overdue or the liquidation being compulsory. "Cargo Forwarding UK and International were reputable operations - just ask the National Guild of Removers," he says.

We do and discover that Cargo's membership has been suspended due to a high number of complaints which were not resolved satisfactorily. Intriguingly, the guild had Tony Bird registered as director of Cargo Forwarding International, a post he never held.

Over to Cargo's local Trading Standards which declines to comment publicly. The Department of Trade and Industry says it is taking the matter "extremely seriously", and Companies House claims it is hamstrung by the fact that all the serving officers of Cargo Forwarding have resigned so there's no one it can talk to. "The Companies Act says it's illegal to trade without directors and a company secretary but it doesn't say what action we can take if they do," says a spokesman.

All this raises interesting questions about how such companies are allowed to get away with liquefying and resurrecting. Companies House claims that the fact that details of each company are available for public scrutiny is a safeguard, but that doesn't stop directors of failed firms resurrecting their business with new directors nominally in charge. The law can force a director to surrender his personal assets if he can be shown to be partially responsible for his company's insolvency, but it's the company liquidator who has to bring the action.

One small consolation comes in the form of new regulations planned for this spring which will allow certain consumer groups and trading standards authorities to take injunctions out to stop faltering companies in their tracks.

Storm in a teacup

Ever thought your office cuppa tasted like wet cardboard? No, it's not Monday morning blues souring your tastebuds. Research by the consumer rights website, www.consumer solicitors.co.uk, has found that tea manufacturers sell inferior teabags to businesses.

Tetley was quite candid about its double standards. "The blends and amounts used for the food service market are completely different to the ones you can buy in the shops," said a spokesman. "The normal Tetley bag will contain 3.125g of tea whereas the catering one-cup bags contain 2.5g. Therefore you will notice a marked difference in taste."

fields.headline: Fashion honours favourite bad boy
fields.standfirst:
Alexander McQueen named designer of the year
Special report: London Fashion Week 2001
fields.trailText: Alexander McQueen may be the self-styled bad boy of British fashion, but the industry can't seem to get enough of him. Last night it awarded McQueen the British Designer of the Year award at the Rover British Fashion Awards.
fields.body:
Alexander McQueen may be the self-styled bad boy of British fashion, but the industry can't seem to get enough of him. Last night it awarded McQueen the British Designer of the Year award at the Rover British Fashion Awards.

McQueen, who will leave his post at the House of Givenchy to concentrate on his own label, collected his award at the star-packed ceremony in Battersea Park. The Prince of Wales, Sir David Hare, Jodie Kidd and Joely Richardson were among the audience who watched McQueen beat off fellow designers Clements Ribeiro and Julien Macdonald.

McQueen's own show last season featured a padded cell as a stage set, with the models pounding desperately at the partitions separating them from the unnerved audience. Among the more elegant and commercial clothes were dresses made from feathers and mussel shells, with skull caps pulling their faces back into seemingly agonising contortions.

The show played with the accusations of madness frequently levelled at him by his detractors, accusations equalled by the compliments paid to his "genius" by fans.

McQueen, 31, recently sold a 51% stake in his company to the Gucci Group. This sale is said to be behind his future departure from Givenchy, which is owned by the rival fashion conglomerate, LVMH. McQueen's show on Thursday is the most anticipated event in London Fashion Week this season.

Despite the prestige of the award, it was never going to be a wholly celebratory affair. Hussein Chalayan, winner of the award for the past two years, went into liquidation last month - his accolade unable to keep him solvent.

webTitle: Napster offers billions to record companies

fields.headline: Napster offers billions to record companies
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: The song-swapping internet service Napster yesterday offered $1bn to the recording industry to settle the copyright infringement suit that threatens to shut it down.
fields.body:
The song-swapping internet service Napster yesterday offered $1bn to the recording industry to settle the copyright infringement suit that threatens to shut it down.

Under the proposal, Napster would pay $150m annually for five years to record companies Sony, Warner, BMG, EMI and Universal. An additional $50m would go to independent labels in each of those five years.

The offer comes a week after a US appeals court said the music industry would almost certainly win its suit against Napster, forcing it to shut its free song-swapping service down.

But by tapping into the popularity of that service, Napster believes it can generate hundreds of millions of dollars through monthly subscriptions. The subscription deal is expected to consist of a monthy membership fee of between $2.95 and $9.95.

It has tried to reach agreements with record companies before, but has done so only with BMG's parent, Bertelsmann. Thomas Middlehoff, head of Bertelsmann, said he believed Napster's new service could be ready by July.

Analysts said they doubted the rest of the recording industry would allow Napster and Bertelsmann to control the online distribution of their music. "Napster is basically trying to purchase the copyrights and resell them," said Susan Billheimer, an analyst with Zona Research. "The record companies have an interest in distributing their music themselves."

"I think it would take a small miracle to get all five labels to agree to this," said another analyst, PJ McNealy. Sony, for instance, produces and distributes music, movies and books. "To sit there and carve out the music piece to Napster doesn't seem to make much sense."

Universal played down Napster's offer as a rehash of previous promises that have gone unfulfilled.

"It is Napster's responsibility to come to the creative community with a legitimate business model and a system that protects our artists and copyrights. Nothing we have heard in the past and nothing we have heard today suggests they have yet been able to accomplish that task," the company said in a statement.

Napster CEO Hank Barry said it was crucial for all parties involved to reach an agreement "as fast as we can".

"We're saying this is something consumers really want. Let's do something to keep it going."

webTitle: Feature: Last year Maria Grachvogel put Posh Spice on the catwalk. What will she do this year?

fields.headline: Cutting edge
fields.standfirst:
Last year Maria Grachvogel's stunt was to put Posh Spice on the catwalk. What has she got up her sleeve for this year's London fashion week? Jess Cartner-Morley finds out

Special report: London Fashion Week 2001
fields.trailText: Last year Maria Grachvogel's stunt was to put Posh Spice on the catwalk. What has she got up her sleeve for this year's London fashion week? Jess Cartner-Morley finds out.
fields.body:
Her dresses have featured on more front pages than Alexander McQueen's or Stella McCartney's, although hers is hardly a household name. For the past two seasons, the British designer Maria Grachvogel has stolen the show at London Fashion Week. A year ago, Victoria Beckham caused a paparazzi frenzy when she appeared on the catwalk wearing Maria Grachvogel. Last autumn, it was Jodie Kidd in a £1m dress dripping with diamonds, also designed by Maria Grachvogel. On Friday, she will unveil her latest collection at this year's fashion week. So, should we hold the front page?

"They weren't gimmicks," sighs Grachvogel. There are just a few days to go until showtime, and the designer, who hasn't taken a day off since Christmas, is standing in her airy West End studio in a toile (a mock up of an outfit) trying out sleeve shapes. Indeed, she is an easy target for criticism - at last year's British fashion awards, Hussein Chalayan railed against the invasion of celebrities on to the catwalk. Much of the criticism stems from the fact that in London, an astute young designer who knows how to manipulate the media to gain exposure is regarded with suspicion. British fashion designers are supposed to grow pale and thin in as-yet-undiscovered parts of east London, spending every last penny on Cambodian rubber buttons and vintage kimono fabric; not, as Grachvogel has done, win awards for running a successful small business.

Grachvogel must have known that the Beckham catwalk stunt would garner publicity. "Of course I did. But, honestly, neither of us had any idea how much coverage there would be. The day after she did my show we talked on the phone and we were both, 'ohmigod, it's everywhere!' I mean, it was on the front page of the Bombay Times."

The picture made the New York Times and the Los Angeles Times, as well as newspapers in France, Germany and Singapore.

When the next fashion show rolled around, Grachvogel knew she "couldn't get another celebrity to model. That would just have been awful. But I had this great idea of dewdrops on a spiderweb, and I thought, if the dewdrops could be diamonds . . . so I asked Van Peterson." The diamond dress, which had its own team of security guards made the finale to her show and caused another media flurry.

With so many British fashion designers struggling to keep afloat, it would be churlish to turn noses up at such astute commercial sense. Grachvogel is well aware of the pitfalls. "It is very hard to make a fashion business work. The cost of doing a collection now - just of getting the samples made - is around £30,000. Then you've got the show itself which can cost anything from £30,000 to £50,000. And you've got to do that twice a year. You've got to sell a hell of a lot of clothes to make money."

None the less, conscious that "the last two shows were taken as a gimmick", Grachvogel is keen to "do something different, put all my energies into the clothes". This season, the starring role on the Grachvogel catwalk will go to a sub-col lection of around 10 couture gowns - "one-off, over the top, fantastical, glamorous." How much will they cost? "Expensive. These are money-no-object gowns".

The inspiration for the couture collection stems from her current personal project: designing and making the dress for her own wedding in May. But don't expect demure white frocks. The feather-strewn studio - "it looks a bit like an abbatoir in here" - is the aftermath of days spent making feather corsets, and there will be "amazing devoré and appliqué, all done by hand; gold lace appliquéd on to stretch velvet, and glossy garnet sequins on soft satin chiffon. Really glamorous gowns."

Glamorous gowns are what Grachvogel has always done best, but her own office wear is business-like - black polo neck with trousers and ankle boots, not a thigh slit or sequin in sight. An engagement ring is her only jewellery. But she combines a deeply sensible and practical nature with a romantic, fairytale imagination: not many 31-year-old women refer to dresses as "gowns", after all.

Grachvogel was "making stuff for people, if they paid me" by her early teens. At around 14, she got "really into how things were made. My needlework teacher told me that if you cut something on the bias you don't need darts. I hated making darts, so I started bias cutting." She worked on herself and her friends, taking measurements and making pattern blocks. "I still use the same basic shape. All designers have their own blocks, and they are the building blocks of your fit. My dresses are a very different fit from anyone else's. There are bias cut dresses, and there are bias cut dresses."

The daughter of a Polish father, who was an accountant, and an Irish mother, who was a housewife, Grachvogel grew up in the suburbs of north London "spending all my time on buses coming up to town". At 16, she knew she wanted to be a fashion designer. "Everyone said, you need to go to St Martins [Central St Martins College of Art and Design, London]. But you can't go there until you're 18 and that seemed like ages away. So I thought, I'm going to set up my own business."

Half embarrassed, half proud of her precociousness, Grachvogel recalls being interviewed after applying to take a stand at the prestigious London Fashion Week designers' exhibition. "I turned up for an interview, with my clothes in a suitcase. The woman must have thought I was completely bonkers but she was really nice. She would say: 'This is lovely, how much is it?' And I was just making up prices. She would ask me: 'What's going to happen when you take an order from a buyer, how will you produce it?' And I was just making it up as I went along. At the end she said: 'My advice to you is to go away and learn about running a fashion business.' So I did."

After college, Grachvogel needed to find some money with which to start her business. "I went into the City because it was well paid." At 17, she took a London stock exchange exam, and became the youngest person ever to pass it. "Which seemed funny, since all I wanted to be was a fashion designer." Grachvogel's first business, a collaboration with a friend and fellow designer, didn't work out. She wound up back in the City. "I needed money and needed to get out of that situation." Six months later, she was designing again.

It is 10 years since Grachvogel set up her own company, in January 1991. "The first collection was just nine dresses. I kept to eveningwear and glamour because people I had been making clothes for privately had said to me that they wanted something special, so I knew that even if I didn't do any wholesale I had clients who would order these dresses." For the first five years, growth was slow. "Glamour was just not big then, and grunge wasn't me and I knew it. You have to stay true to the essence of your style." In the latter half of the 90s, the style zeitgeist began slowly but surely to swing towards glamour and gowns. Grachvogel's time had come.

The collection that will be shown on Friday has been gruelling to produce. "I've reached a point of delirium now, working 15 hours every day for so long," she says. "I haven't worked this hard in years. But then, this is the most excited I've been about a collection in a long time. Because it's all about the clothes."

fields.headline: Wednesday's rumours
fields.standfirst: All today's rumours drop national secrets into a shopping bag and wait for the Russians to pick them up
fields.trailText: All today's papers report Kanu's agent claiming that if the Nigerian doesn't play against Lyon tonight, he will leave Arsenal. "If Kanu doesn't play then the relationship is over," Dutchman Frank Seedoc is quoted as saying, "It is no threat because there is no threat in the truth."
fields.body:
All today's papers report Kanu's agent claiming that if the Nigerian doesn't play against Lyon tonight, he will leave Arsenal. "If Kanu doesn't play then the relationship is over," Dutchman Frank Seedoc is quoted as saying, "It is no threat because there is no threat in the truth."

These remarks come after constant reports of unhappiness amongst Arsenal's strikers over Arsene Wenger's constant squad rotation. However, Planet Football has Seedoc backtracking on his non-threat somewhat, saying: "I certainly never gave Arsenal any kind of ultimatum." Kanu is not expected to start against Lyon this evening.

Italian sports daily Corriere Dello Sport claims that Internazionale have their eyes on both Emile Heskey and Michael Owen as potential summer recruits. The free-spending Serie A giants will also be looking for a new coach in the summer, but what hope they have of signing Liverpool's star assets is a moot point.

Ipswich have signed Celtic striker Mark Burchill on a three-month loan with a view to a permanent deal, according to the Daily Express. Burchill has already had a similar spell at Birmingham this season, but failed to agree terms with the First Division side.

Patrick Kluivert has threatened to leave Barcelona, citing differences between himself and coach Lorenzo Serra Ferrer. "There is more than one problem between us," the striker said. "I have to renegotiate my contract and it's very important to know who will be the coach. I think it is a very normal thing and I am not the only one involved." Kluivert had an open row with Ferrer after Barca's recent 4-0 league defeat by Racing Santander.

webTitle: In brief: Star Wars Part Two given a name

fields.headline: Star Wars Part Two given a name
fields.standfirst: Plus: Captain Correlli's Mandolin release date pushed back to August
fields.trailText: Plus: Captain Correlli's Mandolin release date pushed back to August
fields.body:
 After last year's blaze of rumour, gossip and hearsay surrounding the casting of George Lucas's next Star Wars instalment, attention has now swung to the small matter of what the thing will actually be called. Now we have the answer perhaps. According to movie website Aint it Cool News, Star Wars Episode Two will be titled (drum roll, please) "The Shadow Falls". This, however, follows a report in an Australian paper last August that had it pegged, less snappily, as "The Rise of the Empire" - a rumour subsequently shot down as being too similar to 1980's The Empire Strikes Back.

 The release of the romantic blockbuster Captain Correlli's Mandolin has been bumped back from its scheduled slot in April because of a slow postproduction process. Insider reports suggest that the film, based on the bestseller by Louis de Bernieres and starring Nic Cage and Penelope Cruz is experiencing problems at the editing stage. Viewers will now have to wait until August at the earliest to see the result.

fields.body:
Flamboyant designer Alexander McQueen will tonight present his eagerly awaited new collection at London Fashion Week after being named British Designer of the Year for the third time.

McQueen won the accolade at the star-studded British Fashion Awards ceremony last night.

In January, his couture collection for Givenchy was closed to the press at the last minute, so the appetite for his design among the fashion industry will be greater than ever.

fields.headline: Government to review communications body
fields.trailText: 11am: COI Communications, the government communications agency, is to undergo a root-and-branch review, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
COI Communications, the agency responsible for the government's massive communications operation, is to undergo a root-and-branch review that could lead to privatisation.

Cabinet office minister Ian McCartney has said a review will begin "as soon as possible" and will be completed early next year.

A steering group will be set up to conduct the review in cooperation with the cabinet office and COI bosses.

"The standard options are continued agency status, privatisation, abolition, merger, contracting out and market testing," said Mr McCartney.

"Each option will be considered on its merits and the preferred option will be the one that offers best value for money."

The last major review of the COI was conducted in 1996/7, when the Conservative government raised the issue of privatisation.

However, the Labour government halted plans to privatise semi-independent government bodies when it came into power.

The review will once again raise the question of whether the government needs its own communications body.

There have been suggestions in the past that it would be more cost effective to employ a private sector company to carry out the work.

Separately, COI Communications has confirmed plans to put more than £100m worth of advertising business up for grabs in a review expected to kick off once a general election date has been announced.

The timing means the review would take place during a lull in government advertising.

The government is not allowed to advertise between the time it calls an election and polling day.

The review will affect many of London's biggest advertising agencies.

The government's advertising agency roster includes Abbott Mead Vickers BBDO, TBWA/London, St Luke's, Euro RSCG Wnek Gosper, BMP DDB, Saatchi & Saatchi and M&C Saatchi, among others.

fields.headline: Survivors torpedo Ford's sub movie
fields.trailText: A forthcoming film about a real-life accident on a Soviet nuclear ballistic submarine has been attacked by survivors of the incident as distorted and offering a stereotyped version of events
fields.body:
Still weeks away from filming, a fact-based blockbuster starring Harrison Ford and Liam Neeson is already fighting criticism from the true-life survivors of the crisis it documents. Directed by Kathryn Bigelow, K19: The Widowmaker will tell the tale of a fraught period in 1961 when the first Soviet nuclear ballistic submarine suffered a reactor malfunction on its maiden voyage. But the remnants of the K19 crew are already taking issue with what they claim is a distorted and stereotyped account of their experiences.

K19: The Widowmaker is based on the memoirs of the submarine's late captain, Nikolai Zateyev, played in the film by Ford. In December Ford and the film's makers met with the surviving crew members and handed them a copy of the script. They were less than happy with what they saw, charging that Hollywood has warped their story and fallen back on the usual Russian stereotypes. "It portrays our crew as a bunch of stupid, disrespectful, eternally drunk Soviet sailors who played cards as the alarms were sounding," K19 survivor Yury Mukhin told Variety.

Reporting the controversy, the independent Russian TV network NTV claimed that: "In the script one comes across the words 'vodka' and 'drink' almost more often than 'sea' and 'submarine'. When the survivors saw the translation they decided to do all they could to stop this film from seeing the light of day." They are now attempting legal manoeuvres to halt production on the film until the script is rewritten.

The saga is the latest in a line of instances where Hollywood has been at odds with the survivors of true-life incidents. Last year U-571 came under fire for Americanising a mission taken by British soldiers in world war two, while the upcoming Mel Gibson movie We Were Soldiers Once and Young, which documents America's first clash with the Viet Cong, is already drawing criticism from veterans of the Vietnam War.

In the meantime the makers of K19 are pressing on with their production schedule. "K19 is a riveting story of intense drama and powerful real-life challenges," said Tim Kelly, president of National Geographic Television, which is co-producing the film. "We will bring all the National Geographic Society's resources to bear to ensure that K19 is authentic and accurate."

fields.headline: Violent times
fields.standfirst: The face of Football Italia on the rising levels of violence sweeping the game in Italy
fields.trailText: The face of Football Italia on the rising levels of violence sweeping the game in Italy.
fields.body:
Last Saturday afternoon at the Stadio Olimpico in Rome, a group of officials were standing around a pool of blood, discussing who should clear it up. The blood was almost certainly from one of six Liverpool fans stabbed two days before, but the various officials present hadn't yet agreed on whose responsibility it might be.

Talk about metaphorical. Right now, Italy is scratching its collective head over a wave of football violence, and there's similar lack of response on a national level. Everyone's sure it's a problem. No-one's sure who should tackle it.

This weekend's round of Serie A matches brought fresh horror: during Atalanta v Vicenza, a policeman in Bergamo lost a finger after what appeared to be a flare exploded in his hand. Vicenza fans had hurled tens of these colourful items towards the pitch - this one though was booby trapped with handmade explosive, and went off as soon as it was touched. Worryingly, it had been aimed at the players.

Like most countries, Italy has had a problem with football violence since the 70s, when a wave of hooliganism swept across Europe from Britain. Crossing into Italy, though, the phenomenon took on a new political dimension: the 70s here after all were a decade of intensely polarised politics with Red Brigades on one side, neo-fascist terrorists on the other and all manner of factions in between.

Hooliganism was simply absorbed into this context. Thus, the new band of AC Milan supporters fans took the name Brigata Rosso-Nera in honour of the Red Brigade. To the south and a long way to the right, meanwhile, Lazio's supporters formed the now infamous Irriducibile, amid a heady mix of fascist ideology and nostalgia for Il Duce.

Three decades on, some believe it's still politics behind the violence. One noted sociologist even argues incidents are now on the rise because of the forthcoming April elections - that left and right are simply warming up across the stadiums of Serie A.

Frankly, this theory is a bit daft. While Mussolini's portrait still hangs on the walls at the Irriducibile's headquarters, it's now another generation of supporters that's causing problems - and since they're largely all right-wing these days, the squabbles between them are anything but ideological.

So here's another view: Violence isn't on the increase here, it's just getting more attention from a media that's caught the scent of footballing scandals.

What's causing it is a mixture of alienation and impunity. Alienation, because in a sport of multi-million pound contracts and pay-TV, the fans don't count too much anymore, and this is their way of not going quietly.

Impunity, because they get away with it. Hard-core supporters in Italy inhabit the areas behind the goals - the "curvas" - and packed in here in their thousands, they're safe from the police and free to roll a joint or lob a flare at the opposition as the fancy takes them.

"We don't go into the curvas because it's too dangerous," confirms a police inspector with years of stadium experience. "Roma's curva sud contains 20,000 supporters: there's no passageways, no route through them. To go in we'd need the same number of police as there are fans. Otherwise they'd strip us of our guns, our shields, everything."

Thus, throw a firework or home-made bomb at someone in the street, and you'd stand a chance of doing time. Do the same thing in a stadium, and they can't touch you for it - little wonder that the fans have grown increasingly daring.

Now, this week the thrower of the Bergamo booby-trapped flare was actually arrested within hours of the incident - he'd been identified via the stadiums' security cameras. Score one for the good guys! However, here's some more bad news: the courts are unlikely to do anything meaningful with him.

In 1998 amidst "rising levels" of violence, the Italian home minister drew up a new bill containing serious deterrents (like actual jail sentences) for offending supporters. Three years on, that bill is still stuck in parliament - and with a change of government due in two months time it's unlikely to emerge any time soon.

So while the Italian police can identify, our police inspector tells us, "every supporter in every major ground", they often don't bother. And even though every Sunday no less than 110,000 Italian police draw match duty, the Curvas are still no man's lands. Until there's a real desire from all parties to confront the issue here, that's the way it'll stay. As ever, don't hold your breath.

webTitle: TV bosses censor Celebrity Big Brother

fields.headline: TV bosses censor Celebrity Big Brother
fields.trailText: 8.30am: BBC and C4 chiefs have decided not to screen live uncut footage of Celebrity Big Brother online, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
The BBC and Channel 4 are censoring Celebrity Big Brother, the seven-day version of last summer's warts-and-all TV and internet sensation.

Bosses at the TV stations have taken the decision not to screen live uncut 24-hour footage of the housemates via the website, ComicRelief.com.

The live 24-hour coverage was what made Big Brother such a phenomenon last year.

Millions of office workers addicted to the show abandoned work and logged on.

But in the new version, internet viewers will be restricted to selected archived footage, which will probably amount to anodyne footage of celebrities eating dinner, washing up and amiably chatting.

The decision was taken in order to appease the 10 celebrities, who will be locked in the house for one week in March.

Insiders say the celebrities would never have agreed to appear on the show if there was live coverage, because it could have damaged their public image.

"They certainly wouldn't have gone on if there were cameras in the loos or cameras catching every detail of their behaviour, like the show did last year when Mel was caught plucking her pubic hair in the garden," said one source.

So far there are no confirmed celebrities for the show but those tipped include Mel B, Anthea Turner, Ruby Wax, Frank Skinner and Richard Blackwood.

Meanwhile, work has now started on the website for Big Brother 2 following the reappointment of Victoria Real to develop and maintain the site.

Despite being 50% by Endemol, Victoria Real was subject to a pitch process against e4.com developer KPE Europe.

According to a spokesman from Victoria Real, this year's website will be "bigger and better than before" with more streaming, chat rooms and online voting.
