webTitle: Oftel chief hits out at BBC

fields.headline: Oftel chief hits out at BBC
fields.trailText: 10.30am: Telecoms regulator David Edmonds has called on the government to impose external regulation on the BBC, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Telecoms regulator David Edmonds has called on the government to impose external regulation on the BBC.

He has also hit out at a perceived arrogance at the highest level of the BBC saying the board of governors must wake up to the changing world and stop treating the BBC as a special case.

The head of Oftel said the BBC should be "more susceptible to the government in the future" and should have paid closer attention to last year's communications white paper.

"The need to ensure consistency and the need to treat people on a far more equitable basis would have been better demonstrated had the government proposed the BBC be more susceptible to the government in the future," Mr Edmonds said at last night's Royal Television Society dinner.

Senior figures within the broadcasting industry will be buoyed by the senior regulator's hints that the BBC should be brought under the wing of the Ofcom watchdog unveiled in the white paper.

The BBC was not threatened with independent regulation in the white paper.

However, Mr Edmonds warned the corporation it must stop treating itself as a unique and special case in the UK media.

"My own view is that the BBC is missing an opportunity.

"If I were a governor I would have been asking myself how I could use this paper to create a solid base for the future rather than saying 'this does not apply to me'," he said.

Mr Edmonds went on to urge the broadcast industry to embrace the Ofcom watchdog.

This body will combine Oftel, the Independent Television Commission and other regulators including the Broadcasting Standards Commission and the Radio Authority.

"My hope is the broadcast industry puts to one side some of the anxieties it may have and shares in the development and evolution of the organisation," he added.

fields.headline: The defiant one dies, but justice lives on in celluloid
fields.standfirst: The movies of Stanley Kramer won 15 Oscars and woke up Hollywood
fields.trailText: The director known as "Hollywood's conscience", because of his interest in social themes, has died. Stanley Kramer, who made some of the most highly regarded films in the history of cinema, was responsible for 15 Oscar-winning movies.
fields.body:
The director known as "Hollywood's conscience", because of his interest in social themes, has died. Stanley Kramer, who made some of the most highly regarded films in the history of cinema, was responsible for 15 Oscar-winning movies, including High Noon, The Caine Mutiny, Guess Who's Coming to Dinner, The Wild One and Judgment at Nuremberg.

Kramer, 87, died of pneumonia at hospital in Woodland Hills on Monday night. He had suffered from diabetes and had been in hospital for several months.

The producer-director was best-known for bucking the prevailing trends in Hollywood by tackling large social themes such as racism and fascism. "He never thought he was a message film-maker; just a man who believed very strongly in social conscience issues," said Karen Sharpe Kramer, his wife of 35 years.

"What epitomised Stanley Kramer as a man and a father and as a film-maker was that line from Judgment at Nuremberg which is: 'Let it be known this is what we stand for: truth, justice and the value of a single human being'," she said.

Born in New York, Kramer was one of the early independent film-makers operating in the 1940s and 1950s, and made a series of films that won him critical acclaim but made little money. His breakthrough came with The Caine Mutiny in 1954, in which Humphrey Bogart starred as the disturbed Captain Queeg.

Possibly his best-known film on a racial theme was Guess Who's Coming to Dinner, starring Sidney Poitier, Spencer Tracy and Katherine Hepburn.

Kramer, who gave Marlon Brando his debut and made a star of Kirk Douglas, always denied having a "message", but said: "I do have provocations, thoughts, doubts, challenges and questions to offer."

"Kramer was a guy who fought some hard battles," said Charles Champlin, the former arts editor of the Los Angeles Times, yesterday. "He took on social issues when it was not popular to do so in Hollywood."

His 35 films won 15 Oscars and were nominated in a further 70 categories. Although he never won an Oscar himself, he received the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences' Irving G Thalberg award in 1961, the industry's highest award.

Kramer's admirers spanned the generations. "He was a serious director," Gregory Peck, who starred in On The Beach, once said. "He kept trying. Sometimes he failed, but now and then he hit and he made a difference." Director Steven Spielberg called him one of the "great film-makers ... for the impact he has made on the conscience of the world."

Criticised by some for being sanctimonious in his tone, his career faded in the 70s and his last movie, The Runner Stumbles, made in 1979, was a flop.

Kramer, a father of four, wrote in his 1997 autobiography: "I've enjoyed a good career in the movie industry yet not as good as my ambitions led me to hope. My pictures were never, ever good enough to approach the dream"

Kramer's best

Director and producer

Guess Who's Coming to Dinner (1967)

Ship of Fools (1965)

It's a Mad Mad Mad Mad World (1963)

Judgment at Nuremberg (1961)

Inherit the Wind (1960)

On the Beach (1959)

The Defiant Ones (1958)

The Pride and the Passion (1957)

Not as a Stranger (1955)

Producer

The Caine Mutiny (1954)

The Wild One (1954)

High Noon (1952) (uncredited)

Death of a Salesman (1951)

The Moon and Sixpence (1942) (associate)

webTitle: Feature: Is our command of foreign languages the worst in Europe? Guardian writers find out.

fields.headline: Can you say that in English?
fields.standfirst:
Parlez-vous francais? Sprechen Sie Deutsch? No? Well, you're not alone. A new report says our command of foreign languages is the worst in Europe. Two-thirds of us have absolutely no knowledge of any language other than English. But can we really be that bad? To find out, six Guardian writers, each with a smattering of a European language, made a few calls


Talk about it
fields.trailText: Parlez-vous francais? Sprechen Sie Deutsch? No? Well, you're not alone. A new report says our command of foreign languages is the worst in Europe. Two-thirds of us have absolutely no knowledge of any language other than English. But can we really be that bad? To find out, six Guardian writers, each with a smattering of a European language, made a few calls.
fields.body:
The British Council

We call, in Spanish, to find out if they have any placements for Spanish speakers.

G: Buenas tardes. Me puede decir si hay trabajo para españoles?

British Council: (Takes a deep breath, then in a sarcastic and moody voice) INGLAIS. (Pause.) I only speak ENGLISH.

G: Se puede hablar con alguien que habla español? (Can I speak to someone who speaks Spanish?)

BC: (As if to a village idiot) This is the BRITISH COUNCIL. INGLAIS. INGLAIS. INGLAIS. This is English-speaking only.

G: Hay alguien que habla español?

BC: (In Spanish accent, shouting) No!

G: Como?

BC: INGLAIS, INGLAIS, INGLAIS, only INGLAIS. Bye bye.

Madame Tussaud's

We call, in French, and ask to speak to Madame Tussaud. Within moments, a Frenchwoman is at hand. In perfect French, she explains that the madame is dead, and has been for quite some time, but would we like to book some tickets for the museum?

The Millennium Stadium, Cardiff

We ring, in Welsh, to ask about tickets for the FA Cup final in May. A woman answers.

G: Esgusodwch fi, Stadiwm y Mileniwm?

Millennium Stadium: Yes?

G: Oes yna rhywun sydd yn siarad Cymraeg os gwelwch yn dda? (Is there any body who speaks Welsh please?)

MS: Pardon?

G: 'Alla' i siarad rhywun sydd yn siarad Cymraeg os gwelwch yn dda? (Can I talk to someone who speaks Welsh, please?)

MS: I'm sorry, I don't speak Welsh.

G: Oes yna rhywun sydd yn? (Is there anybody there who does?)

MS: I'm afraid I don't speak Welsh, sir.

The Football Association, London

We call, in Swedish, and ask for Sven Goran Eriksson, the new England manager.

Guardian: God eftermiddag, kan jag tala med Sven Goran Eriksson?

FA: Sorry?

G: Jag skulle vilja tala med Sven Goran Eriksson.

FA: One moment. (The call is put through to a voicemail. We try again.)

G: Jag skulle vilja tala med Sven Goran Eriksson.

FA: One moment. (The call is transferred to a human being, female, who seems very helpful, but does not speak or recognise Swedish.)

Buckingham Palace

The Guardian calls, in German, to ask about opening times.

G: Könnten Sie mir Ihre Offnungszeiten sagen?

BP: Sorry, we speak English.

G: Sprechen Sie Deutsch?

BP: We speak English.

G: Spricht jemand dort Deutsch? (Does anyone there speak German?)

BP: We speak English.

G: Wird niemand mir helfen? (Will no one help me?)

BP: (Very irritated) WE SPEAK ENGLISH.

G: Danke schön, wiederhören.

Arsenal

We call to book some tickets for today's match between Arsenal and Olympique Lynonnaise.

G: Est-ce qu'il y a quelqu'un qui parle francais?

Arsenal: Sorry, I don't speak French.

G: Est-ce qu'il y a quelqu'un qui parle francais?

A: Sorry, I don't speak French.

(This goes on for some time.)

A: (Finally) Which match?

(We ask for tickets for the match between Arsenal and Lyon.)

A: Versus who?

G: Arsenal.

A: Which match?

G: Lyon.

A: Lyon? No tickets.

G: Excusez-moi, je ne comprends pas.

A: No tickets.

G: Excusez-moi, je ne comprends pas.

A: (Shouting) NO TICKETS. NO. TICKETS.

Imperial War Museum

We ring, in German, to ask what exhibitions are showing.

G: Entschuldigen Sie bitte, könnten Sie mir etwas sagen über Ihre Ausstellung bitte?

IWM: Sorry.

G: Sprechen Sie Deutsch?

IWM: Nein, ein Moment bitte.

(The call is transferred to public relations.)

G: Entschuldigen Sie bitte, konnten Sie mir etwas sagen über Ihre Ausstellung bitte. (Excuse me, can you tell me something about your exhibition, please?)

IWM: Do you speak English?

G: Nein, sprechen Sie kein Deutsch?

IWM: Ja, aber nur ein bisschen. (Yes, but just a little bit.) Two secs. Wie sagt man Ausstellung in Englisch? (What is Ausstellung in English?)

G: Ich weiss nicht. Ich spreche kein Englisch.

IWM: (She returns leafing through what sounds like a dictionary and asks me to repeat the word.) Oh, exhibition. Wir haben eine von der Kunst über "symbols und stereotypes" und eine Ausstellung von der . . . err . . . Holocaust.

G: Holocaust . . . Danke schön.

IWM: ( Slightly embarrassed ) Entschuldigen Sie, mein Deutsch ist sehr schlecht. (Sorry, my German is very bad.)

The London Eye

We call in Spanish to ask if 30 people can be safely accommodated in one capsule, and if so, if we may buy 30 tickets.

G: Buenas tardes. Caber 30 personas en un pod del London Eye?

London Eye: Hello?

G: Cuanto es para 30 personas para el London Eye?

LE: (Sarcastic) I'm sorry I can't understand you.

G: Quiero comprar 30 billetes para el London Eye por favor.

LE: (Slightly more sarcastic) I'm not Spanish. I don't understand you.

G: Son 30 billetes, por favor.

LE: (In a huff now) Sorry. I can't UNDERSTAND you.

G: Se vende billetes para el London Eye?

LE: Oh, tickets on National Express?

(After much more of this, the call is transferred to Yusef, an Iraqi, who says he has South American friends. He helps us book tickets.)

European Parliament

We call its London offices, in German, to ask for a copy of the Maastricht treaty.

G: Guten Tag, ich möchte eine Kopie des Maastricht Vertrag bitte.

European Parliament: (The person on the phone clearly speaks better German than the Guardian). Hatten Sie lieber Englisch sprechen? (Wouldn't you rather speak in English?)

G: (Feeling rumbled) Nein, ich bin Deutsch.

EP: (In flawless German) Aber ich bin im Augenblick der einzige ins Buro. (It's just that I'm the only person in the office at the moment.) Geben Sie mir Ihre Addresse und ich werde es Ihnen schicken. (Give me your address and I'll send it to you.)

Millennium Dome

We call the Millennium Dome, in French, to ask if it's still possible to buy it.

G: Allo. Je voudrais acheter le Millennium Dome.

MD: No, it's closed now, it's ferme.

G: Je voudrais acheter le Millennium Dome.

MD: It's not possible now. On December 31, it closed. It ferme-ed. To everyone.

G: Ce n'est pas a vendre? (It's not for sale?)

MD: Um, vendre, vendre - oh! (excited yelp) You want to BUY some pieces from the Dome? Yes? From inside the Dome? Auctions? Yes?

Our caller attempts to speak English - "I would verrrry mush like to buy zee dome". This has the perverse effect of inciting the operator to further adventures in French. Cautious, but perfect, she gives us the telephone number for English Partnership before ringing off with a chirpy, de rien (no problem).

Advertising Standards Authority

We call to complain about the portrayal of Italians in the English press.

G: Buona sera. Volevo fare un reclamo.

ASA: Em, sorry, do you speak English?

G: Non mi piace la stampa inglese. Ogni giorno scrivono nuove bugie sull' Italia. (I do not like the English press. Every day they write new lies about Italy.)

ASA: I'm sorry but I don't understand a word. Perhaps if you . . .

G: Solo stereotipi. Mi da fastidio. (Only stereotypes. It annoys me.)

ASA: Please, if you could repeat that in English I'd be very grateful.

G: Non rompermi i coglioni. Dammi una riposta. (Don't break my balls. Give me an answer.)

ASA: Hopeless. If you could hold on for a moment, sir. (Shouts to colleagues: "Does anyone here speak Italian?") Thank you for waiting sir but I'm afraid . . .

G: Si, avrai paura. Voglio parlare con tuo capo. (Yes, you will be afraid. I want to talk to your boss.)

ASA: I'm afraid you must call tomorrow.

Les Miserables

We ring up, in French, for some tickets.

G: Est-ce que vous avez des places pour le 28 fevrier?

M: (Long pause) Speak English.

G: Est-ce qu'il y a quelqu'un qui parle francais?

M: (He echoes me verbatim) Est-ce qu'il y a quelqu'un qui parle francais?

G: Les Miserables?

M: Les Miserables. (The ticket operator is inexplicably repeating everything we say. We ask again if we can buy tickets for February 28.)

M: February 18? Hang on. Right, February 28? Certainly.

G: Il y a encore des places? (Are there seats still available?)

M: The prices? Yes, they go from £37.50, to £32.50.

G: Il y a encore des places?

M: This is the 28 of February at 7.30pm. (I say I better call back later and book them with a French speaker.)

M: (Outburst of laughter) Right. Whatever.

Guardian foreign desk

We call posing as a Spanish journalist and ask, in Spanish, if anyone on the desk can speak Spanish.

Foreign desk: Um, hello?

G: Buenas tardes. Me escucha?

FD: (Groaning) Oh God, um, er. (Long pause. The call is passed to someone else.)

FD: Hola.

G: Buenas tardes.

FD: Scusi? (Italian for "get out of my way".)

The writer explains she has a story. The person on the foreign desk mumbles something which sounds like "Guardian forever". The writer says she has a story about corruption in the Spanish government.

FD: En España?

G: Si, en el gobierno español.

FD: Um, si? (laughing nervously)

The writer asks why he is laughing.

FD: Sorry. Um, parlez vous francais?

G: No entiendo, perdón.

FD: OK, um, English?

The writer, in Spanish, says she will take the story elsewhere.

FD: No, no, no. (Eventually, the man gives us a number for the Spanish correspondent, but he gives it in Italian. The writer tells him he's speaking Italian. "I know," he says.)

Interviews by Emma Brockes, Rory Carroll, Angelique Chrisafis, Caroline Furneaux, Tomos Owen and Gary Younge

G: Könnten Sie mir Ihre Offnungszeiten sagen? BP: Sorry, we speak English. G: Sprechen Sie Deutsch? BP: We speak English. G: Spricht jemand dort Deutsch? (Does anyone there speak German?) BP: We speak English. G: Wird niemand mir helfen? (Will no one help me?) BP: (Very irritated) WE SPEAK ENGLISH. G: Danke schön, wiederhören. Arsenal We call to book some tickets for today's match between Arsenal and Olympique Lynonnaise. G: Est-ce qu'il y a quelqu'un qui parle francais? Arsenal: Sorry, I don't speak French. G: Est-ce qu'il y a quelqu'un qui parle francais? A: Sorry, I don't speak French. (This goes on for some time.) A: (Finally) Which match? (We ask for tickets for the match between Arsenal and Lyon.) A: Versus who? G: Arsenal. A: Which match? G: Lyon. A: Lyon? No tickets. G: Excusez-moi, je ne comprends pas. A: No tickets. G: Excusez-moi, je ne comprends pas. A: (Shouting) NO TICKETS. NO. TICKETS. Imperial War Museum We ring, in German, to ask what exhibitions are showing. G: Entschuldigen Sie bitte, könnten Sie mir etwas sagen über Ihre Ausstellung bitte? IWM: Sorry. G: Sprechen Sie Deutsch? IWM: Nein, ein Moment bitte. (The call is transferred to public relations.) G: Entschuldigen Sie bitte, konnten Sie mir etwas sagen über Ihre Ausstellung bitte. (Excuse me, can you tell me something about your exhibition, please?) IWM: Do you speak English? G: Nein, sprechen Sie kein Deutsch? IWM: Ja, aber nur ein bisschen. (Yes, but just a little bit.) Two secs. Wie sagt man Ausstellung in Englisch? (What is Ausstellung in English?) G: Ich weiss nicht. Ich spreche kein Englisch. IWM: (She returns leafing through what sounds like a dictionary and asks me to repeat the word.) Oh, exhibition. Wir haben eine von der Kunst über "symbols und stereotypes" und eine Ausstellung von der . . . err . . . Holocaust. G: Holocaust . . . Danke schön. IWM: ( Slightly embarrassed ) Entschuldigen Sie, mein Deutsch ist sehr schlecht. (Sorry, my German is very bad.) LE: (Slightly more sarcastic) I'm not Spanish. I don't understand you. G: Son 30 billetes, por favor. LE: (In a huff now) Sorry. I can't UNDERSTAND you. G: Se vende billetes para el London Eye? G: Je voudrais acheter le Millennium Dome. MD: It's not possible now. On December 31, it closed. It ferme-ed. To everyone. G: Ce n'est pas a vendre? (It's not for sale?) MD: Um, vendre, vendre - oh! (excited yelp) You want to BUY some pieces from the Dome? Yes? From inside the Dome? Auctions? Yes? Our caller attempts to speak English - "I would verrrry mush like to buy zee dome". This has the perverse effect of inciting the operator to further adventures in French. Cautious, but perfect, she gives us the telephone number for English Partnership before ringing off with a chirpy, de rien (no problem). Advertising Standards Authority We call to complain about the portrayal of Italians in the English press. G: Buona sera. Volevo fare un reclamo. ASA: Em, sorry, do you speak English? G: Non mi piace la stampa inglese. Ogni giorno scrivono nuove bugie sull' Italia. (I do not like the English press. Every day they write new lies about Italy.) ASA: I'm sorry but I don't understand a word. Perhaps if you . . . G: Solo stereotipi. Mi da fastidio. (Only stereotypes. It annoys me.) ASA: Please, if you could repeat that in English I'd be very grateful. G: Non rompermi i coglioni. Dammi una riposta. (Don't break my balls. Give me an answer.) ASA: Hopeless. G: Est-ce que vous avez des places pour le 28 fevrier? M: (Long pause) Speak English. G: Est-ce qu'il y a quelqu'un qui parle francais? M: (He echoes me verbatim) Est-ce qu'il y a quelqu'un qui parle francais? G: Les Miserables? M: Les Miserables. (The ticket operator is inexplicably repeating everything we say. We ask again if we can buy tickets for February 28.) M: February 18? Hang on. Right, February 28? Certainly. G: Il y a encore des places? (Are there seats still available?) M: The prices? Yes, they go from £37.50, to £32.50. G: Il y a encore des places? M: This is the 28 of February at 7.30pm. (I say I better call back later and book them with a French speaker.) M: (Outburst of laughter) Right. Whatever. Guardian foreign desk We call posing as a Spanish journalist and ask, in Spanish, if anyone on the desk can speak Spanish. Foreign desk: Um, hello? G: Buenas tardes. Me escucha? FD: (Groaning) Oh God, um, er. (Long pause. The call is passed to someone else.) FD: Hola. G: Buenas tardes. FD: Scusi? (Italian for "get out of my way".) FD: En España? G: Si, en el gobierno español. FD: Um, si? (laughing nervously) The writer asks why he is laughing. FD: Sorry. Um, parlez vous francais? G: No entiendo, perdón. FD: OK, um, English? The writer, in Spanish, says she will take the story elsewhere. FD: No, no, no. (Eventually, the man gives us a number for the Spanish correspondent, but he gives it in Italian. The writer tells him he's speaking Italian. "I know," he says.) Interviews by Emma Brockes, Rory Carroll, Angelique Chrisafis, Caroline Furneaux, Tomos Owen and Gary Younge

webTitle: Slings and arrows from NRA supporters

fields.headline: Slings and arrows from NRA supporters
fields.standfirst: Duncan Campbell responds to the barrage of criticism he received after his recent dispatch on Charlton Heston and gun control
fields.trailText: Duncan Campbell responds to the barrage of criticism he received after his recent dispatch on Charlton Heston and gun control.
fields.body:
A couple of weeks ago in this spot I wrote a fairly gentle piece about Charlton Heston and his work with the National Rifle Association.

This led to a flow of emails from all over the United States from supporters of the NRA.

For a moment I was amazed that the Guardian Unlimited website reached such a wide constituency but on closer inspection of the emails it became clear that one or two NRA members had spotted the piece and emailed it to friends with an implicit suggestion that they make their views felt.

The views were lively: "fascist liberal" and "socialist smut" were among the kinder comments from people who suggested that "Brits like you sicken me". There was also a long list of arguments against gun control.

Now there are few more sterile arguments in the US that those for and against gun control. People on each side have generally unshakeable views.

But two things were interesting in the responses: firstly, that people would bother to send such vitriolic messages to someone they have never heard of writing in a publication they have never heard of in a country they have no desire to visit.

The thought occurs that if they get that livid about something so remote, what happens when something really serious happens - like someone cutting in front of them on the freeway or jumping the queue at the supermarket? (One of the most vituperative emails came from someone who, touchingly, was genteel enough to call me an 'a--hole' without spelling it out.)

Perhaps the answer lies in the statistics. The latest figures show that 32,436 people died in the US from firearms in one year, of which 13,252 were homicides.

Children die accidentally through firearms at the rate of nearly one a day and it is estimated that guns will be the leading cause of gun death for children, overtaking car accidents, within five years. Children in the US are currently 12 times more likely to die from firearms than in any other similar industrialised country.

Now the old argument is that many who die are either victims of gang violence or are shot while carrying out crimes. The figures indicate that of 9,390 homicides by handgun only 176 were classified by police as justifiable and 31 per cent of homicides resulted from an argument, usually between family members or people who knew each other.

Since the US has much in common with Australia, it is interesting that the gun homicide rate in the US is fifteen times that of Australia where a ban was imposed in 1996. Americans with guns in the house are five times more likely to commit suicide.

There are, I know, counter arguments but the ones most frequently advanced to me were that in the UK the burglary rate is higher than in the US because burglars do not fear being shot. The other is that Hitler was in favour of gun control.

On the former argument, sentimentalists may argue that they would rather hear that their friend or relative had been burgled than shot dead and on the latter - well, Hitler also wore socks but that does not necessarily make all sock-wearers into fascists.

However, I did receive some friendly and rational pro-NRA emails. One, Matteo from Maryland, put forward the case for gun ownership without invoking either British burglaries or suggesting that we would have served Stalin/Castro/Hitler well.

There is also an article in the February issue of Brill's Content on the subject of the media's treatment of gun control. Michael Korda argues in the piece, Loaded Words, that there is a pro-gun control bias within the media which he sees as having "both a regional and a class component". This leads, he believes, to the sympathetic handling of any books which have an anti-gun message.

But with George Bush in the White House, all is well for gun owners in the US for the time being, which is why I presume they need to let off their excess steam in odd directions. Better they do so in argument than by going into their den and coming out with their favourite weapon to blast off at some a--hole.

webTitle: GPs pushed to 'point of mutiny' over NHS reform plan

fields.headline: GPs pushed to 'point of mutiny' over NHS reform plan
fields.trailText: Doctors' leaders warned last night that GPs were on the point of mutiny against the government's NHS reform plan because ministers were persistently devaluing the work of family doctors and diverting resources into more glamorous hospital services.
fields.body:
Doctors' leaders warned last night that GPs were on the point of mutiny against the government's NHS reform plan because ministers were persistently devaluing the work of family doctors and diverting resources into more glamorous hospital services.

The GPs' concerns will be voiced in a manifesto prepared by the British Medical Association for distribution to all candidates in the forthcoming general election.

It will seek to identify a gap between the service patients should get from an effective NHS and the reality of what they can expect from the government's plans.

John Chisholm, chairman of the BMA's GPs committee, said the last straw had been what he called a Department of Health decision to limit the growth in numbers of GPs to 1% a year over the next nine years. This compared with a 4.5% annual growth target for numbers of hospital consultants.

The committee, representing 30,000 GPs in England and Wales, passed a vote of no confidence in the government last week in protest at an unex pected cut in expense allowances. It said the cut would reduce this year's increase in GPs' salaries to 2.3%.

In a survey of GPs in Scotland, 56% said their morale was low and 54% said they would not recommend a career in general practice to an able 16-year-old.

Simon Fradd, a deputy chairman of the GPs committee, said: "The only topic of conversation at GP meetings is retirement. Within five years it is going to be as hard to find a GP in the NHS as it already is to find an NHS dentist."

The GPs' leaders launched their attack on the eve of a separate protest by hospital doctors. Consultants are angry about the government's plans - to be unveiled by Alan Milburn, the health secretary, today - to give them a new contract, banning work in the private sector for seven years after qualification.

The GPs' irritation was fuelled by a medical workforce census carried out by the Department of Health. It showed that the number of GPs increased by 110 in the year to September - only just over a quarter of the annual growth rate of 400 set out in the NHS plan.

The average time available for a consultation was already only eight minutes and this would reduce to five minutes if the government went ahead with its guarantee that every patient should get an appointment within 48 hours.

Dr Fradd said: "In the past week we have reached a crisis point. The profession is being asked to go along with deception of the public."

A spokesman for the Department of Health said increasing numbers of doctors could not be delivered overnight. "This is not just about expanding numbers," the spokesman said. "It is also about changing the way they work. There are lots of minor tasks that GPs do that could be done by practice nurses."

fields.headline: Stanley Kramer
fields.standfirst: Master film-maker whose bold movies challenged his audiences' perceptions of racial prejudice, Nazism and the bomb
fields.trailText: Master film-maker whose bold movies challenged his audiences' perceptions of racial prejudice, Nazism and the bomb.
fields.body:
Film producer-director Mervyn LeRoy once famously commented: "If I wanted to send a message, I'd use Western Union." Although he hated the expression "message picture", Stanley Kramer, who has died aged 87, spent most of his career countering critics who attacked him for his wishy-washy liberal sentiments, and for tackling huge themes with inadequate artistic means.

Andrew Sarris wrote: "If Kramer were not so vulnerable in his sincerity, he would not have made such a tempting target. He will never be a natural, but time has proved that he is not a fake." Pauline Kael felt that Kramer's films were "melodramas with redeeming social importance, and if their messages were often irritatingly self-righteous, the situations and settings were, nevertheless, excitingly modern and relevant."

Despite his proselytising air, Kramer himself explained: "I was spawned during the Roosevelt era, a time of great change. I still believe in getting people to think, but I don't believe films change anyone's mind."

After a tough childhood in the Hell's Kitchen district of New York, Kramer took a degree in business administration at New York University. At 21, he got a job as an assistant writer at 20th-Century Fox, moving on to become apprentice senior editor at MGM. There, he acquired the sense of structure that enabled him to edit in the camera with minimal wastage.

He became a production assistant on So Ends Our Night (1941), about three people forced to flee the Nazis in 1937, while the United States was still at peace with Germany. Prejudice, in all its forms, would become a central theme of his work. During the war, he joined the US Army Signal Corps, and helped make training films.

Kramer then set up his own production company, its first film being So This Is New York (1948), an unusual and amusing comedy directed by Richard Fleischer and based on Ring Lardner's novel The Big Town. The following year, he started to make his reputation as one of the most enterprising and successful independent producers by making economical, but serious, films just outside the Hollywood mainstream. In fact, Kramer was more instrumental than any other independent producer in breaking the stranglehold of the major studios, thus giving the movie industry a shot in the arm.

The two films that set him on his way were both directed by Mark Robson and written by Carl Foreman in 1949: Champion, a powerful study of ruthless ambition starring Kirk Douglas as a boxer who gets his comeuppance, and Home Of The Brave, which courageously took on the subject of racial prejudice in the US army; the main character was changed from a Jew in the stage play to a black man. It was one of the first American pictures to deal with the topic, preparing the way for other explorations of racial bigotry.

In 1950, Kramer became even more prominent with Cyrano de Bergerac, an effective showcase for José Ferrer's Oscar-winning performance, and The Men, directed by Fred Zinnemann and written by Foreman, an uncompromising movie starring Marlon Brando as the former GI paralysed from the waist down. This was followed by a faithful screen version of Arthur Miller's poignant play Death Of A Salesman (1951), directed by Laszlo Benedek.

A year later came two Zinnemann-directed pictures - Member Of The Wedding, an excellent transposition of Carson McCullers' novel about adolescence, and High Noon, probably the high-water mark of the careers of Kramer as producer, Zinnemann as director, Foreman as writer and Gary Cooper as actor. Ironically, Columbia, which was releasing Kramer's films, suggested he give "the western without action" to United Artists. He went on to produce The Wild One (1953), with Brando starring and Benedek directing. Faithful to a small circle of collaborators, Kramer hired Edward Dmytryk, who had recanted after being blacklisted by the House UnAmerican Activities Committee, to direct three of his productions, notably The Caine Mutiny (1954).

It was in 1955 that Kramer decided to direct his own productions, something he did in a heartfelt but rather heavy-handed manner, keeping a shrewd eye on both the box-office and the Oscar donors. His first was the torpid hospital drama Not As A Stranger (1955), with Dr Robert Mitchum acting as if under anaesthetic. He then spent $5m on The Pride And The Passion (1957), a few cents of which could have been spent on a pair of scissors and a red pencil. Yet this sprawling, 130-minute epic, starring Cary Grant, Frank Sinatra and Sophia Loren, earned its money back.

The Defiant Ones (1958) was an advance on Hollywood's usual treatment of racial themes, though a chain was the clankingly obvious symbol which bound racist Tony Curtis to Sidney Poitier, both convicts on the run. When the chain is finally severed, they are bound by an iron friendship. The picture won five nominations and two Oscars for the screenplay and cinematography. In all, Kramer's films won 15 Oscars in various categories and one for lifetime achievement.

Kramer claimed to have been inspired to make On The Beach (1959) by a letter from his nine-year-old son's teacher asking: "In the event of nuclear war, do you want your son to remain at school or will you call for him?" The anti-nuclear scientist Linus Pauling remarked: "Some years from now we can look back and say On The Beach is the movie that saved the world."

Aside from a sense of urgency from a young couple, however, most of the characters behaved as if the atomic war was little more than an irksome interruption to a cocktail party. The last image of the film was a banner saying, "There is still time, brothers!" - a judicious warning to audiences at the height of the cold war. The real message was that, although nuclear war is bad for the health, it is good for the box-office. Extremely successful financially as his films were, Kramer claimed: "The worst enemies of the motion-picture industry are the critics whose highest praise is the word 'commercial'."

The subject of his next film, Inherit The Wind (1960) was the famous "monkey trial" of 1925, in which a US schoolteacher was tried for teaching Darwin's theory of evolution. The well-staged battle that takes place in the stifling courtroom came down to a struggle for acting honours between the underplaying Spencer Tracy and the overplaying Fredric March.

Nothing if not ambitious, Kramer then tackled Judgment At Nuremberg (1961), dealing with the 1948 trial of four German judges accused of crimes against humanity. For 190 minutes, the arguments were shouted across the court, calmly presided over by Spencer Tracy, who has the last, self-righteous word in the matter. Despite its laboured treatment and film-star witnesses, the movie must be commended for attempting to analyse one of the great issues of the 20th century, and it was presumably informative to a public that paid more than $3.5m dollars to see it.

Putting gloom behind him, Kramer next paid a gigantic homage to slapstick comedy with It's A Mad, Mad, Mad, Mad World (1963), filmed in Ultra Panavision 70 (a form of Cinerama). The movie impressed cumulatively with its vast roster of comedians, past and present, its sheer size, and the number of pratfalls and spectacular stunts. The characters are all led on a trail of greed by Jimmy Durante, who gives a clue to the whereabouts of buried loot just before he dies, literally kicking a bucket. This cynical, and often funny, movie made off with more than $10m.

Ship Of Fools (1965), an adaptation of Katherine Anne Porter's hefty novel, weighing in at 148 minutes, made the best of an excellent cast, including Vivien Leigh in her final screen role and José Ferrer as an anti-semite. Guess Who's Coming To Dinner (1967), about a liberal, white middle-class couple coming to terms with their daughter's wish to marry a black man, provided an ideal vehicle for Katharine Hepburn and Spencer Tracy to co-star for the last time.

Kramer knew he was taking an enormous risk in hiring the ailing Tracy. When an insurance company refused to cover the star, he accepted personal responsibility for any financial loss should Tracy die during shooting. As Tracy delivered his last line to Hepburn - "If what they feel for each other is even half what we felt, then that is everything" - she was not the only one moved to tears. In the event, Tracy died a few months later.

Kramer was never able to repeat his huge triumphs of those earlier decades. The wartime comedy, The Secret Of Santa Vittoria (1969), was too long and loud (it starred the undemure Anthony Quinn and Anna Magnani), and with RPM (1970), he failed to catch the momentum of student revolution. At the time, during a talk at Stanford University, he declared: "I've been fighting the establishment for 30 years, and I still don't know what the establishment is." A student stood up and said: "Maybe because it's you."

Undaunted, in Bless The Beasts And Children (1971), Kramer addressed the issue of endangered species, but it was the producer-director who was identified with disappearing buffalo. After The Runner Stumbles (1979), about a priest (Dick Van Dyke) falling for a nun (Kathleen Quinlan), failed at the box office, he decided that "somewhere between films on outer space and [Sylvester] Stallone, there was no place for me".

He left Hollywood for Seattle, where he wrote a weekly column for the Seattle Times. "I felt that after being half a step ahead for many years, I was suddenly half a step behind," he said. "This helped me catch up again." When David Puttnam became president of Columbia Pictures in 1986, he asked Kramer to deliver new projects. Typically, the great man hoped to make a film on the Chernobyl disaster, but nothing came of it.

Kramer, is survived by his second wife, Karen Sharpe Kramer, and two daughters, and a son and daughter from his first marriage, to Anne Pierce. He will be remembered fondly as a producer-director who made films with universally significant subjects, valiantly continuing to do so while American cinema, on the whole, became increasingly trivial.

 Stanley Earl Kramer, film-maker, born September 29 1913; died February 19 2001

Pauline Kael felt that Kramer's films were "melodramas with redeeming social importance, and if their messages were often irritatingly self-righteous, the situations and settings were, nevertheless, excitingly modern and relevant." Despite his proselytising air, Kramer himself explained: "I was spawned during the Roosevelt era, a time of great change. I still believe in getting people to think, but I don't believe films change anyone's mind." After a tough childhood in the Hell's Kitchen district of New York, Kramer took a degree in business administration at New York University. At 21, he got a job as an assistant writer at 20th-Century Fox, moving on to become apprentice senior editor at MGM. There, he acquired the sense of structure that enabled him to edit in the camera with minimal wastage. He became a production assistant on So Ends Our Night (1941), about three people forced to flee the Nazis in 1937, while the United States was still at peace with Germany. Prejudice, in all its forms, would become a central theme of his work. During the war, he joined the US Army Signal Corps, and helped make training films. Kramer then set up his own production company, its first film being So This Is New York (1948), an unusual and amusing comedy directed by Richard Fleischer and based on Ring Lardner's novel The Big Town. The following year, he started to make his reputation as one of the most enterprising and successful independent producers by making economical, but serious, films just outside the Hollywood mainstream. In fact, Kramer was more instrumental than any other independent producer in breaking the stranglehold of the major studios, thus giving the movie industry a shot in the arm. The two films that set him on his way were both directed by Mark Robson and written by Carl Foreman in 1949: Champion, a powerful study of ruthless ambition starring Kirk Douglas as a boxer who gets his comeuppance, and Home Of The Brave, which courageously took on the subject of racial prejudice in the US army; the main character was changed from a Jew in the stage play to a black man. It was one of the first American pictures to deal with the topic, preparing the way for other explorations of racial bigotry. In 1950, Kramer became even more prominent with Cyrano de Bergerac, an effective showcase for José Ferrer's Oscar-winning performance, and The Men, directed by Fred Zinnemann and written by Foreman, an uncompromising movie starring Marlon Brando as the former GI paralysed from the waist down. This was followed by a faithful screen version of Arthur Miller's poignant play Death Of A Salesman (1951), directed by Laszlo Benedek. A year later came two Zinnemann-directed pictures - Member Of The Wedding, an excellent transposition of Carson McCullers' novel about adolescence, and High Noon, probably the high-water mark of the careers of Kramer as producer, Zinnemann as director, Foreman as writer and Gary Cooper as actor. Ironically, Columbia, which was releasing Kramer's films, suggested he give "the western without action" to United Artists. He went on to produce The Wild One (1953), with Brando starring and Benedek directing. Faithful to a small circle of collaborators, Kramer hired Edward Dmytryk, who had recanted after being blacklisted by the House UnAmerican Activities Committee, to direct three of his productions, notably The Caine Mutiny (1954). It was in 1955 that Kramer decided to direct his own productions, something he did in a heartfelt but rather heavy-handed manner, keeping a shrewd eye on both the box-office and the Oscar donors. His first was the torpid hospital drama Not As A Stranger (1955), with Dr Robert Mitchum acting as if under anaesthetic. He then spent $5m on The Pride And The Passion (1957), a few cents of which could have been spent on a pair of scissors and a red pencil. Yet this sprawling, 130-minute epic, starring Cary Grant, Frank Sinatra and Sophia Loren, earned its money back. The Defiant Ones (1958) was an advance on Hollywood's usual treatment of racial themes, though a chain was the clankingly obvious symbol which bound racist Tony Curtis to Sidney Poitier, both convicts on the run. When the chain is finally severed, they are bound by an iron friendship. The picture won five nominations and two Oscars for the screenplay and cinematography. In all, Kramer's films won 15 Oscars in various categories and one for lifetime achievement. Kramer claimed to have been inspired to make On The Beach (1959) by a letter from his nine-year-old son's teacher asking: "In the event of nuclear war, do you want your son to remain at school or will you call for him?" The anti-nuclear scientist Linus Pauling remarked: "Some years from now we can look back and say On The Beach is the movie that saved the world." Aside from a sense of urgency from a young couple, however, most of the characters behaved as if the atomic war was little more than an irksome interruption to a cocktail party. The last image of the film was a banner saying, "There is still time, brothers!" - a judicious warning to audiences at the height of the cold war. The real message was that, although nuclear war is bad for the health, it is good for the box-office. Extremely successful financially as his films were, Kramer claimed: "The worst enemies of the motion-picture industry are the critics whose highest praise is the word 'commercial'." The subject of his next film, Inherit The Wind (1960) was the famous "monkey trial" of 1925, in which a US schoolteacher was tried for teaching Darwin's theory of evolution. The well-staged battle that takes place in the stifling courtroom came down to a struggle for acting honours between the underplaying Spencer Tracy and the overplaying Fredric March. Nothing if not ambitious, Kramer then tackled Judgment At Nuremberg (1961), dealing with the 1948 trial of four German judges accused of crimes against humanity. For 190 minutes, the arguments were shouted across the court, calmly presided over by Spencer Tracy, who has the last, self-righteous word in the matter. Despite its laboured treatment and film-star witnesses, the movie must be commended for attempting to analyse one of the great issues of the 20th century, and it was presumably informative to a public that paid more than $3.5m dollars to see it. Putting gloom behind him, Kramer next paid a gigantic homage to slapstick comedy with It's A Mad, Mad, Mad, Mad World (1963), filmed in Ultra Panavision 70 (a form of Cinerama). The movie impressed cumulatively with its vast roster of comedians, past and present, its sheer size, and the number of pratfalls and spectacular stunts. The characters are all led on a trail of greed by Jimmy Durante, who gives a clue to the whereabouts of buried loot just before he dies, literally kicking a bucket. This cynical, and often funny, movie made off with more than $10m. Ship Of Fools (1965), an adaptation of Katherine Anne Porter's hefty novel, weighing in at 148 minutes, made the best of an excellent cast, including Vivien Leigh in her final screen role and José Ferrer as an anti-semite. Guess Who's Coming To Dinner (1967), about a liberal, white middle-class couple coming to terms with their daughter's wish to marry a black man, provided an ideal vehicle for Katharine Hepburn and Spencer Tracy to co-star for the last time. Kramer knew he was taking an enormous risk in hiring the ailing Tracy. When an insurance company refused to cover the star, he accepted personal responsibility for any financial loss should Tracy die during shooting. As Tracy delivered his last line to Hepburn - "If what they feel for each other is even half what we felt, then that is everything" - she was not the only one moved to tears. In the event, Tracy died a few months later. Kramer was never able to repeat his huge triumphs of those earlier decades. The wartime comedy, The Secret Of Santa Vittoria (1969), was too long and loud (it starred the undemure Anthony Quinn and Anna Magnani), and with RPM (1970), he failed to catch the momentum of student revolution. At the time, during a talk at Stanford University, he declared: "I've been fighting the establishment for 30 years, and I still don't know what the establishment is." A student stood up and said: "Maybe because it's you." Undaunted, in Bless The Beasts And Children (1971), Kramer addressed the issue of endangered species, but it was the producer-director who was identified with disappearing buffalo. After The Runner Stumbles (1979), about a priest (Dick Van Dyke) falling for a nun (Kathleen Quinlan), failed at the box office, he decided that "somewhere between films on outer space and [Sylvester] Stallone, there was no place for me". He left Hollywood for Seattle, where he wrote a weekly column for the Seattle Times. "I felt that after being half a step ahead for many years, I was suddenly half a step behind," he said. "This helped me catch up again." When David Puttnam became president of Columbia Pictures in 1986, he asked Kramer to deliver new projects. Typically, the great man hoped to make a film on the Chernobyl disaster, but nothing came of it. Kramer, is survived by his second wife, Karen Sharpe Kramer, and two daughters, and a son and daughter from his first marriage, to Anne Pierce. He will be remembered fondly as a producer-director who made films with universally significant subjects, valiantly continuing to do so while American cinema, on the whole, became increasingly trivial.  Stanley Earl Kramer, film-maker, born September 29 1913; died February 19 2001

fields.headline: Ten-man Wycombe spot on
fields.trailText: Wycombe twice came back from a goal down to win 8-7 in the penalty shoot-out to earn a quarter-final tie against Leicester City.
fields.body:
This last week has been all about Wycombe's manager Lawrie Sanchez reliving memories of scoring the FA Cup final winner for Wimbledon in 1988. Last night he conjured up something just as dramatic to knock his old club out of this season's competition, book a sixth-round tie at Leicester and enhance his reputation as one of the country's best up-and-coming managers.

After seeing his Second Division side come back dramatically to equalise from 2-0 down in Saturday's first tie, he watched as they were reduced to 10 men but still displayed the never-say-die attitude that characterised the Wimbledon team Sanchez played in for 10 years.

They twice came back from a goal down to win 8-7 in the shoot-out after Wimbledon's Mark Williams missed the 20th penalty kick.

The rest of an unbelievably eventful plot had unfolded like this. First Wimbledon took the lead when Gareth Ainsworth grabbed a breakaway goal after Wycombe themselves had almost scored.

The visitors equalised when Andy Rammel's shot was parried by the Wimbledon keeper and the long-serving Dave Carroll converted the rebound.

Wycombe, however, were hit badly when Rammell, their leading scorer, had to limp off and his replacement Andy Baird was carried off on a stretcher four minutes later after an awful challenge from Williams. The defender was only booked.

Wimbledon dominated after the restart and Wycombe's hopes were further hit when Michael Simpson was sent off for a second yellow card on 70 minutes. But they looked to be holding on for extra-time when, with only a minute left, Wimbledon were awarded a penalty after Paul McCarthy appeared to handle Marcus Gayle's cross.

However, Martin Taylor saved Neal Ardley's penalty. Wycombe's relief was short lived. Thirty-four seconds into extra-time Wayne Gray picked up Jason Euell's knock-on and shot Wimbledon into the lead with his first senior goal.

This was both teams' third replay in this season's competition but it was Wycombe who were feeling the pressure as Taylor was forced into a great save to deny Euell.

As extra-time ticked away Wanderers' best run in this competition looked to be over. But with 30 seconds remaining they benefited from another slice of luck to go with their blatantly offside equaliser on Saturday.

Dannie Bulman, in front of goal, sliced his shot but it found McCarthy on the far post and he found the net. Wimbledon's manager Terry Burton protested so vehemently that McCarthy was offside that he was banished from the bench.

Burton watched from the stand as Wycombe won the shoot-out and perhaps the most famous victory in their history. Sanchez took the plaudits from the Wycombe faithful who made up half the crowd. He and his players deserved every cheer.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Winton to front C5 reality show

fields.headline: Winton to front C5 reality show
fields.trailText: 10am: Dale Winton will present Channel 5's Japanese-style reality show, Touching the Truck, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The ubermeister of camp, Dale Winton, has been signed up to present Channel 5's Japanese-style reality show, Touching the Truck.

Mr Winton, who shot to TV prominence as the face of Supermarket Sweep, will present the five-day TV endurance contest from the Lakeside shopping centre in Thurrock, Essex.

Twenty contestants will pit their boredom thresholds and cross their legs to see who can keep contact with a four wheel-drive Toyota Land Cruiser Amazon.

Mr Winton said he was "delighted to be working with Channel 5 on such a groundbreaking concept".

"The combination of great human drama and the best elements of a gameshow will make this a compelling TV event."

Contestants are allowed one ten-minute toilet break every two hours and a 15-minute food break every six hours.

But apart from that, they must maintain physical contact with the truck if they want to stay in the game.

The show is based on an American game show format called Hands on the Hardbody.

Touching the Truck will go out every evening from Sunday to Thursday from March 11.

fields.headline: Martin Sorrell predicts tough year
fields.trailText: 9.45am: The world's largest advertising group has warned of 'economic uncertainties' ahead, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Martin Sorrell's WPP, the world's largest marketing and advertising company, has predicted a tough year ahead for the pressurised sector.

The advertising market is already being hit by the economic downturn.

The dramatic slump in the US economy is prompting many big advertisers to rein in their marketing budgets.

WPP today reflected this when it reported full-year profits in line with analysts' expectations, but warned of "economic uncertainties" over the next few years.

"Economic conditions in North America are now, to say the least, more challenging," said WPP in statement.

Despite reporting a rise in pre-tax profit from £318m in 1999 to £365m last year, any admission of weakness in the North American market will damage confidence in a company that generates 46% of its revenues in the US.

WPP admitted the uncertainty is set to continue because the measures being taken to rekindle the US economy could cause long-term damage.

"The real economic challenge may come not in 2001 but in 2002 if lower interest rates and US tax cuts overheat the economy," said WPP.

However, WPP's aggressive acquisition policy helped push up revenues by 37% to £2.98bn.

The group bought New York-based rival Young & Rubicam in a £2.6bn deal last year, adding the company to a portfolio that includes J. Walter Thompson and Ogilvy & Mather.

WPP now owns three of the industry's biggest ad agencies.

fields.headline: Express blasts Harmsworths
fields.trailText: 10am: The Express has launched an unprecedented attack on the Mail's proprietors, write Jessica Hodgson and Lisa O'Carroll.
fields.body:
The Express today launched an unprecedented attack on its nearest rival, the Daily Mail, in a bid to regain some ground in the middle market.

In a swingeing editorial on the the Harmsworth dynasty, the Express attacks "the hypocrisy" of the aristocratic proprietors of the Daily Mail, which has "for decades piously preached about patriotism and family values".

It tells its readers that while the Mail likes to push family values and is filled with indignation at those it regards as responsible for moral decline in the this country, members of the Rothermere family, now dead, have been guilty of adultery, multiple marriages, divorce and drug abuse.

And the Express also points out that the current head of the family, Viscount Rothermere, has fathered an illegitimate son.

"Theirs was a dysfunctional family long before the term was invented," says the Express.

The double-page spread is confirmation of Richard Desmond's determination to lure readers from the Mail.

The strategy follows disastrous set of circulation figures, which showed sales for the Express dropping below the 1m mark.

Sources say Mr Desmond, who took over the Express last year, believes the Mail is "fair game" following its blistering attack on his pornography empire, which publishes titles such as Forum and Asian babes.

The Express article - carrying no byline - goes on to chronicle examples of the Mail dynasty's hypocrisy.

It pictures Harold Sidney Harmsworth, a Nazi sympathiser, standing next to Adolf Hitler.

And its lengthy headline notes that Vere Rothermere, the third Viscount, kept a mistress for 15 years while his wife, fondly known as Bubbles, was still alive.

And in a bid to steal the mantle of the paper of family values, the Express regurgitates Vere Rothermere's candid last interview.

In this, Vere Rothermere made it plain that even he didn't agree with the Mail's simplistic conservatism.

He said: "Family values - what does that phrase mean?

"I've not the least idea! It doesn't mean anything. Today, the whole idea is that morality is a matter of opinion."

webTitle: Blackburn's social services must focus on Asians

fields.headline: Blackburn's social services must focus on Asians
fields.trailText: Blackburn with Darwen borough council must improve social services for Asian communities, according to a joint social services inspectorate and audit commission review. Linda Steele reports
fields.body:
Blackburn with Darwen borough council must improve social services for Asian communities, according to a joint social services inspectorate and audit commission review.

Asian communities are under-represented in staff, referrals and services, the review found. Around 15% of the local population - and 30% of those of school age - are from an Indian or Pakistani background. The unitary council needs to work with Asian communities, and improve the range and take-up of services for them, according to the report.

However, the inspectors were in "no doubt" of the Labour-controlled council's wish to make progress in this area, and to "promote tolerance and respect diversity". The borough is undertaking an audit using Commission for Racial Equality standards. On all issues, the social services department is "moving in the right direction by identifying problem areas and developing strategies to make appropriate changes", said John Bolton, joint reviews director.

The review also found that the department is serving some of its catchment population well and prospects for improvement are "promising". But, it says: "The council faces a number of challenges if it is to continue to improve services in the borough to achieve the high standards to which it aspires."

The challenges include clarifying "who is eligible for services and [ensuring] consistency in standards".

The report says social services should ensure reliability and quality by setting standards, using performance indicators, and monitoring service delivery. A new, but delayed, integrated social services computer system needs to be fully operational, to provide activity data, financial controls and support service development.

The department needs to move away from an over-reliance on residential care, improve its commissioning process, pace its change programme and avoid overloading staff.

But the review highlighted many positive areas including "a strong officer team", an effective political leadership, which is enthusiastic about change, and good cross-party collaboration. The department has "positive and constructive" working relationships with partner agencies.

Moreover, initial response times are good and most people are "very satisfied with the services". Corporate finances are "sound". Staff training and an "innovative" management training programme are good, as are communications with staff and unions.

"The council has commendable ambition for the borough and its people," says the report.

The outcome of the review was welcomed by the authority. "The joint review came just at the right time as it gave us the opportunity to have external scrutiny on just how far we have travelled towards achieving our ambitions and how far we still have to go," said councillor Sue Reid, executive member for social services.

The council is a two-year-old unitary covering Blackburn, its smaller neighbour Darwen and the surrounding rural area. It is primarily urban with a large manufacturing base. The area has one of the highest levels of deprivation in the country but has a relatively small population (140,000).

fields.headline: French health service is best
fields.trailText: The NHS is one of the great failures of the Blair government. Are there better ways of achieving the NHS ideal of universal access? An open-minded appraisal of European systems would show that there are, writes David Green
fields.body:
The NHS is one of the great failures of the Blair government. Are there better ways of achieving the NHS ideal of universal access? An open-minded appraisal of European systems would show that there are.

But instead of showing how social democratic France, Germany and the Netherlands have systems which combine consumer choice, health insurance and a measure of personal payment in different ways which guarantee the poorest people a higher standard of care than under the NHS, the pusillanimous Tories have been paralysed by fear that Labour will unfairly accuse them of being ready to ride roughshod over the interests of the poor.

In which leading European country is there the widest gap between the standard of care available to the poor and that enjoyed by the rich? The answer is the UK: the rich can always take care of themselves, but the poor rely on the government and in this country the state provides only a low standard.

Take France as an example. France has a reputation for central direction but French healthcare is based on a compromise between egalitarianism and liberalism. All citizens are said to be equal; yet, choice and competition are fiercely protected.

In France, individuals can identify on their pay slips how much they are paying and form a view about whether the cost is justified. Consequently, the standard of care guaranteed by the state reflects the personal preferences of people who are self-sufficient through work. And it is this high standard of care which is made available to all. France performs well on almost all health status measures, and when the World Health Organisation ranked world healthcare systems in 2000, France came top.

Compulsory health insurance covers the whole population. Premiums are charged as a percentage of income and the total cost is nearly 20% of payroll, including the employer's and employee's contribution. The insurers are non-government, non-profit agencies, which owe their allegiance to employers (who pay about two-thirds of the premium) and employees. In addition to their compulsory contribution (6.8% of payroll), most employees pay an additional voluntary 2.5% of their salary to a mutual insurer.

The French enjoy choice of doctor, whether a GP or a specialist, and typically pay their doctor's fee and then claim back 75-80%. It is recognised that payment might deter the poorest people from seeking care and so about 6m people are not expected to pay. All patients, whether exempt from co-payments or not, may go directly to a specialist either outside or within a hospital. The French dislike GP gatekeepers. French national insurance makes no distinction between public and private hospitals and patients have complete freedom of choice. Public hospitals provide about 65% of beds and the remainder are private (about 20% are for-profit and about 15% non-profit).

No doubt it will be said that the French government has been trying to control costs. It has. But it has done so under a system which deliberately encourages responsible consumer demand by requiring modest consumer payments. It also has a built-in safety valve of supplementary insurance in case the wishes of the French government are out of sync with the preferences of the French people. The result has been that, as the French government has tried to lower expenditure since the 70s, so the French people have taken up the slack. In the 60s about 30% of the French paid privately for supplementary health insurance. The proportion had increased to 50% in the 70s and today is about 85%.

T o a central planner schooled in NHS administrative technique, the French system looks like a chaotic mess, but in reality the mess is a pragmatic blend of consumer choice, professional autonomy, central regulation and a government-backed guarantee for the poor which exceeds the NHS standard by far. Like the Belgians, the Dutch and the Germans, the French in their own way have discovered how to universalise the benefits of a competitive market. The NHS, by comparison, has universalised the drawbacks of public sector monopoly.

In choosing to defend an outdated public sector monopoly, whose deficiencies become more apparent with each passing day, the Blair government has opened itself up to effective attack. But, instead of raising the level of the debate by demonstrating that there are better ways of meeting the NHS ideal, the Conservative opposition has steered clear of the subject in case they are misunderstood.

David G Green is director of Civitas, a market- oriented thinktank

An open-minded appraisal of European systems would show that there are. But instead of showing how social democratic France, Germany and the Netherlands have systems which combine consumer choice, health insurance and a measure of personal payment in different ways which guarantee the poorest people a higher standard of care than under the NHS, the pusillanimous Tories have been paralysed by fear that Labour will unfairly accuse them of being ready to ride roughshod over the interests of the poor. In which leading European country is there the widest gap between the standard of care available to the poor and that enjoyed by the rich? France has a reputation for central direction but French healthcare is based on a compromise between egalitarianism and liberalism. All citizens are said to be equal; yet, choice and competition are fiercely protected. In France, individuals can identify on their pay slips how much they are paying and form a view about whether the cost is justified. Consequently, the standard of care guaranteed by the state reflects the personal preferences of people who are self-sufficient through work. fields.headline: United vulnerable to US downturn
fields.trailText: 9.30am: Analysts fear United Business Media will be affected by the crumbling US technology market, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Lord Hollick's radically transformed United Business Media has been knocked by analysts, who fear it will be hit by shockwaves from the crumbling US technology market.

United Business Media became a business publishing group late last year.

It dumped its old name of United News & Media along with its ITV franchises and the Express newspaper group.

However, the media team at ABN Amro have questioned the timing of the move, saying the group's close ties with the US market have made it the most exposed European media stock.

"We believe the transition is poorly timed given the significant slowdown in US hi-tech advertising.

"There is a significant risk of earnings disappointments and downgrades," said ABN.

The ABN team said more than 80% of United's profits come from the US market and advertising provides 67% of the group's revenues.

"We believe recent trading statements from US companies with a hi-tech exposure point to a significant downturn in the advertising outlook," ABN added.

The US technology sector has been hit by a series of profit warnings and job cuts at the likes of Motorola, Microsoft and Intel, which have borne the brunt of a slowing national economy.

United's portfolio includes the CMP magazine group, PR Newswire and the United Information market research group.

The majority of analysts who cover the company give it a "buy" rating.

United made £3.2bn from selling off its consumer assets last year.

However, the ABN team said the group's plan to reinvest the windfall in a share buy-back scheme would not be enough to support the company's stock.

ABN said the buy-back has already affected United's share price.

Attention will soon revert to the company's core businesses, which faces stiff year-on-year revenue comparisons.

United's shares, which ABN have kept on a "reduce" rating, slipped 2% to 762p by late afternoon trading.

United was not available for comment.

fields.headline: Minister bullish on pregnant pause
fields.standfirst: Soon taking maternity leave will become so normal that no one will bat an eyelid, says Yvette Cooper of her pioneering decision.
fields.trailText: Soon taking maternity leave will become so normal that no one will bat an eyelid, says Yvette Cooper of her pioneering decision. Lucy Ward reports
fields.body:
The prospect of women ministers taking full maternity leave and then returning to their departments will become so normal that "no one will bat an eyelid", according to the first minister to plan to do so.

Yvette Cooper, the public health minister, who is expecting her second child in mid-August, will take a complete break from red boxes - the daily in-trays stuffed with ministerial documents and parliamentary legislative duties - when she goes on leave for around five months in July.

Arrangements to cover for her absence, assuming Labour wins the expected spring general election, have yet to be nailed down, but options could include appointing another MP to cover her role, or distributing elements of the job among other health ministers. The complexity of finding cover for her role is compounded by the fact that ministers are not, in law, employees, subject to normal employment legislation, but office holders, with unique status.

The 31-year-old minister, speaking in the week that the leader of the Lords and minister for women, Baroness Jay, announced plans to quit her cabinet post because her work-life balance had shifted out of kilter, is clear that any problems can be surmounted. Her confidence may be well-founded: while her announcement may have sent Department of Health mandarins into a spin, a government which says it supports family-friendly employment policies cannot be seen to be a careless employer.

Ms Cooper has already rescheduled her day to ensure that her red boxes are dealt with during the day instead of at home in the evening as is traditional, leaving her free to spend time with her family.

"It's business as usual," she insisted, amid a breakneck schedule of meetings, a hospital visit and a sweet factory tour in her Pontefract and Castleford constituency. "Millions of women take maternity leave from jobs and it ought to be normal in every occupation and every walk of life. People at work have families too.

"One day no one will bat an eyelid at ministers taking maternity leave because of course it's something that ministers, MPs, nurses, businesswomen and everybody else needs to be able to do."

Ms Cooper, who took five months' maternity leave after the birth of Ellie, now 20 months, is keen to see attention paid instead to the maternity and child health services she will be using.

Under a new drive to address the inequalities which mean that UK children from low income backgrounds suffer poorer health and higher death rates than their more affluent counterparts, the government has set a new infant mortality target. Amid evidence that the death rate of babies under one in the lowest income areas is 70% higher than in the most affluent areas, the aim is to reduce the gap between the poorest and the average by 10% in 10 years.

Equal treatment

In a move designed to iron out the postcode lottery affecting child health care, ministers are to draw up a new children's national service framework - NHS jargon for a plan to offer equal treatment and services, including maternity care, across the country.

The step follows recent moves to extend the Sure Start programme, aimed at helping poorer families with children under four, to support expectant mothers, and an initiative to provide free daily fruit in infant schools.

Ms Cooper, who pushed strongly within her department for the focus on child health, points to the relatively lower birthweight of babies from low income homes, together with statistics showing that smaller babies have increased risk of higher blood pressure and heart disease later in life. "If you look at the health inequalities issue, so many of them are rooted very early in life, if not passed down from one generation to another."

The government, with its pledge to abolish child poverty within 20 years, has much to do: the latest published figures, for 1998/99, show that 4.5m children in the UK were living in poverty: one of the worst rates among industrialised countries. The numbers have since been reduced by 1m, according to government figures, but child poverty campaigners warn those deepest in poverty will be hardest to lift out.

More passionate

Ms Cooper admits personal experience has strengthened her concern over child health. "When you are a parent, inevitably, it makes you more sensitive or more passionate about what happens to young children because it is what you see immediately around you in your own life. In the same way, when you are using maternity services, and talking to other parents, that can be quite effective for the policy-making process because you are not divorced from the policy area you are working on."

Ms Cooper will take the statutory 18 weeks leave, on full ministerial pay. At the birth of the baby, her husband, Ed Balls, also at New Labour's epicentre as chancellor Gordon Brown's closest aide, will take two weeks' paternity leave and will continue to help out with childcare in the evenings.

Publicly, she will refuse to admit she is doing anything unusual, though the prospect of a minister taking maternity leave inevitably breaks new ground. "It has never been done before - this is new territory and it will take some time to work out how to do it. The department will have to look at what the best arrangements are. But I have found everybody is very keen to make it work."

fields.headline: Britannic to sponsor C4's Frasier
fields.trailText: 9am: Channel 4 sitcom Frasier is to be sponsored by Britannic Money in a £1m deal, reports Julia Day.
fields.body:
Channel 4 sitcom Frasier is to be sponsored by Britannic Money in a £1m deal.

Britannic Money is the new name of First Active Financial, which Britannic Assurance acquired last year.

The sponsorship deal forms part of Brittanic Money's launch programme, which also includes national TV and press advertising, tube panels and an outdoor poster campaign.

The sponsorship will run for the remainder of the 2001 series of Frasier.

It was negotiated on behalf of Britannic Money by Andrew Cole-Bulgin, director of Connexus.

Matt Smith, Britannic Money head of marketing, said: "Sponsoring Frasier is an ideal choice for us because the programme reflects the type of discerning customer we appeal to."

The Frasier sponsorship executions are intended to reflect Britannic Money's aim of helping people change the way they manage their personal finances, while mirroring the theme of Frasier.

The creative executions centre on the concept of dreams and include images of people dreaming about holidays, children and lifestyle aspirations.

Each scenario is shot in black and white and accompanied by atmospheric music.

Troubled pensions company Equitable Life was the previous sponsor of Frasier.

webTitle: Tories aim £1,000 tax cuts at families

fields.headline: Tories aim £1,000 tax cuts at families
fields.trailText: The Conservatives will today step up their campaign to woo disaffected voters with a pledge to cut taxes by up to £1,000 a year for families in which one partner stays at home to look after children under 11 years old.
fields.body:
The Conservatives will today step up their campaign to woo disaffected voters with a pledge to cut taxes by up to £1,000 a year for families in which one partner stays at home to look after children under 11 years old.

The Tory leader, William Hague, will announce the policy change later today after an internal party tussle which saw the social realists led by the shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, win what amounts to a pledge to reverse the anti-family tax policies of the Thatcher era.

Andrew Smith, who holds the post Mr Portillo once held as chief secretary to the Treasury, immediately protested that the shadow chancellor was again "making promises he cannot fund on the basis of savings he cannot justify" - a reference to the £8bn worth of alleged savings the Tories have identified in recent months.

The mechanism chosen by the shadow chancellor and his social security spokesman, David Willetts, in a notoriously difficult field in which to deliver cash to those who most need it, is the so-called transferable tax allowance, albeit restricted to standard rate taxpayers from 2003-04.

Mr Hague will pledge to create a right to transfer a non-working spouse's personal tax allowance to the working partner (worth £4,535 a year at 2001-02 rates), the equivalent of £997 a year assuming the working husband or wife is paying income tax at the standard rate of 22p in the pound.

Labour was quick to denounce the scheme, not least because Mr Portillo's nimble footwork as shadow chancellor has allowed Mr Hague to backtrack from repeated Tory pledges, far more costly to fullfill, to restore the married couples' tax allowance .

It was eroded in the Tory years and finally phased out to widespread dismay under the chancellor, Gordon Brown, who devised a new working families tax credit to replace it, targeting larger sums at the poorest families who became the new chancellor's prime concern.

Mr Brown argues that the working families tax credit already delivers up to £2,000 a year extra to single-earner families with children.

Tory figures suggest that there will be at least 1m winners from Mr Hague's plans, a tacit admission that most married couples will not benefit, either because they have no children, none under 11 or because both parents are in employment.

Mr Portillo has worked hard to restore the credibility of the Conservative tax-and-spend policies he inherited from Francis Maude and the "tax guarantee" first unveiled by Mr Hague in 1999. Last month he promised to abolish taxes of savings for mainly older voters. This week he promised extra cash to improve the children's tax credit at a cost of £400m.

Only yesterday, in a move overshadowed by the leaking of Mr Hague's new scheme, he promised to abolish income tax on the traditional widowed mother's allowance which would benefit single parents with modest incomes who are working and raising children alone. That would benefit an estimated 50,000 families.

Tory sources last night told friendly newspapers that the Hague plan reflects the restoration of the pre-Thatcher belief that the tax system should reflect the cost of raising children and encourage the formation of proper family units rooted in marriage.

With the general election 10 weeks away at most, Labour was quick to protest that 6m of the 7.5m families with children would not benefit from the new scheme, and that the crucial Tory savings already identified do not add up - a point endorsed by many independent experts.

This week's Guardian/ICM poll suggests that voters believe both parties will raise their taxes if elected but that Labour will spend more money. Given the public concern about the state of health and education, that is a more persuasive vote-winner.

Mr Hague's pledges are therefore made from a position 15% behind, according to ICM, though MPs on both sides admit that many voters say they are undecided.
