webTitle: Barak turns down post in Sharon cabinet

fields.headline: Barak turns down post in Sharon cabinet
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText:
Israel's Ehud Barak executed one of his famous political u-turns last
night, announcing that he would not serve as defence minister under
the new hardliner prime minister, Ariel Sharon.
fields.body:
Israel's Ehud Barak executed one of his famous political u-turns last night, announcing that he would not serve as defence minister under the new hardliner prime minister, Ariel Sharon.

Mr Barak's departure could delay Mr Sharon's continuing efforts to form a national unity government with Labour for several days, or might shelve such an enterprise entirely.

Hours before last night's announcement, aides to Mr Sharon said he was losing patience with negotiations to form a national unity coalition, and might abandon the idea entirely to seek to form a narrow coalition with religious and far-right parties.

That would see Mr Sharon embracing as coalition partners leaders who have called for the bombing of Beirut and Tehran - in case of attack on Israel - and who espouse the expulsion of the Palestinians to Jordan.

"I hope the Labour party will approve the unity government and we can progress quickly. But if that will be delayed beyond Monday then another government will be formed," Ehud Olmert, the mayor of Jerusalem and a Likud negotiator said before Mr Barak's announcement.

Such machinations following the former prime minister's exit could take several days to play out. But what was immediately clear from last night's surprise resignation is that Mr Barak, who was trounced by a 25% margin in elections two weeks ago, at last appears to have accepted that he has become a hugely unpopular figure in Israel.

Mr Barak's announcement last week that he was ready to serve as Mr Sharon's defence minister caused an upset in Israel. For many Israelis, Mr Barak could hardly be a less suitable candidate. After sweeping to power less than two years ago on a promise to bring peace, he delivered a bloody Palestinian uprising.

Many Israelis were happy to see him go when he announced his retirement on election night two weeks ago. When he announced his change of heart only a few days later, both the left and right joined hands to denounce him as an opportunist, and political commentators accused him of spitting in the face of an electorate who so clearly had voted for a change.

Within his own Labour party, Mr Barak's determination to keep a toehold on power was pushing the party towards a split. Rivals for the party leadership were determined to block him from becoming defence minister, and the peace camp was upset at the very idea of sharing power with Mr Sharon.

"Mr Barak's announcement last night appears to signal his realisation that the public does not want him, and that his continued leadership of Labour could lead the party into collapse," Haim Ramon, a Labour party leader, said.

The move marks the second time Mr Barak has announced his retirement from public life since his election rout two weeks ago.

Meanwhile, Palestinians threatened revenge against Israel at yesterday's funeral of an Islamic militant gunned down in a refugee camp, allegedly by Israeli special forces.

As tensions in the region increased, a Jewish settler was shot and wounded in a drive-by shooting by Palestinian gunmen in the West Bank, the army said. The 40-year-old man was treated for wounds to his chest and stomach.

In other violence yesterday, a Palestinian woman stabbed an 18-year-old Jewish seminary student in Hebron. The student was taken to hospital for treatment and the attacker apprehended, the military said.

Since the current unrest in the Middle East began on September 28 of last year, 405 people have been killed, including 333 Palestinians, 14 Israeli Arabs, 57 other Israelis and a German doctor.

But if that will be delayed beyond Monday then another government will be formed," Ehud Olmert, the mayor of Jerusalem and a Likud negotiator said before Mr Barak's announcement. Such machinations following the former prime minister's exit could take several days to play out. But what was immediately clear from last night's surprise resignation is that Mr Barak, who was trounced by a 25% margin in elections two weeks ago, at last appears to have accepted that he has become a hugely unpopular figure in Israel. Mr Barak's announcement last week that he was ready to serve as Mr Sharon's defence minister caused an upset in Israel. For many Israelis, Mr Barak could hardly be a less suitable candidate. After sweeping to power less than two years ago on a promise to bring peace, he delivered a bloody Palestinian uprising. Many Israelis were happy to see him go when he announced his retirement on election night two weeks ago. When he announced his change of heart only a few days later, both the left and right joined hands to denounce him as an opportunist, and political commentators accused him of spitting in the face of an electorate who so clearly had voted for a change. Within his own Labour party, Mr Barak's determination to keep a toehold on power was pushing the party towards a split. Rivals for the party leadership were determined to block him from becoming defence minister, and the peace camp was upset at the very idea of sharing power with Mr Sharon. "Mr Barak's announcement last night appears to signal his realisation that the public does not want him, and that his continued leadership of Labour could lead the party into collapse," Haim Ramon, a Labour party leader, said. The move marks the second time Mr Barak has announced his retirement from public life since his election rout two weeks ago. Meanwhile, Palestinians threatened revenge against Israel at yesterday's funeral of an Islamic militant gunned down in a refugee camp, allegedly by Israeli special forces. As tensions in the region increased, a Jewish settler was shot and wounded in a drive-by shooting by Palestinian gunmen in the West Bank, the army said. The 40-year-old man was treated for wounds to his chest and stomach. In other violence yesterday, a Palestinian woman stabbed an 18-year-old Jewish seminary student in Hebron. The student was taken to hospital for treatment and the attacker apprehended, the military said. Since the current unrest in the Middle East began on September 28 of last year, 405 people have been killed, including 333 Palestinians, 14 Israeli Arabs, 57 other Israelis and a German doctor. fields.headline: Consultant contract - main proposals
fields.trailText:
Consultant contract - main proposals
• Under the current system, next year's starting salary for an NHS consultant would be a minimum of just over £50,000. Under the government proposals that could rise to a minimum of £60,000.
fields.body:
Consultant contract - main proposals
 Under the current system, next year's starting salary for an NHS consultant would be a minimum of just over £50,000. Under the government proposals that could rise to a minimum of £60,000.

 Two new pay thresholds would be introduced so that NHS consultant salaries could go up by around £10,000 five years after appointment and by another £10,000 five years after that, say ministers - so consultants could typically get another £20,000 more under the new contract.

 The current "outdated and complex" system of performance related pay involves two schemes - distinction awards and discretionary points - which are "fundamentally flawed" according to the Department of Health.

 The government proposes to replace these with a single scheme which it says would pay out more in total, increase the number of consultants who get awards, and give most to those consultants who "contribute most to the NHS".

 All consultants would have work plans setting out the hours they will work for the NHS, so that their time can be used most effectively. This would include their clinical duties, out-of -hours commitments and service objectives.

 The proposals repeat the position set out by the government in the NHS plan in July 2000 that consultants should work exclusively for the NHS for a period of "perhaps" seven years following appointment. After that period consultants could pursue private practice as well as NHS work, but consultants who reduced their commitments to the NHS in order to pursue private practice beyond a certain earnings level would not receive automatic access to the full range of benefits under the contract.

 The current, "confusing", 'maximum part-time' system of managing the relationship between NHS and private work, would be replaced with one in which those consultants who wanted to work in the private sector after the initial seven years would be paid for their NHS time on a pro-rata basis.

webTitle: Forging links between mental health treatment and religious communities

fields.headline: Restored faith
fields.standfirst: Sophie Petit-Zeman on how a spiritual dimension has been added to treating people with mental health problems
fields.trailText: Sophie Petit-Zeman on how a spiritual dimension has been added to treating people with mental health problems
fields.body:
Persuading the NHS to extend its remit amid countless budgetary demands is a tough job. However, two years ago cash was found to set up a department for religious, spiritual and cultural care in Newham, east London. And a report out today shows how the initiative has forged links between people with mental health problems and their faith communities, while raising awareness among health and social care staff of the importance of religion.

The department was the brainchild of Nigel Copsey, an ordained minister and resident of London's east end for most of his life. Some 40% of his local population - one in two of whom is black or Asian - is estimated to have links with a faith group. No fewer than 294 religious organisations are active locally, covering almost the entire spectrum of major world religions, with the exception of Judaism - although the population of neighbouring Hackney is 12% Jewish.

Copsey spent two years researching how best to provide mental health services within such multi-faith communities. He says: "Religion is inextricably bound with culture, and as fundamental to the lives of many minority ethnic communities as food and drink. Faith communities are the most significant group within the local population. People understandably become suspicious when the secular and spiritual are separated."

The western psychiatric model traditionally excludes spiritual dimensions and overlooks the significance of religion in people's lives. Indeed, in many cases, Copsey found that faiths attribute what British society would describe as mental illness to "spiritual sickness".

Despite the recent declaration by health and social care minister John Hutton that development and delivery of culturally appropriate services can no longer be regarded as optional, it can still prove very hard to get such issues on to the NHS agenda. Copsey admits to having been incredibly lucky in having had full support from the outset from leaders of the East London and City mental health trust.

He stresses that the department needed to reflect the area's diversity, moving way from the chaplaincy model. "Other places tried to launch similar initiatives by appointing chaplains and assistants, but neither an imam nor a priest can cover the range of religions," he says. "The department clearly needed to be run by a neutral coordinator to assess what's there and what's needed."

The first coordinator was an Asian woman with Hindu and Christian backgrounds, who was also a trained counselling psychologist. After six months, however, it was clear that the workload was too great for one person and the department now has three coordinators, from different religions, and has also co-opted two multilingual Muslim co-workers from acute wards within Newham.

These workers have proved invaluable in liaising with patients, who may not speak English well enough to explain their religious needs to staff. As shown in today's report, Forward in Faith, published by the Sainsbury Centre for Mental Health, many such patients fear they will be labelled psychotic, then compulsorily detained and forcibly medicated - the faith that they need most at a time of crisis itself becoming a burden.

The team applies an action research model - asking patients on the wards what they want - which Copsey stresses is vital to "turn findings into action that results in social change". But simple changes of fundamental importance to many patients can be surprisingly complex to implement, as the department found when it discovered that the needs of Muslim men during Ramadan were being overlooked.

Although their hospital had a prayer room, it was unfurnished, contained no religious symbols, and few staff and patients knew it existed. The department set about making the room welcoming, buying prayer mats and publicising its existence, and produced a staff handout explaining the meaning of the festival and related issues, such as prayer times and fasting. The latter raised the importance of ensuring that meals were available at unusual times of day - necessitating revised kitchen timetables - and that religious observance was reconciled with the need to take some medication with food.

Such complexities have prompted the department to expand, establishing two teams - one to research need, the second to turn ideas into action. The department will also soon take its work outside hospitals, meeting religious needs within a community context, and the changing boundaries of local NHS trusts will bring extension of its remit into Hackney and Tower Hamlets.

Within the next two years, the department aims to be able to: respond holistically to the specific needs of people from all religious, spiritual and cultural backgrounds, supporting them during and after treatment; offer people receiving mental health care a befriender from their own background and mother tongue, as well as contact with their own faith group in the community; and run comprehensive training programmes that bring together mental health care workers, faith leaders and members of faith communities.

Peter Horn, chief executive of the East London and City mental health trust, is strongly supportive of the approach. "The work on spiritual care that Nigel and his team have undertaken in Newham has been an important success," he says. "It has helped link people with mental health problems to their spiritual communities and has raised staff awareness of these issues. As a trust, we would like to extend the work across east London."

Copsey has also helped the South Essex mental health trust, which is hoping to roll out a similar project in its area, and his work has been welcomed by other mental health organisations.

Vicky Nicholls, who is coordinating related research as part of the Mental Health Foundation's "strategies for living" project, based on user-led research with a particular focus on alternative and self-help strategies for coping with mental health problems, wants to see comparable services set up across the country. She says: "We recommend that mental health service providers and local faith communities work together to improve mutual awareness and communication, as is happening in Newham.

"Our research has found that religious beliefs are important to many people with mental health problems and we have looked in depth at how religious and spiritual beliefs and practices are sustaining and supportive. The situation is complex, because some people have negative experiences with religious communities, but positive findings include giving a sense of purpose and meaning to life, peace and comfort, inner spirituality, the support of others and the presence of God."

Forward in Faith is available at £7, plus 70p p&p, from the Sainsbury Centre for Mental Health, 134-138 Borough High Street, London SE1 1LB (020-7827 8352).

webTitle: Business: Napster plays the wooing game

fields.headline: Napster plays the wooing game
fields.standfirst:
Napster
More net news
fields.trailText: Napster yesterday gave details of a subscription plan, a week after its free service was ruled illegal, writes Jane Martinson.
fields.body:
Napster, the online song-swapping company, yesterday gave details a proposed subscription plan for users, a week after an appeals court ruled that its free service was illegal.

The move was worked out with Bertelsmann, the entertainment company, and given to journalists in a private briefing in San Francisco last night.

Napster, which faces closure for infringing copyrights, hopes that its proposals will convince the record industry and the financial community that it has a viable business model.

Sources close to the talks said that the plan was likely to consist of a monthly membership fee of between $2.95 and $9.95. An estimated 61m users have so far downloaded musicfrom Napster for free, which led to the legal action against the company.

Napster and Bertelsmann have spent the past six months trying to garner support for the plan from the other record labels. They hope that it can be used in any settlement discussions between the five major record labels that brought the lawsuit and Napster.

They have had little success. Even BMG, the record label owned by Bertelsmann, has not yet reached an agreement over possible compensation.

The two sides have held settlement discussions with a court-appointed mediator.

Analysts were expected to welcome the details of the alliance between Bertelsmann and Napster. The two companies announced their plans to work together on a new service last October, following judge Marilyn Hall Patel's initial ruling last summer.

As part of the deal, the German company agreed to lend Napster about $50m to finance operations and to work on a viable, subscription service.

The agreement upset both Napster users and the the recording industry, which continued to push its case through the courts.

Yesterday's announcement was made at a joint briefing by Andreas Schmidt, CEO of the Bertelsmann subsidiary set up to oversee the Napster cooperation, Shawn Fanning, Napster's founder, and Hank Barry, the company chief executive.

Judge Patel is expected to release her new ruling within weeks. Napster has promised to appeal against the decision.

webTitle: Controls may stay on mobile call prices

fields.headline: Controls may stay on mobile call prices
fields.trailText: Price controls on the cost of calling mobile phones could be extended beyond 2002, writes David Teather.
fields.body:
Price controls on the cost of calling mobile phones - estimated to have have saved consumers £1bn over three years - could be extended beyond 2002, when they are due to end.

Regulator Oftel said it had launched an inquiry into the need for further price controls, taking into account the rapid growth of the sector - and in particular of the increase in text messaging.

The controls which affect only Britain's two most popular networks, Vodafone and BT Cellnet, may also be extended to Orange and One2One.

The consultation will focus on whether there are sufficient alternatives for consumers to avoid the fees charged by mobile networks for the handling of calls on their networks.

The most dramatic change in recent years has been the growth of SMS, or text messaging, which is charged at the rate of between 9p and 12p.

The consultation will look at the extent to which consumers are using SMS as a cheaper alternative to voice calls and whether the weight of text messaging is enough to force the networks to bring down the price of handling voice calls. Around 1.65bn text messages were sent across the four networks in the three months to last November.

Two-thirds of the cost of calling a mobile phone is charged by the network which terminates the call and the price is, consequently, not subject to usual competitive pressures.

Other means of avoiding the termination charge is to contain calls in a single network - calling an Orange phone from another Orange handset, for instance. The consultation will also look at the extent to which mobile users call back people on fixed lines to avoid the original caller incurring a large bill. David Edmonds, Oftel's director general, acknowledged that the market had grown significantly since the present price controls were introduced. "I want to establish whether competition has developed sufficiently to keep prices down when the current controls expire," he said.

A Vodafone spokesman said the company would fully cooperate with the inquiry. "We will be discussing ways that regulation could be relaxed, given the intense nature of competition in the market," he said. "Consumers are also much more aware of tarrif structures since the last controls were introduced."

BT Cellnet charges 12.5p a minute for calls terminating on its network, Vodafone charges 13.15p, Orange charges 15.2p and One2One, 16.78p. Callers will then pay the additional charge imposed by their own telecoms company.

The price controls were put in place in 1998 following an inquiry by the then monopolies and mergers commission - now the competition commission - which found prices were too high. At the time, Orange and One2One were excluded from the regulations due to their weaker position in the marketplace. But Orange, particularly, has gained on its larger rivals and now has 24% of the market - just behind BT Cellnet, which has 25%.

The consultation will not deal with third generation mobile technology, otherwise known as UMTS.

A spokesman for Marconi yesterday announced that chairman Sir Roger Hurn "had not been approached" to succeed Sir Iain Vallance in the same role at BT. Speculation about Sir Iain's early retirement has been circulating for months - despite repeated denials from BT.

webTitle: Billy Connolly's dogged cyber fight gets result

fields.headline: Billy Connolly's dogged cyber fight gets result
fields.trailText: The comedian has successfully wrested control of billyconnolly.com from a cybersquatter, writes Paul Kelso.www.billyconnolly.com
fields.body:
Heard the one about the Scottish comedian, the golden labrador stud and the professional cybersquatter? A bizarre introduction to a gag perhaps, but it is one that Billy Connolly may wish to add to his repertoire.

Yesterday the comedian successfully wrested control of the internet domain name www.billyconnolly.com from a cybersquatter who registered the name to advertise the stud services of his pedigree dog.

Connolly was distinctly unamused when he discovered the site - still live yesterday evening despite the ruling - carrying a picture of the pedigree golden labrador, full name Rougemar Billyconnolly, and the message "Available now for stud duty". The site had been registered by the dog's owner, Anthony Stewart, a trader in internet domain names.

"Here I am getting ready to launch myself on the world wide web to announce my availability for stud duty and out of the blue Billy Connolly, the banjo playing, ex-shipyard welder from Partick, the well-known Glasgow suburb, wants to take possession of my web address, billyconnolly.com," the site says. "I know it's a dog's life, but is there no justice in this world?"

Connolly took the case to the UN-controlled World Intellectual Property Organisation, which ruled yesterday that the 58-year-old comedian had the right to control the name.

Connolly claimed he had established common law rights during a career spanning nearly 30 years. He said that sales of Billy Connolly merchandise since 1994 were estimated at £175,000.

Mr Stewart originally offered to hand over the domain name in return for a five-year supply of Connolly's Tickety-Boo Tea and a press release to announce the agreement. But he then rejected an offer of £202.80, the cost of buying the tea bags commercially, and also knocked back an increased offer of £750 for the name. Mr Stewart increased his demand to £7,500, plus legal expenses.

David Perkins, a member of the ruling panel, said Mr Stewart had intended to "tarnish and damage" Connolly's name, and rejected the suggestion that the website could be named after the dog, whose kennel name was Rougemar Pindar. He ruled that Mr Stewart was using the name in bad faith, and that he was in the business of buying and selling celebrity domain names.

The UN introduced the system of control to prevent "cybersquatters" profiteering by buying celebrity domain names for a few dollars and selling them for vast sums.

The UN introduced the system of control to prevent "cybersquatters" profiteering by buying celebrity domain names for a few dollars and selling them for vast sums.

fields.headline: Bondholders block Telewest-UPC deal
fields.trailText: The structure of the key shareholdings in cable company Telewest was thrown into doubt yesterday, writes David Teather.
fields.body:
The structure of the key shareholdings in cable company Telewest was thrown into doubt yesterday when the complex asset swap among investors outlined last June ran into trouble.

The agreement would have left Europe's largest cable network, United Pan-Europe Communications, with 25% of Telewest. But the deal has been blocked by bondholders in UPC's parent company, UnitedGlobalCom.

Under the terms of the deal UGC would have bought the 25% stake in Telewest at present held by John Malone's Liberty Media for $200m (£138.5m) and 75m UGC shares.

The bondholders were able to block the deal because Liberty would in effect seize control of UGC, increasing Mr Malone's growing influence in the global cable market. Mr Malone is keen to consolidate his cable interests in Europe into a single company.

The plan was then for UGC to pass the Telewest stake to UPC in return for shares. The agreement would have left UGC with 61% in UPC. A spokesman for UPC described the obstacles to the deal as a "technical issue" which would be resolved shortly. He said it is not yet certain whether UPC or UGC will end up as Telewest's largest investor.

A spokesman for Telewest said the agreement was a matter for shareholders. The other large investor in Telewest is Microsoft, with 23.6%. The latter, trying to build a bridgehead in the digital television market, also owns 8% of UPC.

Analysts said the delays were not positive for UPC, which is struggling with €7bn of debt. The company raised €4bn last year to pay for a digital upgrade of its networks.

Based in Amsterdam, UPC has interests in 17 European countries. At the end of last year it had 6.5m cable TV subscribers. It also had 358,000 telephony customers and 343,000 internet users, along with a satellite business in central Europe delivering TV services to 474,000 subscribers.

Telewest yesterday named the American electronics firm, Scientific-Atlanta, as the company's second supplier of digital set-top boxes. The cable company will hope to avoid the situation it found itself in last year, when its then sole supplier, Pace Micro Technology, ran into supply problems.

fields.headline: BT staff slate management
fields.trailText: 3.45pm: BT's annual attitude survey has revealed its employees are dissatisfied with senior management, reports Julia Day.
fields.body:
City analysts are not the only ones criticising BT's senior management and demanding more information on its strategy.

Now the telecom giant's own employees have rounded on the company.

In the latest annual employee attitude survey, BT workers overwhelmingly demanded better leadership and more information on the strategic direction of the company.

There was an 11% drop in the number of employees who said they felt proud to work at BT.

Only 58% of respondents to the latest survey felt proud to a BT employee.

Sixty-seven per cent of the company's 131,000 workforce responded to the survey, an increase on the 63% response rate the year before.

The focus of most of the employees' dissatisfaction stemmed from BT's leadership and senior management style.

But nine out of 10 respondents said they were committed to the company's vision.

The City is losing patience with BT chief executive Sir Peter Bonfield and chairman Sir Iain Vallance.

BT has committed itself to a convoluted break-up plan, including a partial flotation of BT Wireless.

But the flotation now looks to be a bad move in the light of Orange's recent flotation flop.

Credit rating agency Standard & Poor's has threatened to cut BT's rating and BT has strenuously denied rumours Sir Iain has recently been close to resigning.

fields.headline: ASA slams C4 ads
fields.trailText: 8.30am: The watchdog ruled a poster for Cutting Edge could have encouraged people to commit suicide, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Channel 4 has been condemned as irresponsible after advertising regulators ruled a poster for its Cutting Edge series could have encouraged people to commit suicide.

The Advertising Standards Authority ruled that an advertisement showing the lower legs and feet of a person looking down over the edge of a tall building, alongside the words, "Go on. Jump" was irresponsible.

The ASA received several complaints about the poster, which advertised a documentary about the extreme sport of base jumping.

Anti-suicide charity the Samaritans was one of the complainants.

"We lodged a complaint because we felt this ad was highly misleading," said a spokeswoman for the Samaritans.

"It was a blatant referral to suicide and that can lead to copycat cases."

Another complaint came from Camden Council's assistant director for housing, who said the poster was offensive because a tower block near the one shown had been used in three recent suicides.

But Channel 4 said it did not believe it had behaved irresponsibly.

It said it had made every effort to ensure the poster conveyed clearly that the programme was about base jumping and not suicide by replacing the title of the show, Seconds to Impact, with the line "confessions of a base jumper".

The ASA also upheld a complaint against Honda cars.

A member of the public complained a national press advert promising "the opportunity of a lifetime" was misleading because it promised more reductions that were in fact available.

Honda has since withdrawn the advert.

Separately, the ASA has referred Planet Telecom, a company that specialises in sending unsolicited faxes on a variety of subjects to other organisations, to the Office of Fair Trading.

The watchdog has called on the OFT to take action against Planet Telecom under the control of misleading advertisements regulations.

The decision follows repeated violations of the ASA's regulations by the Wigan-based company.

The first ruling was published three years ago after Planet Telecom sent out a fax headed "paedophiles in your neighbourhood".

The ASA concluded the fax condoned violence and was likely to cause serious or widespread offence.

"This sends out a clear message to those advertisers that do not abide by the rules of self-regulation.

"The ASA will, when necessary, resort to its ultimate sanction of referring advertisers to the OFT to ensure advertisements remain legal, decent, honest and truthful," said ASA director general Christopher Graham.

webTitle: Petrol price cut in the pipeline

fields.headline: Petrol price cut in the pipeline
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the petrol crisis
Special report: budget 2001
fields.trailText: The government today announced measures to ensure that all motorists would benefit from a temporary fuel duty cut on budget day on March 7.
fields.body:
The government today announced measures to ensure that all motorists would benefit from a temporary fuel duty cut on budget day on March 7.

The Treasury said a cut in environmentally friendly ultra-low sulphur petrol, signalled by Chancellor Gordon Brown his pre-budget report last November, would be matched by a similar, temporary reduction in the duty on unleaded fuel.

The financial secretary to the Treasury, Stephen Timms, said the measure was being introduced because independent petrol retailers had been unable to guarantee that ULSP would be available nationwide at all their outlets by budget day.

"One of the reasons we are doing it is to ensure there is no competitive disadvantage for independent retailers," Mr Timms told a news conference at the Treasury.

The duty cut in unleaded fuel will run until June 14.

In the pre-budget report, Mr Brown indicated that he was prepared to cut the duty on ULSP - which has already been reduced by 1p since October - by a further 2p, subject to consultation.

It was part of a carefully crafted package drawn up by the chancellor to assuage the concerns of the fuel tax protesters without appearing to give too much ground.

He said at the time that he expected ULSP to account for 100% of the market this year, with motorists "using any petrol station in Britain" able to benefit from a duty cut on budget day.

Mr Timms said that at a meeting today which he attended with the transport minister, Lord Macdonald, the major oil companies had said they were on track to meet their target to supply ULSP at all their filling stations by the end of March.

However, the independent retailers, who met ministers separately, said they would need more time to ensure that ULSP was available at all their 5,000 outlets - many serving remote areas - because of constraints on the capacity of UK oil refineries.

Mr Timms said: "The government's objectives are to ensure that everyone should be able to share the environmental benefits of ULSP, and the benefits of the duty cut associated with it."

fields.headline: Go in, City says. And never mind the bottom line
fields.standfirst:
When it comes to the single currency, business support depends upon what line they're in

Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: When it comes to the single currency, business support depends upon what line they're in.
fields.body:
The City yesterday gave a strong vote in favour of joining the euro even though Britain's largest companies say it will make relatively little difference to profits.

The European currency is seen as beneficial by 63% of larger companies and 68% of British fund managers, in an annual survey for the information group Reuters.

The main advantage of joining the euro lay in its impact on the cost of financing and valuations, said respondents to the survey compiled by Tempest Consultants.

A quarter of big companies questioned said being in the system would reduce financing costs while only 3% thought it would make things more difficult. For 42%, euro entry would enhance company valuations while 4% thought they would be reduced.

Fund managers were bullish about prospects of improving sales and profits through the euro: 54% said joining would improve sales and 45% said it would help profits.

The study shows views on the euro vary between business sectors. Car and component manufacturers were firmly positive while electricity and metals firms were negative. Those responses reflected different sectors' existing exposure to the European currency, said Stephen Parker, chief executive at Tempest.

Larger companies were already increasingly thinking outside their national boundaries when communicating with financial audiences. Respondents said they planned to spend far more time talking to foreign fund managers and brokers.

"Together with fund management groups' views on the euro and the declining role of UK equities in global portfolios, this is leading to the adoption of a more international investment perspective," Tempest said.

The UK equities market has underperformed other European markets and now accounts for less than 10% of a neutral global portfolio. Tempest argues it is difficult to see how the British market can stand alone.

"All three parts of our Equity Triangle [quoted companies, fund managers and sell-side analysts] are telling us that the future of UK equities market is inextricably linked to the global market place and to a European equity market in particular. These are important signals for regulatory authorities and stock exchanges alike - in the UK, in continental Europe and elsewhere."

The Reuters survey was carried out over three months with the participation of 254 companies representing 94% of the £1.7bn equity market value of the 350 largest quoted companies in Britain.

In the "Reuters' Oscars", best individual fund manager award, according to finance directors, went to Donald Tosh of Morley Fund Management. The best analyst research team, fund managers said, was the pharmaceuticals group at Credit Suisse First Boston.

Fund managers judged the best broker research came from Merrill Lynch. Finance; finance directors granted the investment bank accolade to Goldman Sachs.

 The 2001 Reuters Survey of UK Larger Companies, Tempest Consultants, 138 Cheapside, London EC2V 6LX, £250

fields.headline: Euro's approach catches French napping
fields.standfirst:
Schoolgirl spearheads ad campaign as countdown to single currency gathers pace

Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: With less than a year to go before the demise of the franc, the French government has launched a massive campaign to publicise the euro.
fields.body:
With less than a year to go before the demise of the franc, the French government has launched a massive campaign to publicise the euro amid a rash of surveys warning that the economy could suffer from ill-preparedness for the coming of the common currency.

"There is no need for alarm quite yet, but individuals, and most particularly companies, need to radically speed up their preparations," said the finance minister, Laurent Fabius, unveiling the multimillion franc campaign that will run in the press, on billboards and on television until September.

"If companies think there's plenty of time between now and January 2002, they are making a big mistake. They will need between three and six months to get their systems ready and tested. There is no time at all to be wasted."

One finance ministry survey this week showed that 43% of France's smaller companies, including many shops, had not yet made any special preparations for the euro, which will fully replace the franc at midnight on February 17 next year.

"Scales, cash registers, computer programs, credit card machines, accounting systems, pay slips, everything has to be converted," said Philippe Giraud-Sauveur of the French Banking Association. "If everyone leaves it till the last minute, as it looks like they're planning on doing, we're heading for disaster."

To help get France ready, the government is relying on the unlikely figure of Lise, a fresh-faced 12-year-old, to spearhead the campaign . Mr Fabius described her as "the daughter, the granddaughter, even the great granddaughter of every Frenchman and every Frenchwoman".

Maurice Levy, chairman of the Publicis advertising agency which created the campaign, said the infectiously cheerful adolescent was chosen from 100 other hopefuls "because she looked just like all the others". His colleague Daniel Robert said Lise's main rival for the role was rejected because she was too pretty.

In her first 45-second appearance on French TV channels, a gaily bouncing Lise leads viewers through a series of signposted tunnels representing the major steps en route to the euro: in July 2001, she chirrups against a sunkissed summer holiday background, bank accounts will be in euros and "we will all be counting together".

By December 31, she continues, surrounded by piles of brightly wrapped Christmas presents, "everyone will be able to pay in euro coins and banknotes". And next February, Lise concludes with a warm and reassuring smile, "there'll be be just one currency - the euro".

The campaign punchline, accompanied by an unpleasantly strident electric guitar chord, runs: "The euro. Together, it'll be easier."

That slogan, together with the ever-smiling Lise, also features on the cover of the official Transition Guide to the Euro, 10m copies of which will be distributed throughout the year, and on a special government website, www.euro.gouv.fr.France has made surprisingly little fuss about losing the franc, which has been a currency in its own right since the day Jean Le Bon was ransomed from his English captors in 1360 for 3m gold crowns and declared "franc des Anglais", or free of the English.

The last franc-denominated coin was struck at the national mint in Pessac, near Bordeaux, some 18 months ago and the last banknote was printed in May last year. Neither event was marked by screaming headlines or rabid editorials. But the switch to the euro may not go as smoothly as that might lead the government to suspect.

"No one has explained any thing to us, not the government, nor the union, nor the bank," complained Nicole from behind the counter of Tribollet butcher's shop on the rue Montorgeuil in central Paris. "I have a very bad feeling about this. It's all going to be a monumental mess."

The government is counting on at least one positive side effect of the euro's introduction: the expected conversion, in the early weeks of 2002, at the height of the New Year sales, of hundreds of millions of francs stashed away in cupboards and under beds.

webTitle: Fake notes allow sneak peek at euro

fields.headline: Fake notes allow sneak peek at euro
fields.standfirst: Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: Almost 200,000 euro banknotes will be distributed across the 12 countries which have signed up to the single currency in the next few weeks, but they will be absolutely worthless.
fields.body:
Almost 200,000 euro banknotes will be distributed across the 12 countries which have signed up to the single currency in the next few weeks, but they will be absolutely worthless.

The notes look the part - they are exactly the same size, colour and feel and are printed on the same paper as the real thing - but they are in fact dummies produced to help Europe's blind and deaf and those with learning disabilities to get to grips with the new currency ahead of its official launch in January.

A full set of seven banknotes ranges from the largest denomination 500 euros, worth around £300, to the smallest five euro note, worth about £3.

Special precautions have been taken to thwart forgers. The words "no value" are printed in bright red ink, each note is individually numbered and the system of watermarking and the magnetic strip expected to be unveiled in September are missing.

In the spring equally elaborate mock-ups of euro coins will be distributed to people with "sensory and intellectual disabilities".

The real roll-out exercise will involve shipping some 15bn genuine banknotes and 56bn coins to banks and retail outlets across the continent culminating in "E-day" on January 1, 2002.

fields.headline: Unit trusts and investment trusts
fields.trailText: Unit trusts and investment trusts which invest in the stock market and can produce good returns are an alternative to Isas. Again, the risk that the investment may fall in value makes them a bad idea if you only have a few years to save, or do not have any alternative investments to rely upon should you wish to cash in the Isa at a time of lower value. Longer term investing should ensure any short-term losses are evened out. On the downside, the fees and charges can seem high and the returns are not tax free.

fields.headline: Brown spurns call to spend
fields.standfirst:
No Budget 'giveaway' despite £18bn surplus

Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: Chancellor Gordon Brown was last night facing down the growing pressure to abandon Labour's plans for a cautious pre-election Budget after the last set of figures before his annual fiscal package on March 7 showed the government on course for a record surplus of up to £18bn this year.
fields.body:
Chancellor Gordon Brown was last night facing down the growing pressure to abandon Labour's plans for a cautious pre-election Budget after the last set of figures before his annual fiscal package on March 7 showed the government on course for a record surplus of up to £18bn this year.

Official data released yesterday showed surging tax receipts, and a failure of Whitehall departments to spend cash allocated to them by the treasury left the government £17bn in the black with only two months of the current financial year remaining.

As recently as November, Mr Brown was forecasting a surplus for the whole 2000-01 financial year of just £10bn, but City analysts said last night this estimate now looked wildly pessimistic and the surplus would surpass last year's £15bn.

They added that the size of Mr Brown's war chest - which excludes the £22.5bn from selling off mobile phone licences - looked certain to dwarf the modest package of targeted tax cuts planned for the Budget.

But officials insisted that there would be no back-tracking on the chancellor's hardline stance. The treasury said there would be no irresponsible pre-election giveaway that might risk a repeat of the boom-bust cycles of the past.

Mr Brown is thought to have pencilled in tax cuts worth £3bn over two years on top of the increases in pensions and cuts in fuel duties announced in November, fearing that a more expansionary set of measures would put the stability of the economy at risk.

However, with all parties gearing up for an election in April or May, the Conservatives and Liberal Democrats seized on yesterday's data to attack the chancellor's tax and spending plans.

Matthew Taylor, the Liberal Democrat treasury spokesman, said: "The public finance figures out today confirm that Brown's war chest is overflowing. It's hardly surprising - spending under Labour has been below even Conservative plans. The chancellor should use the Budget to boost schools, hospitals and pensions instead of following the Tory agenda of tax cuts."

The shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, said any Budget surplus was a "people's surplus". "It has only arisen because Gordon Brown has over-taxed British people," he said. "If the chancellor can afford to cut taxes in the Budget he should do so, but people will know he will only be giving back a tiny proportion of the taxes he has already taken."

Figures released jointly by the Treasury and Office for National Statistics showed that the public sector was in surplus in January by £11.2bn, taking the cumulative total to £16.7bn in the first 10 months of the financial year.

Departmental spending on salaries and running costs picked up this year but was outstripped by the increase in tax revenues, boosted by the fall in unemployment and higher consumer spending.

The size of the Treasury's surplus is also being affected by a continued shortfall in capital spending. In the 1999-2000 financial year spending on the infrastructure stood at £3.5bn, less than the Conservatives were spending during their last year in power before 1997.

Amid concerns about the decaying fabric of the public realm, Mr Brown authorised an increase to £7bn this year, but in the first 10 months of the year only £2. 2bn has been spent. Even if last year's surge in capital spending in February and March is repeated, the figure would only rise to around £4.5bn.

Geoffrey Dicks, chief economist at the Royal Bank of Scotland, said: "If February and March pan out as per last year, the surplus will be £18bn, way above pre-Budget estimates."

A Treasury spokesman said last night: "The chancellor has said many times over many years that he is not going to repeat the mistakes of the late 1980s and take long-term decisions about the public finances on the basis of short term fluctuations in revenue.

"Because of the tough decisions this government has been prepared to take we are now building a virtuous circle of falling debt, lower interest rates, lower debt repayments and a stronger economy, releasing more resources for public services. The chancellor will do nothing which puts this hard-won stability at risk."

Mr Portillo said the Conservatives would offer "sustainable tax cuts" over and above any changes announced in the Budget. "This is because we plan to keep the growth of government spending within what the nation can afford, whereas Labour plan to increase government spending faster than the economy is growing."

webTitle: UN backs use of cheap generic anti-Aids drugs

fields.headline: UN backs use of cheap generic anti-Aids drugs
fields.standfirst: Special report: Aids
fields.trailText: The UN is preparing to challenge the multinational drug companies' control over HIV and Aids treatments in developing countries by encouraging a far wider use of cheaper, generic alternatives.
fields.byline: Peter Capella in Geneva and James Meikle
fields.body:
The UN is preparing to challenge the multinational drug companies' control over HIV and Aids treatments in developing countries by encouraging a far wider use of cheaper, generic alternatives.

The organisation, frustrated by slow progress in brokering discounts between pharma ceutical giants and countries threatened by social and economic chaos because of Aids, is ready to back states such as Brazil, Thailand and India where national laws allow them to override drug patents in cases of dire emergency.

The new gloves-off approach, outlined by the UN's secretary general, Kofi Annan, is likely to be widely welcomed by aid agencies. It comes as 42 drug companies begin a court case to stop South Africa importing generic versions of the life-enhancing drugs it so desperately needs. The United States is meanwhile preparing to challenge Brazil's attitude towards drug patents in the World Trade Organisation.

Mr Annan, in his report to the general assembly's special session on HIV and Aids in New York in June, says that the "equitable and affordable" provision of life saving treatments is a cornerstone of the worldwide battle against Aids.

Although some progress has been made in price reductions by big companies, the UN chief says more needs to be done through other measures such as "tiered" pricing between rich and poor countries, subsidies by the public and private sector, and "the effec tive use of health safeguards in trade agreements".

Governments must bring their "power and authority" to bear in fighting the "most formidable development challenge of our time", he says.

Mr Annan praises Brazil, where reported Aids deaths have been reduced by a quarter. "With a rights-based approach to care, together with local production of generic anti-retrovirals in some countries, coverage of patients is increasing in Brazil, Argentina, Chile and Uruguay, where HIV-positive people are living longer, positive lives."

His report makes a stark case for affordable treatment and care. In many African states, more than half today's 15-year-olds will die from HIV/Aids if present rates of infection continue. Only adults who escape HIV infection can expect to survive to middle and old age.

UNAids, the agency set up to combat the disease, says it supports Oxfam and Médecins sans Frontières, which have been highly critical of drug companies' pricing policies.

A UNAids initiative to improve access to drugs and care attracted 29 applications involving generic products but the emphasis until recently appeared to concentrate on brokering discounts with five major pharmaceutical companies. The discounts have only been taken up in Rwanda, Senegal and Uganda.

UNAids insists it is sticking by a multiple approach to tackling epidemics, but its call for the "reinforcement and use" of health safeguards indicates a big change of gear.

fields.headline: Theatre, West Bank-style
fields.standfirst: The roads are blocked. The venue has been shelled. The children in the audience are mourning
fields.trailText: The roads are blocked. The venue has been shelled. The children in the audience are mourning.
fields.body:
'I feel there is no use in telling anyone what has been happening here tonight. Since 4.30 we have been under heavy shelling. We tried to hide my nieces behind a cupboard but they are babies and cannot sit still. Guess what - we could see our houses being shelled on Israeli TV." Marina Barham of Inad Theatre in Beit Jala on the West Bank was sending emails to friends about what was happening to her family. One of those friends was Elyse Dodgson, director of the Royal Court's international department. And that is why, with actor Linda Bassett, director Stephen Daldry and others involved in my play Far Away, I was reading Barham's messages while we were rehearsing at the Royal Court.

As well as working with playwrights and directors in Russia, Uganda, India and Brazil, the Royal Court has a longstanding connection with two theatres in the Occupied Territories, Al Kasaba and Inad. Al Kasaba started over 20 years ago in East Jerusalem. Inad - "stubborn" - Theatre is a smaller and newer community theatre near Bethlehem.

In 1995 Dodgson and Daldry visited Israeli and Palestinian theatres and met George Ibrahim, director of Al Kasaba. He introduced them to a young director, Raeda Ghazaleh, who had learned Hebrew to get a theatre training not available on the West Bank. She was invited to the Royal Court, where she worked as Stephen Daldry's assistant on Ron Hutchinson's play Rat in the Skull.

Over the next few years Palestinian playwrights came to the Royal Court and the Royal Court sent Stephen Jeffreys, April de Angelis and Phyllida Lloyd to work with young writers in Bethlehem, Ramallah, Nablus, Hebron and Jericho. The Royal Court encouraged David Hare to visit the area, which led to his writing Via Dolorosa, a monologue based on the troubled politics of the region.

Meanwhile, because access to Jerusalem was becoming increasingly difficult for Palestinians, George Ibrahim decided to move Al Kasaba to Ramallah. He took over a disused cinema and planned a 250-seat theatre, a cinema and a cafe. Ghazaleh and some friends had started Inad when she was a student, and the group moved into an empty garage in Beit Jala. By 1999 Inad had converted the garage into a theatre space and Al Kasaba opened its new theatre last summer. But now both theatres are under threat.

Inad has been concentrating particularly on working with children. It has a mobile theatre - a truck that it takes to schools, refugee camps, community centres and village squares, with five different plays for children as young as four or as old as 18. Inad's building was shelled on three nights and it is difficult for the truck to get about because of road closures. Barham writes about taking the truck to Hebron, where 1,500 children were waiting - looking for dirt tracks to avoid blocked roads, climbing over barriers of rocks and earth carrying sets and equipment, being turned back by shooting. But despite the difficulties they played to 31,000 children between September and the end of the year.

At first, she writes, "We thought after a week of violence it would be impossible to perform, since in our culture we cannot have any entertainment while people are in mourning." But to their surprise schools asked them to come. "The headmasters said their students are suffering from traumas and were stunned by what was happening. They felt we could do something." She describes how the children were able to smile and laugh after being in shock, and how discussions after the shows helped them to share their fears.

Al Kasaba has kept open despite the difficulties. People have been coming to the centre asking the actors to make theatre about what has been going on. Every day monologues have been performed about people's experiences, and some are being formed into a theatre piece. Barham's emails are being adapted for performance at a festival at Amman in Jordan, and Rose Fenton and Lucy Neal hope to bring both pieces to London for the London International Festival of Theatre this summer.

But because there is now so much unemployment, with many Palestinians not allowed to travel to work, there is little money for theatre. Ibrahim stopped charging for performances, but it is becoming impossible to continue. The schools that have supported Inad's play can no longer afford to do so. Both theatres are in danger of having to stop work.

So this is why we are doing an extra performance of Far Away tomorrow at the Albery Theatre. All the money from ticket sales - normal price - will go to Al Kasaba and Inad.

As I write, the latest news from Barham is that after a relatively quiet few weeks, the Israelis set up tanks in Beit Jala a few days ago, one opposite the theatre. From 8.30pm till midnight on February 13 there was shooting and shelling. Next morning Marina and her friends made jokes about Valentine's day and bought each other flowers. They tried to perform in Hebron that day, but the roads were blocked.

 The extra performance of Far Away is tomorrow at 6pm at the Albery Theatre, London WC2 (020-7369 1740).

fields.headline: Newborns blessed with perfect pitch
fields.trailText: All babies may be born with perfect pitch - that astonishing, one-in-10,000 ability to hit the right note unaccompanied, rare even in professional musicians.
fields.body:
All babies may be born with perfect pitch - that astonishing, one-in-10,000 ability to hit the right note unaccompanied, rare even in professional musicians.

Puzzlingly, according to Jenny Saffran, director of the infant learning laboratory of the University of Wisconsin, babies do not seem to have relative pitch, the capacity to remember the intervals between notes. Instead, they seem to have an innate capacity to recognise the precise number of cycles per second of a sound.

"We don't know when the flip happens," she told the American Association for the Advancement of Science. "I tested eight-month-olds and adults, and eight-month-olds seemed to be processing absolute pitches, not relative pitches and adults seemed to be processing relative pitches more than absolute. When that switch happens we don't yet know."

Professor Saffran had already shown that babies acted as little statisticians: on the way to learning to listen and speak, they made sense of sounds by looking for consistent patterns. She devised a test to measure whether infants and adults recognised tunes by absolute or relative pitch. The infants all showed the same talent that distinguished Mozart, Nat King Cole and Menuhin. She played a three-minute stream of bell-like tones, and followed that with segments which were identical in relative pitch but transposed to a different key.

The adults recognised the similar "tunes". Eight-month-old babies were not able to comment on the sounds they heard, but they gave their opinion by showing the intensity with which they listened.

Psychologists had long ago learned to use a baby's attention span as a measure of novelty. Babies attend to something new, and show much less interest in the familiar.

"We certainly know that infants are not blank slates, and that they enter the world with a structure or hardwiring that helps them learn," Prof Saffran said. "But what's interesting here is we may not have dedicated hardware just for language. The structure is probably general to many complex forms of learning, including music."

Babies probably lost their uncanny ability to remember the precise frequency of a sound because it wasn't important to them in language - unless that language was Chinese, Vietnamese or Thai.

"Absolute pitch is too fine a form of categorisation," she said. "If that is all we knew, we couldn't generalise any of the sounds we hear. If we only used absolute pitch as adults, we couldn't understand that 'happy birthday' in two different pitches is the same song, or that the word 'cup' spoken by a man or a woman, is the same word."

The ability was more likely to be preserved in very young children who started learning music early on. Most people start learning musical instruments at around the age of eight. The musicians in her sample who did have perfect pitch had started playing at around four years old.

webTitle: New clue to Star Trek version of the universe

fields.headline: New clue to Star Trek version of the universe
fields.standfirst: Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: For the first time, astronomers have indirect evidence that there could be billions of earthlike planets in the galaxy, many of them home to forms of extraterrestrial life.
fields.body:
For the first time, astronomers have indirect evidence that there could be billions of earthlike planets in the galaxy, many of them home to forms of extraterrestrial life.

The clue to a Star Trek version of the universe, according to Norman Murray of the University of Toronto, can be read in the distinctive light from more than half the stars in a sample of the galaxy. If there was iron in the starlight, he argued, there could be rocky planets wheeling around it.

"If there are bodies in orbit around these stars, at least the probability that there is life - similar to what we consider to be life - has to be more likely than it would have been before we discovered this evidence," Professor Murray said. "It is one more indication that life may be common in the galaxy."

Since 1995, using subtle observational techniques, astronomers have detected the presence of 55 planets, all the size of Jupiter or bigger, orbiting around faraway suns.

But all of them would be vast balls of gas, and all of them were very close to their parent stars, which was why they could be detected. In such star systems, there would be no room for rocky planets like Earth, Mars and Venus, on which water could flow and an atmosphere could form. And such rocky planets would be too small to see across the light years of space.

But Prof Murray told the American Association for the Advancement of Science in San Francisco that there was another way to look for evidence of earth-like planets.

Bodies such as Earth and Mars were about 30% iron. Meteors and asteroids were about 20% iron. Comets were mostly water, but even they contained iron, and crashed into the sun at the rate of at least one a day.

In the life of a solar system, lumps of rock and iron equal to the mass of a planet or two would be swept into the outer envelope of the sun.

So, he said, those stars which were anaemic - with a low signature of iron in their light - probably had no orbiting rocky planets. Although iron is forged in the thermonuclear cores of stars, the only way it would appear in the outer sheath would be as dust attracted from its orbiting companions.

He studied the spectra of 640 sun-like stars, and found that 466 of them had at least half a planet's worth of iron in their atmospheres. There are about 100bn stars in the Milky Way, and there are about 100bn galaxies in the observable universe.

If even a small percentage had rocky planets in the "habitable zone" near enough to the parent star for water to remain liquid, that means potentially a large number of homes for life.

Prof Murry said: "Up to this point, it's a complete unknown. The methods used to detect planets cannot detect bodies of that mass, although that may well change. Up to this point there has been no indication. No, one other indication is that we haven't got any signals from somebody out there.

"We are just making this argument by analogy. It happened in our solar system. We see the same signature in these other solar systems. And we just conclude that that seems like a likely possibility, that those systems look like ours. Presumably you could have rocks without planets, but then the question would be how did they get on to the stars? In our solar system, they are perturbed by massive bodies."

He examined only a fraction of the galaxy, but he assumed that it resembled the rest of the galaxy. "I'm just making a statistical argument," he said. "Probably more than half have accreted this material, and therefore probably more than half of the stars in our galaxy have accreted that material. The number of stars in our galaxy is about 100bn."
fields.bodyText: For the first time, astronomers have indirect evidence that there could be billions of earthlike planets in the galaxy, many of them home to forms of extraterrestrial life. The clue to a Star Trek version of the universe, according to Norman Murray of the University of Toronto, can be read in the distinctive light from more than half the stars in a sample of the galaxy. If there was iron in the starlight, he argued, there could be rocky planets wheeling around it. "If there are bodies in orbit around these stars, at least the probability that there is life - similar to what we consider to be life - has to be more likely than it would have been before we discovered this evidence," Professor Murray said. "It is one more indication that life may be common in the galaxy." Since 1995, using subtle observational techniques, astronomers have detected the presence of 55 planets, all the size of Jupiter or bigger, orbiting around faraway suns. But all of them would be vast balls of gas, and all of them were very close to their parent stars, which was why they could be detected. In such star systems, there would be no room for rocky planets like Earth, Mars and Venus, on which water could flow and an atmosphere could form. And such rocky planets would be too small to see across the light years of space. But Prof Murray told the American Association for the Advancement of Science in San Francisco that there was another way to look for evidence of earth-like planets. Bodies such as Earth and Mars were about 30% iron. Meteors and asteroids were about 20% iron. Comets were mostly water, but even they contained iron, and crashed into the sun at the rate of at least one a day. In the life of a solar system, lumps of rock and iron equal to the mass of a planet or two would be swept into the outer envelope of the sun. So, he said, those stars which were anaemic - with a low signature of iron in their light - probably had no orbiting rocky planets. Although iron is forged in the thermonuclear cores of stars, the only way it would appear in the outer sheath would be as dust attracted from its orbiting companions. He studied the spectra of 640 sun-like stars, and found that 466 of them had at least half a planet's worth of iron in their atmospheres. There are about 100bn stars in the Milky Way, and there are about 100bn galaxies in the observable universe. If even a small percentage had rocky planets in the "habitable zone" near enough to the parent star for water to remain liquid, that means potentially a large number of homes for life. Prof Murry said: "Up to this point, it's a complete unknown. The methods used to detect planets cannot detect bodies of that mass, although that may well change. Up to this point there has been no indication. No, one other indication is that we haven't got any signals from somebody out there. "We are just making this argument by analogy. It happened in our solar system. We see the same signature in these other solar systems. And we just conclude that that seems like a likely possibility, that those systems look like ours. Presumably you could have rocks without planets, but then the question would be how did they get on to the stars? In our solar system, they are perturbed by massive bodies." He examined only a fraction of the galaxy, but he assumed that it resembled the rest of the galaxy. "I'm just making a statistical argument," he said. "Probably more than half have accreted this material, and therefore probably more than half of the stars in our galaxy have accreted that material. The number of stars in our galaxy is about 100bn."

webTitle: TV review: A kind of magic

fields.headline: A kind of magic
fields.trailText: When they open Paul up, "What first attracted you to the millionaire Paul Daniels?" will be found written on his heart. He is 20 years older than Debbie McGee, his second wife, former assistant and the only living woman to wear an off-the-shoulder pink basque at breakfast. She is blonder and he is balder than when they married in 1988, especially since she persuaded him to stop wearing a toupée. Now he is financing her dancer's dream of running her own company, Ballet Imaginaire.
fields.body:
When they open Paul up, "What first attracted you to the millionaire Paul Daniels?" will be found written on his heart. He is 20 years older than Debbie McGee, his second wife, former assistant and the only living woman to wear an off-the-shoulder pink basque at breakfast. She is blonder and he is balder than when they married in 1988, especially since she persuaded him to stop wearing a toupée. Now he is financing her dancer's dream of running her own company, Ballet Imaginaire.

To publicise it, he agreed to a documentary, When Louis Met Paul And Debbie (BBC 2). Very warily. Louis Theroux wanted to work the mechanical swan in Swan Lake, and who wouldn't? This bird was constructed to Paul's design and even Debbie was doubtful ("It's not got its feathers on or anything. We're not sure about it.") Personally, I was enthusiastic the moment I saw it swim backwards in rehearsal, adding a novel and much needed touch of comedy. Which is, no doubt, why Paul turned Louis down like a bedspread. "Not on the opening night, not on any night. Ask me why." "Why?" "You have a devious and distorted sense of humour."

He is clearly devoted to Debbie, and she is open, friendly and easy to get along with. She got along so well with Louis that Paul cracked a couple of jokes, sharp as pistol shots, and Louis said thoughtfully, "There is no such thing as a joke."

Discuss this nervously.

Debbie, in a slashed cat suit with lace inserts, cooked a farewell dinner and Louis ("I remember drinking a fair amount of wine") delivered a you're-my-best-friend-you-are tribute to their marriage. His best friend ground a tooth or two. "It upsets some journalists that we kind of get along. It upsets them that we're happy together. It's all the manky, miserable little people, who make the biggest shout and they're the ones who move into positions of power and try to destroy things for everybody else. Not you personally. Most people on the planet are very happy." Not, perhaps, him personally.

Nick Mirsky's excellent Blood On The Carpet series (BBC 2), a pearl in the trashcan of television, ended last night. The Sausage Wars was, as usual, both funny and poignant.

One day I went to O'Hagan's Sausage Shop ("No Artificial Anything") in Greenwich and it was gone, leaving not a sausage behind. I hadn't eaten sausages since the thought of crisp, cindery fingers of pig standing proud in a pyramid of mash kept me sane through piano lessons, but this was devastating. O'Hagan's sausages - pork and leek, pork and watercress, pork and chives, pork and fresh apples, great grandfather's very own, beef and Guinness, wild boar - were the stuff to give the troops. Or anyone you wanted to remember you with warmth and in their will.

Bill O'Hagan - you will note his emphasis on real ale - could sometimes be found in the pub, demonstrating on his ample person which bit of pig was best for his purpose. He was a journalist who, after exchanging a few words with the South African police about a marijuana sausage, left quite quickly for Britain, the heartland of the banger. What he found would have turned a less rubicund man ashen. "It was paste in a skin that wasn't natural and they tasted awful. It was disgraceful. I read the label and there were about 11 different chemical ingredients. Do we need that? No! We don't need bloody rubbish in our sausages! We want meat!" Bill, you think wistfully, should have stood for parliament. He stood for sausages, and began to make them to his own recipes in a back shed. His success was instant and enormous.

The rest of the story is so sad I can hardly bring myself to tell you. Martin Heap, a failed chef, whom Bill brought in to handle the business side, manoeuvred him out. Bill believes Martin used his recipes. Martin says loftily, "The idea that I would have to lift recipes from a South African sausage-maker is absolute nonsense."

What Bill had left was his name, and he refused to lend it to an inferior supermarket sausage. Martin was less picky. "If you have to make a process to adjust to try and target your product to taste as near to what you can do as possible, then I'm quite happy with that." Follow that? Martin, it occurred to you, is the natural politician.

Only pigs will be pleased with the outcome.

webTitle: GPs pushed to 'point of mutiny' over NHS reform plan

fields.headline: GPs pushed to 'point of mutiny' over NHS reform plan
fields.trailText: Doctors' leaders warned last night that GPs were on the point of mutiny against the government's NHS reform plan because ministers were persistently devaluing the work of family doctors and diverting resources into more glamorous hospital services.
fields.body:
Doctors' leaders warned last night that GPs were on the point of mutiny against the government's NHS reform plan because ministers were persistently devaluing the work of family doctors and diverting resources into more glamorous hospital services.

The GPs' concerns will be voiced in a manifesto prepared by the British Medical Association for distribution to all candidates in the forthcoming general election.

It will seek to identify a gap between the service patients should get from an effective NHS and the reality of what they can expect from the government's plans.

John Chisholm, chairman of the BMA's GPs committee, said the last straw had been what he called a Department of Health decision to limit the growth in numbers of GPs to 1% a year over the next nine years. This compared with a 4.5% annual growth target for numbers of hospital consultants.

The committee, representing 30,000 GPs in England and Wales, passed a vote of no confidence in the government last week in protest at an unex pected cut in expense allowances. It said the cut would reduce this year's increase in GPs' salaries to 2.3%.

In a survey of GPs in Scotland, 56% said their morale was low and 54% said they would not recommend a career in general practice to an able 16-year-old.

Simon Fradd, a deputy chairman of the GPs committee, said: "The only topic of conversation at GP meetings is retirement. Within five years it is going to be as hard to find a GP in the NHS as it already is to find an NHS dentist."

The GPs' leaders launched their attack on the eve of a separate protest by hospital doctors. Consultants are angry about the government's plans - to be unveiled by Alan Milburn, the health secretary, today - to give them a new contract, banning work in the private sector for seven years after qualification.

The GPs' irritation was fuelled by a medical workforce census carried out by the Department of Health. It showed that the number of GPs increased by 110 in the year to September - only just over a quarter of the annual growth rate of 400 set out in the NHS plan.

The average time available for a consultation was already only eight minutes and this would reduce to five minutes if the government went ahead with its guarantee that every patient should get an appointment within 48 hours.

Dr Fradd said: "In the past week we have reached a crisis point. The profession is being asked to go along with deception of the public."

A spokesman for the Department of Health said increasing numbers of doctors could not be delivered overnight. "This is not just about expanding numbers," the spokesman said. "It is also about changing the way they work. There are lots of minor tasks that GPs do that could be done by practice nurses."

fields.headline: Pass notes No 1824
fields.standfirst: Alistair McAlpine
fields.trailText: Alistair McAlpine
fields.body:
Age: 58.

Appearance: Billy Bunter after a lifetime of oysters and champagne.

Occupation: Gadfly.

Politics: Exceedingly complicated.

How so? McAlpine was treasurer of the Conservative party throughout Lady Thatcher's glorious reign, but loathed John Major and supported the Referendum party in 1997. He has now announced that he will be voting Labour at the next election.

He doesn't think much of Hague, then? "It kills me to say it, but Major is considerably superior to Hague. You can't shave your head and talk about the face of caring Conservatism."

Remind us what he thought of Major: "He was often at Chequers pretending to be a pair of curtains."

And is his judgment to be trusted? Almost certainly not - he thinks that Margaret Thatcher has a sense of humour.

What does he do these days? Travels between his homes in London and Monte Carlo, writes books on art and politics (he loves Machiavelli as well as Maggieavelli), and slags off the Tories.

He's worth a packet, presumably. Hard to say. There's family money - "Concrete Bob" McAlpine was his great-grandfather - but he lost a fortune on property ventures in Australia, and said he was "pretty much down to my last penny" before he started writing.

Life can be tough. It gets worse. He's just separated from his second wife, Romilly, despite the fact that she nursed him through a recent multiple heart bypass operation.

How heartless. Er, yes.

Explanation for his apparently bizarre behaviour: "Deep down inside me, I think there is anger, though I've no reason to be angry. Everybody has been nice to me all my life."

Clubs: Garrick, Carlton, Buck's, Pratt's, Beefsteak.

Parties: Almost as numerous.
