webTitle: Cable, satellite and digital pick of the day

fields.headline: Cable, satellite and digital pick of the day
fields.trailText: Gaslight | Live Tennis | Roswell
fields.byline: Paul Howlett, Simon Burnton, Richard Vine
fields.body:
Films

Gaslight (Thorold Dickinson, 1940) 1.45pm, TCM

Compared to the illustrious Hollywood remake four years later with Ingrid Bergman, this cheap British production is small beer, but the fact that MGM tried to have the negatives destroyed is a clue to how effective it is. Adapted from Patrick Hamilton's play, it stars Anton Walbrook as the murderer trying to drive innocent wife Diana Wynyard insane while he searches for a stash of rubies. Gripping performances, tautly directed, and just smothered in murky Victorian menace.

The Doors (Oliver Stone, 1991) 9pm, Studio

Oliver Stone flings open the doors of perception on to the strange, insane world of 60s rock, and that manic rider on the storm, Jim Morrison. Val Kilmer lives it as the singer-cum-mystic poet, notorious for lewd acts on and off stage and a relentless appetite for drugs and booze that left him dead at 27. Meg Ryan plays long-suffering girlfriend Pamela Courson; Kyle MacLachlan, Kevin Dillon and Frank Whaley are the other boys in the band.

The Outlaw Josey Wales (Clint Eastwood, 1976) 10pm, Sky Cinema

Eastwood directs and stars as Josey Wales, who, scarred by the brutal killing of his wife and child in the civil war, goes looking for revenge. Along the way he attracts a surrogate family of stragglers - notably Chief Dan George as a not-so-wise old Cheyenne - that gradually and comically undercuts the icy Man With No Name persona. Josey wreaks his vengeance and learns forgiveness, while Eastwood the director is equally adept with violent action and stunning landscape.

A Streetcar Named Desire (Elia Kazan, 1951) 1.45am, Sky Cinema

Marlon Brando's sweaty brute Stanley Kowalski hard up against fey, faded southern belle Blanche Dubois (Vivian Leigh). One of the big screen's enduring love-hate relationships, Oscar-laden and all hot and steamy from the Tennessee Williams play. Good support too from Kim Hunter and Karl Malden as Blanche's sister and suitor.

Paul Howlett

Sports

Live Tennis 12.30pm, British Eurosport
Martina Hingis, winner of last week's Qatar Open, is looking to stretch her early season lead at the top of the women's rankings at the Dubai Open, where she is top seed. Although her two main rivals, Lindsay Davenport and Venus Williams, have taken the week off, it will not be plain sailing, with Arantxa Sanchez-Vicario and Mary Pierce among her challengers. Scarily, it would be her 38th title. Simon Burnton

Drama

Roswell 8pm, Sky One
For the second series of this X-Files-meets-Dawson's-Creek show aspects of the original premise (alien students, shapeshifters, homework, angsty romance) are in place, but the scriptwriters have managed to fuse these elements into a fun space all its own. It's still pretty goofy stuff, but keep watching those skies.
Richard Vine

webTitle: FBI agent 'sent spies to their death'

fields.headline: FBI agent 'sent spies to their death' for cash and diamonds
fields.trailText: An FBI spycatcher was accused yesterday of helping to send American agents to their deaths by trading secrets to Russia for $1.4m, in one of the biggest security breaches in United States history.
fields.body:
An FBI spycatcher was accused yesterday of helping to send American agents to their deaths by trading secrets to Russia for $1.4m, in one of the biggest security breaches in United States history.

Robert Hanssen, a 56-year-old FBI veteran and father of six, faces charges stretching back more than 15 years, contained in a 110-page affidavit that details payments to Swiss bank accounts and in diamonds.

They include identifying former Soviet KGB double-agents who were working for the US.

"I think one of the worst parts is agents killed in the line of duty," said Louis Freeh, the FBI's director, who described the arrest as a coup for the bureau. "This case is a grave and tragic moment for us."

Asked if the case was one of the worst breaches of US security, Mr Freeh replied: "I would characterise it in that fashion."

Mr Hanssen, who has worked for the FBI for 27 years, was said to have been caught red-handed three days ago while leaving classified information at a "dead drop" in a park in northern Virginia. A payment of $50,000 was found nearby.

FBI agents said Mr Hanssen helped to cross-check and confirm intelligence sold by Aldrich Ames, thought to be the most damaging mole in CIA history. Ames, who was arrested six years ago, is serving a life sentence for revealing more than 100 operations and betraying about 30 agents, 10 of whom were executed.

Mr Hanssen, who is said to have offered his services to the former Soviet Union in 1985, gave details about KGB double-agents who had already been compromised by Ames.

"When these two KGB officials returned to Moscow they were tried and executed," said Mr Freeh. "Two were executed and one was in prison and later released."

John Ashcroft, the US attorney general, said: "The arrest should remind us that our free society is an international target in a dangerous world."

Mr Hanssen, known to his Russian handlers by the code-name Ramon, is accused of passing on secrets about US electronic surveillance techniques. The four handlers did not know where he worked because he was able to use his experience to prevent both sides from following him.

High security clearance and sensitive assignments gave Ramon, who is thought to have been operating alone, access to details of US security operations. In the end, KGB documents that fell into the hands of FBI-CIA officers investigating a mole in their ranks led them to Mr Hanssen, who was due to retire in two months.

While he was supposed to have been operating as a counter-espionage officer spying on the spies in New York and Washington he was actually working for the Soviet Union and then Russia.

"In short, the insider betrayed his trust," Mr Freeh said. "The FBI entrusted him with some of its most sensitive matters and the US government relied upon him for his service and integrity. The crimes alleged are an affront not only to his fellow FBI employees but to the American people."

The Russian embassy in Washington declined to comment, but a security services spokesman in Moscow suggested that publicity about the case was politically motivated.

Plato Cacheris, a prominent Washington lawyer who is representing Mr Hanssen, said: "He's quite upset, emotional. It's a serious matter, an FBI agent charged with espionage."

Mr Cacheris, whose previous clients have included Ames and Monica Lewinsky, spoke after Mr Hanssen appeared in court in Alexandria, Virginia, dressed in a black shirt and grey trousers. "We'll have to see what the quality of the case is. As far as I know he is of good character," Mr Cacheris said.

He said that Mr Hanssen, who has been working recently for the state department and is only the third FBI agent to have been accused of espionage, intends to plead not guilty. Mr Hanssen could face the death penalty if he is convicted.

Nancy Cullen, a neighbour of the Hanssen family, who live in a $300,000 (£200,000) split-level brick and cedar home in a Washington suburb, said: "We just can't believe it... a dog and six kids and a regular routine.

"Part of the routine that made us feel guilty was that every Sunday they would pack up the van and go to church. They're just a great family." Mr Hanssen's wife Bonnie teaches religious education part-time at a Catholic school.

"They didn't appear to be unusual in any way," said another neighbour. "They did nothing to raise a red flag or make me suspicious."

They include identifying former Soviet KGB double-agents who were working for the US. "This case is a grave and tragic moment for us." Asked if the case was one of the worst breaches of US security, Mr Freeh replied: "I would characterise it in that fashion." Mr Hanssen, who has worked for the FBI for 27 years, was said to have been caught red-handed three days ago while leaving classified information at a "dead drop" in a park in northern Virginia. A payment of $50,000 was found nearby. FBI agents said Mr Hanssen helped to cross-check and confirm intelligence sold by Aldrich Ames, thought to be the most damaging mole in CIA history. Ames, who was arrested six years ago, is serving a life sentence for revealing more than 100 operations and betraying about 30 agents, 10 of whom were executed. Mr Hanssen, who is said to have offered his services to the former Soviet Union in 1985, gave details about KGB double-agents who had already been compromised by Ames. "When these two KGB officials returned to Moscow they were tried and executed," said Mr Freeh. "Two were executed and one was in prison and later released." John Ashcroft, the US attorney general, said: "The arrest should remind us that our free society is an international target in a dangerous world." Mr Hanssen, known to his Russian handlers by the code-name Ramon, is accused of passing on secrets about US electronic surveillance techniques. The four handlers did not know where he worked because he was able to use his experience to prevent both sides from following him. High security clearance and sensitive assignments gave Ramon, who is thought to have been operating alone, access to details of US security operations. In the end, KGB documents that fell into the hands of FBI-CIA officers investigating a mole in their ranks led them to Mr Hanssen, who was due to retire in two months. While he was supposed to have been operating as a counter-espionage officer spying on the spies in New York and Washington he was actually working for the Soviet Union and then Russia. "In short, the insider betrayed his trust," Mr Freeh said. "The FBI entrusted him with some of its most sensitive matters and the US government relied upon him for his service and integrity. The crimes alleged are an affront not only to his fellow FBI employees but to the American people." The Russian embassy in Washington declined to comment, but a security services spokesman in Moscow suggested that publicity about the case was politically motivated. Plato Cacheris, a prominent Washington lawyer who is representing Mr Hanssen, said: "He's quite upset, emotional. It's a serious matter, an FBI agent charged with espionage." Mr Cacheris, whose previous clients have included Ames and Monica Lewinsky, spoke after Mr Hanssen appeared in court in Alexandria, Virginia, dressed in a black shirt and grey trousers. "We'll have to see what the quality of the case is. As far as I know he is of good character," Mr Cacheris said. He said that Mr Hanssen, who has been working recently for the state department and is only the third FBI agent to have been accused of espionage, intends to plead not guilty. Mr Hanssen could face the death penalty if he is convicted. Nancy Cullen, a neighbour of the Hanssen family, who live in a $300,000 (£200,000) split-level brick and cedar home in a Washington suburb, said: "We just can't believe it... a dog and six kids and a regular routine. "Part of the routine that made us feel guilty was that every Sunday they would pack up the van and go to church. They're just a great family." Mr Hanssen's wife Bonnie teaches religious education part-time at a Catholic school. "They didn't appear to be unusual in any way," said another neighbour. "They did nothing to raise a red flag or make me suspicious."

fields.headline: Portillo's centre-stage stance at conference
fields.standfirst: Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: Michael Portillo, the shadow chancellor, has taken a final step on his road to the centre of British politics by agreeing to speak at a fringe meeting of the Tory One Nation group.
fields.body:
Michael Portillo, the shadow chancellor, has taken a final step on his road to the centre of British politics by agreeing to speak at a fringe meeting of the Tory One Nation group.

Mr Portillo will speak on "Building the Responsible Society" at a fringe meeting organised by the umbrella group, Mainstream, at the Conservatives' Harrogate conference in early March.

Mainstream speakers in the past have been pro-European, and included Michael Hesletine and Kenneth Clarke. Mainstream was established to act as a coalition of a variety of centre-left organisations including the Tory Reform group and the Conservative group for Europe.

Mr Portillo's decision to speak on one of its platforms will be seen as a significant new staging post in his continuing political journey, and reflects his developing views on liberalism and Europe. But his aides played down the importance of his speech, insisting it would be a straightforward attack on the government's economic policies. They denied that any wider political import was to be attached to his decision to speak for the group.

Only two months ago, the shadow chancellor left the No Turning Back group, the Thatcherite caucus which was established during the 1980s. He resigned after he was attacked for supposedly refusing to do enough to counter the basic economic policies of the chancellor, Gordon Brown.

Reportedly he has also been recently questioned by Lady Thatcher, suggesting that her former protege may have lost his way.

Mr Portillo has insisted that no one can put a cigarette paper between himself and William Hague, and he has been careful not to become involved in any open policy split with the Tory leader. However, it is known that he has effectively broken contact with some of Mr Hague's key aides.

Mr Portillo faces a difficult political decision if Mr Hague loses the election badly, since he is unlikely to want to challenge for the leadership.

He may anyway feel that the Conservative leadership will be a more attractive option if the party loses a referendum on joining the single currency, since any such defeat would open the way for a more systematic review of Conservative policy.

The Mainstream group yesterday refused to make an issue of Mr Portillo's decision to talk on its platforms saying previous speakers had ranged from Mr Hesletine to John Major.

fields.headline: Serco to sign £100m PFI deal
fields.standfirst:
Green light for national traffic control centre

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Green light for national traffic control centre.
fields.body:
Serco, the business services group, is near to signing a £100m contract to build and operate a national road traffic control centre in Britain.

Kevin Beeston, Serco's chief executive, said the centre would enable the police to have an overall view of traffic on motorways and trunk roads so they could divert traffic to avoid congestion.

In addition the data gathered by the centre could be sold to outside organisations or used by Serco itself to provide other value-added services, such as warning motorists of delays.

"It could develop over time to a situation in which you could imagine someone who makes a regular journey getting a telephone call at home saying 'take a different route or leave half an hour earlier'," Mr Beeston said. "This is possible with the technology."

Serco is in the final stage of negotiating the 10-year contract with the highways agency as a public finance initiative project.

The group would have to invest about £7.5m to build the centre and set up the monitoring system.

Mr Beeston said that the UK transport sector was one of the growth areas for the group. It is bidding for the Wales and Borders train franchise and is on a short list of four.

Final bids for the franchise are due to be submitted in May. "The strategic rail authority is trying to operate a single railway for Wales," Mr Beeston said. "It will be a government subsidised community service."

The franchise will take in operations at present run by four different rail operators.

Serco, which yesterday announced a 20% jump in profits for last year, has about 500 contracts for a wide range of activities, 90% of them for governments. They range from setting up and running complex IT projects to building and running prisons.

It is the world's largest air traffic control operator and is seeking virtually to double the size of its ATC operations by acquiring control of Britain's National Air Traffic Services, which is responsible for the airspace over Britain and parts of the Atlantic.

The government is selling a controlling stake in Nats under one of the most controversial public private partnerships. Serco at present handles about 6.2m aircraft movements a year, compared with the 5.5m a year handled by Nats. The government is due to announce which of the short-listed companies will get the contract by the beginning of April.

Serco also runs the Atomic Weapons Establishment in a joint venture with Lockheed Martin UK. Its operations have just been extended to cover support for weapons convoys. The two firms are in the final stage of negotiations to extend the AWE contract from 10 to 25 years and to raise £400m private finance for the development of the AWE.

Serco reported pretax profits of £37.7m for last year on turnover 19.7% ahead at £967m. Mr Beeston said it was expected that group profits would continue to grow by 20% a year - as they had over the past 13 years.

fields.headline: Briton jailed for wife's murder
fields.trailText: A British businessman, three of whose wives have died in suspicious circumstances, was jailed for 13 years for murder yesterday - five years after a court originally ruled him not guilty.
fields.body:
A British businessman, three of whose wives have died in suspicious circumstances, was jailed for 13 years for murder yesterday - five years after a court originally ruled him not guilty.

Kevin Sweeney, a 50-year-old computer publisher based in Holland, was cleared in 1996 of killing his third wife, Suzanne Davies, 35, by setting fire to their home in a £700,000 insurance swindle in July 1995.

Yesterday he was convicted at the court of appeal in Den Bosch, Netherlands, after police pushed for a retrial - permitted by Dutch law if, as in this case, new evidence comes to light.

The decision has prompted Scotland Yard to assess whether it should investigate the will of a previous wife, Beverly, who died of an alleged sudden heart attack at the age of 33 after taking out a life insurance policy worth £240,000, and just days after receiving a clean bill of health.

The third Mrs Sweeney, the daughter of a former British Airways executive from Thame, Oxon, had been married for nine months when her naked body was discovered in the bedroom of their fire-ravaged home in the Dutch town of Steensel.

The couple, who had met after she responded to his advert in the personal columns of Private Eye, had bought the £194,000 house on the Dutch-Belgian border three months before the fire, with a large mortgage in her name backed by big insurance policies.

At the initial trial, police failed to prove Sweeney's guilt, but new evidence presented to the appeal court proved "beyond any doubt" that he had murdered his third wife.

A meticulous reconstruction concluded that the fire was started deliberately, with experts testifying that they had found traces of an inflammable liquid on a carpet in the property.

Investigators also discovered the home had been locked from the outside before the fire took hold, while further investigation into Sweeney's finances showed he stood to gain more than £700,000 from her death - £200,000 more than previously thought.

Mrs Sweeney, who had married twice before and who left a daughter Charlotte, now nine, was said to have told friends shortly before her death that she was deeply unhappy with the relationship and that they were in financial difficulties.

Friends have explained that she threatened to leave Sweeney, who allegedly enjoyed sadomasochistic pornography and introduced his wife to the sex clubs of Amsterdam, but that she felt "she had a lot invested".

A former friend of his second wife, Beverley, has alleged that she witnessed the deceased's will, which left everything to her two children, but only after she died. Her husband was sole trustee after her death.

Last night a Scotland Yard spokesman said: "We have received a complaint regarding the alleged forging of a certain document and are considering what action to take."

Sweeney also told police his first wife died in a car accident. Dutch police have also investigated the death of a former girlfriend in a car crash in America during the early 90s.

After murdering Suzanne Davies, Sweeney, who at the time of his 1996 acquittal described marriage as "wonderful to me", married once again.

webTitle: Irvine to tell Lords about cash letter

fields.headline: Irvine to tell Lords about cash letter
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Lord Irvine, the lord chancellor, will today reject claims he is destroying the judiciary's independence when he tells peers he is currently doing more than any of his predecessors to open up the judicial appointments process to independent scrutiny.
fields.byline: Patrick Wintour, Michael White  and Clare Dyer
fields.body:
Lord Irvine, the lord chancellor, will today reject claims he is destroying the judiciary's independence when he tells peers he is currently doing more than any of his predecessors to open up the judicial appointments process to independent scrutiny.

In a long delayed counter-attack, he will point out the Lord Chancellor's department is interviewing for a new judicial appointments commissioner, responsible for handling complaints over judicial appointments.

Officials inside the department are angry that Lord Irvine is being accused of a "cash for wigs" scandal in the same month they claim he is moving to lift the shroud of secrecy surrounding judicial appointments.

His officials argued yesterday that the new commissioner will be entitled to attend all interviews and handle complaints, not just from a disappointed applicant, but also their representatives.

The new appointment body is his own initiative and directly follows recommendations from Sir Leanard Peach, the former commissioner for public appointments.

Conservatives yesterday renewed calls for Lord Irvine to resign following his admission that he sent a letter to leftwing lawyers urging them to give £200 at a Labour fundraising dinner earlier this month.

Lord Irvine will reply today to an oral question tabled by Lord McNally, the Liberal Democrat peer. Lord McNally is not seeking a resignation, but challenging the lord chancellor's judgment.

Sitting silently on the woolsack yesterday, he refused to respond when the shadow leader of the Lords, Lord Strathclyde, demanded an emergency statement. The leader of the Lords, Lady Jay, had contemptuously rejected the demand for a statement, accusing the Tories of "a high level of opportunism" and taking all their views from the newspaper delivery boy.

The shadow lord chancellor, Lord Kingsland, yesterday wrote to Lord Irvine, calling on him to restore the "probity" of his office by releasing lists of lawyers attending and declining to attend a Labour fund-raising lunch on February 7, along with details of the funds they had given.

Speaking on BBC radio earlier, Lord Kingsland defended Lord Irvine's record in appointing judges and QCs, saying he had always acted with "absolute probity".

But Lord Kingsland later said that he did believe that Lord Irvine should resign. Tories insist Lord Irvine's refusal to come clean voluntarily on Sunday had made them demand his head.

The lord chancellor stood down yesterday from a House of Lords case on which he had been due to sit next month as one of five judges.

His spokesman said he had been obliged to take himself off the case because he had to attend a special cabinet committee to discuss the budget on the day it was set to start, March 7.

But the House of Lords judicial office had not been told by late yesterday afternoon that they would have to draft in another judge for the case, which Lord Irvine had been listed to hear since January.

The case is a compensation claim by three men abused as children by a housefather at a private school for maladjusted and vulnerable children.

It is seen as an important test case to decide whether the owners of children's homes and schools are liable to pay compensation to children abused by one of their employees.

Critics of the lord chancellor's dual role as judge and politician argue that he should not sit on any cases in which the state could have an interest in the result.

webTitle: Blair sets up 'phone a friend' link with Bush

fields.headline: Blair sets up 'phone a friend' link with Bush
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Tony Blair last night served notice on Britain's European allies and his own party that he intends to make a "pick up the phone" friendship with President George Bush a major priority as the new Republican administration settles down in Washington.
fields.body:
Tony Blair last night served notice on Britain's European allies and his own party that he intends to make a "pick up the phone" friendship with President George Bush a major priority as the new Republican administration settles down in Washington.

On the eve of Mr Blair's visit to the US and Canada, Downing Street insisted that choosing between the US and Europe was a "false and foolish" choice - and announced that the annual US-EU summit will, for the first time, be attached to the six monthly EU summit in Gothenburg on June 14.

That will allow Mr Bush to meet all 15 EU leaders rather than the Swedish EU presidency. But the prime minister's spokesman made it plain that the switch from Democrats to Republicans in the White House would not affect Britain's self-declared status as the oldest ally of the US. That means closing ranks on divisive issues - most conspicuously the US plans to deploy a national missile defence (NMD) shield which British ministers have indicated already they will back, to the dismay of France.

Basking in the prospect of being the first EU leader to pay court in Bush's Washington -and to spend a "fairly relaxed and informal" 24 hours at the presidential retreat of Camp David - No 10 invoked an emerging relationship of trust and confidence. "It would allow the two men to engage in straight talking, problem solving and standing shoulder-to-shoulder against the likes of Saddam Hussein and Milosevic", Alastair Campbell told reporters. "In the kind of relationship he would like they would pick up the phone as they liked and talk over problem solving as they see it."

With divisive controversies simmering over the EU's rapid reaction force, the US plan for NMD deployment and the renewed US-UK bombing of Iraq, Mr Blair's hopes may fall foul of both Labour backbenchers and EU colleagues.

When British officials invoked London's historic cold war role as the bridge between Europe and the US, German reporters yesterday quoted back a remark made by a Schroder official in Berlin that "the traffic on that bridge seems all one-way", with Britain in the supplicant's role.

Mr Campbell brushed such talk aside. "The prime minister has always seen the notion that we have to choose between Europe and the US as a false choice and always a foolish choice," he said. Later he conceded: "If we were to list the most important parts of his job, making sure he gets on with the US president would be pretty high on the list."

All British prime ministers make varying successes of that task and Mr Blair did not make John Major's mistake of being identified with George Bush Snr, the man Bill Clinton defeated in 1992. But the ex-Texas governor's priorities lie more with Asia and Mexico - which he visited last week - than did Mr Clinton's.

His global instincts are also more unilateralist than his predecessor's and there was no mention of Northern Ireland on the Blair agenda yesterday.

Mr Blair will first visit Canada, and make a major speech to parliament in Ottawa. He and the Canadian prime minister, Jean Chretien, will jointly call for a new, world trade round after the abortive Seattle and Prague conferences. When Mr Blair flies south to Washington on Friday, Mr Bush is likely to agree.

Trade between the EU and the US is trickier with the "banana wars" row threatening to produce US sanctions against EU luxury exports. But 98% of Atlantic trade is row-free, officials stressed yesterday.

On the rapid reaction force, officials said much of the reporting had been misleading. "What we have to do is set out the facts. The US would be opposed to it if it undermined Nato, and so would we."

But the ex-Texas governor's priorities lie more with Asia and Mexico - which he visited last week - than did Mr Clinton's. His global instincts are also more unilateralist than his predecessor's and there was no mention of Northern Ireland on the Blair agenda yesterday. Mr Blair will first visit Canada, and make a major speech to parliament in Ottawa. He and the Canadian prime minister, Jean Chretien, will jointly call for a new, world trade round after the abortive Seattle and Prague conferences. When Mr Blair flies south to Washington on Friday, Mr Bush is likely to agree. Trade between the EU and the US is trickier with the "banana wars" row threatening to produce US sanctions against EU luxury exports. But 98% of Atlantic trade is row-free, officials stressed yesterday. On the rapid reaction force, officials said much of the reporting had been misleading. "What we have to do is set out the facts. The US would be opposed to it if it undermined Nato, and so would we."

fields.headline: At this price? Forbidden
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Stephen Streater, chief executive of Forbidden Technologies, yesterday announced that the AIM-listed company's video-over-the-internet technology has finally been developed into a saleable product.
fields.body:
Stephen Streater, chief executive of Forbidden Technologies, yesterday announced that the AIM-listed company's video-over-the-internet technology has finally been developed into a saleable product.

"The first product is now available enabling video playback over the internet at high resolution, full frame rate and large screen size," Mr Streater said in a statement to the stock exchange.

He directed sceptics to his website - forbidden.co.uk co.uk - to see how impressive Forbidden's streaming video technology, which avoids the need for lengthy downloads, has become.

The market duly raised shares in Forbidden by 42.5p to close at 96.5p - an increase of 79%, making it yesterday's highest rise on the London market.

In reality, Mr Streater acknowledges that his video compression software has been available for months. While there is little doubt it is increasingly impressive - Forbidden claims quality has improved 2.5% per week since September - the technology will only be truly regarded as a saleable product when it attracts its first customer. So far it has none.

That might change, given that the government has all but abandoned its commitment to the rollout of broadband internet access.

Unlike many rivals, Forbidden has confined the development of its video compression technology to the strictures of a standard dial-up 56k modem connection.

Iain McInally, an analyst at house broker Bell Lawrie White, said wideband delays left Forbidden well placed to establish itself in the interim.

While yesterday's share price rise looks impressive, it is worth noting that, given Mr Streater's 84% private holding, the scope for large scale sales of Forbidden's shares is restricted, leaving shifts in price exaggerated.

Forbidden shares are worth a gamble as long as the broadband access process continues to flounder.

webTitle: Youth worker used web to befriend sex victim

fields.headline: Youth worker used web to befriend sex victim
fields.standfirst:
More net news
Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: An evangelical Christian lecturer who helped run his local church youth club was convicted yesterday of sexually assaulting a schoolboy he befriended through an internet gay chatroom.
fields.body:
An evangelical Christian lecturer who helped run his local church youth club was convicted yesterday of sexually assaulting a schoolboy he befriended through an internet gay chatroom.

Judge David Morris told Anthony Gray, 30, of Bicester, Oxfordshire, that it was "inevitable" that he would receive a lengthy custodial sentence.

He added: "I have come to the view you came to Cardiff with deceit in your heart and lust in your loins."

He remanded Gray in custody for reports and ordered him to register as a sex offender.

The jury heard how Gray, who studied theology at Exeter and Oxford universities, met the 14-year-old boy after logging on to www.Gay.Com and they chatted online about 20 times before meeting in Cardiff.

Gray, now the father of a six-month-old daughter, was due to go to the city on a business meeting in April last year. The meeting was cancelled but he made the 200-mile round trip and met the boy at the city's central railway station. They went to a cinema and then booked into a hotel.

Gray, who denied the charges, said that in the hotel room they had only chatted about the boy's struggle with his sexuality. But the judge said it had been "pre-planned" and that he had "wreaked his sexual satisfaction on a young and vulnerable boy knowing full well he was under age".

Gray admitted he had told the schoolboy during their on-line chats that he was a 22-year-old openly gay man and said he wanted to advise the boy about his sexuality.

Gray, now a lecturer for the University of Colleges of Christian Fellowship, said he had started struggling with his sexuality five years ago after seeing images of gay pornography on a borrowed computer.

He described his home life as "happy and content" but found that he was excited by the gay pornography.

The court heard that he bought gay porn magazines and videos on trips to London and Oxford and hid them from his wife in the attic.

When police raided the house after his arrest in August they found 33 gay videos, hundreds of magazine cuttings and 3,000 gay images of teenage boys downloaded on to his computer.

Prosecutor Greg Bull described Gray as a "Jekyll and Hyde" character who appeared to be a respectable citizen. "But he had deeper, darker motives for seeking out young boys," he said.

The court heard that the boy told of the meeting when, three months later, his parents questioned him about his internet phone bill. In evidence, the boy, who had been given the computer with a dedicated phone line to help with his homework, said he was "confused" because he thought he might be gay. "I confided in my friends but not my parents. I was trying to speak to people of my own age who would understand me. I gave [Gray] my telephone number. It was a novelty at first, just talking."

After the hearing, the boy's mother said: "I would warn other parents to watch what their children are doing on the computer."

The case comes less than a week after seven men were jailed for their part in the Wonderland internet paedophile ring. Michele Elliott, director of Kidscape, said recent cases showed the urgent need for restrictions on the internet.

fields.headline: Bullimore sails into trouble
fields.standfirst: Three crew members quit as Team Legato languishes 7,000 miles behind the leader amid claims of in-fighting and concerns over safety
fields.trailText: Three crew members quit as Team Legato languishes 7,000 miles behind the leader amid claims of in-fighting and concerns over safety.
fields.body:
Any hopes of Ellen MacArthur's solo yachting triumph herald-ing a renaissance for British sailing were swiftly dashed yesterday after three crew members abandoned Tony Bullimore's troubled attempt to race around the world amid allegations of crew in-fighting and concerns over safety.

Rob Salvidge, a 43-year-old journalist with BBC Radio Bristol, quit Mr Bullimore's Team Legato catamaran n Wellington, New Zealand, on Monday, blaming "continuing unrest" and crew "bickering".

Two Frenchmen, Armand Coursodon and Olivier Cusin, cited medical reasons for leaving the vessel, which has been plagued by crewing problems and tales of shambolic organisation for months.

The catamaran is languishing 7,000 miles behind Club Med, the leader in the 23,000-mile round-the-world challenge known as "The Race".

Team Legato rounded ag gressively on the three yesterday, accusing them of a lack of professionalism and unjustified complaining. "The three crew getting off are the three inexperienced guys in the team, and you need to read what you will into that - nobody ever said this thing was going to be easy," spokesman Barry Pickthall said.

The dispute is the latest in a series of problems to beset the 102ft craft, which left Barc-elona on New Year's Day. Many have been blamed on personality differences arising from the "gentleman amateur" style of Mr Bullimore, who rose to widespread fame in 1997 after surviving for four days under the hull of his capsized yacht in the Antarctic.

Four of Team Legato's original crew abandoned ship before its departure, one reporting that "the level of confusion and disorganisation on board was totally farcical". Others blamed friction among crew.

Only two days before departure, the crew had yet to paint the boat's rudders and dagger boards in the bright safety paint required by the rules of the race, and only managed to complete the compulsory safety course - including rescue drills and man-overboard procedures - at the very last minute. New rocket flares had to be purchased because those Mr Bullimore had planned to take expired the day the race began, and crucial satellite equipment and life rafts were installed just hours before departure.

Mr Bullimore lost much-needed preparation time by having to sail an additional 150 miles before setting off in order to meet regulations for the minimum pre-departure mileage required of all boats.

The catamaran eventually left its starting-point in Barcelona 20 hours after its five rivals, and the stopover in Wellington, for medical check-ups and urgent repairs, will delay matters further, since the rules require the team to sit out a 60-hour penalty period, which is due to end today.

Mr Salvidge, a last-minute replacement, said he had decided to leave because of "continuing unrest, which I felt wasn't being sorted out, to do with certain interpersonal issues regarding the crew - and a big, ocean-going boat isn't the sort of environment to have ongoing bickering." In an interview with BBC Radio Bristol he also cited "what might well be an irrational fear that I had developed to do with safety".

Speaking to the Guardian from Wellington yesterday, Mr Salvidge rejected the idea that his inexperience had caused problems and said he wished to avoid a "slanging match". He added: "I stand by my statements, and I don't think I'd be speaking out of turn if I said that the other guys on the boat were sorry to see me go and keen for me to carry on."

In a statement, Mr Bullimore, 61, denied reports of arguments on board. Commenting on the journalist's decision to quit, he said: "I think it was something very personal with him."

Last December, Mr Salvidge was among a group of journalists on an apperently short trip in Team Legato from Bristol to Falmouth.

When storms broke outside Falmouth, Mr Bullimore refused to enter the harbour, instead taking his alarmed crew on a perilous 1,000-mile trip in mountainous seas into the Bay of Biscay. They eventually docked in Portugal six days later.

Sir Robin Knox-Johnston, who won the first non-stop solo round-the-world race in 1969 and has skippered numerous journeys with larger crews, said yesterday: "He's taken 50 days to get to Wellington. We took 35 days to get that far with much the same boat. You dont' have to be very bright to see how good he is."

webTitle: Business: RMC bid chatter taken seriously

fields.headline: RMC bid chatter taken seriously
fields.standfirst: Market forces
fields.trailText: Traders have been chattering about it for at least a couple weeks now, but the possibility of a bid for cement specialist RMC is only now starting to be taken very seriously in the Square Mile.
fields.body:
Traders have been chattering about it for at least a couple weeks now, but the possibility of a bid for cement specialist RMC is only now starting to be taken very seriously in the Square Mile.

According to Stephen Rawlinson, an analyst at stockbroker Peel Hunt, evidence is mounting that an offer is on the way, but because the performance of RMC's shares has not been sufficiently good to force an announcement the market has been left to guess what may be happening.

Mr Rawlinson reckons that the realists on RMC's board have accepted that consolidation is inevitable and have been waiting for "external interest" to emerge.

He sees the Mexican company, Cemex, and Swiss group Holderbank as the most likely bidders - although he does not rule out a bid from the Irish group, CRH, if the price is right.

As RMC's share price has failed to rise above 850p for more than a year, Mr Rawlinson sees this as the level at which institutions might be willing to entertain a cash offer.

RMC shares closed 5p higher at 724.5p.

In the wider market, the dealers - who had spent much of the day sitting idle at their desks - found themselves in the midst of a nasty sell-off late yesterday afternoon.

The FTSE 100, which was in positive territory for half of the trading session, ended at its lowest level since October 1999 - 5,980.1, down 113.9 points - as investors baled out of some of London's most heavily weighted stocks.

After opening higher, Vodafone down 8p to 190p - and BT - off 23p to 586p - went into a tailspin as the Nasdaq, reopening for business after the Presidents' day holiday, fell sharply. By the time London closed for business, the Nasdaq, which fell 5% on Friday, was down 2.8%.

Over in the banking sector, Lloyds TSB dipped 20.5p to 650p and Abbey National fell 37p to £11.36 after Halifax, off 28p to 680p, rekindled fears of a mortgage price war by lowering its standard variable rate. In pharmaceuticals, GlaxoSmithKline- London's third largest company - compounded the misery, falling 75p to £18.45 on profit-taking ahead of today's full year figures.

Elsewhere, the picture was slightly brighter. Although IT group CMG lost 36p, or 4%, to 850p, and chip designer ARM slipped 20p, or 4.83%, to 394.5p, the FTSE Techmark 100 lost just 29.79 points to end at 2,475.60.

Lower down, the FTSE mid-250 finished 16.6 points easier at 6,700.2, with Elementis, the speciality chemicals company, proving a key talking point.

Market professionals believe that takeover talks revealed back in December are about to come to fruition. They insist that Elementis, which is leading supplier of chromium, has agreed a 125-130p offer from a venture capital firm, which it will announce at some point next week. Last night Elementis shares stood at 95.5p.

David S Smith, the paper and packaging group whose shares have underperformed the sector by up to 80% over the past five years, had a miserable session. News that UK sales had weakened since its half-time figures in December saw the stock marked 13.5p lower at 131.5p.

Dealers reckon it could move higher again today. Late yesterday Merrill Lynch, which retained its position as London's top equity research house in the latest Reuters survey, was said to have uprated the company to "buy" on the ground that some form of corporate activity is likely.

Market professionals were chasing Navan Mining higher. Word has it that trenching - or opencast mining - results from its Krumovgrad prospect in Bulgaria will be released on Thursday. According to the gossips, the results will show that Navan is sitting on a gold deposit of between 4m and 5m ounces. Navan shares rose 7p to 123p.

fields.headline: LSE 'has links with Chechen terrorists'
fields.standfirst: Special report: crisis in Chechnya
fields.trailText: The Russian government yesterday claimed that the London School of Economics was being used as a recruiting ground for Islamic fundamentalist mercenaries fighting state forces in Chechnya.
fields.byline: Amelia Gentleman in Moscow and  Jamie Wilson
fields.body:
The Russian government yesterday claimed that the London School of Economics was being used as a recruiting ground for Islamic fundamentalist mercenaries fighting state forces in Chechnya.

Sergei Yastrzhembsky, spokesman for Russian president, Vladimir Putin, on Chechnya, alleged students were being targeted by groups which funded Chechen separatists involved in Russia's war in the Caucasus.

His comments coincide with the implementation on Monday of the Terrorism Act, which for the first time will allow the authorities to target groups using Britain as a base for terrorist acts abroad.

Mr Yastrzhembsky said the authorities in Moscow would be presenting the Foreign Office with a list of terrorist groups which he hoped the British government would ban.

"We have repeatedly drawn attention to the existence of a whole series of organisations which are collecting funds for the support of Chechen separatists, and for gangsterism, terrorism and for information centres which more or less openly support these forces," Mr Yastrzhembsky told the newspaper Sevodonya.

"Clearly Britain has adopted this law as a result of its own national interests. But we are sure that in this area, British interests will coincide with Russian," he said.

Asked to name specific organisations on the list, he replied: "We are talking about organisations whose actions can be seen as supporting terrorism - offering financial, informational or political support... recruitment of mercenaries is being carried out in places like the London School of Economics, where mostly nationals of African and Asian countries are studying."

But Mr Yastrzhembsky's comments were met with incredulity at the LSE. "We are astonished to hear of these allegations and we would like to see the evidence - if there is any," a spokeswoman said.

Lee Federman, general secretary of the student union,said: "This has come completely out of the blue. I have been at the grassroots level on campus and there has been no indication of anything like that at all."

Last night an aide to Mr Yastrzhembsky moved to clarify the comments, stressing that LSE had been named as just one of a number of places in the world where extremists were recruiting followers.

"We are not making accusations against either the country or the university administration, but simply identifying a place where recruitment occurs," he said, adding that the same process could be seen in the Moscow universities.

Russian officials have repeatedly claimed that many of the guerrillas fighting in Chechnya are Muslim terrorists recruited from around the world.

Extremist groups are known to have been active on British campuses in the past.The extremist party Al-Muhajiroun has been banned by several universities for its extreme views. Sheikh Bakri-Muhammad, who founded the party in Saudi Arabia in 1983 and is known to condemn Russia's actions in Chechnya, claims it is the duty of all Muslims to engage in jihad.

The LSE may have been picked out by Mr Yastrzhembsky as a result of the activities of Ahmad Omar Sayyed Sheikh, a former student, who became a member of the Pakistan-based Islamic fundamentalist Harkat ul-Ansar group. Sheikh was jailed in India for three years over his alleged involvement in the kidnap of British tourists, but was freed in exchange for 155 hostages on board a hijacked Air India plane.

The LSE may have been picked out by Mr Yastrzhembsky as a result of the activities of Ahmad Omar Sayyed Sheikh, a former student, who became a member of the Pakistan-based Islamic fundamentalist Harkat ul-Ansar group. Sheikh was jailed in India for three years over his alleged involvement in the kidnap of British tourists, but was freed in exchange for 155 hostages on board a hijacked Air India plane.

webTitle: NEC and Matsushita issue profit warnings

fields.headline: NEC and Matsushita issue profit warnings
fields.trailText: Two of Japan's big electronics firms joined the growing ranks of hi-tech companies issuing profit warnings in the face of a US economic slowdown, weak domestic spending and rising competition from Asia.
fields.body:
Two of Japan's big electronics firms joined the growing ranks of hi-tech companies issuing profit warnings in the face of a US economic slowdown, weak domestic spending and rising competition from Asia.

NEC, the world's third-biggest chipmaker, said consolidated operating profit for the year to March would be 190bn yen (£1.1bn), 24% shy of its previous estimate made in October, on sales of 5.4 trillion yen, down from 5.5 trillion yen.

Matsushita Electric Industrial, the world's biggest consumer electronics manufacturer, also cut its 2000-01 group operating profit forecast by 15% to 220bn yen, on sales of 7.56 trillion yen.

The news came as little surprise to the market, which has been braced for bad tidings from Japan's big electronics companies since signs began to emerge of a US slowdown late last year. Many analysts are hopeful that a turnaround will be achieved in the second half of this year.

"The outlook isn't particularly bad," said Akira Minamikawa, technology analyst at WestLB Securities in Tokyo. "For PCs, we should see further adjustment in January-March, some initial orders in April-June and a resurgence in July-September."

NEC's revised operating profit figure would still be a 72% gain on the previous year's result, and Matsushita's would be a 38% increase.

NEC's shares dipped modestly at yesterday's opening after a news report indicating a profit warning was likely, but they quickly bounced back and ended the session up 2.17% at 2,115 yen, outperforming a 0.98% rise in the Nikkei share average.

The shares have shed more than 15% of their value over the past month, compared with a 5.6% drop in the Nikkei.

Matsushita's announcement came after the close of trade. Its shares slumped to a 15-month low in the morning at 2,165 yen but managed to rebound to close up 3.17% at 2,280.

Japan's hi-tech sector was hit two weeks ago by a profit warning from NEC's rival, Toshiba, which cut its 2000-01 group operating profit estimate by 30%.

Reuters

fields.headline: Baltimore secures i-mode alliance
fields.trailText: Baltimore, the Dublin-based online security firm, has signed a deal with Japan's leading mobile telecoms group, NTT DoCoMo, to provide secure links for i-mode, the internet-access cell phone service.
fields.body:
Baltimore, the Dublin-based online security firm, has signed a deal with Japan's leading mobile telecoms group, NTT DoCoMo, to provide secure links for i-mode, the internet-access cell phone service.

It is hoped Baltimore's technology will give users increased confidence to use i-mode for internet transactions, boosting e-commerce. With more than 18m i-mode users, DoCoMo is seeking to offer its customers services beyond its already successful music, news and entertainment features.

John Fallon, Baltimore's director of wireless, yesterday said he hoped to provide security for a number of i-mode's 20,000 online content providers. He hopes the deal will allow Baltimore to showcase its technology and build trust among consumers.

"Every i-mode phone with our security has a Baltimore certificate on the phone.This means we will be increasingly trusted and are well placed to develop our relationship with DoCoMo further." The Baltimore certificates have been embedded into DoCoMo's latest models in the 503i Series.

Shares in Baltimore rose by 1.25p to close at 311.75p yesterday.

The Irish firm refused to reveal how much revenue would result from the agreement but it is said to be more of an opportunity than an immediately lucrative arrangement.

The deal is not exclusive to Baltimore but Jemma Houlihan, an analyst at ABN Amro in Ireland, said it gave Baltimore a "huge potential" within the Japanese market, placing it well ahead of US rival Entrust, which last year won a deal with Motorola to develop security systems for its mobile handsets.

Ms Houlihan said Baltimore could also benefit if DoCoMo's i-mode service is introduced in Europe through Telecom Italia Mobile or the Dutch group KPN Telecom.

fields.headline: Empowering the MPC
fields.trailText: The process of setting interest rates in the UK has undergone a revolution since Nigel Lawson famously said that he made the decisions and the Bank of England carried them out.
fields.body:
The process of setting interest rates in the UK has undergone a revolution since Nigel Lawson famously said that he made the decisions and the Bank of England carried them out. The first steps towards Bank independence were taken after Black Wednesday, when the governor and the chancellor would meet every month to discuss rates. Edited minutes of the meeting were published, but ultimately the chancellor's view prevailed, even when every Bank official - and, occasionally, every Treasury official too - disagreed.

All that changed on the Tuesday after the 1997 election. Gordon Brown said his intention was to take the politics out of interest rate decisions by giving the Bank day to day control over monetary policy. A new, four-part process was introduced. At its apex sits the chancellor. He sets the rules for the Bank's monetary policy committee, fixing a target for inflation - at present 2.5% on the measure that excludes mortgage interest payments. If inflation falls below 1.5%, Sir Eddie George will have to send an open letter to the chancellor explaining what steps he is taking to return to the target. That is because the target is symmetrical - an undershoot is considered to be as serious as an overshoot.

Once the target has been set, it is up to the MPC to meet it. Meetings are normally held on a Wednesday and Thursday early each month, although the process actually begins on the previous Friday, when MPC members run through all the latest economic data and are given reports by the Bank's agents. One will present a picture of life in the regions, another will give the findings of a specific question asked each month. In February, the MPC wanted to know why investment was so low. At the decision-making meeting, each MPC member has a say before the vote is taken. A simple majority is sufficient.

The government has sought to make the process transparent. Minutes are published two weeks after the meeting, a detailed guide to the Bank's thinking is provided in the quarterly inflation report and MPC members make regular speeches explaining their views. Some believe the system is not yet transparent enough, however. The Lords committee on the MPC said yesterday that the chancellor should consider involving the commissioner for public appointments in the scrutiny of new members of the body.

Finally, the MPC is accountable to parliament - where both the Commons and the Lords hold regular hearings to scrutinise the conduct of monetary policy and question the individual members of the committee.

fields.headline: City diary
fields.trailText: How fascinating it was to see Reuters' survey of investment bank company analysts yesterday - and hats off to the crack team at Credit Suisse First Boston for being voted by fund managers the top analysts in the electrical engineering category.
fields.body:
How fascinating it was to see Reuters' survey of investment bank company analysts yesterday - and hats off to the crack team at Credit Suisse First Boston for being voted by fund managers the top analysts in the electrical engineering category.

The CSFB squad made something of a splash last week with the revelation that it was quietly circulating an aggressive "sell" note on shares of Invensys, the manufacturing and software group, to the bank's customers while telling the rest of the world that CSFB was recommending a "buy" of the company's shares. Oh dear! If nothing else, this distinction shows that the road to success is telling your clients one thing and telling Joe Public another.

 Exciting news, courtesy of the New Scientist, about conditions of internet use imposed by phone company NTL: "13. Abuse of the services," it reads. "You must not disclose your password or user ID to anyone else." So far, so good. "Your account can only be used for a single internet session at any one time..." yes, yes... "and for no more than 24 hours in any one day." Got that?

 Yesterday - as exclusively revealed here, probably - it was Gordon Brown's 50th birthday. Big Gordie perhaps didn't want to be reminded, so how sensitive of an insurance company to bang out a press release titled: "The Chancellor can elect to save money now he's 50", which has the manager supposedly saying, "Turning 50 is something to positively look forward to, particularly as it can lead to valuable savings on home insurance." Mmm.

 Wonderful news that Egg, the internet bank, only lost £150m last year, and I'm especially taken by chief executive Paul Gratton's vow: "Watch my lips: I really am going to break even in quarter four." So... things are worse than anyone thought, as shown by Egg's umpteenth website redesign. This latest revamp seems designed to confuse customers - to move money in and out of savings accounts users used to click on a section marked "transfer funds". Straightforward enough, you'd think. But no, the designers have removed the button, renamed it "payment centre" and left customers to use their own initiative to work it out.

 But running these internet banks can be tricky, as Halifax found out last year during its comic opera struggles to get its unfortunately named If (Intelligence Finance) internet bank off the ground. This time, Halifax is getting ready to launch its E-sure online insurance service, and chief executive James Crosby isn't going to do anything rash, such as predict a start date. "Oh no," he said. "That was my one big lesson of 2000. I'm not giving you any more hostages to fortune."

 An email arrives from someone named Oscar Jenkins. "We are getting a bit miffed that as the first UK SMS marketing outfit and one of Vodafone's largest SMS resellers, we have not been getting any press so we fired our PR firm and have decided to manage our PR in-house," writes Oscar. Excellent news, and well done Oscar, because every time a PR firm is sacked an angel smiles in heaven - and I'd love to mention the name of your company, but there isn't room today. Sorry.

 The quality of Mr Rupert Murdoch's television is bad enough here (has anyone ever laughed at a gag on the awful Baddiel's Syndrome on Sky One?), but things are even worse in the US. Last week, the Fox network (proprietor R Murdoch) treated viewers to Conspiracy Theory: Did We Land on the Moon?. A clue to its "high" quality is that it was hosted by an actor from the X Files, and concluded that Nasa faked the Apollo Moon landings. The show went out at prime time on Thursday, proof of Rupert's relentless pursuit of the lowest common denominator.

fields.headline: Low slips despite de-packaging
fields.trailText: Low & Bonar, the building materials group, fell into the red last year, largely as a result of the £46.1m exceptional cost of disposing of its packaging businesses.
fields.body:
Low & Bonar, the building materials group, fell into the red last year, largely as a result of the £46.1m exceptional cost of disposing of its packaging businesses.

Pretax profits before exceptionals nearly halved to £16.5m as a result of higher raw material prices and the strong pound.

But total exceptional costs of £50.6m left the group with a pretax loss of £34.1m for the year. The exceptional charge included not only the cost of pulling out of packaging but also moving the head office from Dundee to London and other internal reorganisation.

The group has been transformed under Phil Reeder, who was brought in as chief executive about 15 months ago. It now focuses on easy to clean flooring materials built into schools and hospitals.

The main raw material price rises were for oil price-related polypropylene, up 35%, and polyethylene, up 10%.

The group suffered from the strong pound because the majority of its revenue comes from trading overseas, especially in continental Europe.

John Robinson, the group's chairman, said the disposal programme had been completed ahead of schedule and at prices "considerably above expectations". He added: "Today we have a much stronger platform from which to maximise shareholder value than at this time last year."

Unlike Low & Bonar, David S Smith remained in packaging only to see British sales weaken since it reported a 66% rise in first half profits in December.

The company, which specialises in corrugated and plastic packaging and paper from recycled waste, issued a trading statement yesterday warning that second half sales would be similar to the same period last year.

Analysts who had been forecasting full year profits of about £82m have now lowered their sights to about £72m, which would still be a significant improvement on last year's pretax profit of £48.6m.

webTitle: Bus service sets villagers the devil of a job

fields.headline: Bus service sets villagers the devil of a job
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: In Somerset they call it the bus journey from hell. And, while the village of Shepton Montague is more sleepy than diabolical, route 666 lives up to its nickname as the Devil's Bus.
fields.body:
In Somerset they call it the bus journey from hell. And, while the village of Shepton Montague is more sleepy than diabolical, route 666 lives up to its nickname as the Devil's Bus.

The 666 service sets off for the town of Castle Cary four miles away once a day, but then that's it - to make the return trip, passengers must wait until next morning.

Yesterday the MP for Somerton and Frome, David Heath, joined locals in attacking the bus company responsible, Atmos. "This is clearly a very ill thought out piece of route planning," said the LibDem MP. "Residents of Shepton Montague are not asking for more buses - just for the timetable to make sense."

Villager Jean Bonner, 72, does not drive and relies on the bus to travel to do her shopping. She said: "It's absolutely ridiculous. Surely, if a bus company picks you up, it has a responsibility to drop you back where you got on?"

With a population of 220, Shepton Montague has no bank, village store or post office. When the bus departs at 12.26pm each day to make the 10-minute journey to Castle Cary, there is no return service until 9.47am next morning; passengers must pay £5 for a taxi or be stranded overnight.

Mrs Bonner asked: "I cannot afford a taxi, so what am I supposed to do? It basically means I cannot use the bus any more. I wait until someone I know is going into town and they offer me a lift."

The bus is run by Badgerline under contract to Atmos of Taunton, a private firm that sets the timetable after having taken over Somerset county council's public transport network last year.

Atmos said the 666 service was designed to link Shepton Montague with Wincanton and not to provide a dedicated service between the village and Castle Cary.

"We realise it's not ideal and we are hoping to add another bus to the route and revise the timetable in the near future," a spokesman said.

fields.headline: Allies repackage 'smart' embargo
fields.standfirst:
Targeting Saddam: Britain and US mount public relations offensive in lead-up to first Blair-Bush summit

Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: The British government will discuss plans to impose "smart" sanctions on Iraq with the new US administration this week as opposition to the transatlantic policy against Saddam Hussein mounts throughout Europe and the Arab world.
fields.byline: Richard Norton-Taylor, Julian Borger in Washington and Brian Whitaker
fields.body:
The British government will discuss plans to impose "smart" sanctions on Iraq with the new US administration this week as opposition to the transatlantic policy against Saddam Hussein mounts throughout Europe and the Arab world.

Foreign Office officials confirmed yesterday that the question of how to contain President Saddam would be high on the agenda when Tony Blair meets George Bush in Washington on Friday.

Confirming a report in yesterday's Guardian, officials said the time had come to define a more "clear-cut" sanctions policy while highlighting President Saddam's repression of his people. The strategy would concentrate on the Iraqi leader's attempts to acquire weapons of mass destruction and the finances of leading members of his regime.

"The mixture of measures, sanctions, military posture, oil revenues and enforcement around the borders, these are all elements that will be looked at again," a Downing Street policy maker said.

A Foreign Office diplomat will meet US officials in Washington on Thursday to draw up a framework for more focused sanctions removing controls on civilian goods.

US officials admit that the alliance between the US and Britain which has spearheaded the sanctions and upheld no-fly zones in the north and south of the country has begun to lose the public relations war. With governments across Europe lining up to condemn the strategy, the Washington-London axis looks increasingly isolated.

But the new Bush administration is likely to follow a hawkish line, with the vice-president, Dick Cheney, and the defence secretary, Donald Rumsfeld, loath to be seen granting any concessions to President Saddam.

Fuelling speculation of a rift within the administration, the secretary of state, Colin Powell, has shown more readiness to shift the US stance on Iraq. He is likely to experience first-hand the extent of anger across the Arab world after last Friday's bombing raids on Baghdad by US and British planes.

On Friday he is to begin his first trip abroad, aimed at selling the smart sanctions idea to America's Gulf war allies.

State department officials have been assigned the task of retooling sanctions, so that Mr Powell will have new policies to offer Arab countries including Syria, Egypt and Jordan, which fear President Saddam's military intentions but face popular outrage about the trade embargo's perceived effect on ordinary Iraqis.

In advance of the Blair-Bush meetings, officials on both sides of the Atlantic were yesterday emphasising that any change of policy should not be interpreted as a softening of approach on Iraq.

Containment

A British official said the objective would remain the same - "containing Saddam, weapons of mass destruction and internal repression". Brian Wilson, the new Foreign Office minister responsible for Iraq, told the BBC there were two strands to British policy.

"The first is to minimise the human impact and the second is to maximise the inability of Saddam Hussein to wage war on his own people, the region and the rest of the world," he said.

The Iraqi leader, he said, had "ruthlessly" used the sanctions to blame the west for the suffering of his people and any changes to stop him doing that would be welcome. "I have a positive desire to see sanctions developed in such a way that they do the only purpose that they are intended for," Mr Wilson said.

Meanwhile Washington has given the US-funded Iraqi National Congress, the opposition coalition, the green light to move its operations back into its home country for the first time since it was forced out by Iraqi offensives in 1996. Some INC members will be given light weapons training, but the scope of the training is limited, and there are divisions within the Bush administration over how far to go in supporting the faction-ridden resistance movement.

Anti-US and anti-British unrest on Arab streets has been heightened by the strikes against Iraqi anti-aircraft defences around Baghdad. The missile attack was intended to protect coalition air patrols from improved Iraqi air-defence batteries, but they have focused attention on the suffering of the Iraqi people.

US officials insist that the hardships are imposed by the Iraqi government and not by the sanctions, which allow for the sale of Iraqi oil to buy food and medicines. "Our goal [is] to make sure that Iraq complies with the arms control agreements it entered into and let's move beyond this," Mr Powell said last week on his first visit to the UN as secretary of state.

Easing

On his Middle East tour, Mr Powell is expected to suggest the easing of selected sanctions to allow Iraq to rebuild its civil infrastructure. The Bush administration is considering lifting "holds" on $3bn (£2bn) in goods ordered by Baghdad, such as refrigerated trucks, which could in theory be used to transport weapons but are urgently required for civilian purposes - moving food and medical supplies.

In his attempt to rejuvenate the sanctions policy, Mr Powell is expected to attempt to plug some of the big leaks in the oil embargo. He intends to confront Syrian officials over reports that Iraq is exporting between 100,000 and 150,000 barrels of oil a day through the pipeline to Syria.

Exports through Syria could be legitimised and included in the UN's oil for food programme. But the Baghdad regime is eager to maximise its illegal revenue; it is said to be using the pipeline to earn an extra $3m a day.

At the pre-summit briefing before Mr Blair's Washington visit officials said UN security council resolution 1284 justified what they called "targeted sanctions very much on the regime". Faced with wide condemnation of the sanctions and the bombing they stressed "very wide scope" for oil sales to buy humanitarian goods: "Some critics should ask why the Iraqi regime does not do so, why so much money is still lying in its accounts."

FO spokesmen said British policy was to contain President Saddam's "aggression against his own people and his neighbours by acquiring weapons of mass destruction and abusing human rights on a massive scale".

The Liberal Democrat foreign affairs spokesman, Menzies Campbell, said if last week's raids had been carried out in the context of purely military sanctions, they would have had more public support in the Arab world. fields.bodyText: The British government will discuss plans to impose "smart" sanctions on Iraq with the new US administration this week as opposition to the transatlantic policy against Saddam Hussein mounts throughout Europe and the Arab world. Foreign Office officials confirmed yesterday that the question of how to contain President Saddam would be high on the agenda when Tony Blair meets George Bush in Washington on Friday. Confirming a report in yesterday's Guardian, officials said the time had come to define a more "clear-cut" sanctions policy while highlighting President Saddam's repression of his people. The strategy would concentrate on the Iraqi leader's attempts to acquire weapons of mass destruction and the finances of leading members of his regime. "The mixture of measures, sanctions, military posture, oil revenues and enforcement around the borders, these are all elements that will be looked at again," a Downing Street policy maker said. A Foreign Office diplomat will meet US officials in Washington on Thursday to draw up a framework for more focused sanctions removing controls on civilian goods. US officials admit that the alliance between the US and Britain which has spearheaded the sanctions and upheld no-fly zones in the north and south of the country has begun to lose the public relations war. webTitle: Threat to builders over rise in deaths

fields.headline: Threat to builders over rise in deaths
fields.trailText: Britain's leading construction groups might be barred from bidding for lucrative public sector contracts under plans being considered by the government to reverse a rise in fatal accidents within the booming building industry.
fields.body:
Britain's leading construction groups might be barred from bidding for lucrative public sector contracts under plans being considered by the government to reverse a rise in fatal accidents within the booming building industry.

John Prescott, deputy prime minister, has called an emergency meeting next week to persuade the industry to tighten health and safety procedures after a 30% rise in deaths so far this year.

Mr Prescott, who will be accompanied by four of his ministers, is incensed by the rising trend in fatal accidents after commissioning and launching with great fanfare two years ago a report by Sir John Egan urging the industry to clean up its act and make itself more attractive to young recruits.

Unions will use the summit to press their demands for companies that tender for public sector contracts - worth 45% of annual construction turnover - to be subject to a system of yellow and red cards if they fail to improve safety performance.

Allan Black, national construction official for the GMB union, said: "You could have a yellow and red card system whereby a company that fails to meet industry norms is warned it risks losing government business and is taken off the tendering list if it still failed to act."

The Construction Confederation, representing 5,000 larger companies, admitted the industry's record was "pretty appalling". In 1998-99 there were 66 deaths among construction workers, employed and self-employed, rising to 78 in 1999-2000. In the first eight months of the current accounting year there have already been 58 fatal accidents, compared to 37 in the same period last year.

Nigel Bryson, GMB director of health and environment, said deaths had gone down while the industry was in the doldrums but accelerated as new sites mushroomed across the country, many of them smaller projects such as homes.

fields.headline: Strongman for Burger King
fields.trailText: Diageo - the world's largest liquor group - has hired an airline executive to prepare its Burger King food division for stock market take-off, but the timetable for flotation appears to be slipping.
fields.body:
Diageo - the world's largest liquor group - has hired an airline executive to prepare its Burger King food division for stock market take-off, but the timetable for flotation appears to be slipping.

John Dasburg is to switch from being chief executive of US-based Northwest Airlines to a similar position at Burger King in April with the task of reviving investor appetite for the company.

A 20% stake in the rival to McDonalds had been expected to be placed on the stock market later this year. No new date was set yesterday but analysts believe it is more likely now to float early in 2002.

Diageo's chief executive, Paul Walsh, said the appointment of Mr Dasburg was the first step towards separating Diageo from Burger King. He admitted however that "currently, the financial markets are not really conducive to an IPO [initial public offering]."

Mr Dasburg comes with a strong commercial reputation after a 10-year stint with Northwest Airlines.

He is credited with saving it from bankrupcy and launching a successful flotation on the stock market.

He is renowned for tough action, with Northwest losing $1bn (£690m) in revenues during 1998 after a two-week strike by pilots. Mechanics at Northwest are preparing for a strike over wages and conditions next month.

Before Northwest, Mr Dasburg worked for the international Marriott Hotel group.

Last June Diageo announced its intention to list Burger King, and immediately lost Dennis Malamatinas, the head of its fast food division. Colin Storm, who took over from Mr Malamatinas, is due to retire from Diageo later this year.

Diageo planned to float 20% of Burger King in the first half of this year but that timetable was changed after Mr Malamatinas's unexpected departure. The rest of the shares in Burger King were to follow in a second sale.

Mr Walsh has been engaged in a major restructuring, disposing of parts of the former Guinness and Grand Metropolitan empires in order to concentrate on alcoholic beverages. He agreed the sale of its Pillsbury food group and succesfully bid for half of Seagram's spirits empire in conjunction with French drinks group Pernod-Ricard.

Diageo shares were down 23p last night, closing at 676p.

fields.headline: FTSE slides below 6,000
fields.standfirst: Markets across Europe feel impact as investors stop believing this is the boom era
fields.trailText: Stock markets across Europe fell to their lowest levels for more than a year yesterday, with London closing below the 6,000 mark for the first time in 16 months as banking, telecom and drug stocks dragged down indices.
fields.body:
Stock markets across Europe fell to their lowest levels for more than a year yesterday, with London closing below the 6,000 mark for the first time in 16 months as banking, telecom and drug stocks dragged down indices.

Renewed nervousness in the telecoms sector hit index heavyweight Vodafone and the prospect of a mortgage price war weighed on the banking sector, causing the FTSE 100 share index to fall more than 100 points, closing at its lowest point since October 1999.

"It was mainly telecoms and banks, there wasn't much going on elsewhere in the market to offset that," said one share dealer. "We have finally fallen back below 6,000. It should have happened before. It's just the market catching up with reality."

A lacklustre showing from Wall Street, back in operation after Monday's holiday, also weighed on sentiment. By mid-afternoon in New York the Nasdaq index of technology shares was down 3%, extending Friday's sharp losses prompted by profits warnings from Nortel and Hewlett Packard.

The Paris and Milan bourses closed at their lowest levels for 13 months while the Netherlands' AEX was down to its lowest level since December 1999.

The telecoms sector has been undermined by worries about the size of the debt being taken on by companies in the sector because of mergers and acquisitions, and the costs of acquiring third-generation mobile phone licences and building their infrastructure.

Shares in Vodafone, which on Monday fell below 200p for the first time in two years, lost another 9p to 190p yesterday.

The sector's cash needs were underlined yesterday when France Télécom announced that it was planning to raise up to $8bn through a bond issue.

Commerzbank equity strategist Rolf Elgeti nonetheless said he remained reasonably bullish about the outlook for the UK market.

"We have a year-end target of 7,500 for the FTSE 100. As long as the fundamentals don't change we don't see any need to change our view of a fair value for the market.

"The question is what is going to happen in the meantime. There is a lot less confidence in the market. People just don't believe the earnings forecasts and projections."

In London, banking shares, which have propped up the market in recent months, were undermined by fears of a price war after Halifax, Britain's biggest mortgage lender, announced it would be cutting its standard variable rate by 75 basis points.

The move came a day after Nationwide, the mutually owned building society, announced it would be lowering its basic mortgage rate.

Fears that the government will refer Lloyds TSB's offer for Abbey National to an in-depth competition inquiry also weighed on sentiment.

An end to the recently solid performances from market heavyweight GlaxoSmithKline, which dropped 4% ahead of today's full-year results, removed another a central pillar of support for the FTSE 100.
