fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Tory peers test tax barrier
fields.body:
Tory peers test tax barrier

Tory peers today open a campaign to simplify Britain's increasingly complex tax laws by seeking to amend the 1911 Parliament Act which banned the upper house from tampering with the budget plans of the Commons.

The bill being presented by Lord Saatchi, the advertising tycoon who is now a Conservative frontbench spokesman, will not seek to directly challenge MPs' power. Instead he will endorse calls by experts for the mechanics of the tax system to be separated from more controversial aspects - rates of tax, types and incidence.

If the Saatchi bill becomes law, peers would be allowed to examine such legislation for "simplicity, clarity and openness".

Lord Saatchi said British tax laws cover 6,000 pages, and pensioners seeking to obtain the new minimum income guarantee had to fill in a 40-page form.

Retailer boosts US connection

Fashion retailer French Connection yesterday accelerated its move into the US market with the $33m purchase of the remaining 50% of its American joint venture.

French Connection said the purchase of Best of All Clothing, or BoAC, would strengthen its global brand strategy by expanding its retail and wholesale businesses in the US, potentially the strongest market for the retailer over the longer term.

The acquisition from its joint venture partner, Michael Axelrod, is to be funded from the existing resources and cashflows of the group.

CGNU counts cost of sale

Newly merged insurance group CGNU said yesterday that it would incur an extra cost of £138m from the sale of its general insurance business in the United States to White Mountains Insurance group. The £1.4bn sale was announced in September.

Albert Fisher consolidates

Food manufacturer Albert Fisher is to shake up its frozen vegetable processing operations, leading to 180 job losses.

The group said yesterday it planned to consolidate its frozen vegetable operations on one site in King's Lynn, Norfolk, and cease operations in Grimsby, Lincolnshire.

Chief executive Terry Robinson said: "The board cannot ignore the need to maximise efficiency in order to underwrite competitive pricing."

AstraZeneca win in Sweden

Pharmaceuticals group AstraZeneca said a Swedish court had upheld its patent for a key ingredient in ulcer drug Losec, the world's top selling prescription medicine with annual sales of $6bn (£4bn).

The company, which has 40% of its global sales tied up in the drug, is fighting to extend patents in countries such as Norway, Germany, Hong Kong and South Africa. Legal battles are also due to start in the American market, which accounts for more than $4bn of Losec sales.

webTitle: Business: Cammell Laird rescue offer in jeopardy

fields.headline: Cammell Laird rescue offer in jeopardy
fields.trailText: Government attempts to save 1,500 jobs at Cammell Laird appeared to have failed last night after the chairman of the firm offering a new shipbuilding contract said the deal looked dead.
fields.body:
Government attempts to save 1,500 jobs at Cammell Laird appeared to have failed last night after the chairman of the firm offering a new shipbuilding contract said the deal looked dead.

Jim Davis, chairman of cruise ship start-up Luxus, said: "We have been offered impossible terms. I do not want to be the one to bring bad news but you cannot keep pushing water up a hill indefinitely."

Cammell said it was fighting to save the potential contract and has sent a joint letter with Luxus to the Department of Trade and Industry asking for clarification of an aid package received on Monday night.

The DTI originally offered $300m (£208m) of help in guaranteed loans to underwrite the $500m contract to build two cruise vessels for US-based Luxus.

"The DTI is now willing to share $100m more risk with the private sector during construction of the vessels," said a DTI spokeswoman, pointing out it was higher than any amount offered to anyone else.

Brett Martin, Cammell Laird's corporate development director, said Luxus was "jumping the gun" to write off the deal before the parties had heard from the DTI.

Two weeks ago Cammell threatened to cut up to 1,500 jobs and close shipyards unless the government came up with financial support within days. Cammell has been in trouble since late last year when a £50m deal to lengthen a cruise ship for Italian company Costa Crociere was cancelled at the last minute.

John Stafford, the chief executive who was architect of a renaissance at Cammell, resigned this month after the company announced first-half losses of £3.5m, compared to £7.7m profits for the same period last year.

fields.headline: Radio pick of the day
fields.trailText: Big dreams squashed into the mundanity of the nine to five are the subject of The Little Big Woman Radio Show (Radio 4, 11.0pm). Llewella Gideon plays, among other characters, Cynthia, a 35-year-old actress who is temping until West End stardom comes her way. She has the knack of making others confide in her, so she soon knows all about the dreams of canteen lady Amma and Mrs Henry, the office cleaner. Then there is the office bitch, who has it in for Cynthia just because the handsome security guard has shown an interest. Gideon's self-penned show zips through office politics in 15-minute daily segments, and whatever bad happens to Cynthia she rounds her day off with a song.

It might be a great job - assisting some of the greatest pianists in the world - but it is unlikely to get you noticed. Simon Townley explores this unsung art in Turning The Page (Radio 3, 8.30pm). Page-turners and pianists discuss their relationship, how they cope with the unexpected, and how a page-turner can add to, or detract from, a concert performance. The silent figure beside the maestro will never be overlooked again.

Charlie Gillett's world tour in search of The Sound Of The City reaches its final stop in Los Angeles (Radio 2, 9.0pm). Gillett explores how musicians, voices, rhythms and producers came together to produce a unique LA sound.

The silent figure beside the maestro will never be overlooked again. Charlie Gillett's world tour in search of The Sound Of The City reaches its final stop in Los Angeles (Radio 2, 9.0pm). Gillett explores how musicians, voices, rhythms and producers came together to produce a unique LA sound.

webTitle: Nappy threat to call centre staff

fields.headline: Nappy threat to call centre staff
fields.standfirst: NetNotes: Call Centres
fields.trailText: A call centre's staff were amazed and humiliated when their manager brought in disposable nappies and threatened that whoever made the most visits to the toilet would be forced to wear one.
fields.body:
A call centre's staff were amazed and humiliated when their manager brought in disposable nappies and threatened that whoever made the most visits to the toilet would be forced to wear one.

The horror story was just one of hundreds that have emerged over the past week via a TUC hotline, set up on February 12 as part of a campaign to improve conditions in call centres across Britain.

Some 550 people have phoned in complaining of bullying, impossible sales targets, risible breaks between calls, and hostility to unions.

But the majority have mentioned extreme pressure not to go to the toilet. "One of the most common themes has been needing permission to go to the toilet, having to put up your hand to do so, being monitored on toilet breaks, people who are spending more time in the toilet than others being marked out and, in one particular instance, a manager taking in a box of nappies," said a TUC spokeswoman.

The manager had made workers sign a "toilet book", but failed to carry out his threat of forcing them to wear nappies after a worker stood up to him."

Call centre workers, who on average earn just £12,850 - £9,000 less than the national average, also told of having been threatened with the sack if they joined unions.

Some were forced to go into work to report in sick, instead of being able to phone in and some were not allowed to take more than three days' consecutive leave, preventing anyone taking a proper holiday.

A caller complained of being allowed a three-second break between calls, and one was accused of being "idle" after taking a break for six seconds.

Another caller said that his boss forced people to take a monthly general knowledge quiz, disciplining them if they failed to get more than 95% three times.

John Monks, TUC general secretary, said many centres treated staff with respect while others were making an effort to "clean up" their image.

The call centre industry, which employs 400,000 people, has been blighted with a "sweatshop" tag. Workers stay less than 18 months on average, often leaving through the stress and tedium of the job. About 70% of them are women.

The extent of dissatisfaction with the industry emerged in a survey for Bella magazine.

The survey also revealed that employers in other industries were giving cash bonuses to workers to encourage them not to take sick leave - despite the risk of spreading infection to other colleagues.

Ann-Marie Stagg, chair of the Call Centre Management Association, which represents 500 call centre managers, said: "In the majority of centres, standards are very high, but there are small call centres, such as telesales teams, where you findthis level of over-supervision."

webTitle: Comment: Simon Tisdall offers Bush some tips on Saddam

fields.headline: Dear George...
fields.standfirst:
Simon Tisdall offers the US president a word or two of advice on defence and foreign policy, and some tips on Saddam

Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: Simon Tisdall offers the US president a word or two of advice on defence and foreign policy, and some tips on Saddam.
fields.body:
George Bush does not get out much. He has little personal experience of the world in which he now wields such critical influence. It is clear that he is relying heavily on hawkish old-stagers to run what increasingly looks from Europe like a go-it-alone, like-it-or-lump-it US security and foreign policy. When his top advisers said it was time to bomb Saddam again, for example, he said fine, go ahead, without much apparent thought or understanding of the consequences.

But Bush's world view is not yet set in stone. There is still a chance to persuade the greenhorn president that there is an alternative, consensual approach to international affairs, that alliances, partnerships and problem-sharing strengthen leadership, not weaken it.

This is Tony Blair's chal lenge as he prepares to meet Bush for the first time in Washington later this week. Striking up a good personal and working relationship is important for the prime minister after the cosy, in-the-loop Clinton years.

If Blair really wants to be a good friend to the Texan ingenue, he should offer some candid advice before it is too late on a range of contentious issues where the Bushmen are in serious danger of getting things wrong. There's self-interest here, of course. Labour and its supporters will not thank Blair for fudging or ducking these issues for the sake of a slavish, superficial amity, and nor will Britain's European partners.

Some plain talking now may save much future trouble. And if Blair can establish himself as a well-disposed but independent voice, it will strengthen Britain's position in both Europe and Washington. Here are some of the things Blair should tell the president:

 National Missile Defence or "Son of Star Wars" is a bad idea, badly presented, George. To us allies, it suggests that the US is abandoning collective defence. To Moscow, Beijing and Delhi, it looks like a military offensive.

 Nobody denies that there is an emerging threat from the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction. But if the US really wants new defensive systems, it must first genuinely consult the European allies and Russia and China about their scope and purpose. The US has got to demonstrate their effectiveness, how they fit with existing arms control treaties and how they can jointly serve everybody's security interests.

 Contrary to what Dick Cheney may have told you, George, Nato does not have a veto over the EU's plans to create a rapid reaction force. You're understandably suspicious about French intentions; Britain can help keep Paris in line. But having complained for years that Europe does not pull its weight militarily, it's plain daft to make more trouble over the RRF.

We in Britain appreciate you're worried about military over-stretch. But your talk of withdrawing from the Balkans is alarming. Kosovo and Serbia remain deeply unstable and we have our own troops there. It is simply not true that the US carries more than its fair share of the peacekeeping burden. Look at Britain's actions in Sierra Leone and East Timor. Try to be more positive towards the UN, George. This would increase American leverage when it really matters, as over Iraq now.

 Do stop antagonising Russia unnecessarily, as you did when your guys accused Moscow the other day of being an arch-proliferator. Vlad Putin, a man I know well, is an insecure little bloke with cold war instincts. He feels threatened by NMD, the EU's and Nato's eastward expansion and your rearmament plans. He is already beginning to react aggressively. Putin needs flattery and coaxing. You'll need Russia one day, as you did when the Kosovo air campaign was getting nowhere.

 Don't allow Ariel Sharon to destroy all the progress made in Israel's negotiations with the Palestinians. But if you don't want to lead Middle East mediation efforts, stand back and let us Europeans have a go. And whatever Donald Rumsfeld says, air strikes on Iraq (which I supported, by the way) do not constitute a strategy or a solution.

 Maybe you and I should offer an immediate lifting of all UN sanctions other than those relating to weapons and dual-use technology in return for a resumption of UN weapons inspections? US pillorying of Saddam just upsets the Arabs, who thought you were their new chum. And George, do try to engage with Iran instead of demonising it. The reformers in Tehran need positive encouragement to see off all those mad mullahs.

 Frankly, you have to try a lot harder on global warming, Dubya - may I call you Dubya? People in Europe have got the idea that you don't care about the environment. The Kyoto process must be revitalised. And please, think twice about pursuing trade wars with the EU and squeezing small countries through the World Trade Organisation. It's bad politics and bad business.

 And yes, since you ask, Britain will probably join the euro eventually. No, I don't have a date yet. Don't push me on this, okay! You know, our Eurosceptics are even worse than all your nutty, vote-fiddling, born-again pro-lifers... Whoops! Nothing personal, Mr President.

Do come visit soon, George. Despite all the above, we still have a lot in common.

simon.tisdall@theguardian.com

webTitle: Test case on jail tariff could set Hindley free

fields.headline: Test case on jail tariff could set Hindley free
fields.trailText: Two men serving life sentences for murder launched a test case yesterday which could pave the way for the Moors murderer Myra Hindley to win her freedom.
fields.body:
Two men serving life sentences for murder launched a test case yesterday which could pave the way for the Moors murderer Myra Hindley to win her freedom.

Lawyers for Anthony Anderson and John Taylor argued at the high court in London that the home secretary's role in fixing their tariff or earliest date of release is incompatible with the European convention on human rights.

The two, represented by Hindley's QC, Edward Fitzgerald, invoked the Human Rights Act, which made the convention part of UK law when it came into force last October.

Hindley lost her challenge to the "whole life tariff" set by Jack Straw, the home secretary, after a lengthy battle which ended in the House of Lords in 1999. But that was before the advent of the Human Rights Act, which has allowed new arguments to be mounted.

Lord Woolf, the lord chief justice, said in an interview that Mr Straw could be forced by the courts to release Hindley and other murderers against his will. He predicted judges might remove the home secretary's power to set the tariff.

Mr Fitzgerald argued that allowing a politician rather than a judge to fix the tariff breached article six of the European convention, which requires sentences to be set after a fair hearing by an independent and impartial tribunal.

A Home Office spokeswoman said hundreds of cases in which the home secretary had fixed a higher tariff than the minimum term recommended by judges could potentially be affected, although most of the tariffs for the country's 3,000 mandatory lifers had been set in line with judicial guidelines.

All 23 murderers, including Myra Hindley, who have been told they will never be released, will be able to challenge that decision if Anderson and Taylor succeed.

Mr Straw has already lost his role in setting tariffs for discretionary lifers - those serving life for crimes other than murder - and for young murderers like Jon Venables and Robert Thompson who are detained at her majesty's pleasure.

Mr Fitzgerald told Lord Justice Rose, Mr Justice Sullivan and Mr Justice Penry-Davey: "We submit that the writing is on the wall for the system _ the principal vice is simply one of principle. These are sentencing functions which should not be performed by a politician but by the judiciary."

Anderson, 38, was convicted in 1988 of murdering Thomas Walker, 60, and Michael Tierney, a homosexual, and got two life sentences. The judge, with the agreement of the lord chief justice, recommended his tariff should be 15 years.

In July 1994, the then home secretary, Michael Howard, set the minimum term Anderson must serve at 20 years, and that decision was reaffirmed by Mr Straw. The home secretary said the tariff was justified because Anderson had killed on two separate occasions.

Taylor, 45 and serving life at Whitemoor prison, was convicted at Sheffield crown court in January 1989 of murdering Susan McNamara, a snooker club owner. The trial judge and the lord chief justice set his tariff at 16 years, but in March this year Mr Straw set the minimum term he should serve in prison before being considered for parole at 22 years.

Mr Straw gave as his reasons evidence of sexual interference with - or theft from - the victim, the absence of mitigating factors, the "brutal nature" of the attack, the absence of any particular motive, and Taylor's previous convictions.

The hearing continues today.

fields.headline: Channel 4's 'Go on, jump' advert rapped
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Advertising watchdogs have criticised Channel 4 for an "irresponsible" poster that could have encouraged people to commit suicide.
fields.body:
Advertising watchdogs have criticised Channel 4 for an "irresponsible" poster that could have encouraged people to commit suicide.

The advertising standards authority upheld complaints about a poster that showed a man about to leap from a roof, promoting a documentary on basejumping the practice of jumping from buildings. A message below the picture read: "Go on, jump."

One of the complaints came from the Samaritans, which said that the force of the caption and image could have led to copycat action from anyone who felt depressed or suicidal. Camden council in north London also complained.

Channel 4 claimed its "innovative and unusual" advertising was designed to match the style of its programmes, saying the poster was intended to be provocative in order to depict the danger of basejumping. The text of the poster was later altered to the title of the Cutting Edge documentary: Confessions of a Base Jumper.

But the authority warned the broadcaster that it was forbidden from "encouraging dangerous practices" by the advertising code. In its ruling, the regulator said: "The authority considered the prominence of the text: 'Go on. Jump', with the image of a person standing on the edge of a high-rise building could have encouraged members of the public to commit suicide and was irresponsible.

"The authority noted the campaign had finished and welcomed the advertisers' assurance that the posters would not be used again."

The controversial sport of basejumping hit the headlines in 1992 when a carpenter, Darren Newton, was killed parachuting from the 27th floor of the London Hilton hotel.

All participants agree that if anyone is injured or killed on a jump the others will leave him to his fate, preserving their anonymity. The British Parachute Association condemns the sport as dangerous.

fields.headline: British youth tops drinking league
fields.standfirst:
Parents must share the blame for growing number of underage boozers, who look to their elders for example say health researchers

Interactive guide to drugs banned by the IOC
fields.trailText: Parents have to take some blame for British teenagers being near the top of international leagues in binge drinking, intoxication and experimenting with illegal drugs, researchers said yesterday.
fields.body:
Parents have to take some blame for British teenagers being near the top of international leagues in binge drinking, intoxication and experimenting with illegal drugs, researchers said yesterday.

Three in 10 of 15- to 16-year-olds have been drunk at least 20 times in their lives, one in three have tried an illicit drug, and one in five claim they were smoking at least a cigarette a day by the time they were 13.

The sorry tale of theUK's status for boozing and drug use was revealed in a study covering 60,000 teenagers in 30 countries.

It also pointed to a possible explanation for the UK's love affair with alcoholic excess at the weekends. Nearly one in 10 of British youngsters questioned claimed their families did not know where they were on a Saturday night and only half said their parents always knew where they were on such evenings.

That was worse than many European countries, including France, where seven in 10 teenagers said parents knew their whereabouts.

The publication of the survey results from research conducted in 1999 coincides with a World Health Organisation conference in Stockholm designed to wake Europe up to its drink problems.

Retailers and publicans were criticised for turning a blind eye to substantial sales of drink and tobacco to under-age buyers. Martin Plant, director of the alcohol and health research centre, Edinburgh, and coordinator of the UK part of survey, said the high tobacco use posed the greatest and most lasting risk to health.

"If boys and girls are raised in families where smoking or drinking or misuses of prescribed medication or illicit drugs is taking place, they are going to think it is normal _ Parents are clearly influential."

He said French parents seemed to communicate more with their children. "That suggests to me French parents may be better at establishing or delineating some kind of boundaries for what is acceptable for their teenagers."

His colleague Patrick Miller said there was a link between alcohol, drug and tobacco misuse and whether parents knew where their children were. Single parents "mostly strive to do a very good job" but there were indications that children from lone parent families in the UK, where mothers or fathers were generally poorer and more likely to be unemployed than in Europe, were also more prone to misuse.

Cultural changes

The researchers pointed out that adult drinking cultures had changed rapidly in some parts of Europe with big falls in France and Italy but soaring consumption in eastern states.

The results showed that 20% of the UK teenagers said they had smoked at least a cigarette a day when they were 13 or younger - although their lifetime consumption by 16 put this country 20th in the table, one of its more "healthy" results.

But young people in the UK vied with those in Denmark , Ireland and Poland to be the young heavy drinking "champions" of Europe. A third of boys and more than a quarter of girls said they had been drunk at least 20 times in their lives.

Their experience of other drugs was also more widespread than young people in other countries, although French teenagers had used cannabis more often recently.

There were strong indications that drug use was falling, including that of ecstasy, perhaps as a result of widely-publicised tragic consequences.

Dr Plant said policy must take account of the fact that 120,000 people a year died prematurely in the UK from smoking-related diseases, against up to 35,000 from alcohol and 1,200 from illicit drug taking. "The prime minister suggested we should set up a UK register for people dealing hard drugs _ that register should include a tobacconist who sells to 13-year-olds, because tobacco kills a higher proportion of regular users than any other drug. The le gal age for alcohol purchase is 18. With tobacco, the most dangerous drug on the planet, it would be better if the age was raised from 16 to 18, to 21, or 50."

Dr Plant added: "We are getting the extreme consequences of the centuries-old tradition of concentrating our drinking around weekends. Teenagers have adopted this behaviour at young ages."

Wider issue

Existing rules, including those forbidding sale of drink to people already intoxicated, should be more widely enforced, he said. More flexibility of licensed drinking hours in England and Wales might help, as it had in Scotland. "If you have too many controls, you could drive things underground."

Paul Boateng, minister for children and young people, said: "This study raises a wider issue of rights and responsibilities in society today. Our drive to improve standards in education, reform the youth justice system and the New Deal for the young unemployed are helping to ensure that young people are encouraged to take greater responsibility for themselves and others, as well as providing better work and social opportunities.

"But this cannot just be a matter for government. Encouraging more responsible behaviour amongst the young is a matter for us all - parents, teachers, friends and communities."

Another report by Paul Willner, director for the centre for substance abuse research at the University of Wales, Swansea, suggested that huge numbers of 16-year-olds, and girls as young as 13, were buying alcohol, and that retailers, including supermarkets, were making little attempt to check their age. Vendors saw little risk in selling to minors and showed little sign of changing their behaviour in response to threats of legal action that were not followed through.

The 1999 ESPAD Report - The European school survey project on alcohol and other drugs, £30 (including p&p), Alcohol and health research centre, Greenbank Drive, Edinburgh EH10 5SB.

The results showed that 20% of the UK teenagers said they had smoked at least a cigarette a day when they were 13 or younger - although their lifetime consumption by 16 put this country 20th in the table, one of its more "healthy" results. But young people in the UK vied with those in Denmark , Ireland and Poland to be the young heavy drinking "champions" of Europe. A third of boys and more than a quarter of girls said they had been drunk at least 20 times in their lives. Their experience of other drugs was also more widespread than young people in other countries, although French teenagers had used cannabis more often recently. There were strong indications that drug use was falling, including that of ecstasy, perhaps as a result of widely-publicised tragic consequences. Dr Plant said policy must take account of the fact that 120,000 people a year died prematurely in the UK from smoking-related diseases, against up to 35,000 from alcohol and 1,200 from illicit drug taking. "The prime minister suggested we should set up a UK register for people dealing hard drugs _ that register should include a tobacconist who sells to 13-year-olds, because tobacco kills a higher proportion of regular users than any other drug. The le gal age for alcohol purchase is 18. With tobacco, the most dangerous drug on the planet, it would be better if the age was raised from 16 to 18, to 21, or 50." Dr Plant added: "We are getting the extreme consequences of the centuries-old tradition of concentrating our drinking around weekends. Teenagers have adopted this behaviour at young ages." Wider issue Existing rules, including those forbidding sale of drink to people already intoxicated, should be more widely enforced, he said. More flexibility of licensed drinking hours in England and Wales might help, as it had in Scotland. "If you have too many controls, you could drive things underground." Paul Boateng, minister for children and young people, said: "This study raises a wider issue of rights and responsibilities in society today. Our drive to improve standards in education, reform the youth justice system and the New Deal for the young unemployed are helping to ensure that young people are encouraged to take greater responsibility for themselves and others, as well as providing better work and social opportunities. "But this cannot just be a matter for government. Encouraging more responsible behaviour amongst the young is a matter for us all - parents, teachers, friends and communities." Another report by Paul Willner, director for the centre for substance abuse research at the University of Wales, Swansea, suggested that huge numbers of 16-year-olds, and girls as young as 13, were buying alcohol, and that retailers, including supermarkets, were making little attempt to check their age. Vendors saw little risk in selling to minors and showed little sign of changing their behaviour in response to threats of legal action that were not followed through. The 1999 ESPAD Report - The European school survey project on alcohol and other drugs, £30 (including p&p), Alcohol and health research centre, Greenbank Drive, Edinburgh EH10 5SB.

webTitle: How support for UN strategy withered away

fields.headline: How support for UN strategy withered away
fields.standfirst:
What went wrong: Iraqi defiance pays dividends

Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: What went wrong: Iraqi defiance pays dividends.
fields.body:
The operation to keep Saddam Hussein in his cage began with broad international support but, more than 10 years later, is now mainly an American concern with Britain tagging along to help keep up appearances.

Sanctions were originally designed to force Iraq out of Kuwait, and later to make it comply with UN security council resolutions -of which there are now about 50. The main goal now is to pressure Iraq into allowing inspectors back to complete the elimination of all its weapons of mass destruction. Another aim - at least for the US - is to bring about the overthrow of President Saddam. The multi-pronged approach comprises:

 Trade sanctions A few days after the invasion of Kuwait in August 1990 the security council imposed comprehensive trade sanctions on Iraq. Amid mounting concern about the shortages and suffering that resulted, this was adapted, in 1996, into the oil for food programme which allowed Iraq to sell limited amounts of oil as "a temporary measure to provide for the humanitarian needs of the Iraqi people".

Although there is no longer a ceiling on oil exports, and most items can now be imported without specific approval by the UN, earlier hold-ups with medicines and other essential items have discredited the programme.

Under the programme, large deductions are made from Iraq's oil revenue to feed the northern Kurds, compensate victims of the invasion of Kuwait and cover UN administration costs.

This has given Iraq an incentive to develop illicit sources of revenue outside the UN programme: smuggled oil is worth roughly twice as much to Iraq as legitimate oil, and about 10% of Iraqi production is thought to be smuggled. Smuggling has also helped to keep President Saddam in power by providing funds to pamper the Iraqi elite.

 No-fly zones The zones were established after the Gulf war to protect the Shia population in southern Iraq and the Kurds in the north.

Patrolling US and British aircraft have flown more than 16,000 sorties in the past four years alone and have frequently attacked Iraqi anti-aircraft systems on the ground.

Apart from the financial cost (Britain has spent £800m), accidental civilian casualties have played into Iraq's hands by discrediting the policy - though western sources say Iraq's claim of 300 deaths is exaggerated.

Iraq's military aircraft are barred from operating in the no-fly zones, but in November Iraq complicated the situation by resuming civilian flights into the zones: from Baghdad to Basra in the south and Mosul in the north.

 Weapons inspections Since the Gulf war Iraq has played a cat-and-mouse game over inspections of its nuclear, chemical and biological weapons programmes.

The UN inspectors left in December 1998 after confrontations over access to presidential "palaces" in Iraq. US and British bombing raids failed to secure their return.

The latest plan, set out in security council resolution 1284 more than a year ago, is to send a new monitoring team to Iraq in return for the probable suspension of trade sanctions. Iraq shows no sign of agreeing to the plan.

fields.headline: Rod Liddle's diary
fields.standfirst: Listen without prejudice
fields.trailText: A week off and the chance to hear Today as normal people hear it; a sort of fractious, episodic, three-hour argument. And all overlaid with the predictable soundtrack of an ordinary domestic morning... bacon sizzling, bath water gurgling, the harrowing screams of children playing with a rusty bradawl, the cheery rat-a-tat-tat of the bailiff.
fields.body:
A week off and the chance to hear Today as normal people hear it; a sort of fractious, episodic, three-hour argument. And all overlaid with the predictable soundtrack of an ordinary domestic morning... bacon sizzling, bath water gurgling, the harrowing screams of children playing with a rusty bradawl, the cheery rat-a-tat-tat of the bailiff.

It's not perfect. "Tell those boring men to shut up," says Tyler at 8.15. And then, hitting the radio with a piece of wood which was once the skirting board, "shut up, shut up, shut up, SHUT UP." He's too young for debates about genetic testing, but maybe he should pay a bit of attention - news junkie genes will get him in the end. Even now, at three years old, he's a fan of Nicky Campbell.

Listened to like this, the programme seems different. The things that annoy are not a general lack of Keith Vaz or Peter Mandelson, as they are when I'm in the office, but bewildering time checks that defy basic temporal logic and interviews or debates that are truncated suddenly for no apparent reason.

You sit at home thinking, "why did they do that?" And sometimes, if you're me, you ring in and howl. Serving the episodic listener is a tricky business and I think we do a pretty good job, most of the time. Broadcasting House, on a Sunday morning, invariably gets it right; it is superbly produced and well-paced.

My last act for the BBC, before this brief sabbatical in hell, was to act as Jonathan Dimbleby's rather nervy warm-up man for a London edition of Any Questions. You may not be aware of this, but the first question Jonathan asks is not broadcast; it's just there to test the microphones and general sound level. The panellists know this and, as a result, their replies are sometimes rather more candid than if the question were asked on air.

"What one thing would you abolish, given the chance?", was the test question last week. To a general murmur of assent from the gathered audience, Ken Livingstone replied: "Breakfast television." As a BBC employee, pledged to neutrality on all contentious issues, it would have been quite improper to punch the air and scream with Schadenfreude or delight.

The other panellists chime in, Channel Five boss Dawn Airey and transport minister Lord Macdonald, both witty and sharp. And then there's a general hush as the question is asked of guest number four, Sir Edward Heath. Midway through his ninth decade, he carries with him an extraordinary sense of both gravitas and mischief, in equal measure. "Oh," he replies, waving an age-mottled hand in the air, "just Government."

 Rod Liddle is editor of BBC Radio 4's Today Programme. His column appears every Wednesday.

webTitle: Gary Young: Tory policy on the telegraph letters page

fields.headline: Tory policy seems to be based on the Telegraph letters page
fields.standfirst:
Hague is welcome to sail away on Battleship Nostalgia. Let's leave him to it

Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: Hague is welcome to sail away on Battleship Nostalgia. Let's leave him to it.
fields.body:
Rear Admiral Sir Morgan Morgan-Giles sounds like a rum old chap. "Women are wonderful," he says, writing on the prospect of female soldiers fighting on the frontline in a missive to the Telegraph from his home in Little Sodbury. But their wonders, he believes, have limits. "Women's work is to create life, nurture life and protect life. Mother love is the strongest of all human emotions, and is indeed the basis of civilisation."

Major John Cann from Ascot agrees. In a letter published the same day he argues: "In the majority of the animal world the male species protects the female species, and in the army in the frontline this is bound to apply."

For those of us who are incapable of living our lives according to the laws of nature there is still hope, writes John Capel from Usk, on the subject of "homosexual temptations". "For Christians," he writes, "the important distinction is whether or not the individual is acknowledging the weaknesses, repenting of the failures and seeking to amend."

Writing to the Telegraph after shadow chancellor, Francis Maude, suggested the Tories might one day have a gay leader, he states: "Of course the liberal intelligentsia claim 'being gay' is not wrong, but most of us know that it is."

Just below, Pastor Ken Slater is preparing the stable boys for the four horsemen of the apocalypse. After a quote from The Revelation of St John the Divine comes the omen: "Sexual deviation is a mark on the spiritual barometer which indicates that stormy days are ahead."

Britain, according to the Telegraph letters page, is indeed a scary place. When it comes to gender politics and sexual orientation its postbag reads like an unholy alliance between Eminem and the squires from the shires.

To be fair there is occasional dissent - the day after the page had been transformed into a homophobic pamphlet, there were several pleas for sanity. But for the most part it is a land where men are chaps, women are ladies and Maude is a liberal. It is as though the past 50 years never happened. Like an afternoon watching reruns on UK Gold, you are left with the peculiar sense that the past and the present run not consecutively but concurrently.

Confined to the Telegraph letters page all of this would represent little more than an everyday tale of ordinary, rightwing, letter-writing folk - a group of people for whom, like their leftwing counterparts, conviction and obsession are close bedfellows. But it does not stop there. These views are a fairly accurate reflection not only of Telegraph readers but Tory leaders. It is an expression of impotent rage that the world is not how it should be with no accompanying notion of how it might be improved.

They hate the Macpherson report, but have no suggestions for restoring confidence in policing; they revile the Northern Ireland peace process, but offer no alternative. They not only mythologise the past and loathe the present but refuse to even contemplate the future.

It is a mindset which Hague at first appeared keen to challenge. His appearance at Notting Hill carnival in his baseball cap was the first sign, albeit a cheesy one, that he wanted to shift the perception, if not the direction, of his party. He spoke of "compassion" and "inclusivity", brought gay, Eurosceptic businessman Ivan Massow into the spotlight, and looked forward to a time when his party would have a black or Asian leader.

But gradually it all started to unravel. When he wasn't demonising homosexuality in debates over section 28, he was targetting asylum seekers and upsetting the grieving parents of Damilola Taylor, with outbursts of racist opportunism.

While his remarks provoked predictable rage from liberals they also began to alienate some of his own side. Massow defected to Labour. Through his senior aide Steve Norris, the Tory mayoral candidate for London, said that he felt "increasingly detached" from the "rather unpleasant core" of the party. Last month Lord Archer (remember him?) de scribed his former party as one which "would give blacks and Asians a 'pat on the head' but not invite them into their homes"

Labour should take some of the credit for this mayhem. By lowering the age of consent for gay men, launching the inquiry into Stephen Lawrence's death and passing anti-discrimination legislation, they helped reshape the discourse on equality and minority rights. With an election imminent and the prospect of Tory victory distant, Hague sensed an opportunity to rally his own troops around the fear of change.

In the short term this is less reckless a strategy than it looks. Nobody expects Hague to win, just to put a serious dent in Labour's lead. Given that more than a third of Labour's majority comprises seats held by less than 5,000 votes, Hague could do it - particularly if he motivates his base and Labour voters stay at home. In crude electoral terms he may be right; in moral terms he is simply crude.

But while there is an immediate market for the brand of Powellite rhetoric Hague has been dabbling in of late, there is not a political future in it for a party that needs to reclaim the centre-right in order to return to office.

The average age of a Tory member is over 60, and now that the membership elect the leadership it actually matters what they think. If Hague wants his party to sound, look and act like it has plans for the century we have just entered rather than the one we left behind, he will have to tell it things it does not want to hear. The more he galvanises his traditional base, the more he ostracises potential support. That leaves the Tories in a similar place today with public and private morality that Labour were in with the economy during the early 80s - in a hole, in fact. The deeper they get the more furiously they dig.

The tragedy is that whereas Thatcher was proud of her market credentials, New Labour appears embarrassed by its professed commitment to equality. Instead of looking down on Tory scapegoating as an act of desperation, they keep getting down in the muck with them; unleashing bull dogs onto party political broadcasts, vilifying asylum seekers and trumpeting family values.

Moral bankruptcy aside, there are two principal problems with this. First, the Tories will always make better bigots than Labour. They have had more practice and have fewer qualms of conscience. So when Labour propose vouchers and dispersal for asylum seekers, the Conservatives do not retreat but advance with the promise of mass detentions. Second, it is off message. A party which simultaneously prides itself on modernisation cannot simultaneously mourn the passing of the good old days with either consistency or credibility.

So let Hague lead the Telegraph's admirals on the Battleship Nostalgia. It is heading for rocks. If Labour do not have the confidence to sink it, the least they could do is not follow it.

webTitle: Reactions to US policy on Iraq

fields.headline: International reaction
fields.standfirst:
From frosty silence to vocal criticism, doubts abound

Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: From frosty silence to vocal criticism, doubts abound.
fields.body:
France Foreign minister Hubert Védrine says he is waiting for the Bush administration to provide a "redefinition of the policy on Iraq". Existing sanctions against Iraq are "not working well - it is the population that is suffering and we are calling for it to end"

Germany Silence. Chancellor Gerhard Schröder says he prefers to discuss Iraq directly with Washington rather than conduct diplomacy in public

Italy Foreign minister Lamberto Dini plans to question US secretary of state Colin Powell about the attack on Iraq's air defences when they meet in Washington this week

Japan US ally, but withheld public support for the recent bombing

Turkey Allows US and British jets to use its air bases to patrol northern Iraq but criticised the bombing

Russia President Vladimir Putin aims to work with France "to restore the dialogue between the Iraqi side and the United States and to undertake efforts for the rapid resolution of the Iraqi question on the basis of UN security council resolutions". Described recent air strikes as counter-productive

Kuwait Wants a firm policy towards Iraq but does not object to more flexibility in sanctions. Its main concerns are ensuring security in the region and protecting Kuwait's own sovereignty. It does not want sanctions lifted until Iraq has returned, or accounted for, the 600 Kuwaitis who disappeared during the Iraqi occupation

Saudi Arabia Provides facilities for western forces to maintain the no-fly zones. Remained silent after last week's attacks around Baghdad. Although a close US ally, it is sensitive to Arab popular feelings about double standards applied by the US towards Iraq and Israel

Egypt Another important US ally. Favours a negotiated solution but criticised

US-British bombing on the grounds that it would undermine talks due to begin at the UN next week

Syria Supported the allied side in the 1991 Gulf war, but has recently improved its relations with Baghdad. Some analysts say the change is because Syria feels isolated and is looking for new friends in the region

Oman Says it wishes "those strikes had not happened"

webTitle: Comment: Scotland and Wales could undermine Labour in the election

fields.headline: Pulling the party down
fields.standfirst: Success, and failure, in Scotland and Wales could undermine Labour when it comes to the election
fields.trailText: They're playing "guess the majority" over at Millbank Tower. Not publicly, of course, since complacency is a capital crime on Planet New Labour, but in private all is confidence. The election, whether it comes on April 5 or May 3, belongs to them.
fields.body:
They're playing "guess the majority" over at Millbank Tower. Not publicly, of course, since complacency is a capital crime on Planet New Labour, but in private all is confidence. The election, whether it comes on April 5 or May 3, belongs to them.

You can understand their swagger. Every possible sign points their way; every light is turning green. They look at yesterday's Guardian/ICM poll and see a lead stretching into the distance: a 15-point margin at a time when most governments are lucky to be in the low single digits.

Or they can glance at the "poll of polls" produced by that veteran number-cruncher, Ivor Crewe. His latest average of the competing surveys shows Labour with an even fatter 17-point lead - enough to swell Labour's majority from 179 seats to 229.

The Millbankers can slice it whichever way they like, it's still the same story. Labour are more trusted than the Conservatives to handle education, health and transport - and even traditional Tory strong suits like the economy and law and order. On every measure, they win. No postwar government has enjoyed a command like it; even Margaret Thatcher's post-Falklands surge in 1983 was not as strong.

The private polling, where Labour might tell itself some unwelcome truths, is just as encouraging. Voters still associate the Tories with the bad old days of the early 90s - sky-high interest rates, repossessions, negative equity. Black Wednesday has become the Tories' Winter of Discontent: Labour only has to mention it to scare voters on to their side. Reporters may be bored rigid by hearing Gordon Brown chant "No return to boom and bust", but the polls show it works. Yesterday the Halifax did their bit to help, too: their cut in base rates, and the general price war in the mortgage business, all add to the pre-election, feelgood mood.

As if Labour's advantage was not great enough already, it has two more weapons at the ready. First, the Millbank crew have had a recent lesson in how not to do it. They watched Al Gore's narrow defeat last year, realising that even a party presiding over economic good times can lose. Gore's mistake, they concluded, was to treat America's prosperity as a given, thereby denying the Democrats credit for their achievement. That's why the Blairite soundbite du jour is that Britain's economic health - record lows in both inflation and unemployment - is the fruit of "choice, not chance". Labour refuses to let this election become a debate with the Tories on how to spend it - they want credit for generating the surplus cash in the first place. And, so far, they're getting it.

Labour's second nuclear device is William Hague. Polls show the British have warmed to him about as much as they did to Neil Kinnock: they simply do not see him as a plausible prime minister. Indeed, Blair's personal lead over Hague is a whopping 20 points.

No blot, it seems, can muddy this landscape. The Tory boomlet of September's fuel protests went as fast as it came. Peter Mandelson's resignation excited the natterers and chatterers of the Westminster village but made no dent on the polls. The Derry Irvine, cash-for-wigs affair adds to the widespread impression of an arrogant Labour administration - but it seems unlikely to shift many votes. Tony Blair must reckon that his is the Teflon government: both the Mandy and Derry episodes would have unravelled John Major, but they seem to wash right off him.

Can anything darken this blue sky for Labour? Only one thing: turnout. If Labour's supporters stay at home, confident that victory is theirs, and Conservatives head out, energised by their determination to keep the pound, a gap that should have been a mile-wide could suddenly narrow. That's why Blair's last two big speeches were so blatantly aimed at waking up and motivating Labour voters.

In this context there are a couple of distant clouds which, even if they don't threaten to ruin Labour's spring day, could certainly cause the odd unwanted shower. The irony is that both are of the government's own making. Indeed, the source of the trouble is one of Labour's most radical first-term achievements: devolution.

I t is in Wales that the problem is most obvious. Labour figures there warn that the party could lose between seven and 10 of the 34 Welsh seats they now hold. They cite the 1999 elections for the new Welsh assembly, when Labour lost the iconic strongholds of the Rhondda, Islwyn (Kinnock's old seat) and Llanelli.

The explanation is simple. "You ask people here what they would prefer to have, the national assembly or bubonic plague, and most of them would opt for the latter," says one Labour sceptic. He believes the government is now blamed for creating a body - following the narrowest of referendum victories in 1997 - which nobody wants. One recent poll found two-thirds of Welsh voters disapproved of the assembly, with Labour taking the rap. A recent council byelection in Wrexham saw Labour's total vote slump to just 50 - in a seat where its previous majority had been 654.

Activists are still smarting over the Alun Michael episode - when Millbank sought to impose its own man as Welsh Labour leader over the people's choice, Rhodri Morgan -and have struggled to recover ever since. Now installed as first minister, Morgan has missed the odd political trick, too: he let himself announce the Corus steel closure in Llanwern, but allowed one of his Liberal Democrat coalition partners to get the glory of revealing that the FA Cup was coming to Cardiff. "Naff politics," sniffs one critic. Punishment could come on polling day, when Welsh voters either defect to Plaid Cymru again - or stay home.

In Scotland, Labour has the reverse problem - not that devolution has failed to bed down, but that it has bedded down too comfortably. While the Welsh still doubt the purpose of their assembly, Scots have grown entirely used to their new parliament in Edinburgh: "It's as if it was always there," says one fulltime observer.

The result is that a general election for Westminster could feel a very faraway affair. Now that so many key decisions are taken at Holyrood, Labour will have an uphill struggle explaining why the coming poll is even relevant to Scotland. After all, the key Blair themes - education, health and crime - are no longer decided in Westminster at all, but in Edinburgh. If anything, the new dispensation helps the Tories: at least their core issues - Europe and asylum, for example - remain Westminster matters. The one crumb of comfort for Labour is that if the remoteness of the House of Commons hurts them, imagine what it does to the Scottish National party: how on earth will they get their vote out?

For wholly opposite reasons - the success of devolution in Scotland, its struggle to take root in Wales - two Labour bastions threaten to spoil the party this spring. It won't be enough to change the final outcome, but it could alter the scale of victory. Any of those Millbank workers, about to place their bet in the office sweepstake, take note.

fields.headline: Country Diary
fields.standfirst: Woolly thinking
fields.trailText: Tamar Valley
fields.body:
Tamar Valley

Carrying two lambs and imitating their bleating, Queenie encourages the mother into the strawed-down linhay to join another dozen ewes and their 3-day-old lambs, prior to being turned out onto grass. After initial confusion they soon rebond, matching identity numbers on their backs. The lambs were born in the adjoining covered yard, tended day and night by Queenie, her husband and son.

Only a few of their first 200 Close Wools and Mules remain to lamb, and then another 300 will be brought indoors. The third and final batch will bring the total to over 750 lambed ewes. By the steep farm drive, black-faced rams skulk beside a sunny hedge and, in the higher field, ewes bearing single lambs eat hay from a galvanised feeder. The majority, scanned with twins or triplets, are given extra rations.

Recent frosty nights and sunny days have dried up sodden, poached ground. Across the valley, below St Mellion's silhouetted church tower, Crocadon woods are still wintry, grey lichened oaks above brown leaf mould, contrasting with the south-facing, sheep-trodden pastures leading up to Vernigo. In the sheltered, high-banked lane to Halton Quay, among masses of round pennyworts, primroses are already in flower and straggly, unflailed hazel twigs bear pollen-full, lemon-yellow catkins. Further down, in sight of the tidal river, growing between shiny celandines are clumps of full-out daffodils - relics from the defunct market gardens of Brentswood; there is also one surviving garden, which has been planted with rows of staked eucalyptus.

webTitle: Arts: La vie en rose. America's unruly jazz musicians found a home from home in Paris.

fields.headline: La vie en rose
fields.standfirst: The women danced half-naked, the men settled disputes with bullets. But America's unruly jazz musicians found a home from home in Paris. By  Stuart Jeffries
fields.trailText: The women danced half-naked, the men settled disputes with bullets. But America's unruly jazz musicians found a home from home in Paris. By Stuart Jeffries.
fields.body:
When Josephine Baker was eight, she worked for a white woman who plunged Baker's hands into boiling water because she used too much soap in the wash. In her native St Louis, she witnessed terrifying race riots in 1917 that left 39 black people dead and thousands homeless. She had a better time in France. In her first two years in Paris she received 46,000 fan letters and 2,000 marriage proposals.

The singer and dancer sailed for France in 1925, when she was 19. In Paris, Baker joined the cast of the Revue Nègre, a song and dance troupe put together by a bored American diplomat's wife. Baker drove Paris wild. But then she would, wouldn't she? She danced bare-breasted, often wore a belt of bananas and had a rear end that wiggled at least 120 times per minute.

"Eroticism has found a style," wrote Jean Cocteau. Erich Maria Remarque, author of All Quiet on the Western Front, wrote that Baker "brought a whiff of jungle air and an elemental strength and beauty to the tired showplace of western civilisation".

When she returned to the States in the 1930s, having established herself as France's leading variety artist and contributed enormously to the popularity of jazz in Europe, Baker was ridiculed because of her reedy, high-pitched voice. In France she lived in a chateau in the Dordogne; in the US she was refused a hotel room because she was black.

The 1920s Revue Nègre started a craze in Paris for things black and American, especially jazz. It has been a long love affair, commemorated in the release this week of 50 remastered CDs by Universal Records, which include everything from Django Reinhardt, Stéphane Grappelli and the rest of the Quintette du Hot Club de France playing Limehouse Blues, to Toots Thielemans's Blues Pour Flirter, as well as lots of wonderful Oscar Peterson, Zoot Sims and Lucky Thompson, all of it recorded in Paris between the 1930s and the late 1970s. Above all, it gives us a chance to savour that now-distant time when Saint Germain-des-Prés swung and many a black-turtle necked existentialist knew more about the discography of the musician on stage than the musician himself.

But Paris's jazz craze could have been nipped in the bud. In the 1920s the authorities decided to impose quotas: half the members of every band had to be French nationals, a rule that would have made Parisian jazz desperately insipid. Fortunately, the Americans got round that by having French musicians sitting in the band doing nothing more than hold their instruments.

During this time, a young clarinettist from New Orleans called Sidney Bechet arrived in Paris for the first time. He joined a band led by Claude Hopkins, taking part in a show featuring Josephine Baker. It all went well until 1929, when he had an argument with a banjo player. They ended up trading gunshots, three people were wounded and Bechet was jailed for a year before being deported.

But, as they had done with Baker, the French clasped Bechet to their bosom. The authorities managed to "lose" the evidence of Bechet's deportation order, and so, after the war, he was able to settle in Paris for good. One American visitor wrote: "Sidney could have become mayor of Paris if he wanted to. Crowds of people followed him through the streets. I was never so surprised in my whole life as when I discovered that a compatriot, whom I had barely heard of, had become the darling of the French."

The French called Bechet "le dieu" and after he died in 1959 the seaside town of Juan-les-Pins, where he had one of his two mansions, erected a statute to him.

Bechet installed himself in Paris at the right time. The city had just been liberated and jazz in France was just about to come of age. In the aftermath of the second world war jazz clubs spread quickly around Saint Germain. Near the church of St Julien-le-Pauvre the Trois Mailletz club opened in a cellar complete with gothic arches. The Chat Qui Peche club saw Donald Byrd's bebop quintet play regularly, and Jean-Luc Ponty and Eddy Louiss started their careers there. There was jazz and dancing at the Tabou. In most Left Bank clubs, though, there was no dancing, just a great deal of chin-scratching contemplation.

There's a lovely photograph of the Donald Byrd Quintet in some tiny Left Bank club in the mid-1950s. They're probably halfway through a skittering reading of Salt Peanuts or an achingly slow take on Stardust. Bobby Jaspar is playing the tenor solo, with Walter Davis Jr on an upright jammed against the wall. Doug Watkins is on bass and somehow Art Taylor has managed to get his drum kit into this little cellar. In the foreground, the last word in cool in a sharp suit, Byrd stands with his eyes closed. He's taking a last drag before picking up his trumpet to play the theme.

Crammed around them in this tiny room are lots of studious white Parisians in jackets and ties. One man in particular draws one's attention. He's standing against a pillar with his head tilted down and thus repeating the posture and extreme concentration of Doug Watkins. Jazz - it's as serious as life, you know.

In an article called Jazz 1947 Jean-Paul Sartre wrote wrote gnomically: "Jazz music is like bananas; you eat them on the spot." He added that French musicians were "melancholy imitators". But this notion became less true as time went on. In the 1920s Paris could only listen to this new-found art form. But in the 1930s, Reinhardt and Grappelli showed the way. Over the next two decades Paris produced an increasing number of original musicians who thrived in Saint Germain - Guy Lafitte, Pierre Michelot, Guy Pederson, Henri Renaud and Jean-Luc Ponty.

"Saint Germain did for music what Montparnasse did for painting after 1918. And it wasn't just any kind of music, it was jazz," said Renaud. For a while jazz was everywhere in Paris. Everybody had copies of Sidney Bechet's huge hits, Petite Fleur and Oignons. His lavish Riviera wedding was shown on newsreels. At the Olympia theatre, Louis Armstrong, Erroll Garner and the band from the Club St Germain appeared on the same bill as Juliette Greco.

Despite the rise of French musicians, Americans dominated Paris jazz in the 1960s. Miles Davis, Dizzy Gillespie, Chet Baker, Peanuts Holland, Lucky Thompson and Zoot Sims played long residencies, while Kenny Clarke and Bill Coleman were virtually permanent fixtures.

What drew them to Paris? Scott Fitzgerald put it this way: "There is no second act in an American's life." Especially if you're a jazz musician. But in France it was and is different: the French love their jazz so much that they give musicians not only second acts, but third, fourth and fifth acts, as well as generous state subsidies and the occasional statue.

In France they look after jazz talent long after it has passed its American sell-by date. Consider Chet Baker. In 1952 this good-looking trumpeter was top of the Billboard charts, but his drug addiction put paid to that. His pretty-boy looks became spectacularly craggy, and his popularity waned. In the mid 1950s he arrived in Paris and immediately took Saint Germain by storm. Though he was strung out on drugs for much of the time, he kept up an intense and gloomy relationship with the city for the next three decades.

And Paris gave Baker not just a second act, but an unexpected final one, too. He returned to France in 1975, where he started to play and record extensively. There was a renewed assurance and heartfelt lyricism in both his playing and his singing. Universal has just re-released an album he cut in Paris on the afternoon of December 28 1978, at the instigation of one of his most loyal friends and admirers, Gilles Gautherin. It's called Broken Wing and, if you can quickly acquire a taste for his singing (not everybody can), it's a wonderfully tender album, as good as anything he ever did - especially the track called Blue Gilles, written in honour of the Frenchman who helped him thrive anew.

But that story, of the ageing American jazz musician helped by some French enthusiast, is a classic of Parisian jazz. It's told in Bertrand Tavernier's 1986 film Round Midnight, in which a lanky, ageing black tenor sax player (played uncannily by lanky, ageing black tenor player Dexter Gordon) is befriended by a small white jazz buff. The once-great musician has been booked at the Blue Note but seems to be over the hill. Now he's just a guy struggling to work and to overcome a drink problem.

The Parisian hasn't enough money to pay for admission to the club to hear his beloved musician play. But he loves jazz so much that he borrows some money from his wife to buy a flat where the tenor player can stay and rebuild his life. And it works: the American stops drinking and starts composing again. "You treat me like a king," says American to Frenchman. But will it last when he is back in New York and his old environment - without his French friend to nurture him? Probably not.

Paris is no longer head over heels in love with jazz. Now it's mostly for nostalgics or tourists, though some good gigs remain. The international stars play at New Morning, and the Jazz Club Lionel Hampton, named after the francophile wizard of the vibraphone, still thrives in the Meridien hotel. Even on the Left Bank, some clubs cling on amid the couturiers' boutiques. Le Petit Journal St-Michel and La Villa on Rue Jacob struggle to keep afloat amid high rents. Bilboquet, a Saint Germain club that opened in 1947 and was a haven of cool jazz in the 1950s, now relies largely on tourists.

But Paris is still a haven for black jazz musicians from the States. The American jazz singer Dee Dee Bridgewater is virtually unknown in her homeland but since 1983 has flourished in France. "I had stopped doing jazz in the US," she recalls. "There wasn't a market for it, so I wound up doing pop. But I found in Europe there was a huge market for standard jazz.

"I went to Paris to work. I was hired to sing in Sophisticated Lady as the lead. The show was a big hit. Then I started getting concert work, which floored me because in the US without a big record company behind you you only get club dates. I started playing small theatres and my reputation grew and then the festivals kicked in. I arrived in November 1983 and I stayed."

Why? "Because I loved it and because I met a Frenchman and fell in love." Now, like Josephine Baker and Sidney Bechet before her, Dee Dee Bridgewater is a French national icon. It's her second act, and she doesn't want it to end any time soon.

"France allowed me to grow as an artist. I have been able to do just about anything that I wanted to do. That's really, really cool. As soon as I get on to the plane going to France I get real good treatment in first class. And I always get people asking why. And I have to tell them, 'Baby, you gotta realise one thing. I'm a big star in France.' "

 The Jazz in Paris CD series is available now from Universal Jazz.

The French called Bechet "le dieu" and after he died in 1959 the seaside town of Juan-les-Pins, where he had one of his two mansions, erected a statute to him. Bechet installed himself in Paris at the right time. The city had just been liberated and jazz in France was just about to come of age. In the aftermath of the second world war jazz clubs spread quickly around Saint Germain. Near the church of St Julien-le-Pauvre the Trois Mailletz club opened in a cellar complete with gothic arches. The Chat Qui Peche club saw Donald Byrd's bebop quintet play regularly, and Jean-Luc Ponty and Eddy Louiss started their careers there. There was jazz and dancing at the Tabou. In most Left Bank clubs, though, there was no dancing, just a great deal of chin-scratching contemplation. There's a lovely photograph of the Donald Byrd Quintet in some tiny Left Bank club in the mid-1950s. They're probably halfway through a skittering reading of Salt Peanuts or an achingly slow take on Stardust. Bobby Jaspar is playing the tenor solo, with Walter Davis Jr on an upright jammed against the wall. Doug Watkins is on bass and somehow Art Taylor has managed to get his drum kit into this little cellar. In the foreground, the last word in cool in a sharp suit, Byrd stands with his eyes closed. He's taking a last drag before picking up his trumpet to play the theme. Crammed around them in this tiny room are lots of studious white Parisians in jackets and ties. One man in particular draws one's attention. He's standing against a pillar with his head tilted down and thus repeating the posture and extreme concentration of Doug Watkins. Jazz - it's as serious as life, you know. In an article called Jazz 1947 Jean-Paul Sartre wrote wrote gnomically: "Jazz music is like bananas; you eat them on the spot." He added that French musicians were "melancholy imitators". But this notion became less true as time went on. In the 1920s Paris could only listen to this new-found art form. But in the 1930s, Reinhardt and Grappelli showed the way. Over the next two decades Paris produced an increasing number of original musicians who thrived in Saint Germain - Guy Lafitte, Pierre Michelot, Guy Pederson, Henri Renaud and Jean-Luc Ponty. "Saint Germain did for music what Montparnasse did for painting after 1918. And it wasn't just any kind of music, it was jazz," said Renaud. For a while jazz was everywhere in Paris. Everybody had copies of Sidney Bechet's huge hits, Petite Fleur and Oignons. His lavish Riviera wedding was shown on newsreels. At the Olympia theatre, Louis Armstrong, Erroll Garner and the band from the Club St Germain appeared on the same bill as Juliette Greco. Despite the rise of French musicians, Americans dominated Paris jazz in the 1960s. Miles Davis, Dizzy Gillespie, Chet Baker, Peanuts Holland, Lucky Thompson and Zoot Sims played long residencies, while Kenny Clarke and Bill Coleman were virtually permanent fixtures. What drew them to Paris? Scott Fitzgerald put it this way: "There is no second act in an American's life." Especially if you're a jazz musician. But in France it was and is different: the French love their jazz so much that they give musicians not only second acts, but third, fourth and fifth acts, as well as generous state subsidies and the occasional statue. In France they look after jazz talent long after it has passed its American sell-by date. Consider Chet Baker. In 1952 this good-looking trumpeter was top of the Billboard charts, but his drug addiction put paid to that. His pretty-boy looks became spectacularly craggy, and his popularity waned. In the mid 1950s he arrived in Paris and immediately took Saint Germain by storm. Though he was strung out on drugs for much of the time, he kept up an intense and gloomy relationship with the city for the next three decades. And Paris gave Baker not just a second act, but an unexpected final one, too. He returned to France in 1975, where he started to play and record extensively. There was a renewed assurance and heartfelt lyricism in both his playing and his singing. Universal has just re-released an album he cut in Paris on the afternoon of December 28 1978, at the instigation of one of his most loyal friends and admirers, Gilles Gautherin. It's called Broken Wing and, if you can quickly acquire a taste for his singing (not everybody can), it's a wonderfully tender album, as good as anything he ever did - especially the track called Blue Gilles, written in honour of the Frenchman who helped him thrive anew. But that story, of the ageing American jazz musician helped by some French enthusiast, is a classic of Parisian jazz. It's told in Bertrand Tavernier's 1986 film Round Midnight, in which a lanky, ageing black tenor sax player (played uncannily by lanky, ageing black tenor player Dexter Gordon) is befriended by a small white jazz buff. The once-great musician has been booked at the Blue Note but seems to be over the hill. Now he's just a guy struggling to work and to overcome a drink problem. The Parisian hasn't enough money to pay for admission to the club to hear his beloved musician play. But he loves jazz so much that he borrows some money from his wife to buy a flat where the tenor player can stay and rebuild his life. And it works: the American stops drinking and starts composing again. "You treat me like a king," says American to Frenchman. But will it last when he is back in New York and his old environment - without his French friend to nurture him? Probably not. Paris is no longer head over heels in love with jazz. Now it's mostly for nostalgics or tourists, though some good gigs remain. The international stars play at New Morning, and the Jazz Club Lionel Hampton, named after the francophile wizard of the vibraphone, still thrives in the Meridien hotel. Even on the Left Bank, some clubs cling on amid the couturiers' boutiques. Le Petit Journal St-Michel and La Villa on Rue Jacob struggle to keep afloat amid high rents. Bilboquet, a Saint Germain club that opened in 1947 and was a haven of cool jazz in the 1950s, now relies largely on tourists. But Paris is still a haven for black jazz musicians from the States. The American jazz singer Dee Dee Bridgewater is virtually unknown in her homeland but since 1983 has flourished in France. "I had stopped doing jazz in the US," she recalls. "There wasn't a market for it, so I wound up doing pop. But I found in Europe there was a huge market for standard jazz. "I went to Paris to work. I was hired to sing in Sophisticated Lady as the lead. The show was a big hit. Then I started getting concert work, which floored me because in the US without a big record company behind you you only get club dates. I started playing small theatres and my reputation grew and then the festivals kicked in. I arrived in November 1983 and I stayed." Why? "Because I loved it and because I met a Frenchman and fell in love." Now, like Josephine Baker and Sidney Bechet before her, Dee Dee Bridgewater is a French national icon. It's her second act, and she doesn't want it to end any time soon. "France allowed me to grow as an artist. I have been able to do just about anything that I wanted to do. That's really, really cool. As soon as I get on to the plane going to France I get real good treatment in first class. And I always get people asking why. And I have to tell them, 'Baby, you gotta realise one thing. I'm a big star in France.' "  The Jazz in Paris CD series is available now from Universal Jazz.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: Amazingly, it appears we were right about Tuesday's Carol Thatcher story. We still can't locate Carol herself to ask if she was really a member of the Labour party until recently, but someone is in touch to flesh out facts which any proper journalist might care to confirm in the traditional manner.
fields.body:
Amazingly, it appears we were right about Tuesday's Carol Thatcher story. We still can't locate Carol herself to ask if she was really a member of the Labour party until recently, but someone is in touch to flesh out facts which any proper journalist might care to confirm in the traditional manner.

The Labour party is trying to raise extra money with the election coming, our source explains, and a marketing firm has been retained to phone one-time members who have not renewed subscriptions or donated cash in the last couple of years and do the begging.

When a certain C Thatcher was called, "she lost her rag a bit", we are told, and demanded not to be phoned again, saying in effect that she only joined Labour to get back at her mum and didn't want to be reminded of it. Given the unrelaxed mother-daughter relationship outlined in her book about Denis, this gesture of adolescent rebelliousness is quite credible, and in so far as its emergence now will embarrass the crazy old haddock, admirable. So hats off, Carol! If it's true.

 After his long absence from this bully pulpit, we welcome back Diary vicar the Rev Steve Chalke. My colleague Marina Hyde calls his reverence on various matters, but it is a day before he calls back. He did try yesterday, he explains, but rang the wrong number. When he said "is that the Guardian?", a man became displeased, demanding Steve's number and ringing hurriedly off.

Two minutes later, he rang Steve back. "Never call this number again," he told him, "or I'll be coming after you." Odd that Steve appears to be living in a Guy Ritchie film, but after all that there is no room for his reverence's thoughts on the Hinduja inquiry. These will now appear tomorrow.

 Congratulations to alopecian Sun editor David Yelland for winning the UK Press Gazette Newspaper of the Year award. That, at least, is what the amnesiac (you will recall the grievous damage done to his synaptic pathways when the subway train doors clamped shut on his wig) keeps saying.

Apparently, he's been convinced that this will be his year since last May - and assuming the judging panel is made up of xenophobic, gay-hating slapheads with an infantile crush on America, he may well be right.

If not, recalling his performance at the awards two years ago when he dispensed with conventional seating in favour of the carpet by the bar, we hope that a colleague will be on hand continually to remind him exactly how many he has had.

 The Diary, incidentally, has failed to be shortlisted for any of the 27 different journalistic awards for the sixth consecutive year under this byline. Indeed, neither I personally nor any project with which I have been involved has ever been nominated for anything - an astounding achievement given the volume of cobblers, the number of awards and the law of averages. Rumours of a special UKPG "lifetime non-achievement award" are intriguing, but let's not fall into the unhatched chicken trap with David.

 Surveillance: sane and rational Paul Johnson, looking slightly wild-eyed, walking up Queensway towards the Bayswater Road at 1.30pm on Monday, wearing a vivid red scarf.  Peter Hain's assistant calls back eventually to answer our urgent inquiry into the possibility of Turkish blood in the energy minister's family, "hain" meaning traitor or treacherous in that tongue.

"I'm with him now so I've double checked on that one,"yells Peter Manditch from the train to Manchester, "but the minister is not aware of any Turkish ancestry." Thank you for that. Now to ensure there are no hard feelings, might he put the old boy on so we can wish him the best of luck in the Diary's Turncoat of Turncoats competition? "I'm sorry," Peter crackles convincingly, "We're going into a tunnel..."

diary@theguardian.com
