webTitle: Paris, Rome, Manchester: youth on drink and drugs

fields.headline: Paris, Rome, Manchester: youth on drink and drugs
fields.standfirst: Special report: drugs in Britain
fields.trailText:
Paris: 'Getting drunk is pathetic, girls laugh at you'
Drinking, or rather getting drunk, said Emmanuelle, wasn't very cool. Smoking was for show - she would stop soon, and anyway she had read you could puff away until the age of 30 without doing permanent damage.
fields.byline: Jon Henley, Rory Carroll and Angelique Chrisafis
fields.body:
Paris: 'Getting drunk is pathetic, girls laugh at you'
Drinking, or rather getting drunk, said Emmanuelle, wasn't very cool. Smoking was for show - she would stop soon, and anyway she had read you could puff away until the age of 30 without doing permanent damage.

A joint, however, was a treat. "Saturday nights, for sure, why not?" asked the 16-year-old. "It's less dangerous than drinking spirits. Most of my friends smoke shit [French for dope] from time to time, but I wouldn't say anyone had a habit."

It surprised few of the students outside the gates of the Lycee Lamartine in central Paris that French adolescents are in third place on the list of European teenagers who had used marijuana at least once during their lifetime.

"It's forbidden fruit, isn't it?" said Thomas, 17. "The police are so strict, you hear absurd warnings, of course you want to try. I bet in Holland no one bothers."

The French are by far Europe's heaviest drinkers, consuming 11.9 litres of pure alcohol a year, two-thirds of it as wine. Alcohol is responsible for 25% of all hospitalisations and 50,000 deaths a year.

But France is well below the European average for child alcohol abuse, with only 4% of French 15- and 16-year-olds reporting having got drunk 20 times or more, against 29% in Britain. "I don't see the point in getting drunk," said Pierre-Olivier, 16. "Everyone laughs at you, girls think its pathetic."

The French are a nation of committed smokers: ac cording to government figures, 34% of the population smokes, including 60% of 18-20 year-olds, a quarter of all pregnant women, and even one in three doctors.

But among French teenagers, only 14% of 15- and 16-year-olds said they were smoking daily by the age of 13, against 20% of British adolescents. The Lycee Lamartine students did not believe that. "It can't be true," said Thomas. "Two-thirds of my friends smoke. I was in Birmingham last year and it's a lot harder for kids to smoke in England than it is here."
Jon Henley

Rome: 'It's only losers who like to lose control'
At the end of the week young Italians like to go crazy on Saturday night - bingeing on one, two, maybe even three drinks.

Any more might induce that buzzing in the head which they regard as a handicap to socialising, not an aid. Only losers lose control.

"I had a boyfriend once who used to get drunk. It was disgusting. He couldn't dance properly, he sweated. Who wants that?" said Claudia, 18.

Three friends beside her at the Spanish Steps in Rome nodded. "Some boys do drink too much at the weekends. In our disco there's a group who take four beers each," said Valentina, 16.

Girls limit themselves to two, they said. It is all about keeping your bella figura. Partly that means waistline but mostly image. "I don't want to be drunk. People would stare. You would look dumb, it is dumb," said Maura, 17.

Surveys show Italy's wine consumption falling among virtually all categories, but especially teenagers. "We prefer beer because wine is for old people and families. Also beer is cheaper," said Claudio Grignetti, 16. Being served is not a problem as long as you go to the right bars, cafes and discos.

From 1975 to 1995 the average 15- to 25-year-old's annual consumption of pure alcohol dipped from 1.89 litres to 1.1.

Italians who return after studying abroad, especially in Britain, stand out in pre ferring pints of draught over bottles.

According to the Permanent Observatory on Young People and Alcohol in Rome, a hard core of just over one in 10 has a serious drink problem.

They can occasionally be spotted staggering from the dozens of British and Irish-style pubs in virtually every Italian city. Having no drinking culture means they drink on empty stomachs and weave home on scooters. It does not help that measures vary: one bar's triple is another's single.
Rory Carroll

Manchester: 'Everyone we know is desperate for pills'
On Sunday night, Zoe, 16, went to a designer bar in Manchester, drank £50 worth of Smirnoff Ice, smoked 40 cigarettes, tripped on the kerb and still made it home for midnight, because her mum trusts her.

"You have to have a drink to have a laugh. I don't eat before I go drinking because it makes me look bloated. So I get pissed quite easily. I'm in control and I know when to stop. I always stop just before I puke," she said.

Zoe and her best friend Kelly are from Suffolk. They are doing their GCSEs and are among the brightest in their class. They have come to Manchester to see the bars. They both started smoking at 12 and going to clubs at 13. On a school week, if they only go out three times, they drink about 12 litres of alcopops and smoke 150 cigarettes each.

"We're no different to your average teenagers. If we don't go out, we get alcopops, a bottle of Jack Daniels, and a bottle of vodka, and cane it at home on the sofa," said Zoe.

"Everyone's on pills. Everyone we know is desperate for pills. But I don't touch drugs because I saw my teenage sister's best friend die from a heroin overdose," said Kelly.

"We come from a nice village in Suffolk. There's nothing to do except drink. We don't even have a youth club."

Neville, 16, goes to sixth-form college in Manchester, where there is an excess of activities for teenagers, "but the best thing is getting lagered".

At the pub, Neville drinks five or six pints of Stella and smokes 20 cigarettes in the first two hours. He eats chips to line his stomach. "Once a week, we aim to get totally bladdered. We go to a mate's flat, get a crate of cans and some brandy. I drink 10 cans of lager and half a bottle of brandy in shots. Then I do an eighth of weed. The others, who are 16, drop pills, like ectasy. They get a rush and I start laughing."
Angelique Chrisafis

fields.headline: Orange Order urged to negotiate
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: An international mediator has warned of dire consequences for the Orange Order if it keeps refusing to talk to Northern Ireland's independent parades commission, and residents who object to some of their marches going through Catholic areas.
fields.body:
An international mediator has warned of dire consequences for the Orange Order if it keeps refusing to talk to Northern Ireland's independent parades commission, and residents who object to some of their marches going through Catholic areas.

The South African lawyer Brian Currin, who had been brought in as an impartial negotiator last year to try to sort out the controversial Drumcree dispute, told the order that its present stance, coupled with the UK's new human rights laws, meant it had virtually no chance of winning any court battle to parade down the mainly nationalist Garvaghy Road in Portadown, Co Armagh.

Only a handful of the 3,000 or so Protestant loyal order marches held in the province every year are contentious. Drumcree, where Orangemen have been banned from an annual July parade down the Garvaghy Road for the past three years, has become the focal point for protest.

There was wide-scale disorder when a march was forced down in 1997, and a multi-million-pound police and army operation is put in place every year.

A solution is needed soon because Portadown is in the heart of the Upper Bann constituency - that of the leader of the Ulster Unionist Party, David Trimble - and the issue is sure to become more heated and difficult to resolve as the general election looms.

Mr Currin insisted that he was not taking sides nor advocating what action Orangemen should take. He said that he merely wanted to advise them of the legal and practical implications of their decisions in a paper he gave to their leaders.

In the document, he claimed the future of Orange marches in Northern Ireland was in the balance and cooperation with the parades commission, the autonomous body set up by government to arbitrate on contested routes, was the key to preserving this element of cultural diversity.

"If that key is thrown away, the consequences for Orangism, its culture and traditions, will be dire," he said.

Regular protests are held at Drumcree, including one last week, when nationalists claimed masked men were present, which was denied by the organisers.

There are fears of demonstrations being hijacked by loyalist paramilitaries. A leading Ulster Defence Association figure, Johnny Adair, now back in prison, was a frequent visitor last July.

Orangemen currently refuse to talk to the parades commission, which they see as biased toward nationalists. They will not speak to residents' representatives because they claim they are merely fronts for IRA orientated groups.

They feel they should not have to "ask permission" to walk the Garvaghy Road. They claim this as an inalienable right. But Mr Currin has pointed out that it is for the parades commission to make such a decision, not residents, and it would be up to each side to set their own agenda for talks.

But Mr Currin argued that the parades commission complied with UK and European human rights law by weighing the right to peaceful assembly against the risk of public disorder and freedom of other individuals, and taking into account communication between march organisers and local people.

He said the idea of traditional marching routes cut no ice with Europe and the right to march was seen as a "soft right", easily overruled by concerns over public safety. And he noted that in 17 cases in the past 20 years, the government's decision to restrict or totally ban peaceful processions, had been upheld by the European commission or court.

But the Orange Order grand secretary, Denis Watson, criticised Mr Currin and dismissed his paper as being nothing new. However, he revealed that the leaders of the order had decided not to pass the 170 copies to members.

The South African is not allowed to address a grand lodge meeting because he is not an Orangeman.

"I am disappointed that Brian Currin decided to go public with a private document which was not considered by the grand master and his team because of the late stage it was presented to us," said Mr Watson. "What Brian has done has damaged his own credibility as an honest broker."

"If that key is thrown away, the consequences for Orangism, its culture and traditions, will be dire," he said. Regular protests are held at Drumcree, including one last week, when nationalists claimed masked men were present, which was denied by the organisers. There are fears of demonstrations being hijacked by loyalist paramilitaries. A leading Ulster Defence Association figure, Johnny Adair, now back in prison, was a frequent visitor last July. Orangemen currently refuse to talk to the parades commission, which they see as biased toward nationalists. They will not speak to residents' representatives because they claim they are merely fronts for IRA orientated groups. They feel they should not have to "ask permission" to walk the Garvaghy Road. They claim this as an inalienable right. But Mr Currin has pointed out that it is for the parades commission to make such a decision, not residents, and it would be up to each side to set their own agenda for talks. But Mr Currin argued that the parades commission complied with UK and European human rights law by weighing the right to peaceful assembly against the risk of public disorder and freedom of other individuals, and taking into account communication between march organisers and local people. He said the idea of traditional marching routes cut no ice with Europe and the right to march was seen as a "soft right", easily overruled by concerns over public safety. And he noted that in 17 cases in the past 20 years, the government's decision to restrict or totally ban peaceful processions, had been upheld by the European commission or court. But the Orange Order grand secretary, Denis Watson, criticised Mr Currin and dismissed his paper as being nothing new. However, he revealed that the leaders of the order had decided not to pass the 170 copies to members. The South African is not allowed to address a grand lodge meeting because he is not an Orangeman. "I am disappointed that Brian Currin decided to go public with a private document which was not considered by the grand master and his team because of the late stage it was presented to us," said Mr Watson. "What Brian has done has damaged his own credibility as an honest broker."

webTitle: Putin offers Europe star wars alternative

fields.headline: Putin offers Europe star wars alternative
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: The Kremlin yesterday moved to undermine the US administration's national missile defence plan when President Vladimir Putin presented Nato with a scaled-down "non-strategic" plan to protect Europe against the alleged threat of missile attack from so-called rogue states.
fields.body:
The Kremlin yesterday moved to undermine the US administration's national missile defence plan when President Vladimir Putin presented Nato with a scaled-down "non-strategic" plan to protect Europe against the alleged threat of missile attack from so-called rogue states.

Mr Putin coupled his initiative, which appears to be aimed at driving a wedge between the US and its European allies, with strong criticism of President George Bush's new administration, accusing hardliners in Washington of viewing Russia as "the evil empire".

The Putin gambit came during a visit to Moscow by the Nato secretary general, Lord Robertson, aimed at healing the rift with Russia caused by the Kosovo war in 1999, when Moscow suspended relations with the alliance.

But the current war of words between Moscow and Washington, the US and British bombing of Iraq at the week end, President Bush's apparent determination to pursue the"Son of Star Wars" plan, and the possible expansion of Nato in eastern Europe are sources of growing friction.

Senior Russian officials are threatening to abandon all UN sanctions against Baghdad, the Kremlin is warning of a renewed arms race if the Americans go ahead with its missile defence system (NMD) and the Russian military is talking of retaliatory nuclear deployments if Nato takes in the Baltic states on Russia's borders.

The Russian defence minister, Igor Sergeyev, outlined the three-stage Russian anti-ballistic missile proposals to Lord Robertson. Nato officials are to examine the plan in Brussels before Russian officers arrive at Nato headquarters to flesh out the plan.

"Our experts are ready to travel to Brussels to explain all the issues, including, and this is important, explaining the Russian proposals to the European public," Mr Putin said.

The plan would entail the deployment of missiles close to potentially threatening sites to shoot down any rogue missiles shortly after launch. It would be cheaper than the $60bnUS project and "non-strategic", meaning that it would not violate the 1972 anti-ballistic missile treaty.

The Russians have generally denied US arguments that there is a missile threat from rogue states and are convinced that the US plan is aimed at securing unilateral strategic invulnerability. The Americans are likely to cite yesterday's proposals as evidence that the Russians acknowledge that there is a rogue missile threat.

Lord Robertson said as much yesterday. "What is important now is that we have a Russian proposal to deal with the same kind of perceived threat," he said.

Marshal Sergeyev described any further Nato expansion as "the most painful issue for Russia" and warned that Nato membership for the former Soviet republics of Latvia, Lithuania or Estonia would be "a direct threat to Russia's security".

"For the moment we agreed to disagree," Lord Robertson said after the Kremlin meeting with Mr Putin. He said that no decision on further expansion would be taken until next year.

But while Lord Robertson described Russia as Nato's "partner", the new Pentagon chief, Donald Rumsfeld, last week described Russia as a "problem", and Condoleezza Rice, the US national security adviser, dubbed it a "threat" to the west.

In an interview with a French newspaper, Ms Rice said: "I sincerely believe that Russia constitutes a threat for the west in general and our European allies in particular."

In an apparent reference to Ms Rice's interview, Mr Putin said yesterday: "We are aware of the statements made by certain representatives of the west - we can read - who are trying to recreate the image of Russia as the evil empire."

webTitle: Milburn's plan to keep NHS doctors

fields.headline: Milburn's plan to keep NHS doctors
fields.trailText: Alan Milburn, the health secretary, will today widen the gap between Labour and the Tories over the future of the health service when he unveils plans to ban newly qualified NHS consultants from working in the private sector.
fields.body:
Alan Milburn, the health secretary, will today widen the gap between Labour and the Tories over the future of the health service when he unveils plans to ban newly qualified NHS consultants from working in the private sector.

As the Tories pledge to expand private healthcare, Mr Milburn will announce plans to prevent consultants from boosting their earnings in private practice for the first seven years of their careers.

Mr Milburn said he hopes to win round consultants by offering incentives to remain in the NHS. Under the government's new contracts, consultants' pay will be linked to an annual appraisal.

"Consultants' contracts and the means of giving them extra rewards if they do particularly well in the NHS have remained largely unchanged since 1948, and I think [they do] need to be changed."

His remarks came as the Tories unveiled plans to break down the "Berlin wall" between the private and public sectors in the health service to boost overall investment.

Liam Fox, the shadow health secretary, who has already pledged to match Labour spending on health, announced that a Tory government would offer £500m of tax relief for people who take out private health insurance.

Anyone who takes out a private health insurance scheme would no longer be taxed on the benefit - at a cost of £368m. The Tories would also abolish the £100m national insurance contributions paid by employers on company private health schemes.

In a speech to the Society of Apothecaries, Dr Fox said: "Labour subjects company schemes to heavy taxation penalties. We will abolish both these taxes when it is prudent to do so in order to boost this part of the private sector."

Dr Fox also announced that the Tories would encourage the private sector to carry out less serious operations, such as cataract surgery and hip replacements. Under the Tory plans, patients would continue to be funded by the NHS, but the treatment would be provided by "independent healthcare providers".

But Dr Fox made clear that the Tories would expect increasing numbers of people to pay for such treatment, allowing the NHS to concentrate on more expensive treatment, such as cancer and cardiac care.

Mr Milburn warned that the Tories would privatise the NHS by creating a "two-tier" health service. He added that the Tories' £500m tax relief would deprive the NHS of crucial funds, while their plans to encourage patients to seek treatment in the private sector would break up the NHS.

webTitle: BA pilot burned as lightning hits plane

fields.headline: BA pilot burned as lightning hits plane
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: A British Airways pilot was burned by a massive electrical shock after his plane carrying 158 people was struck by lightning.
fields.body:
A British Airways pilot was burned by a massive electrical shock after his plane carrying 158 people was struck by lightning.

The incident, described by aviation experts as unheard of, is detailed in a report by the air accidents investigations branch, released today.

The pilot told investigators that after the bolt of lightning hit he felt as if he had been kicked in the chest.

The incident is one of two detailed by the AAIB today. In the other, an RAF jet came within 100ft of crashing into a passenger aircraft with 14 people on board last March, prompting the AAIB to call for an urgent review.

The incident where the pilot was burned happened after a BA flight had left Heathrow airport in October last year, and was 10 minutes from landing at Amsterdam's Schipol airport when the lightning struck.

The 54-year-old first officer was at the controls of the Boeing 757, acting as the "handling pilot", trying to fly the plane between two storm systems.

The plane had descended from its maximum height of 35,000ft to 5,000ft as it prepared for an imminent landing.

According to the report: "The first officer was seated with his right hand and part of his right arm resting on the cockpit coaming close to the right forward windscreen.

"At about 5,000ft on the approach the aircraft was struck by lightning just below the right windscreen.

"The first officer was aware of a loud bang and bright flash and described feeling as if he had been kicked in the chest.

"After recovering from the initial surprise the first officer found difficulty in using his right arm. He handed over control to the commander, and reverted to a non-handling pilot.

"After landing the first officer was taken for a medical examination that revealed a burn wound in his chest consistent with an electrical discharge."

The first officer was able to return to flying duties within a fortnight, but the AAIB report says he "has subsequently developed a medical condition that may be a consequence of the incident".

A BA spokesman stressed that the 151 passengers and seven crew on board were never in any danger and that the plane had landed safely.

Usually pilots try to fly their craft either over or around a storm system.

The pilot was still off work, said BA, declining to name him.

The AAIB calls today for a review of the risks of mid-air collisions in airspace where planes fly outside the control of air traffic controllers, so- called uncontrolled airspace.

It follows an incident last March where an RAF Tornado came within feet of crashing into a passenger jet with 14 people aboard at 5,000ft.

Both planes were in uncontrolled airspace near Newcastle airport when the near miss happened, with the craft coming within 100ft of each other.

The Tornado was travelling so fast that neither pilot had time to take any avoiding action.

The civilian plane, a Gill Airways' Shorts SD360, was flying from Aberdeen to Newcastle and carrying 11 passengers. The Tornado was one of four based at RAF Leuchars in St Andrews, which were taking part in a night training exercise involving up to 32 jets.

The report said that statistics from the UK Airprox Board, which investigates near misses, showed that from January 1990 to March 2000, there were 87 reports of near misses involving military aircraft and commercial planes in uncontrolled airspace below 10,000ft.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: We were wrong to say as we did in our lead story on the front page, February 17, Allied planes bomb Baghdad, that the no-fly zones in Iraq were "originally designated by the United Nations". A report on page 13, February 19, correctly pointed out that UN security council resolution 688 of April 1991 which has been cited as the authority for the no-fly zones does not, in fact, mention them at all.
fields.body:
We were wrong to say as we did in our lead story on the front page, February 17, Allied planes bomb Baghdad, that the no-fly zones in Iraq were "originally designated by the United Nations". A report on page 13, February 19, correctly pointed out that UN security council resolution 688 of April 1991 which has been cited as the authority for the no-fly zones does not, in fact, mention them at all.

Contrary to what we implied in a panel headed Hitler's deadly prophecy, page 13, February 17, the Wannsee conference took place in January 1942, not 1941. Its purpose was to plan the "final solution" of the "Jewish question", in accordance with an earlier command from Hermann Göring. See britannica.com (Wannsee Conference).

The article headed Wanna be a pop star? Education, pages 10 and 11, yesterday, does make sense but only if the columns are read in the following order: 1,4,2,3,5,6,7. Apologies.

In an article headed Earthlings beware, page 5, G2, February 19, we suggested that there was a "rule of American film-making that an English person plays the sadistic bastard - Hannibal". The actor who plays Hannibal, Anthony Hopkins, is in origin Welsh.

In an article headed Blinded by limelight, Comment, page 22, February 16, we spelt wrongly the name of Professor John Bayley, in a reference to his late wife, Iris Murdoch. Apologies.

The writer of the letter on the Obituaries page, page 24, yesterday, commenting on our obituary of Sir Reginald Bennett, was Abel Hadden (not Abdel Hadden). Apologies.

The heading on our obituary of the director and screenwriter Burt Kennedy, page 24, February 17, called him George Kennedy. It was corrected for later editions.

In our obituary of the artist Balthus, page 20, February 19, we misspelt the name of André Malraux, the former French minister of cultural affairs.

In an article headed Middle of the road heroes, pages 8 to 11, the Guide, February 17, we referred to a comedy sketch about the class system featuring Ronnie Corbett, Ronnie Barker and John Cleese saying it was performed in That Was The Week That Was. In fact the sketch was first featured in The Frost Report in 1966, then repeated in 1967 in the compilation Frost Over England, which went to Montreux and won the Golden Rose.

fields.headline: William Masters
fields.standfirst: Sex therapy pioneer who transformed our understanding of human relationships, straight and gay
fields.trailText: Sex therapy pioneer who transformed our understanding of human relationships, straight and gay.
fields.body:
William Masters, who has died at the age of 85, was one of the first and leading researchers in the field of human sexuality. With his colleague and sometime wife Virginia Johnson, he could legitimately claim to have done more for couple relationships and marital satisfaction in the last 35 years than that other 60s icon, the contraceptive pill.

The sex therapy programme they developed aimed to help clients by providing sex information, alleviating anxiety about sexual performance and encouraging verbal, emotional and physical communication with their partners. Before this, any approach to sexual disorders had focused on the individual. Masters and Johnson included both partners in the therapy process, emphasising mutual responsibility for change and for finding a solution to their problems.

Born in Cleveland, Masters became interested in the nature of sexuality while studying medicine in New York in the early 1940s, and wanted to conduct research that would lead to an objective understanding of the topics. He joined the Washington University school of medicine in 1947, and began researching sexual functions in 1954. Three years later, Johnson joined him as a research assistant, and they soon became a pioneering team.

Their investigation of the physical aspects of sexuality produced some of the first reliable data in the field, and widened public debate and awareness of the role of sex and sexuality in relationships. Alfred Kinsey and his co-workers had began that debate with Sexual Behaviour In The Human Male (1948) and Sexual Behaviour In The Human Female (1953), which, among other things, had disclosed the frequency of various sexual practices, including homosexuality. They had caused a furore, with critics voicing the view that the study and public discussion of sexual behaviour would undermine the family and society.

Masters himself believed that "science, by itself, has no moral dimension, but it does seek to establish truth, and upon this truth morality can be built" - and he and Johnson set out to find the truth. Their initial research, with 312 men and 382 women, was published as Human Sexual Response (1966), and remains the keystone of modern sex therapy, wherever it is studied or practised.

While Kinsey discovered how many people were doing what, Masters and Johnson explained what happened when they did it. Using polygraph-like instruments, laboratory observation and measurement of their research subjects while they were having intercourse or masturbating, the couple identified four phases in the human sexual response cycle - excitement, plateau, orgasm and resolution.

Although written for the medical community, Human Sexual Response became a bestseller, as did Masters and Johnson's next book, Human Sexual Inadequacy (1970), which was concerned with the treatment of impotence, premature ejaculation, lack of sexual desire and other sexual problems. In the wake of these two publications, the field of sex therapy - the clinical treatment of sexual problems - was born.

In 1964, Masters and Johnson had established the Reproductive Biology Research Foundation in St Louis, with Masters as its director. During this period, he and his first wife divorced and, in 1971, he married Johnson.

Two years later, she became co-director and both became directors of the Masters and Johnson Institute, a clinic for the treatment of sexual problems. Many of the students who trained at their centre went on to establish practices in sex therapy across America, and most of the therapeutic practices begun at the clinic, such as assisting couples to more fully experience and focus on basic physical sensations, remain central to contemporary sex therapy worldwide.

Masters and Johnson used a male-female, dual-therapy team, and a brief, intensive re-education process that involved behavioural exercises such as sensate focus, which encourage each partner to take turns in paying increased attention to their own senses. These exercises were originally developed to help couples experiencing sexual problems, but are also used today to heighten personal awareness and spice up couples' sex lives. As part of a comprehensive psychotherapy programme, they can have a dramatic effect, even in cases where severe sexual dysfunction has lasted for many years.

Throughout the 1970s and 1980s, Masters and Johnson continued their work, publishing The Pleasure Bond (1974), a fresh look at sexuality and commitment, and Homosexuality In Perspective (1979), which described the sexual responses of gay men and lesbians. They debunked the idea that homosexuality is a mental illness, but their claims to be able to change the sexual preferences of homosexuals met with considerable criticism from the gay community and other sex researchers. A further work, Human Sexuality, appeared in 1982.

The couple's later book, Crisis: Heterosexual Behaviour In The Age Of Aids (1988), co-written with Robert C Kolodny, provoked another storm, this time from Aids researchers and health workers who disputed their findings. Masters, Johnson and Kolodny advanced the theory, now largely accepted, that engaging in risky sexual practices may be as important as membership of a high-risk group, such as drug users, in defining HIV risk, and also recommended safer sex practices for heterosexual, non-drug users.

Masters and Johnson worked together until 1992, and continued to collaborate, after their divorce the following year, on Heterosexuality, which was published in 1994, the year that Masters retired and left St Louis.

The expectation that sex should be a source of pleasure, personal development and empowerment for all is a legacy of the 20th century which Masters and Johnson were instrumental in developing. Their contribution on problems of sexual functioning and therapeutic interventions remains among the most significant work in these areas.

Back in 1992, Masters had complained that Americans still had not cast off their puritanism about sex. He could, however, note with satisfaction that all but two or three American medical schools by then included courses on human sexuality. His third wife, Geraldine, survives him, as do a daughter and a son.

 William Howell Masters, gynaecologist, sex therapist and researcher, born December 27 1915; died February 16 2001

Although written for the medical community, Human Sexual Response became a bestseller, as did Masters and Johnson's next book, Human Sexual Inadequacy (1970), which was concerned with the treatment of impotence, premature ejaculation, lack of sexual desire and other sexual problems. In the wake of these two publications, the field of sex therapy - the clinical treatment of sexual problems - was born. In 1964, Masters and Johnson had established the Reproductive Biology Research Foundation in St Louis, with Masters as its director. During this period, he and his first wife divorced and, in 1971, he married Johnson. Two years later, she became co-director and both became directors of the Masters and Johnson Institute, a clinic for the treatment of sexual problems. Many of the students who trained at their centre went on to establish practices in sex therapy across America, and most of the therapeutic practices begun at the clinic, such as assisting couples to more fully experience and focus on basic physical sensations, remain central to contemporary sex therapy worldwide. Masters and Johnson used a male-female, dual-therapy team, and a brief, intensive re-education process that involved behavioural exercises such as sensate focus, which encourage each partner to take turns in paying increased attention to their own senses. These exercises were originally developed to help couples experiencing sexual problems, but are also used today to heighten personal awareness and spice up couples' sex lives. As part of a comprehensive psychotherapy programme, they can have a dramatic effect, even in cases where severe sexual dysfunction has lasted for many years. Throughout the 1970s and 1980s, Masters and Johnson continued their work, publishing The Pleasure Bond (1974), a fresh look at sexuality and commitment, and Homosexuality In Perspective (1979), which described the sexual responses of gay men and lesbians. They debunked the idea that homosexuality is a mental illness, but their claims to be able to change the sexual preferences of homosexuals met with considerable criticism from the gay community and other sex researchers. A further work, Human Sexuality, appeared in 1982. The couple's later book, Crisis: Heterosexual Behaviour In The Age Of Aids (1988), co-written with Robert C Kolodny, provoked another storm, this time from Aids researchers and health workers who disputed their findings. Masters, Johnson and Kolodny advanced the theory, now largely accepted, that engaging in risky sexual practices may be as important as membership of a high-risk group, such as drug users, in defining HIV risk, and also recommended safer sex practices for heterosexual, non-drug users. Masters and Johnson worked together until 1992, and continued to collaborate, after their divorce the following year, on Heterosexuality, which was published in 1994, the year that Masters retired and left St Louis. The expectation that sex should be a source of pleasure, personal development and empowerment for all is a legacy of the 20th century which Masters and Johnson were instrumental in developing. Their contribution on problems of sexual functioning and therapeutic interventions remains among the most significant work in these areas. Back in 1992, Masters had complained that Americans still had not cast off their puritanism about sex. He could, however, note with satisfaction that all but two or three American medical schools by then included courses on human sexuality. His third wife, Geraldine, survives him, as do a daughter and a son.  William Howell Masters, gynaecologist, sex therapist and researcher, born December 27 1915; died February 16 2001

fields.headline: Minister bullish on pregnant pause
fields.standfirst: Soon taking maternity leave will become so normal that no one will bat an eyelid, says Yvette Cooper of her pioneering decision
fields.trailText: Soon taking maternity leave will become so normal that no one will bat an eyelid, says Yvette Cooper of her pioneering decision.
fields.body:
The prospect of women ministers taking full maternity leave and then returning to their departments will become so normal that "no one will bat an eyelid", according to the first minister to plan to do so.

Yvette Cooper, the public health minister, who is expecting her second child in mid-August, will take a complete break from red boxes - the daily in-trays stuffed with ministerial documents and parliamentary legislative duties - when she goes on leave for around five months in July.

Arrangements to cover for her absence, assuming Labour wins the expected spring general election, have yet to be nailed down, but options could include appointing another MP to cover her role, or distributing elements of the job among other health ministers. The complexity of finding cover for her role is compounded by the fact that ministers are not, in law, employees, subject to normal employment legislation, but office holders, with unique status.

The 31-year-old minister, speaking in the week that the leader of the Lords and minister for women, Baroness Jay, announced plans to quit her cabinet post because her work-life balance had shifted out of kilter, is clear that any problems can be surmounted. Her confidence may be well-founded: while her announcement may have sent Department of Health mandarins into a spin, a government which says it supports family-friendly employment policies cannot be seen to be a careless employer.

Ms Cooper has already rescheduled her day to ensure that her red boxes are dealt with during the day instead of at home in the evening as is traditional, leaving her free to spend time with her family.

"It's business as usual," she insisted, amid a breakneck schedule of meetings, a hospital visit and a sweet factory tour in her Pontefract and Castleford constituency. "Millions of women take maternity leave from jobs and it ought to be normal in every occupation and every walk of life. People at work have families too.

"One day no one will bat an eyelid at ministers taking maternity leave because of course it's something that ministers, MPs, nurses, businesswomen and everybody else needs to be able to do."

Ms Cooper, who took five months' maternity leave after the birth of Ellie, now 20 months, is keen to see attention paid instead to the maternity and child health services she will be using.

Under a new drive to address the inequalities which mean that UK children from low income backgrounds suffer poorer health and higher death rates than their more affluent counterparts, the government has set a new infant mortality target. Amid evidence that the death rate of babies under one in the lowest income areas is 70% higher than in the most affluent areas, the aim is to reduce the gap between the poorest and the average by 10% in 10 years.

Equal treatment

In a move designed to iron out the postcode lottery affecting child health care, ministers are to draw up a new children's national service framework - NHS jargon for a plan to offer equal treatment and services, including maternity care, across the country.

The step follows recent moves to extend the Sure Start programme, aimed at helping poorer families with children under four, to support expectant mothers, and an initiative to provide free daily fruit in infant schools.

Ms Cooper, who pushed strongly within her department for the focus on child health, points to the relatively lower birthweight of babies from low income homes, together with statistics showing that smaller babies have increased risk of higher blood pressure and heart disease later in life. "If you look at the health inequalities issue, so many of them are rooted very early in life, if not passed down from one generation to another."

The government, with its pledge to abolish child poverty within 20 years, has much to do: the latest published figures, for 1998/99, show that 4.5m children in the UK were living in poverty: one of the worst rates among industrialised countries. The numbers have since been reduced by 1m, according to government figures, but child poverty campaigners warn those deepest in poverty will be hardest to lift out.

More passionate

Ms Cooper admits personal experience has strengthened her concern over child health. "When you are a parent, inevitably, it makes you more sensitive or more passionate about what happens to young children because it is what you see immediately around you in your own life. In the same way, when you are using maternity services, and talking to other parents, that can be quite effective for the policy-making process because you are not divorced from the policy area you are working on."

Ms Cooper will take the statutory 18 weeks leave, on full ministerial pay. At the birth of the baby, her husband, Ed Balls, also at New Labour's epicentre as chancellor Gordon Brown's closest aide, will take two weeks' paternity leave and will continue to help out with childcare in the evenings.

Publicly, she will refuse to admit she is doing anything unusual, though the prospect of a minister taking maternity leave inevitably breaks new ground. "It has never been done before - this is new territory and it will take some time to work out how to do it. The department will have to look at what the best arrangements are. But I have found everybody is very keen to make it work."

fields.headline: Faithful invited to Mugabe's Victoria Falls bash
fields.standfirst: Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: Robert Mugabe has never been one to shy away from adulation, so he is going for two parties to mark his 77th birthday today.
fields.byline: Andrew Meldrum in Harare and Chris McGreal in Johannesburg
fields.body:
Robert Mugabe has never been one to shy away from adulation, so he is going for two parties to mark his 77th birthday today.

There will be the small one in Harare before he flies off in a futile bid to persuade international bankers to give him more money. Then there will be a big bash at Victoria Falls at the weekend, loans or no loans.

With one eye on a looming presidential election, all sorts of people have made the invitation list to Victoria Falls who might otherwise have been ignored.

Aside from the usual cronies and government officials, young men and women from the youth groups loyal to the ruling party suddenly find themselves in favour; they do not usually get much attention from the president, but every vote is going to count in this election, which may be just months away.

Also, young men are not only good at getting Mr Mugabe's supporters out; they will prove useful in ensuring that opposition supporters stay away from the ballot boxes.

The celebrations at Victoria Falls are being organised by the 21st February Movement, a group named after Mr Mugabe's date of birth, and one which might be more at home in North Korea in the light of its attempts to build a personality cult around him.

The party will be paid for by Zimbabwean taxpayers, very few of whom think it is money well spent, despite the movement's attempts to whip up enthusiasm.

Some view the celebrations as a particularly perverse taunt given the state of Zimbabwe's finances and the misery engulfing the country.

The guest list is a who's who of Africa's historic liberation movements and ruling parties. Tony Blair has not been invited.

There are those among Zimbabwe's neighbours who think it might not be a bad thing if this were Mr Mugabe's last birthday as president. He is doing them no favours by driving Zimbabwe's economy into the ground; but that won't be their public position.

Still, the celebrations are likely to be a relief for Mr Mugabe who flies to Tanzania today to hear the heads of the World Bank and the IMF tell him he has no hope of getting any more money to rescue his collapsing economy.

webTitle: Arts: Suddenly everyone wants to put Bollywood on stage. Krishnedu Majumdar has his doubts.

fields.headline: Salaam Bombay
fields.standfirst: Covent Garden is working on an Indian-themed opera, Lloyd Webber is teaming up with Meera Syal . . . Suddenly everyone wants to put Bollywood on stage. But  Krishnendu Majumdar  has his doubts
fields.trailText: Covent Garden is working on an Indian-themed opera, Lloyd Webber is teaming up with Meera Syal . . . Suddenly everyone wants to put Bollywood on stage. But Krishnendu Majumdar has his doubts.
fields.body:
Last week Tamasha theatre company's Bollywood play Fourteen Songs, Two Weddings and a Funeral transferred to the main stage of the Lyric Hammersmith in London. In the West End, Andrew Lloyd Webber is developing his latest musical, a Bollywood epic called Bombay Dreams. Over in Covent Garden, the Royal Opera is a developing a Bollywood version of Turandot.

But why here, and why now? Bollywood itself contains a mishmash of cultures and influences - from Bond films to spaghetti westerns. It is all about popular culture and it is neither proud nor precious. However, the film industry based in Bombay that spawned the term has changed. Twenty years ago Bollywood made socially aware work. Now, says film-maker Shakilla Maan, "Bollywood no longer has fragrance. It doesn't look at poverty . . . It has lost its humanity. It's an expensively packaged bottle of perfume."

That may in fact suit the West End, with its glitz and soullessness. Lloyd Webber's musical Bombay Dreams is in development at the moment. He has brought together the composer AR Rahmen and director Shekhar Kapur. Meera Syal is to write the book. With over 50 Bollywood films scores to his name, Rahmen is an unquestioned success as a composer. Lloyd Webber, rather than contributing to the score, is producing. So far, he seems to have got things right. The question is: can authenticity survive when producers cross cultural divides and linguistic barriers?

In most large theatres in London, the audience is almost exclusively white (regional theatres such as Birmingham Rep do better). But producers are realising that there is an audience for theatre with Asian themes, one that hasn't yet been exploited. The brown pound is strong. In addition, Hindi films sell globally, with markets in the Middle East, Africa and North America. Surely audiences enjoy entertainment that gives them an experience of another culture?

Tamasha's co-founder Sudha Bhuchar says that its shows appeal to all. "Our last show, Balti Kings, had a 40% core Asian audience, and a 60% non-Asian audience. We gained a mainstream audience following the success of East Is East two years ago."

In terms of accessibility, the choice of language used raises issues. Tamasha decided to translate its text and songs into English. Lloyd Webber is doing the same. But are people hungry to experience another culture through its mother tongue?

According to Jatinder Verma, artistic director of British Asian theatre company Tara Arts, "Audiences have had enough packaging. If language is the window of the soul of a people, then how can you possibly deny language as a medium of cultural exchange? How do we approach it? Then how do we use the power of our own medium to try and bring it to our own audiences?"

It should be possible to keep texts in the original Hindi. The kids in my street all used to watch classic films such as Sholay - we would cycle around in a gang singing Hindi songs pretending to be Amitabh Bacchan. The fact that I grew up in south Wales and none of my friends then was Asian or understood the language didn't matter. Bollywood films have other ways of communicating with a wide audience. So it should be possible for musical theatre to work when sung in Hindi with English surtitles - like opera sung in Italian, German or French.

The Royal Opera House is attempting to capitalise on the similarities between opera and Bollywood films. Its Bollywood Turandot started last month with the house's education department collaborating with staff and over 100 students at Villers High School, Southall. This is multiculturalism at its best. But it's still limited to an outreach project in a single school.

With the commercial pressures that the West End exerts, Lloyd Webber's Bollywood Dreams will undoubtedly be sanitised and packaged, but to what extent? Will the audience see the sights and sounds of Indian entertainment, but without any substance? I don't doubt Lloyd Webber's enthusiasm. It is just that age-old process of assimilation in action: it takes a figure from the establishment to give "minority" arts the thumbs-up. There is a danger that Lloyd Webber milking the sacred cow of Bolly will overshadow the important work done by British Asian artists such as Tanika Gupta, Parv Bancil and Ayub Khan-Din. They won't be going away, even if the media's eyes are dazzled by Bollywood for a while.

But many commissioners of new work tend to lump work by ethnic minorities together: they tick boxes and if one group or individual is visible, then that somehow seems to represent everyone else. The media is probably already growing tired of successful British Asian acts such as Goodness Gracious Me. In that sense Tamasha are one step ahead of the game. They have revived Fourteen Songs at just the right time. The play - an adaptation of the 1994 Bollywood blockbuster Hum Aapke Hain Koun - is making waves, and garnering critical acclaim.

The West End potential of this Indian-inspired theatre lies in its popular appeal. After all, the beauty of Bollywood is that it is meant for the masses. If done with care, it should be a spectacular success in mainstream British theatre. If they manage to keep a little of its soul it will be here to stay.

webTitle: Featur: How the world's most famous shoe collection became a museum piece in the Philippines

fields.headline: The shoe must go on
fields.standfirst: John Aglionby on how the world's most famous shoe collection became a museum piece in the Philippines
fields.trailText: John Aglionby on how the world's most famous shoe collection became a museum piece in the Philippines.
fields.body:
Imelda Marcos, arguably the world's most insatiable shoe collector, caressed a pair of black Charles Jourdan stilettos with rhinestones studded in the heels and reminisced about a party where she wore them. Or was that lavish gala the time she wore one of the four identical pairs sitting next to the one she was holding? "I really can't keep track anymore," she admitted, as her eyes turned to a pair of pink leather pumps.

The occasion last Friday was when the widow of former Philippine dictator Ferdinand Marcos came face to face with 220 of her 1,200 pairs of shoes for the first time since she fled the presidential palace 15 years earlier as tens of thousands of protesters swarmed into the grounds.

Marcos, who has since returned to her homeland and built a political career, was inaugurating the Shoe Museum, located on Shoe Street, in Marikina, a satellite city of the capital Manila famous for its cobblers.

Wearing a locally made pair of silver shoes, Marcos had no qualms in joking about the most infamous manifestation of her immeasurable extravagance. "They went into my closets looking for skeletons, but thank God all they found were shoes, beautiful shoes," she quipped.

The walls of the small, two-story building show shiny high heels, strappy pumps, soft leather moccasin-style shoes and other size 8 1/2 footwear from Christian Dior, Givenchy, Chanel, Ferragamo and many other haute couture designers.

But amid all the glitter and swanky opulence, Marcos held up a pair of innocuous blue espadrilles as her favourite pair. They were what she was wearing when she left all the others behind on their custom-made racks in the palace.

"This museum [is] making a subject of notoriety into an object of beauty," said the one-time regular patron of designer boutiques the world over. "More than anything, this museum will symbolise the spirit and culture of the Filipino people. Filipinos don't wallow in what is miserable and ugly. They recycle the bad into things of beauty."

While Friday was the first time in years Marcos had seen her shoes, it wasn't the first time they had been exhibited. Corazon Aquino, who succeeded Ferdinand Marcos as president, displayed much of the collection at the palace during her six-year term as a reminder of the type of excess that should never be allowed again amid the nation's rampant poverty.

When the horde of footwear was discovered Marcos claimed her only purpose in buying so many pairs was to support the Marikina shoe industry, which provides a livelihood for tens of thousands of people. Her critics might well have described that excuse as a load of old cobblers.

webTitle: Turkey suffers as leaders fight on

fields.headline: Turkey suffers as leaders fight on
fields.trailText: A public row between Turkey's president and prime minister has provoked a renewed financial crisis and highlighted the biggest challenge facing the country - how to deal with the web of corruption that has shaped Turkey for a generation.
fields.body:
A public row between Turkey's president and prime minister has provoked a renewed financial crisis and highlighted the biggest challenge facing the country - how to deal with the web of corruption that has shaped Turkey for a generation.

The prime minister, Bulent Ecevit, stormed out of a routine meeting of the national security council on Monday, saying he had been insulted by President Ahmet Necdet Sezer.

Mr Sezer had harangued the government for looking into corruption allegations too slowly. "You are sitting on the mud. We can clean it up if you're not going to do it," he reportedly said. "Why are you scared of the corruption investigations?"

A copy of the constitution was thrown back and forth across the table before Mr Ecevit and members of his cabinet walked out. An angry prime minister then went on national television to speak of a serious political crisis.

The markets believed the government was about to resign. Within minutes several billion pounds had been wiped off share values, and several billion more had been sold from the foreign exchange reserves of the central bank.

Yesterday the markets stabilised, but some interest rates soared to more than 1,000%.

The latest row between Mr Sezer and Mr Ecevit, who have had several high-profile disputes, is a fundamental disagreement about how the state system should operate.

President Sezer has reactivated a rarely used state inspection board to investigate the political plunder of public banks over the last decade. Mr Ecevit had already appointed investigators, and is angry that the president seems to be "inspecting his inspectors".

Both men have reputations for honesty, and Mr Ecevit clearly believes his integrity has been called into question by the president's criticism.

Whoever is to blame for the current crisis, there is a widespread belief in Turkey that things cannot stumble on as they are. But changing the system will be a massive task.

"Corruption has eaten into everything," said Metin Munir, a leading financial journalist. "It's like a disease, and Turkey can't bear it any longer."

There are entrenched interests who have a lot to lose from a cleaner economy. Many are part of a political system which has lost the confidence of the people. Several leading politicians have been the target of corruption claims that have been dropped at politically convenient moments.

The government insists it has done more than its predecessors to expose corruption, and wants a public apology from the president. Sceptics say that as long as the old guard investigates itself, nothing lasting will be achieved.

But if Mr Ecevit allows a large-scale anti-corruption drive, he may sacrifice the political stability needed to push through economic reforms.

All the while, Turks seem gloomier than ever about their country's prospects.

"We've had the political theatre," said Hakan Avci, a financial analyst with Global Securities. "Now we're waiting to see if the president and the prime minister can find some way to work together. They can't afford a long delay."

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText:
Spain nets huge cocaine haul
Spanish police said yesterday that they had found five tonnes of cocaine, with a street value of £60m, on a British-flagged trawler.
fields.body:
Spain nets huge cocaine haul
Spanish police said yesterday that they had found five tonnes of cocaine, with a street value of £60m, on a British-flagged trawler.

The Spanish crew of the Abrente allegedly tried to throw the cocaine overboard as their vessel was boarded by police and customs officials some 350 miles west of the Canary islands.

Thirteen Spaniards were arrested on the boat and in the northern region of Galicia, which has become the gateway for cocaine into Europe.
Giles Tremlett, Madrid

Manila in talks with rebels
President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo yesterday suspended military operations against Muslim separatists in the southern Philippines and promised peace talks with the Moro Islamic Liberation Front rebels.

But Ms Arroyo said there would be no talks with the second most prominent group, the Abu Sayyaf.
John Aglionby, Jakarta

Food warning for El Salvador
The World Food Programme said yesterday that its food stocks have been exhausted in El Salvador, leaving hundreds of thousands facing hunger after a series of earthquakes.

A further quake, thought to measure around four on the Richter scale, shook San Salvador yesterday, panicking residents.
Agencies, El Salvador

webTitle: Did malaria bring Rome to its knees?

fields.headline: Did malaria bring Rome to its knees?
fields.standfirst: Analysis of 1,500-year-old bones suggests that mosquitoes weakened the empire and helped invaders defeat it
fields.trailText: Analysis of 1,500-year-old bones suggests that mosquitoes weakened the empire and helped invaders defeat it.
fields.body:
Analysis of the skeleton of a child buried on the eve of the fall of the Roman empire has revealed that the barbarians may have had a secret ally: malaria.

British and American researchers say that DNA from the 1,500-year-old bones, found in a cemetery north of Rome, yielded evidence of an epidemic.

A lethal outbreak could partly explain why antiquity's mightiest military machine was too enfeebled to repel the Visigoths, Huns and Vandals.

The discovery - the earliest genetic evidence of malaria yet identified - has been hailed as a breakthrough in the collaboration between archaeology and biomolecular science.

Excavations at a cemetery for infants in Lugnano, dated to the year 450, found a leg bone of a three-year-old child suffering from Plasmodium falciparum, the most virulent form of human malaria.

Around 50 infants' skeletons were buried within a short period of time, suggesting an epidemic. The smallest skeletons were too degraded to produce DNA samples but some had pitted cranium surfaces - another sign of malaria.

The disease is thought to have spawned panic: despite the fact that Romans were by then officially Christians, pagan offerings such as a raven's claw and decapitated puppy skeletons were found nearby.

Malaria is a mosquito-borne fever caused by a protozoan parasite which thrives in warm, marshy areas such as the Tiber river valley. The falciparum strain causes miscarriage and infant death.

Some historians had long suspected that malaria contributed to the empire's decline and fall by sapping morale and manpower.

Robert Sallares, a research fellow at the University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology, and Susan Comz, a student, reported their results in the journal Ancient Biomolecules.

The skeleton was recovered in the early 1990s by ateam of archaeologists led by David Soren of the University of Arizona. He told the Washington Post that the DNA findings were new and exciting. "The idea that this deadly type of malaria really existed in imperial Rome had never been documented."

Rot set into the empire from the late second century. The economy and army stagnated in the third and fourth cen turies as Persians and northern tribes encroached. Traditional historians say the western empire was tottering when Alaric's Visigoths sacked Rome in 410.

In 452 Attila's Huns pillaged northern Italy on their way to Rome. According to Christian chronicles, Pope Leo the Great confronted the barbarian and talked him into withdrawing. The DNA analysis suggests the real reason for the withdrawal may have been Attila's fear of exposing his troops to a malaria epidemic.

It was a short respite. Three years later Gaiseric the Vandal sailed from his pirate kingdom in north Africa to invade Italy and sack Rome.

The western empire finally collapsed in 476 when Odoacer was crowned king of Italy at Pavia.

Professor Michael Whitby, a historian at the University of Warwick, said malaria would probably not have afflicted the legions as they were mostly stationed in northern Italy.

"These armies could on occasion have been exposed to malarial areas but not necessarily. However, if there was a serious outbreak and agricultural prosperity suffered, then there could have been knock-on effects on military supports."

webTitle: UN shaken by refugees' extortion allegations

fields.headline: UN shaken by refugees' extortion allegations
fields.trailText: The United Nations is investigating allegations that some of its employees were members of an organised crime network in Africa which took bribes to resettle refugees in the west.
fields.byline: Adrian Blomfield in Nairobi and agencies
fields.body:
The United Nations is investigating allegations that some of its employees were members of an organised crime network in Africa which took bribes to resettle refugees in the west.

Paul Stromberg, a spokesman for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR), confirmed reports that at least four people who had worked out of the Nairobi office were being investigated. One of the four is understood to be a European.

Mr Stromberg said a number of refugees had alleged that they were asked to pay between $2,000 and $5,000 (£1,400-£3,500) to be resettled in north America, Europe and Australia.

"[The investigation] may involve more than four people. How many people will be investigated, how many people may have charges brought against them we will only know when the... UN watchdog agency gives its final report."

The investigation is understood to be looking beyond resettlement cases to reports that guards charged refugees for entry into UNHCR compounds, and that UN workers demanded payment for appointments and for basic services, he said.

UN staff who allegedly extorted money from refugees should be "harshly" punished if proved guilty, the UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, said yesterday.

"I think it is abominable that refugees who are already suffering, who are displaced, whose lives have been uprooted, should be exploited in this manner," he said.

Many refugees say they believed paying a fee to UNHCR officials increased their chances of being given asylum.

"The refugees who have money do not have the problems that everyone else has," Celestin Kangambo, who fled Congo after his parents were killed by rebels, said outside the UNHCR office in Nairobi.

"As refugees we talk to each other, and there are refugees who have accomplished the process by money," Destaw Berhanu, a refugee from Ethiopia, said.

Mr Annan said: "It was important that we discovered this quite early and got to work very quickly."

The office in Nairobi had carried out an "inconclusive" investigation, he said, adding that the UN's Office of Internal Oversight, based in New York, had taken over the inquiry.

"We are determined to go to the bottom of this and deal with those are responsible. Of course we will have to take measures to make sure that it does not reoccur and tighten our controls," Mr Annan said.

More than 9,000 refugees, mostly from Somalia and Sudan, were resettled through Kenya last year, mainly to the US, Australia, New Zealand and Scandinavia.

Three of the UNHCR's staff under investigation have not been suspended but have been moved off tasks related to the movement of refugees. The European has not had his contract renewed.

There also appear to be links to organised crime groups, and four international UNHCR staff have had to be moved from Kenya after receiving death threats because of their knowledge of the situation, Mr Stromberg said.

"Human trafficking is something which involves in many countries very highly organised and very violent criminal groups," he said. "They made very serious threats against our staff."

Investigations, which began in Nairobi in December 1999, are expected to be complete within the next few months.

Mr Stromberg acknowledged that the allegations were deeply embarrassing for the UNHCR, which is responsible for screening the suitability of refugees who request asylum in western countries.

"We take it very seriously," he said.

"It's clearly a corruption of the [UNHCR] mandate if the allegations are true."

webTitle: Delays prompt arson at Pretoria station

fields.headline: Commuters' revolt
fields.standfirst: Delays prompt arson at Pretoria station
fields.trailText: Commuters enraged when a signal failure forced the cancellation of dozens of trains at rush hour on Monday night burned down a large part of Pretoria's historic railway station.
fields.body:
Commuters enraged when a signal failure forced the cancellation of dozens of trains at rush hour on Monday night burned down a large part of Pretoria's historic railway station.

About 6,000 travellers stormed the station's passenger services office after failing to break into the control room. They smashed through a glass wall, destroyed computers and a few set fire to the 91-year-old station designed by one of South Africa's most famous architects, Sir Herbert Baker.

The roof and third floor of the national monument were destroyed and much of the rest of the building was damaged by water as about 80 firefighters spent the night dousing the blaze.

Witnesses said guards on the station platform fled as passengers vented their anger on any official connected with the railways.

The train firm, Metrorail, blamed the breakdown on the theft of a fibre optic cable. Its chief executive, Honey Mateya, said the problem was compounded by a communications failure which left commuters standing on the platforms with no information. "It was almost operationally hopeless," he conceded.

But he condemned the arson. "This kind of behaviour is not acceptable... It is not good for our image," he said.

Long delays, often with commuters stuck in idle trains, are common in South Africa, as are cancelled services with no explanation. Sometimes a bus is laid on, but usually there are not enough seats for all the passengers.

"Metrorail would leave us at the station all night and not care," said Timid Moekeletsi. "Our children are waiting for their food. They are saying: 'Where are our mothers and fathers?' But they know. Their parents are prisoners on the train. It happens almost every day."

On Monday a woman was hit by a passing train in Johannesburg when passengers forced open doors and started walking along the track after their train had been stationary for close to an hour.

But the fire in Pretoria only compounded the misery for commuters yesterday as thousands of people arrived at the station to find it sealed off by soldiers and riot police with barbed wire. About 70% of train services to other stations in the Pretoria area were cancelled or late.

The rail company sent buses to some townships but there were too few vehicles. The mood was reported to be tense in Atteridgeville where commuters were left completely stranded.

The railways corporation which owns Pretoria station said preliminary investigations suggested that the main structure could be saved but that it is necessary to wait two days for the temperature to settle before a final assessment could be made.

"These incidents make our insurers, Lloyd's of London, very, very nervous about insuring us," said Ben van der Ross, head of the corporation.

The transport minister, Dullah Omar, condemned the riot. "I understand the frustration of commuters when there are delays, but this should never be allowed to find expression in violence," he said.

fields.headline: Boutique bans 'big fuss' Naomi
fields.trailText: Naomi Campbell has been banned from a members-only boutique after her infamous temper allegedly got the better of her.
fields.body:
Naomi Campbell has been banned from a members-only boutique after her infamous temper allegedly got the better of her.

The catwalk star was asked to leave the exclusive Voyage shop in Fulham in west London when she reportedly shouted at staff and accused them of not recognising her.

The model apparently turned up at the store and was unable to gain entry. She rang the doorbell and, receiving no reply, returned to her car to wait.

Shortly afterwards another customer appeared and gained immediate entry to the shop, which boasts members such as Madonna, Mick Jagger and Nicole Kidman.

Rocky Mazzilli, whose parents Tiziano and Louise own the store, said that Ms Campbell then came in and complained that she should not have been made to wait.

"She was saying that we should recognise her and let her in directly. She was making such a big, big fuss. At first we apologised and tried to smooth things over, but she just wanted to pick an argument. My sister, Tatum, was serving a customer and she could hear this commotion. Naomi was saying that we should have let her in straight away because of who she is."

Mr Mazzilli said all his customers were expected to show a degree of respect to the staff, no matter who they were.

"My sister asked her to leave and then we rang her model agency and said her membership was being revoked. Here at Voyage we believe that no matter who you are, whether you are a supermodel or a waitress, you should have a minimum amount of respect for other people," Mr Mazzilli added.

A spokesman for Ms Campbell, 30, refused to comment.

The model last year pleaded guilty to assaulting her assistant with a mobile phone.

Ms Campbell, born in south London, is at present dating Flavio Briatore, the Italian millionaire and founder of the Benetton Formula One team , and is understood to have taken up boxing as a way to channel her aggression.

webTitle: Dettori crash pilot lacked specific training

fields.headline: Dettori crash pilot lacked specific training
fields.trailText: The experienced pilot who was killed in the air crash that left champion jockey Frankie Dettori injured had no record of being trained for the kind of plane he was flying, an official report said yesterday.
fields.body:
The experienced pilot who was killed in the air crash that left champion jockey Frankie Dettori injured had no record of being trained for the kind of plane he was flying, an official report said yesterday.

The report by the air accident investigation branch does not say that the pilot Patrick Mackey, 52, failed to take off properly at the Newmarket racecourse last year.

But it notes he was flying a different kind of aircraft, a Piper Seneca, not the Cessna he was used to. Furthermore, the wing flaps were positioned for take-off at 10 degrees, correct for the Cessna.

Air accident investigators found that one propeller hit the ground as the plane accelerated for take-off with Dettori and fellow jockey Ray Cochrane aboard.

Once in the air, it arched to the right and hit an embankment after failing to gain enough height to clear it.

The plane then spun and burst into flames. The jockeys fled through a rear baggage hatch, but their attempts to rescue the pilot failed, as they were beaten back by the heat of the blaze.

Dettori, 30, was in hospital for four days with a broken ankle but was able to return to racing. Cochrane, who damaged an already-injured back and suffered burns and blurred vision, has since retired from the turf.

The jockeys had taken off from Newmarket's July Strip on the morning of June 1, 2000, heading for a race meeting at Goodwood in West Sussex.

The report added the propeller manufacturer had said that the propeller striking the ground was likely to have resulted in a severe loss of thrust.

The report said: "There was adequate runway remaining for the pilot to have abandoned the take-off, or to have immediately relanded the aircraft _ had he recognised the problem.

"The pilot would have heard the noise of the propeller ground contact but not necessarily have been able to identify the source. It remains a possibility that he thought some other event _ had occurred and this could account for his decision to continue."

A spokesman for the civil aviation authority said: "He should have been fully aware of the different character of that aircraft. He was not required to have special training for that aircraft."

Mr Mackey had had 60 hours' flying time with the Piper, the last time being in 1992.

But it notes he was flying a different kind of aircraft, a Piper Seneca, not the Cessna he was used to. Furthermore, the wing flaps were positioned for take-off at 10 degrees, correct for the Cessna. Air accident investigators found that one propeller hit the ground as the plane accelerated for take-off with Dettori and fellow jockey Ray Cochrane aboard. Once in the air, it arched to the right and hit an embankment after failing to gain enough height to clear it. The plane then spun and burst into flames. The jockeys fled through a rear baggage hatch, but their attempts to rescue the pilot failed, as they were beaten back by the heat of the blaze. Dettori, 30, was in hospital for four days with a broken ankle but was able to return to racing. Cochrane, who damaged an already-injured back and suffered burns and blurred vision, has since retired from the turf. The jockeys had taken off from Newmarket's July Strip on the morning of June 1, 2000, heading for a race meeting at Goodwood in West Sussex. The report added the propeller manufacturer had said that the propeller striking the ground was likely to have resulted in a severe loss of thrust. The report said: "There was adequate runway remaining for the pilot to have abandoned the take-off, or to have immediately relanded the aircraft _ had he recognised the problem. "The pilot would have heard the noise of the propeller ground contact but not necessarily have been able to identify the source. It remains a possibility that he thought some other event _ had occurred and this could account for his decision to continue." A spokesman for the civil aviation authority said: "He should have been fully aware of the different character of that aircraft. He was not required to have special training for that aircraft." Mr Mackey had had 60 hours' flying time with the Piper, the last time being in 1992.

webTitle: Moscow tussle as Nato opens office

fields.headline: Moscow tussle as Nato opens office
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: Nato's secretary general, Lord Robertson, opened a Nato information centre in Moscow last night, establishing a formal alliance presence in the city almost two years after the Kremlin severed relations because of the bombing of Yugoslavia.
fields.body:
Nato's secretary general, Lord Robertson, opened a Nato information centre in Moscow last night, establishing a formal alliance presence in the city almost two years after the Kremlin severed relations because of the bombing of Yugoslavia.

The opening followed months of discreet behind the scenes wrangling between the Kremlin and Nato headquarters in Brussels. Among the issues were: when is a Belgian a Belgian; does an information centre constitute a diplomatic mission; and should the Nato officers staffing the centre enjoy the perks and privileges accorded to the thousands of foreign diplomats accredited in the Russian capital?

The Russians refused to give the Nato office the status of a diplomatic mission equivalent to a foreign embassy.

As a result the two Nato officers running the centre would not enjoy the status of diplomats, would not have diplomatic immunity from prosecution and, as one Russian newspaper said yesterday, could be arrested rather than expelled if caught spying or carrying out other activities incompatible with their non-diplomatic status.

"Nato insisted on full diplomatic immunity. The Russians said the office can't have full diplomatic status because it's not an embassy," explained one west European diplomat in Moscow.

To overcome the problem, the information centre is being located within the Belgian embassy and the two officers, not yet appointed, are to be accredited as Belgian diplomats in Moscow. Neither is expected to be Belgian, though they will both enjoy diplomatic immunity.

The Russian legal nitpicking, said Nato officials, was in contrast to the more expansive conditions available to Moscow's much bigger mission to Nato's Brussels headquarters and at Shape, the military headquarters, at Mons.

The Russians have 21 military officers or diplomats in Brussels, plus several in Mons. But while some 40 non-Nato members maintain small offices within the sprawling compound on the outskirts of the Belgian capital, the Russians rent office spacein the city centre, no doubt to frustrate Nato buggers and phone-tappers.

To confuse things further, another two Nato officers, one German and one French, operated officially as Nato's contact mission at the German embassy in Moscow until they were expelled during the Kosovo war. Most of the Russians remained in Brussels.

"It's very complicated," sighed a west European diplomat. "There will definitely be status problems."
