webTitle: Pirate trawlers put fish stocks on the line

fields.headline: Pirate trawlers put fish stocks on the line
fields.standfirst:
UK-based ship owners profit from plunder of endangered species

Special report: global fishing in crisis
fields.trailText: Japan is urging the EU to outlaw pirate fishing vessels which are plundering Atlantic fish stocks and putting legitimate fishermen out of business.
fields.body:
Japan is urging the EU to outlaw pirate fishing vessels which are plundering Atlantic fish stocks and putting legitimate fishermen out of business.

It accuses the EU of soft pedalling because, although the pirate vessels ply their trade under notorious flags of convenience, many of the trawler owners live comfortably in Spain and the UK.

Fearing a collapse in world fish stocks because of the pirate fishing, the UN Food and Agriculture Organisation meets in Rome today to try to finalise an international agreement banning the landing of catches and clamping down on the owners.

Japan, one of the main recipients of illegally caught Atlantic tuna, has been trying to stop the traffic partly because it fears stocks will become exhausted and partly because its fishing unions believe they are being put out of work.

Without international cooperation to prosecute the owners, Japan believes it will be difficult to stamp out the global trade which accounts for more than 10% of total world catches.

Among the species being wiped out by pirate boats is the patagonian tooth fish, sold in British supermarkets as antarctic ice fish, and caught on long lines. Each line is spiked with 50,000 hooks which also kill albatross and other sea birds.

Estimates based on Lloyd's Maritime Information Services show there are around 1,300 industrial fishing vessels flying flags of convenience. Belize has 404 registered trawlers or "fishing vessels", Honduras, 395, Panama, 214 and St Vincent and the Grenadines 108. A flag registration can be bought over the internet for as little as £350.

The owners are often registered in the same country as the ship, at least on paper, although the real beneficiaries are far away. Taiwan tops the list of beneficial owners with 169 vessels while the EU has 168. Of these Spain and the Canary Islands have 116, Portugal 12, Greece 11 and the UK 10.

Of Britain's 10, four were registered in St Vincent and the Grenadines, four in Panama and two in Belize.

In addition there is a fish-carrying vessel which collects the catch from industrial trawlers at sea and takes it to market, disguising its origins.

The Guardian tried to contact several companies by telephone but failed to find anyone who would admit to owning such a fishing vessel.

In October, at the last meeting on "illegal, unregulated and unreported" fishing, as it is known by the UN, attempts to reach agreement were resisted by Mexico and Brazil, who said that clamping down on pirate boats was a restraint of free trade, and by the EU which managed to delete most provisions calling on governments to penalise or take other action against companies under their jurisdiction.

The Ministry of Agriculture said yesterday that it did not agree with the EU and said state control over nationals was one of the clauses it wanted back in the document.

Greenpeace, which has followed illegal ships, watched them unload at sea and traced freezer vessels to ports in Japan, says pirate vessels are successfully evading all fishing conservation and management regulations.

"We must close ports to these vessels, close markets to the fish, and penalise the companies involved in the jurisdiction of their home country," said Matthew Gianni from Grenpeace.

"The EU has seriously weakened the agreement by removing the parts which allow member states to take action against the beneficial owners. All fishing agreements are made worthless if pirate fishing is allowed to continue."

Pirate fishing has doubled in the last 10 years. Patagonian tooth fish are worth £8 a kilo for sushi and sashimi and the illegal trade in this catch alone is worth £300m annually.

Individual blue fin tuna, now an endangered species, have fetched up to £30,000 on the Japanese market.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Yacht deaths investigation
The Nottinghamshire coroner has asked police to investigate the loss of a yatch last July while it was crossing from the Netherlands to Suffolk. Students James Chew, 22, of Nottinghamshire, Carol Smith, 23, of Staffordshire, and Canadian Chris McMenemy, 26, and skipper Adam Clackson, 58, of Cambridge, were later found drowned.
fields.body:
Yacht deaths investigation
The Nottinghamshire coroner has asked police to investigate the loss of a yatch last July while it was crossing from the Netherlands to Suffolk. Students James Chew, 22, of Nottinghamshire, Carol Smith, 23, of Staffordshire, and Canadian Chris McMenemy, 26, and skipper Adam Clackson, 58, of Cambridge, were later found drowned.

Man held over Rolex robbery
A man aged 19 was in custody last night over the theft of ex-Spurs footballer Gary Mabbutt's Rolex, as he sat in a traffic jam in Shepherds Bush, west London, a week ago.

Catholic leader to be cardinal
Cormac Murphy-O'Connor, Archbishop of Westminster and leader of the Roman Catholic Church in England and Wales, is being made a cardinal by the Pope in Rome today. He is one of 44 appointments announced by the Vatican last month.

Murder and robbery charge
A man aged 24 will appear before magistrates in Rochdale, Greater Manchester, charged with murdering Eileen Jawczak, 65, in Rochdale last September, and with robbing and indecently assaulting another woman.

Firm fined after worker dies
Lehnkering Logistics, of Martlesham Heath in Suffolk, was fined £15,000 and ordered to pay £15,000 costs at Ipswich crown court after admitting two breaches of health and safety legislation, relating to warehouseman Gordon Morling, 38, killed instantly when racking collapsed on him in 1999.

Two arrested in dome inquiry
A man and a woman from Wavertree in Liverpool are on bail after being arrested last week over an alleged fraud in the awarding of a contract for the Millennium Dome. Late last year police questioned two others from Wavertree over the contract.

Four ill at school with hepatitis
One child is still recovering after four pupils caught the hepatitis A virus at St William's primary school at Ince, near Wigan, Greater Manchester. Health inspectors have checked the school, and parents have been informed.

£3m lottery win unclaimed
Camelot said the £3m winner of last year's September 6 midweek draw had less than a fortnight to make a claim within the 180-day limit. The ticket, 6, 7, 11, 23, 32 and 44, was bought in the south of Hertfordshire.

Cruise liner runs aground
More than 170 Britons among 1,130 passengers aboard a cruise liner, the Mistral, are safe after it ran aground off the island of Nevis in the Caribbean. The Greek owners said a tug hoped to pull the ship clear.

Warning device for pensioners
A electronic device triggered by a caller is being installed by the Home Office in 1,300 pensioner households to help prevent burglaries. It plays a message reminding them to use their security chain or ask for identification.

Red tape cut for wind farms
The Department of Trade and Industry is simplifying the procedure for setting up offshore wind farms in England and Wales, to help meet the UK's target of supplying 10% of electricity from renewable sources.

webTitle: Gatwick stowaway found dead in US

fields.headline: Gatwick stowaway found dead in US
fields.trailText: A stowaway who disguised himself in the uniform of an airport worker froze to death in a plane's landing gear on a 15-hour flight to San Francisco.
fields.body:
A stowaway who disguised himself in the uniform of an airport worker froze to death in a plane's landing gear on a 15-hour flight to San Francisco.

The stowaway had dressed as a Gatwick ground crew member before climbing into the landing gear of a US Airways Boeing 767-200 bound for San Francisco on Monday. It is thought the man was still crouched in a wheel well when the plane stopped at Pittsburgh before completing its journey.

A spokesman for US Airways said the plane had been guarded from the time it arrived at Gatwick until it took off. He said: "We are cooperating fully with police inquiries."

The dead man is understood to have been dressed in overalls and fluorescent bib.

A postmortem examination was due to be carried out by the state coroner in San Francisco.

Last December two Cuban stowaways died trying to reach the US via Gatwick. The body of Maikel Almira, 16, fell from a Mexico-bound Boeing 777 in Surrey, on Christmas Eve. Alberto Rodriguez, 15, was found on the runway at Gatwick the next day.

fields.headline: Off the rails
fields.trailText: Developments on Britain's railways inevitably attract speculative articles in the press, but your piece (Railtrack 'facing bankruptcy', February 19) was a nonsense on which I will make only two comments, because they affect the interests of investors and users.
fields.body:
Developments on Britain's railways inevitably attract speculative articles in the press, but your piece (Railtrack 'facing bankruptcy', February 19) was a nonsense on which I will make only two comments, because they affect the interests of investors and users.

First, I welcome the statement Railtrack issued on Sunday to set the record straight about its finances.

Second, the chairman of the SRA does not have the power, nor does he have the wish, to order a "halt to any further funding for rail maintenance". The irresponsibility of such a proposition ought to be apparent to anyone. It follows that no such decision "has been backed by the SRA's board", nor even proposed.
Alastair Morton
Chairman, Strategic Rail Authority

webTitle: Letters: No, things did not get any fairer

fields.headline: No, things did not get any fairer
fields.trailText: Polly Toynbee and David Walker (Things got a little fairer, February 20) accept that "the poorest did best under Blair". Then why do residents of deprived areas continually meet neighbours who are without basic necessities? Toynbee and Walker overlook two matters. First, New Labour refuses to give details as to just how much is an income which allows a decent life style. Of course, benefits have been improved, but not sufficiently to remove real poverty. Second, they ignore the social fund. Desperate families obtain official loans, but then have repayments automatically taken from their incomes.
fields.body:
Polly Toynbee and David Walker (Things got a little fairer, February 20) accept that "the poorest did best under Blair". Then why do residents of deprived areas continually meet neighbours who are without basic necessities? Toynbee and Walker overlook two matters. First, New Labour refuses to give details as to just how much is an income which allows a decent life style. Of course, benefits have been improved, but not sufficiently to remove real poverty. Second, they ignore the social fund. Desperate families obtain official loans, but then have repayments automatically taken from their incomes.

In February 2000 it was reported that 709,000 claimants had an average of £9.41 deducted. Their families are then well below what even the government regards as a mini mum. No wonder that many then turn to high-interest loan sharks. It is nonsense to suggest that the poorest did best under Labour. It is the fat cats, some of whom pretend to be socialists, on £70,000 and more, who did best.
Bob Holman
Glasgow
BOB@holman24.fsnet.co.uk

 Of course we all agree with increasing the resources to the poor, but this is not the main factor in increasing social cohesion. It's the gap that leads to the alienation of the less well-off from the aspirations of the wider society. It is the clearest factor underlying high crime figures, anti-social behaviour in streets and schools and increasing paranoia amongst the well-off. For a society at peace with itself people need to come closer together eco nomically, otherwise they will always be divided socially. That's why it doesn't feel better.

Hugh Williams
Birmingham

 My local Labour party has conducted a survey of members. The questions were: what one government achievement has made you most proud and why? What one thing would you reverse and why? What are you most pleasantly surprised that the government has done and why? What are you most disappointed that the government hasn't done? Which one new government department would you like to see created, why, and which Labour MP should run it? What would be your five main pledges at the next election?

N Flint
London

fields.headline: The word on Alastair
fields.trailText: Roy Hattersley is quite wrong to single out Alastair Campbell's use of the term "bog standard" as evidence that he is "virtually out of control" (Endpiece, February 19). Campbell, rather, is the victim of the extraordinary power of language to engage with popular imagination.
fields.body:
Roy Hattersley is quite wrong to single out Alastair Campbell's use of the term "bog standard" as evidence that he is "virtually out of control" (Endpiece, February 19). Campbell, rather, is the victim of the extraordinary power of language to engage with popular imagination.

The etymology of "bog standard" may be fairly dull (see Tom Boulding and David Bagnall's letter, February 16), but this is far removed from the way in which the term is popularly used. In conversation, "bog standard" is a fairly innocuous piece of slang: reproduced in print it loses the context and becomes associated with lavatories.

Words have long had the ability to lodge in the imagination and then to generate interpretations far removed from those intended. Work done by Glasgow University's media group two years after the Orkney satanic abuse affair, found people clearly "remembering" the involvement of armed troops on the island, these false recollections being attributable to the term "dawn raid". The media had used the words correctly, in that the local authority had moved to take the children involved into care early in the morning, but in the long-term popular memory the term "dawn raid" was laden with connotations involving SAS-style actions.

As an experienced journalist, Campbell, far from being out of control, is well aware of the power of language to seize the agenda. Which journalist coined the name "Frankenstein foods", thereby effectively destroying the possibility of reasoned popular debate?
Robin Croft
University of Glamorgan, Pontypridd, Wales

rcroft@glam.ac.uk

fields.headline: Spurs to press probity
fields.trailText: Whilst there may be issues around the freedom of the press in the Alan Sugar versus the Daily Mail case, there is another that cannot be ignored when reviewing the outcome of the case: that the Mail was wrong in fact (Punishing the press, February 19).
fields.body:
Whilst there may be issues around the freedom of the press in the Alan Sugar versus the Daily Mail case, there is another that cannot be ignored when reviewing the outcome of the case: that the Mail was wrong in fact (Punishing the press, February 19).

I have no particular feeling for Mr Sugar (as a long-suffering season ticket holder), but I estimate that George Graham has spent at least £26m. That does not include money spent by previous managers, probably the same amount again, and the £30m or so spent on improving the ground and training facilities.

It would be nice if all Spurs managers had vast amounts of money to spend, like Chelsea, but what would that mean for our already pricey season tickets? It is not as if the money Spurs have made is being lost in dividends, because shareholders have voted to forgo dividends. Before Mr Sugar the club was close to financial ruin; it now looks that, with the right stewardship, the future could be very bright. Mr Sugar can be accused of many thing - a poor judge of managers perhaps. But a miser? I do not think so. That is why the Daily Mail lost.
Anthony Gold
Barnet, Herts
anthony@wech.org.uk

 Of course the damages are a joke, but they are a different joke. Tabloids are rapidly losing the right to freedom of speech whilst they "give the public what they want". Why no analysis of the economics of footy transfers? No need to worry - slogans are what the punter's after.

Don't get me wrong; I wouldn't like to have made up the laws that protected Mr Maxwell either. But Jeff Powell, author of the article, doesn't seem to be a writer who lets the facts get in the way of a good story. London
paul.howards@virgin.net

MJ Lazarus
Hadley Wood, Herts

London

David Mills
London

fields.headline: Mortgage wars
fields.standfirst: Why the government may be smiling
fields.trailText: Tax cuts in the budget - who needs them? The mortgage war that has just broken out in the high street between banks and building societies will cut a typical interest-only £60,000 mortgage by nearly £40 a month. This will put extra cash into the pockets of borrowers who can either spend or save it. This will undoubtedly fuel the feelgood factor in advance of next month's budget.
fields.body:
Tax cuts in the budget - who needs them? The mortgage war that has just broken out in the high street between banks and building societies will cut a typical interest-only £60,000 mortgage by nearly £40 a month. This will put extra cash into the pockets of borrowers who can either spend or save it. This will undoubtedly fuel the feelgood factor in advance of next month's budget.

A reduction in mortgage interest rates is not a gain for everyone. Those without mortgages or savings are unaffected and those with savings will now receive even less generous interest payments from their banks and building societies. However, savers tend to be older and do not alter their spending habits in response to interest rate changes in the same way borrowers do - so the net effect of the mortgage wars is likely to be a boost to spending. This could pose problems if it continues because consumer outlays have to be kept under control to make room for the big rise in public spending the chancellor is planning for the next few years. But all that is to come. In the run-up to the election he will be delighted that the banks are having their own mini-budget in advance of his.

fields.headline: Silence of the damned
fields.standfirst: West ignores African and Afghan crises
fields.trailText: In West Africa and Afghanistan, major humanitarian crises are unfolding almost unnoticed by the west. Tens of thousands fled camps in Guinea last week where up to half a million people from Liberia and Sierra Leone have taken shelter during a decade of fighting. The UN believes 200,000 may be on the move or hiding in the Parrot's Beak region of south-west Guinea, uprooted again by clashes between rival armies, militias and guerrilla factions across the tri-state area. Some are heading north, deeper into Guinea. Others may take up a suspect offer by Sierra Leone's RUF rebels of safe passage to the south.
fields.body:
In West Africa and Afghanistan, major humanitarian crises are unfolding almost unnoticed by the west. Tens of thousands fled camps in Guinea last week where up to half a million people from Liberia and Sierra Leone have taken shelter during a decade of fighting. The UN believes 200,000 may be on the move or hiding in the Parrot's Beak region of south-west Guinea, uprooted again by clashes between rival armies, militias and guerrilla factions across the tri-state area. Some are heading north, deeper into Guinea. Others may take up a suspect offer by Sierra Leone's RUF rebels of safe passage to the south.

Ruud Lubbers, the UN's new refugee chief, sounded the alarm during a visit to the region last week. But with relief organisations pulling back from the Guinea border and lacking international help, he was reduced to appealing to the RUF's humanitarian conscience. Yet this, with one or two different leaders, is the same RUF that has ruthlessly terrorised Sierra Leone and still holds most of the country in its grip despite various interventions by the UN, Nigeria, and Britain. A settlement in Sierra Leone remains elusive; elections have been postponed; and the UN's $1.5m-a-day peacekeeping operation is at less than half strength now the Indians have quit. Rooted in Freetown, the UN force declines to support British-backed Sierra Leone army plans to advance into rebel-held areas.

Liberia meanwhile has its own intensifying problems of stability and survival as war returns after a sort of peace lasting four years. Charles Taylor's regime, which says it is under attack in the Lofa County area, went onto a full war footing last week. It is closely linked to the RUF and faces American and British-initiated sanctions over it arms-for-diamonds rackets. Guinea claims in turn that it is facing Liberian-backed rebels and threatens to invade its neighbour. A 1,700-strong peacekeeping force agreed by West African states last December has yet to deploy. In the making is another regional war akin to that devastating Congo and central Africa. Given its open-ended commitments in Sierra Leone, Britain ignores this crisis at its peril.

Switch focus to central Asia, where the the combatants and causes have different names but the victims look much the same. Afghanistan, dominated by fundamentalist Taliban zealots, devastated by 21 years of foreign intervention and internal strife, the subject of recently tightened UN sanctions and the playground of drug smugglers and terrorists, also faces a humanitarian disaster. War and drought have now combined with winter cold and hunger to threaten over 1m people, according to UN estimates.

In recent months, 170,000 "internally displaced people" have struggled east towards the Pakistan border and up to 100,000 more west towards Iran. Islamabad already has 1.2m Afghans on its territory; Iran an estimated 1.3m - and they do not want any more. New arrivals daily join those already stranded in makeshift border camps lacking fresh water, sanitation or regular food aid, "a sea of people living in unbelievable misery", according to Kenzo Oshima, a senior UN official. In the north, Tajikistan has closed its border to civilians fleeing fighting between the Taliban and forces loyal to the deposed government. The ostracising of the Taliban means outside help is doubly hard to get. Complaining that all its Afghanistan programmes have been cut back, the UN says that it has received only $14m of the more than $200m it requires this year. Since the seed for this year's crops has been eaten, the risk of a prolonged famine is increasing. Help is urgently needed.

The political roots of these two, separate conflicts and crises are tangled and exasperating; their colonial and cold war histories even more so. Unlike the Gujarat and Salvador earthquake zones, they are man-made disasters. But the plight of their ordinary, vulnerable casualties is identical. The west, whose policies have contributed to this misery just as much as these countries' warring factions, should hear their cries.

fields.headline: And still they lead
fields.standfirst: Don't keep us hanging on too long
fields.trailText: The latest Guardian/ICM poll shows that neither Labour's little local difficulties nor the Tories' recent policy extravaganza - an announcement a minute - have had any effect on the government's support. The Mandelson-Hinduja and now the Irvine dramas probably do affect people's medium-to-long-run perceptions of a party and political system, for the worse. But in the short run Labour is suffering no electoral pain. Indeed its lead has gone up. Perhaps voters are registering the unmistakable signs of an impending election and firming up their long-held belief that Tony Blair deserves a second term. Today he gets useful backing on specifics, too. ICM's results on secondary education suggest the public shares his wish to reconcile the comprehensive principle - which gets a 72% approval rating - with practical selection of pupils on the basis of aptitude, applauded by nearly 60%. While the 18% against comprehensives can vote Tory, the 31% against secondary selection have nowhere else to go.
fields.body:
The latest Guardian/ICM poll shows that neither Labour's little local difficulties nor the Tories' recent policy extravaganza - an announcement a minute - have had any effect on the government's support. The Mandelson-Hinduja and now the Irvine dramas probably do affect people's medium-to-long-run perceptions of a party and political system, for the worse. But in the short run Labour is suffering no electoral pain. Indeed its lead has gone up. Perhaps voters are registering the unmistakable signs of an impending election and firming up their long-held belief that Tony Blair deserves a second term. Today he gets useful backing on specifics, too. ICM's results on secondary education suggest the public shares his wish to reconcile the comprehensive principle - which gets a 72% approval rating - with practical selection of pupils on the basis of aptitude, applauded by nearly 60%. While the 18% against comprehensives can vote Tory, the 31% against secondary selection have nowhere else to go.

Of course the usual caveats apply to such polls. Surveys of voting intentions exclude don't knows yet the ranks of the undecided have been growing. Apathy would not, however, necessarily affect Labour's tally of Commons' seats. Prime ministers have bags of freedom (too much, we would say) to pick election dates but Mr Blair needs to decide sharpish: the public may well start to re sent being denied the decision they evidently have now made. They might seek to punish the man who is keeping them hanging on.

So is Labour's lead a manifestation of the "feel good" factor that famously did not guarantee Al Gore's victory in the United States last year? Recent headlines have certainly been positive, with interest rates, growth and mortgage wars to cheapen borrowing and stimulate house prices (see below). ICM's data suggest not so much that people want to reward the incumbents as that Labour's competence in managing a private enterprise economy has now achieved a sort of background, taken-for-granted quality.

Gordon Brown has managed to re-educate the public over Labour's identity. Two months prior to the 1997 election half the electorate predicted Labour would spend more than the Tories. Now only a quarter think Labour would spend more and they are outnumbered by those who think William Hague would spend more than Labour. Labour may be returned by an electorate that believes its spending and tax proclivities are pretty much the same as the Tories'. Through one end of the telescope, that testifies to Labour's loss of a distinct philosophy of government; through the other it says the Tories have lost their precious reputation for economic and fiscal competence and they may never get it back.

webTitle: Sad 15th anniversary for space station Mir

fields.headline: Sad 15th anniversary for space station Mir
fields.standfirst: Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: On the 15th anniversary of the Mir space station, once a symbol of Russia's space glory, a group of cosmonauts, scientists and hard-line politicians protested against the spacecraft's planned dumping next month.
fields.body:
On the 15th anniversary of the Mir space station, once a symbol of Russia's space glory, a group of cosmonauts, scientists and hard-line politicians protested against the spacecraft's planned dumping next month.

About 100 protesters stood outside the headquarters of the Russian Space Agency, chanting slogans and stamping their feet to stay warm in the freezing temperatures. Nobody from the agency came out of the building.

Cosmonaut Sergei Zalyotin, a member of the space platform's last crew, sighed: "I'll miss Mir, it was part of my life." He and Alexander Kalery, who completed Mir's final manned mission last year, had believed there would be another crew after them.

"When we pulled out, we even left some bread and salt to welcome our successors. It's an old Russian tradition," he said.

"This in an unhappy birthday celebration," an official with the Space Control Centre (TsOUP) at Korolyev near Moscow, one of many who are having difficulty closing this chapter of Russia's 40-year history of space exploration

Protesters slammed the Russian government's decision late last year to bring down the Mir in a controlled descent, which has been tentatively scheduled for mid-March.

The decision brought praise from Moscow's partners in the International Space Station, which want the government to devote its scarce resources for space research to the new station. Many were also relieved that the increasingly accident-prone Mir would end its orbit.

Some in the country's space community objected, saying the Mir has not outlived its usefulness, and nationalists were angered by what they saw as the unwarranted casting off of a symbol of national pride.

"There's no point in dumping Mir before the International Space Station is open for scientific work," said Vladimir Bryukhanov, an engineer at the Moscow Institute for Space Instrument Design.

The 140-ton station was the jewel of the Soviet space program when it was launched on February 20, 1986, and it has far surpassed the three to five years it was expected to last.

But as it aged, it suffered a long string of accidents, including a fire in February 1997 and a near fatal collision with an unmanned cargo ship just four months later. According to current plans, the Mir will be directed to a stretch of the South Pacific about equidistant between Australia and Chile in mid-March. The exact date will depend on solar activity.

webTitle: Irvine to launch counter-attack in Lords

fields.headline: Irvine to launch counter-attack in Lords
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Lord Irvine, the lord chancellor, will today reject claims he is destroying the judiciary's independence when he tells peers he is doing more than any of his predecessors to open up judicial appointments to independent scrutiny.
fields.byline: Patrick Wintour, Michael White  and Clare Dyer
fields.body:
Lord Irvine, the lord chancellor, will today reject claims he is destroying the judiciary's independence when he tells peers he is doing more than any of his predecessors to open up judicial appointments to independent scrutiny.

In a long delayed counter-attack he will point out that the Lord Chancellor's Department is interviewing for a judicial appointments commissioner, responsible for handling complaints.

Last night friends of the embattled lord chancellor said he had been pressured by Labour's Millbank headquarters to drum up donations from Labour supporting lawyers. It was reported that Millbank had put pressure on Lord Irvine to change the ticketing system for the controversial dinner and replace the cover charge with what amounted to a begging letter.

Officials inside his department are angry that Lord Irvine is being accused of a "cash for wigs" scandal in the same month they say he is moving to lift the shroud of secrecy surrounding judicial appointments.

His officials argued yesterday that the commissioner would be entitled to attend all interviews and handle complaints, not just from a disappointed applicant, but also their representatives.

The appointment body is Lord Irvine's initiative and directly follows recommendations from Sir Leanard Peach, the former commissioner for public appointments.

Conservatives yesterday renewed calls for Lord Irvine to resign after his admission that he sent a letter to leftwing lawyers urging them to give £200 at a Labour fundraising dinner this month.

Lord Irvine will reply today to an oral question tabled by Lord McNally, the Liberal Democrat peer. Lord McNally is not seeking a resignation, but challenging the lord chancellor's judgment.

Sitting silently on the woolsack yesterday, Lord Irvine refused to respond when the shadow leader of the Lords, Lord Strathclyde, demanded an emergency statement. The leader of the Lords, Lady Jay, had contemptuously rejected the demand for a statement, accusing the Tories of "a high level of opportunism" and taking their views from the newspaper delivery boy.

The shadow lord chancellor, Lord Kingsland, yesterday wrote to Lord Irvine, calling on him to restore the "probity" of his office by releasing lists of lawyers attending and declining to attend the fundraising lunch, along with the money they had given.

Speaking on BBC radio earlier, Lord Kingsland defended Lord Irvine's record in appointing judges and QCs, say ing he had always acted with "absolute probity". But he later said he did believe that Lord Irvine should resign. Tories insist Lord Irvine's refusal to come clean voluntarily on Sunday had made them demand his head.

The lord chancellor stood down yesterday from a House of Lords case on which he had been due to sit next month as one of five judges. His spokesman said he had to attend a special cabinet committee to discuss the Budget on the day it was set to start, March 7.

The case is seen as an important test case to decide whether the owners of children's homes and schools are liable to pay compensation to children abused by an employee.

His officials argued yesterday that the commissioner would be entitled to attend all interviews and handle complaints, not just from a disappointed applicant, but also their representatives. The appointment body is Lord Irvine's initiative and directly follows recommendations from Sir Leanard Peach, the former commissioner for public appointments. Conservatives yesterday renewed calls for Lord Irvine to resign after his admission that he sent a letter to leftwing lawyers urging them to give £200 at a Labour fundraising dinner this month. Lord Irvine will reply today to an oral question tabled by Lord McNally, the Liberal Democrat peer. Lord McNally is not seeking a resignation, but challenging the lord chancellor's judgment. Sitting silently on the woolsack yesterday, Lord Irvine refused to respond when the shadow leader of the Lords, Lord Strathclyde, demanded an emergency statement. The leader of the Lords, Lady Jay, had contemptuously rejected the demand for a statement, accusing the Tories of "a high level of opportunism" and taking their views from the newspaper delivery boy. The shadow lord chancellor, Lord Kingsland, yesterday wrote to Lord Irvine, calling on him to restore the "probity" of his office by releasing lists of lawyers attending and declining to attend the fundraising lunch, along with the money they had given. Speaking on BBC radio earlier, Lord Kingsland defended Lord Irvine's record in appointing judges and QCs, say ing he had always acted with "absolute probity". But he later said he did believe that Lord Irvine should resign. Tories insist Lord Irvine's refusal to come clean voluntarily on Sunday had made them demand his head. The lord chancellor stood down yesterday from a House of Lords case on which he had been due to sit next month as one of five judges. His spokesman said he had to attend a special cabinet committee to discuss the Budget on the day it was set to start, March 7. The case is seen as an important test case to decide whether the owners of children's homes and schools are liable to pay compensation to children abused by an employee.

fields.headline: Talks open on freeing hostage
fields.trailText: Formal negotiations are to begin today to secure the release of the British hostage, Tim Selby, who was kidnapped by tribal guerrillas in the remote jungles of south-east Bangladesh five days ago.
fields.body:
Formal negotiations are to begin today to secure the release of the British hostage, Tim Selby, who was kidnapped by tribal guerrillas in the remote jungles of south-east Bangladesh five days ago.

The guerrillas who abducted the 28-year-old engineer and two Danish colleagues while they were driving in the isolated Chittagong hill tracks region - have appointed a team of three representatives to meet government officials at a secret location. The guerrillas have demanded £1.2m in ransom.

Intermediaries have established contact with the hostages and sent them biscuits, toothpaste, mosquito nets, mineral water and fresh clothes. They in turn sent back letters to their families assuring them they were "fine". They have also been given faxes from relatives and friends.

The army believes the hostages are still being held close to where they were abducted at Guniapara, near the hill station of Rangamati, 380km (240 miles) from the Bangladeshi capital, Dhaka.

A 30km area of thick, sprawling forests and luxurious teak trees has been encircled by government troops.

Sources last night said Mr Selby, who was on a road-surveying trip for the Danish company Campsax, was in good spirits. He had been surviving on bananas, pineapples, coconuts and rice. The hostages had requested mineral water after having "difficulties" with local jungle water.

The rebels are believed to be members of a dissident faction opposed to a 1997 peace accord between tribal leaders in the Chittagong region and the government.

The guerrillas have, however, have made no political demands. "I don't think the group is political, I think it is criminal," one source said.

Last night Jon Geddes, spokesman for the British High Commission in Bangladesh, told how Mr Selby's four-wheel drive vehicle was stopped by six tribal villagers armed with "almost flintlock-like revolvers". They had barricaded the road with bamboo poles. More rebels watched from the hill.

Mr Selby, with a British colleague David Weston who was later released with the ransom demand, was marched 500 yards into the jungle at gunpoint. "They were told to put their hands in the air. It was quite clear they were being taken hostage, Mr Geddes said. "Their captors seemed fairly naive."

The previous week Mr Selby and his colleagues had a police escort with them when they visited the same area. But for some reason they failed to take an escort on the second trip when they were kidnapped.

webTitle: Girl, 15, dies in school skiing trip accident

fields.headline: Girl, 15, dies in school skiing trip accident
fields.trailText: A 15-year-old British girl has been declared "clinically dead" after a sledging accident in Austria in which she was not wearing a helmet.
fields.body:
A 15-year-old British girl has been declared "clinically dead" after a sledging accident in Austria in which she was not wearing a helmet.

Nasreen Jamalzadeh, of Raynes Park, south-west London, was injured when her sledge crashed during a school skiing trip.

Her father has demanded to know why the teenager had not been wearing a helmet.

Police said Nasreen's head was smashed against a rock after she and a friend lost control as they hurtled down a 160-metre slope at Fusch, near Salzburg. The teenagers hit a tree and their sledge flipped over.

A police spokesman said: "It is not usual for helmets to be worn for sledging here."

The girls were sledging with their 80-strong group from Ursuline High School in Wimbledon, said police in Bruck.

Nasreen's friend, named by police as 15-year-old Cathy Storey, from Wimbledon, was sitting behind her on the sledge and broke a bone in her hand in the accident.

The spokesman said Nasreen had been pronounced clinically dead and was not expected to survive.

Her father, Razeem Jamalzadeh, said his wife Brenda had travelled to Austria with their daughter Layla, 19, and 17-year-old son Yusuf. He was at home with two younger daughters.

Club Europe, which organised the trip, said a review of the accident would take place to see if any lessons could be learnt.

Spokesman Keith Fearby said the 80 pupils were accompanied by nine or 10 teachers on their week-long trip to the resort.

Press Association

webTitle: The danger of discrimination when religious groups provide public services

fields.headline: A test of faith
fields.standfirst: Politicians want to harness the spiritual energy of religion-based organisations to help provide public services. But can they guarantee it will not lead to discrimination? Alex Klaushofer reports
fields.trailText: Politicians want to harness the spiritual energy of religion-based organisations to help provide public services. But can they guarantee it will not lead to discrimination? Alex Klaushofer reports
fields.body:
Some 40 rough sleepers are in for the night at the centre under Trafalgar Square, dozing, watching TV and bickering. There's the quietly spoken gardener who became homeless after losing the job he'd held for 40 years, and the young man whose staring eyes and loud indignation betray obvious mental health problems. He's spent most of the last year living in a tent on a bypass. "I hardly spoke to a soul for nine months," he yells.

With state-funded outreach workers referring London's street homeless to the centre as a first step to services and a long-term solution, the project carries all the hallmarks of the government's social exclusion programme. What is less obvious is that it is part of a growing trend to involve faith communities in the provision of public services. Opened last September, as an extension to the social work done by the Anglican church of St Martin-in-the-Fields, the night centre gets all its funding - £400,000 a year - from the government's rough sleepers' unit.

This month's announcements on both sides of the Atlantic are proof positive, if more were needed, that faith groups have made it on to the political agenda. While one of US president George Bush's first moves has been to entrust social services to the churches, British opposition leader William Hague has continued to court the black Christian vote with the promise of an office of civil society to "empower" faith groups and the voluntary sector. And religious leaders are using their new power. An evangelical Christian charity, Oasis Trust, has launched a campaign to persuade the next government to give faith groups a better hearing. Having surveyed 2,000 Christian leaders, the trust claims one in five is discriminated against when seeking government support. It is going out with road shows to faith groups around the country, giving advice on political and media lobbying.

Yet the government is already engaged with faith groups. The rough sleepers' strategy relies heavily on church-based organisations - from those with long traditions of street philanthropy, such as the Salvation Army, to more innovative schemes. While this might stem from a pragmatic decision to join forces with those already doing the work, with the faith element largely irrelevant, in education the recognition of religious life has developed as a natural feature of a multi-cultural society. Having brought the first Muslim and Sikh schools into the state system, the government is now encouraging schools of all denominations to follow.

But the most concentrated attempt to harness faith groups has been simmering in the social exclusion unit for some time. The conclusions of the unit's policy action teams, recognising the role played by such groups in social and economic life, have now made it into government policy: the action plan on neighbourhood renewal identifies them as a key element to the success of regeneration partnerships.

The unit is now running a series of events to inform religious leaders of their role in the action plan. And the Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions (DETR) plans to launch pilots with faith groups as partners in the New Deal for communities programme early in the summer.

Much of the thinking behind this activity comes from a recognition that government has to work harder to engage with Britain's black and ethnic minorities. Since religion is integral to their identity and daily lives, challenging received ideas about the secular nature of public life may be the price of being truly inclusive.

Saif Ahmed, chief executive of the North London Muslim Housing Association, and a former member of the policy action team on unpopular housing, points out: "If you exclude the Muslim faith community, you are excluding the Muslim majority from any government agenda."

The Muslim-led Salfai Association Community Centre, in Dewsbury, West Yorkshire, already provides IT training courses and acess to computers and the internet, in conjunction with Dewsbury college, primarily for local Muslims. It is about to become involved in the government's online initiative, in partnership with Kirklees council. Run from a converted textile mill, the £650,000 centre was opened last April, with funds raised by the Muslim community matched by the single regeneration budget. Its facilities include day care for elderly people, a creche, youth club, homework club and a number of classes. It also houses a mosque.

Centre manager David Hay says it is designed to serve the whole community but must work hard to ensure that non-Muslims take advantage of what it has to offer. "Already there is a 50:50 mix in the youth club and homework club and some of our new courses, such as beauty therapy and food hygiene," he points out.

Meanwhile, Ahmed's association is running faith-based regeneration pilots, including a multi-faith project, in north and east London. The religious belief of those involved makes all the difference, he says. "There is a passion to see changes take place because it is part of their faith. They believe if they do something for humanity, it makes God happy."

The association will shortly publish research on the housing needs of young Muslims in Hackney, east London. It confirms the centrality of the mosque to the tenants' lives, but also finds that the mosque authorities do not meet the needs of Muslim women. While Ahmed insists that projects will push for a more inclusive approach, the exclusion of certain groups on religious grounds is precisely what worries those opposed to the greater involvement of faith groups in public service.

Examples documented by the Lesbian and Gay Christian Movement include St George's Crypt Centre, a church-run homeless charity in Leeds. A gay job applicant ran up against an equal opportunities policy declaring active homosexuals - together with adulterers and those involved in occult practices - to be contrary to its "Christian ethos".

In the face of such practice, critics see the shift towards more public funding of faith groups as the key problem. "The big Rubicon is taxpayers' money," says Keith Porteous Wood, general secretary of the National Secular Society. "Once you've accepted that, you're entitled to demand that there will be no discrimination in the service that's provided and in the employment of the staff."

But religious groups will get no special treatment, according to one of the main players in the new faith-friendly politics. For David Raynor, secretary to the Inner Cities Religious Council, the only faith-based forum in government and a semi-independent body linked to the DETR, faith groups are "an integral part of civil society, viewed as equals with others". He adds: "What I find difficult is the discourse which says that faith communities bring values and morals, as though other bodies did not."

Yet religious leaders argue that the spiritual energy that politicians want to capture inevitably sets them apart from other organisations. Pecan is a Christian training charity whose work on the Peckham estates in south London won it first place in the neighbourhood renewal action plan's list of good practice. The charity's approach to unemployment aims, through systematic door-knocking, to find the people missed by other schemes and link them into training opportunities. Through its community induction project, all new tenants on the rebuilt North Peckham estates have been receiving visits to help them settle in the refigured community. Although, from the outside, this kind of work may be seen as simply good provision, managing director Simon Pellew insists it arises out of the charity's Christianity and "comes out of our theology".

This faith element will inevitably make for tensions as government and faith groups work more closely together, Pellew believes. Pecan's annual budget of £1.5m includes 80% state funding and, Pellew points out, "any money has strings attached. Government has to understand that, as a faith-driven organisation, we may do things they don't like. For example, Pecan only employs Christians."

The crunch comes where the need of faith groups to keep their identity runs up against the requirement for public services to be neutral - and professional. "It's not sufficient to be enthusiastic - you've got to be professional as well," says Graham Dale, director of the Christian Socialist Movement.

"You don't have to be Christian to come in through the door," says Chris Edwards, director of St Martin's night centre. "We offer non-judgmental acceptance of anyone. The values of the church inform very strongly what we do here."

Tapping into traditions

Some local authorities have been quietly furthering the faith agenda for years. Kensington and Chelsea, in west London, is home to more than 100 minorities from all religious traditions and has produced the first local authority handbook on working with faith communities, Ethnic and Faith Community Development.

An £8m Muslim cultural heritage centre, due to open in May, pays Kensington a peppercorn rent and boasts the only 999-year lease in the borough.

Camden council, in north London, is meanwhile poised to appoint its first faith officer, having commissioned an independent consultancy as part of a project to make more contact with faith groups.

The Local Government Association hopes that councils less familiar with the terrain will benefit from a good practice guide it intends to publish later this year, based on a survey it has just completed.

The move, says Rumman Ahmed, Kensington's community relations officer, is highly significant. He says: "Faith has not been an issue for local government, like race has been."

webTitle: YWCA new agenda plays hard ball

fields.headline: Radical route
fields.standfirst: YWCA new agenda plays hard ball
fields.trailText: YWCA new agenda plays hard ball
fields.body:
The Young Women's Christian Association (YWCA) is to break from its traditional image of piety with a new campaign led by a founding member of the radical group Southall Black Sisters.

Mandana Hendessi, one of several women who formed the black feminist organisation following the 1979 clashes between anti-racist youth and fascists in Southall, has been appointed director of policy and campaigns at YWCA. In its bid to be reckoned as a force for change, YWCA has launched a young women's manifesto which aims to push discrimination and inequality up the political agenda.

The charity was set up for Florence Nightingale's nurses waiting to sail to the Crimea, in 1855. In the first half of the 20th century most if its work was with refugees, and supporting young women leaving their families to find work.

Today, the organisation focuses on lone mothers and homeless young women. Based on consultations with girls and young women who use the organisation's 21 youth and community projects, the manifesto will be officially launched at the first sitting of the UK Youth Parliament (UKYP) this weekend.

Key recommendations include more action from schools to tackle poor body image in young women, sex education to be taught from an earlier age, and an increase in pregnancy and sexual health services.

Proposals contained in It's a Girl Thing are intended to inform and influence the UKYP's youth manifesto. In addition, a more detailed version will be presented to the main political parties in the run-up to the general election.

Hendessi first came into contact with the YWCA in 1992 when she wrote a book about young women made homeless through sexual abuse. The organisation worked with her in trying to implement the book's recommendations.

"It was then that I realised they were going through a big change," Hendessi says. "It was gradual, but by 1999 it started gaining momentum. In the past, the organisation has always stood for social justice and equality for women, but it used to go through traditional channels, such as the Women's National Commission, the Church and bodies associated with it. It may have had access to ministers to make its concerns known but, it was never a public voice."

Hendessi says she was encouraged to get involved because of the charity's "amazing willingness to change and move forward. There was also tremendous recognition that the voice of black women had to be strengthened within the organisation."

webTitle: Joint review heaps praise on Kensington and Chelsea

fields.headline: Capital concerns
fields.standfirst: Joint review of social services heaps praise on Kensington and Chelsea
fields.trailText: Joint review of social services heaps praise on Kensington and Chelsea
fields.body:
Social services in London are at a low ebb, with even Newham - the east London borough named council of the year in 2000 - now on the Department of Health's "special measures" list. Of 15 authorities on the list, seven are in the capital.

It is, therefore, striking that Kensington and Chelsea has this week received what is being seen as the best report so far in the rolling process of joint reviews of social services by the audit commission and social services inspectorate.

The Conservative-run west London council is judged to deliver "high quality social services focused clearly on user outcomes" and to be "in the vanguard of good practice in many service areas". Its joint review report concludes: "The authority can boast of superior skills andproficiency in meeting the needs of its population."

The report will be particularly welcome to the Association of Directors of Social Services, as its current president, Moira Gibb, is Kensington and Chelsea's social services director.

webTitle: Cancer screening advice for people with learning disabilities

fields.headline: Pictures of health
fields.standfirst: Cancer screening advice for people with learning disabilities
fields.trailText: Cancer screening advice for people with learning disabilities
fields.body:
Women with learning disabilities are being given the chance to decide whether they want cancer screening, with the launch of literature specifically designed to explain the process to them.

All women over 20 are invited for a smear test and all those aged 50-64 are invited for breast screening. However, only 8% of women with learning disabilities take up the invitations, compared to 80% of other women. Often their relatives and carers are embarrassed to broach the subject.

Julietta Patnick, national coordinator of NHS screening pro grammes, says: "Screening can't guarantee that you won't get cancer, but it can reduce your risk of dying from it if you do."

To help women with learning disabilities understand the issue, and therefore enable them to give informed consent to smear tests and mammograms, NHS cancer screening programmes has developed simple leaflets and guidebooks using clear illustrations for women and their carers.

The approach was developed by a group chaired by Sheila Hollins, professor and specialist in learning disabilities at St George's hospital medical school in London. Two women with learning difficulties, Wendy Perez and Jackie Downer, worked with Hollins to produce the materials. "This is about having the same rights as other women and having control over the situation and your own health," says Downer.

Perez presented the leaflet and picture book about cervical cancer to a women's group she belongs to. She received positive feedback.

None of the women, in their late 20s and early 30s, knew about cervical screening.

Leaflets are available at www.cancerscreening.nhs.uk

webTitle: Professionals who volunteer their services and skills for nothing

fields.headline: Free style
fields.standfirst: It's true, money isn't everything.  Andy Farquarson  looks at the professionals who volunteer their top services and skills for nothing
fields.trailText: It's true, money isn't everything. Andy Farquarson looks at the professionals who volunteer their top services and skills for nothing.
fields.body:
Every evening Mohammed Mawji switches off his computer at the London advertising agency where he works, heads for home, then boots up his own PC and continues work as a communications and e-media specialist. The task is as demanding as his day job. The difference is that, in the evening, Mawji's efforts are unpaid.

Together with two colleagues, Mawji runs eVolunteer, a free online resource for voluntary organisations. Their website provides a database of volunteering opportunities, a contact system, and links to over 100 participating voluntary sector organisations.

"My paid job is to develop and communicate concepts and sell ideas," says Mawji, a 26-year-old business development manager. "The work for eVolunteer is similar - promoting the concept and the benefits it brings, creating awareness and recruiting organisations to the site. My colleagues contribute complementary skills - one is an expert in educational technology and the other is an internet developer."

What motivates him? "All three of us get enormous personal satisfaction from applying our professional abilities and business acumen to giving something back to society as a whole," Mawji says. "We are also members of a worldwide religious community, the Ismaili, which has a strong tradition of voluntary service. The internet is a global medium and we are working with volunteers as far apart as the former Soviet Union and the American midwest, so eVolunteer is fully behind the UN's vision of a global volunteer network."

Peter Storrie is a planning consultant whose client list includes blue chip companies such as Rover Group and Arlington Securities. A typical recent commission was finding a brownfield site for BMW's new £400m engine factory: contrast that to the hours of unpaid time he devotes to helping ordinary people fight planning decisions.

"I volunteer through the Royal Town Planning Institute's (RTPI) planning aid scheme," says Storrie. "It links qualified planners to groups who need expert assistance, but can't afford professional rates. I help people to help themselves by acting as an informed bridge between them and their local authority. For example, when the council wanted to build an indoor bowling complex in one of the town parks in Leamington Spa, I helped the local amenity society and residents' group fight the application - the case went to appeal and we won.

"I am passionate about historical buildings as well, so I also donate time to English Heritage as a member of one of its advisory committees. All told, I would guess I give about 10% of my time to voluntary work."

Why does Storrie volunteer? "Maybe I'm just a soft touch," he laughs. "I want to help people get better decisions, a better environment, get things right. There is great satisfaction from feeling you've done something people really appreciate, and working on grassroots issues keeps me on my toes. It also reminds me that planning is all about people and how they live."

Mawji and Storrie give the lie to the stereotypical image of volunteers as tweedy, meals-on-wheels ladies, or old soldiers running boys' clubs. They are busy professionals whose main contribution is expertise and knowledge. Although their voluntary work brings great personal satisfaction, there can be more tangible rewards, too. As Storrie explains: "Volunteering can help one understand one's own profession better. You see things from a different angle and get the users' perspective: people ask difficult questions, and challenge orthodoxies, and that refocuses one's mind professionally."

Developing new skills is obviously advantageous to any professional. Voluntary work is also a plus point on a CV and multi-disciplinary experience is attractive to potential employers. Volunteering can also open doors to new career opportunities through peer-to-peer networking and may even contribute to meeting a regulatory body's professional development requirements.

Despite these advantages, the proportion of professionals volunteering their skills in formal schemes remains small. For instance, only 4% of RTPI members participate in planning aid (even so, this amounts to 550 planners from the public, private and voluntary sectors). Their level of input also varies widely: some volunteers donate an evening or two at irregular intervals, while others put in many hours a week - such as the volunteer who spent more than 200 unpaid hours on a single case.

However, professionals may face a conflict of interest. A solicitor employed by a county council would be ill-advised to support a group taking legal action against that authority. Most voluntary programmes run by professional bodies set out guidance for members and some also offer legal protection to both the volunteer and the client.

Most professions run voluntary programmes: examples include the Bar Council's pro bono unit; the chartered surveyors' volunteer scheme; the Media Trust; the solicitors' pro bono group (which has set itself a target of 1,000 new volunteers in 2001); and Prohelp, Business in the Community's multi-profession volunteer network. These all offer services to community organisations, charities and other not-for-profit groups, and some to individuals.

In addition to such schemes, many charities actively focus volunteer recruitment on higher socio-economic groups in the belief that professionals bring specific benefits to their cause. But should they distinguish between specialist volunteers and those who staff a soup kitchen or rattle a tin outside the local supermarket?

"I don't think it is a helpful distinction," says Justin Davis Smith, director of the Institute for Volunteer Research. "I would argue that all volunteers have a worthwhile and meaningful contribution to make. When the institute calculates the economic value of volunteering, we use the average weekly wage rather than, for example, saying a solicitor is notionally contributing several hundred pounds an hour compared to £10 for an unskilled worker."

On that level-playing-field measure, Davis Smith puts the total economic value of volunteer activity at £45bn annually. "That makes it one of the top five contributors to GDP," he says.

But, as Mohammed Mawji points out, it is not about money. "I'd say to any professional out there: forget the greasy pole, the big cheque, the lure of becoming a dot.com millionaire. Devote some of your training, skills, and knowledge to communities who really need them. Make a difference to people's lives."

Armies of volunteers join forces

Businessmen and women who regularly volunteer and raise money for charities have joined forces this week with the launch of Volunteers in Action. The aim of the initiative is to highlight the work of Rotary International, the National Association of Round Tables, Lions Clubs International, the Association of Inner Wheel Clubs, Ladies Circle and Soropitimists International, who between them boast a network of 250,000 volunteers throughout the UK.

Each organisations' individual charitable programme will be publicised under the Volunteers in Action banner. Lions Clubs, the world's largest volunteer organisation, with more than 1.4m members in 185 countries, has 944 clubs and 20,000 members in the British Isles. In the last 18 months, members have provided an estimated 800,000 volunteer hours for its millennium programme to prevent eye blindness. In collaboration with the British Diabetic Association and the International Glaucoma Association, members attend training events and go into the community giving presentations, complete with videos and leaflets, to people at risk of contracting glaucoma.

In contrast, the 13,000 businesswomen who belong to 400 Soropitimists International clubs in the UK focus their fundraising efforts on Limbs for Life, a charity providing artificial limbs for victims of landmines, but members also volunteer as mentors in local schools and youth clubs.

"By raising awareness of the work of these volunteers, who give their time freely, it is hoped that others may wish to join or support them," says a spokesperson for Volunteers in Action. "The need today is greater than ever."

Alison Benjamin

webTitle: New AIDS campaign targeted at black African community

fields.headline: Facts of life
fields.standfirst: Misconceptions surrounding HIV are putting black Africans at risk.  Nicola Hill  on a campaign set to challenge prejudice
fields.trailText: Misconceptions surrounding HIV are putting black Africans at risk. Nicola Hill on a campaign set to challenge prejudice
fields.body:
Black Africans living in Britain are the target of a new campaign launched today by a leading HIV/Aids charity. Terrence Higgins Trust Lighthouse is seeking to curb the rapid increase in HIV infection in the African community, which has emerged as the most pressing concern among those working to combat the disease.

The charity is holding a conference in London to address issues of prevention and is due to start a three-month poster campaign. The key aim is to tackle the stigma surrounding HIV, which hinders black Africans from seeking advice on prevention or coming forward for testing.

The number of new reports of HIV infection is now higher among heterosexuals than gays or bisexuals. In 1996, heterosexual sex accounted for 29% of new reported infections; by 1999, it accounted for 49% of new reports. The increase is attributed largely to a growing number of reported cases among black Africans.

The majority of HIV transmissions during pregnancy also occur among black African women. And most black Africans seek treatment only once they have symptoms of the disease.

Pat Nair, consultant in communicable disease control with Bedfordshire health authority, will report to today's conference on a 200% increase in reports of HIV in Luton. Just over half of those affected were born in Zimbabwe and 86% had arrived in Britain since 1998.

A representative from the Public Health Laboratory Service will highlight a study in Camden and Islington, north London, which found that 70% of 748 black African respondents did not use condoms with new sexual partners.

Liza Kawonza, a Zimbabwean health promotion manager in Terrence Higgins Trust Lighthouse's African team, says: "Within our community, because of religious and cultural beliefs, once you are known to be HIV positive you are no longer considered a human being."

Themba (not his real name), a 40-year-old black African who is HIV positive, confirms this. "I have lost most of my friends and my life has become much more narrow," he says. "People still think they can be infected by coughing or sharing cutlery." He adds: "There is a sense of shame around sex, and a belief that if you catch a disease it is from your own evil doings and you don't deserve support."

Kawonza maintains that HIV is often associated by black Africans with promiscuity and homosexuality. "This prejudice is based on ignorance which, through the campaign, we are hoping to show has parallels with racism," she says.

The poster campaign will use familiar images of segregation in Africa to challenge black people's own prejudice towards HIV. Kawonza says the campaign is not concerned with talking about safe sex, or apportioning blame, but is about changing attitudes to make it more acceptable for people to talk about HIV and come forward for tests. If people could seek help earlier, she argues, they would be better able to take control of their treatment and live longer.

The charity hopes its message will spread across Europe and Africa. It has been shown to African people at various stages of its development and the response is said to have been "overwhelming". Posters will be displayed in community centres, hairdressers, churches, bars and taxi offices.

Themba, however, is sceptical about the campaign. He says: "The stigma will not go away for a long time. The posters are about encouraging people not to be afraid to talk about HIV. People are not ready to do that. The few people who have come out as HIV positive have become superstars, and this deters other people from disclosing their status."

He argues that the campaign should be about encouraging people to take diagnostic tests and assuring them of confidentiality. He is, however, more hopeful of a research forum which is also being launched at the conference.

Ade Fakoya, a consultant specialising in HIV, will introduce the African research forum to delegates. Based at Newham General hospital, east London, he wants to draw together specialists and involve the black African community in planning research.

Fayoka, who runs a family clinic and offers pre-natal testing, says the issues among the black African community are different from those in the gay community, and one of the key problems is transmission of HIV from mother to child.

Kawonza says: "Black African schoolchildren who contracted the disease at birth are now facing the stigma of HIV and being teased in the playground. They are terrified of talking to their friends."

Themba agrees that answers need to come from within the black African community. "We need an African solution to this problem," he says. "By drawing together the most knowledgeable black African specialists, we can formulate a plan to approach our own people. We need to get the message across that the spread of HIV is a reality and we need to concentrate our efforts on prevention."

Special report on HIV and Aids at www.SocietyGuardian.co.uk/hivaids/

webTitle: "Corporate environmental engagment" list aims to make companies greener

fields.headline: Naming game
fields.standfirst: "Corporate environmental engagment" list aims to make companies greener
fields.trailText: "Corporate environmental engagment" list aims to make companies greener
fields.body:
It sounds like a roll call of companies that make green groups go pale - Shell, British Energy, British American Tobacco, Rio Tinto.

While they all might come in the top 20 names of companies which have clashed with environmentalists, today they are the good guys.

On the name and shame list are the Iceland Group, the recent hero of the anti-GM crops and organic farming movement, as well as other companies that environmentalists will feel more comfortable abusing, including McDonald's Restaurants, the Daily Mail, Coca-Cola and British Nuclear Fuels.

Perceptions of companies, at least from the pressure groups' standpoint, are turned on their heads by the Business in the Environment organisation (BiE), which praises companies for their environmental performance. The best performers will be viewed more favourably by investors - and they all get a pat on the back from the patron, Prince Charles.

BiE is today publishing its fifth list of "corporate environmental engagement" and marks 184 companies on their efforts to minimise their impact on the world in terms of pollution and depletion of natural resources, and involving their shareholders, customers and their employees in the process. On the name and shame list are those companies that decline to take part in the survey.

The rest have been praised for their attempts to minimise the adverse effect they have on the world from which they make money.

The aim of the index is "to inspire companies towards reducing the impact they have on the environment whilst gaining competitive advantage through effective management processes."

The goal is "sustainable development," that pipe dream and business cliche which is unattainable for most industry, particularly the mining, oil and gas companies which seem most keen to take part in BiE listings.

This is cheerfully acknowledged by Dr Belinda Howell, director of BiE, who is as doubtful as anyone that a lot of industry can ever be sustainable. "The most important thing we have achieved is to get companies to think about the environment and their performance, to minimise the impacts they make, and think about the wider implications of what they do. There is great room for improvement, and some are getting better. The fact that companies in the same sector compete with each other to have a better performance and come top of their group can only be good," she says.

The number of companies taking part in the survey has grown each year to the point where the list represents 78% of the top 350 companies listed on the stock exchange, plus a number of unlisted publicly or privately owned enterprises.

Those that refuse to take part are named and shamed for the first time this year. fields.bodyText: It sounds like a roll call of companies that make green groups go pale - Shell, British Energy, British American Tobacco, Rio Tinto. While they all might come in the top 20 names of companies which have clashed with environmentalists, today they are the good guys. On the name and shame list are the Iceland Group, the recent hero of the anti-GM crops and organic farming movement, as well as other companies that environmentalists will feel more comfortable abusing, including McDonald's Restaurants, the Daily Mail, Coca-Cola and British Nuclear Fuels. Perceptions of companies, at least from the pressure groups' standpoint, are turned on their heads by the Business in the Environment organisation (BiE), which praises companies for their environmental performance. The best performers will be viewed more favourably by investors - and they all get a pat on the back from the patron, Prince Charles. BiE is today publishing its fifth list of "corporate environmental engagement" and marks 184 companies on their efforts to minimise their impact on the world in terms of pollution and depletion of natural resources, and involving their shareholders, customers and their employees in the process. On the name and shame list are those companies that decline to take part in the survey. The rest have been praised for their attempts to minimise the adverse effect they have on the world from which they make money. fields.headline: Front...to back
fields.trailText: clippings
fields.body:
The road to ruin
A Bing Crosby fan has objected to plans to demolish a bakery in Nairn, in the Scottish Highlands, because it is next to the extension he built to house his vast collection of memorabilia and records of the crooner and film star.
Highland News, 27.1.01
(Marc Hindley, Nairn)

Gunned down
Villagers in Corston, Wiltshire, have managed to slow down speeding cars by putting a shop window dummy by the roadside in police uniform and holding a fake radar gun.
Worcestershire Evening Mail, 3.2.01
(Simon Harley, Redditch)

Cutting edge
A barber in Chippenham, Wiltshire, has installed Sony PlayStations for customers to use while waiting for a haircut.
Western Daily Press, 19.1.01
(Francis Harvey, Exeter)

Wet excuse
A swimming pool in Luton, Bedfordshire, was closed to the public because a burst water tank caused flooding.
Luton News, 31.1.01
(Jim Fisher, Luton)

Pooper snoopers
Park wardens in Aberystwyth, west Wales, are to be given camouflage uniforms to help them catch people who let their dogs foul footpaths.
Western Mail, 3.2.01
(Alexander Welsh, Llanidloes)

Late payment
An anonymous letter containing a £10 cheque has been sent to Bradford city hall, West Yorkshire, from someone confessing to having been a fare-dodger on local trams during the second world war.
Manchester Metro, 1.2.01
(Robert Holmes, Swinton)

Cover blown
A man who left a bag of cannabis in a taxi after running off without paying was arrested when he went to claim it back from the lost property department at a police station in Brighton, East Sussex.
Brighton Evening Argus, 5.2.01
(S Menning, Brighton)

Mr Fixit?
Police in Dorking, Surrey, were baffled by a thief who stole a car which had a flat battery, a broken gear box and no petrol.
Birmingham Evening Mail, 2.2.01
(David Spilsbury, Birmingham)

Warded off
Health chiefs at a hospital in Rochdale, Greater Manchester, have banned a doctor from using a mini-scooter to get round the wards quickly.
Lancashire Evening Telegraph, 7.2.01
(John Forster, Daventry)

Herd instinct
More than 250 people responded to a job advert seeking somebody to look after a herd of wild goats on a new nature reserve on Whitelees and Kielderhead moors, Northumberland.
Newcastle Evening Chronicle, 5.2.01
(Anne Liddon, Tynemouth)

Childlike innocence
A drug addict who broke into the caretaker's house at a primary school near Hartlepool on a Saturday claimed he was just trying to enrol his unborn child.
Hartlepool Mail, 5.2.01
(Carine Jensen, Hartlepool)

Caught short
Two elderly women residents of sheltered housing in Newcastle upon Tyne caught an intruder and locked him in a toilet until police came to arrest him.
East Anglian Daily Times, 2.2.01
(John White, Clacton-on-Sea)

Deeply forgetful
A 24-foot boat, a coffin and a grandfather clock are among the lost items found on the London Underground.
Sunday Independent, 4.2.01
(Ray Rose, Plymouth)

Brush with danger
A hunt saboteur was bitten by an injured fox he was trying to save from a pack of hounds at Dulford, Devon.
Torbay Herald Express, 6.2.01
(John Hoyle, Broadhempston)
