fields.headline: Readers' letters
fields.trailText: society letters
fields.body:
Poster protest

The environment department's plans for fly posting (Taking a pasting, February 14) are classic New Labour - make deals with business and leave political campaigns which criticise government policy out in the cold.

"Formalised" fly posting sites will be available to respectable, profit-making organisations and, as part of the deal, they will clamp down on "rogue" posters. The rogues could include people campaigning to stop the local council from closing their local school or swimming pool, groups defending asylum seekers or car workers demonstrating to stop a multinational shutting their factory.

The deputy leader of my local council talks in the article about "working with responsible fly posters". This clearly in Manchester excludes any political opposition. When the Socialist Alliance in the Withington constituency held a public meeting to agree to select a candidate to stand against the sitting New Labour MP, a local Labour councillor was quick to complain in writing about fly posting for the meeting.

Most political campaigns, not least small local ones, will never have the funds to buy space on advertising hoardings in the way that the mainstream political parties do. Equally, their messages are invariably at odds both with big business, which wants to take over local public services, and local councils, which are queuing up to sell off public services regardless of the views of local people.

I would much rather my urban landscape was populated by indications that groups of people, large or small, are organising to resist the relentless privatisation of every aspect of our lives, than was littered with commercial advertising of multinational chain stores and food outlets.

Dave McNally
Manchester

 Of course New Labour wants to crack down on fly posting. For one thing, it is obsessed with rubbish - except when it wants to privatise waste collection. For another, fly posting annoys its business friends who pay for their advertising on billboards. Worst of all, however, is that fly posting is used by pesky socialists who keep on attacking New Labour.

Keith Flett
London

Bathing blues

Your article on health professionals working when unfit through viruses raises some interesting points (Cold chills, January 24).

I am severely disabled, bedbound and have a compromised immune system. I employ my own personal assistants, who stay at home when ill, but I also use agencies and the local bathing service. Those who do the actual bathing know to stay away when ill, but the office worker who organises them persists in thinking I am being "difficult" because I won't let anyone with a cold bathe me.

When I asked what the policy was, I was told that as "everyone" has a cold in the winter, then they had to work or the service would collapse. As those they visit are either frail or ill, I think that a considerable amount of illness is probably spread like this.

Sue Firth
Halifax

Deal with wheels

Joanna Griffin struck a chord with her account of her frustration in trying to get a wheelchair as a "temporary" measure to help her four-year-old daughter, Ella, get around after she broke her leg on holiday (At breaking point, February 14).

Ella's leg will hopefully mend over time. Disabled children, on the other hand, need the right wheelchair or mobility equipment to enable them to lead an independent life from a very young age right through to adulthood. It is an ongoing need. In the experience of Whizz-Kidz, parents are all too often thrown from pillar to post in their search to find "essential" equipment that meets their child's individual needs - and let's not forget the expense of it, too.

Experiencing movement in their early years (0-4) is an essential stimuli to any child's critical growth period. Whizz-Kidz provides a large number of powered wheelchairs for children under five because the NHS rarely provides for them. Funding is tight in the NHS and criteria strict. Both are neglecting young disabled children and preventing them from getting the best possible start in life.

Jill Cochrane
Whizz-Kidz

Smelling a rat

Malcolm Dean is right to be concerned about the effects of a large part of social services being hived off to care trusts (Only fools and Trojan horses, February 14). But there are two he failed to mention.

The civil liberty implications are particularly alarming: there are certain areas in which the power of the social worker has been explicitly designed to counterbalance the power of the doctor (and, in particular, the consultant). Mental health and hospital social work are only the most obvious examples. If everyone works for the same employer, the ability of a social worker to represent the interests of a client/patient against the doctor will be lost.

It is also likely that a transfer to care trusts will seriously affect the pay and conditions of all care workers - as evidenced by recent examples in Hillingdon and Tameside. Privatisation by any other name smells just as bad.

Mike Scott
Branch organiser, Unison Nottinghamshire

Pregnant pause

"With the highest rate of teenage pregnancy in Europe . . . it is crucial that misconceptions do not shape the services for this important section of society," (Baby blues, February 14).

Aren't most teenage pregnancies the result of "misconceptions"?

Root Cartwright
British Organisation of Non-Parents

Write to Guardian Society, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER; or fax 020-7713 4154 or email society@theguardian.com Please supply your full address. Letters may be edited

fields.headline: Eco soundings
fields.trailText: Environment news
fields.body:
Whale of a time

Disposing of whales, dead or alive, that land on Britain's beaches can be a headache, and they don't come much bigger than the dead sperm whale washed up last week on Vault beach near St Austell, in Cornwall. At 40ft, it is longer than a double decker bus, and at the bottom of cliffs it's almost inaccessible. No one, it seems, wants to take responsibility. Over to the crown: As "fish royal", beached whales are the property of the Queen, but Alison Kentuck, deputy receiver of wreck, was confident the Windsors would not wish to exercise their rights to the rotting carcass and would certainly not be helping to dispose of it. Restormel borough council are also keen to pass the buck. The National Trust denies strong rumours that it's on land covenanted to them, and the "owner", whoever that may be, is saying nothing. Enter Cassandra Phillips, who coordinates whaling policy at WWF International. By one of those spooky coincidences, Vault beach, where the carcass lies, is just a few hundred yards from her family house and its private beach. Indeed, it is the nearest property. So, could the whale have been heading for Phillips's place? Could indeed it have been trying to tell the WWF something? Phillips is not convinced. "The 12ft jawbone should look good in the garden," she says.

Danger zone

Colombia is a dangerous place for environmentalists and human rights workers - witness Terry Freitas, the young US environmentalist who was murdered two years ago after visiting the U'wa tribe, and a young ecologist only two weeks ago. Now nine young people from Friends of the Earth Colombia have been murdered while trekking near south-west Colombia's Purace National Park. Details are still very scant.

Terrorist acts

The new terrorism act may shape the face of future civil protest, but its passing into British law has been met with a deafening silence by Friends of the Earth, animal rights groups, Greenpeace and all the usual suspects. It was left to Reclaim the Streets - with whom these pages have had their spats over the years - to mark the occasion on Monday by hanging placards off statues of Emmeline Pankhurst and Nelson Mandela and others who these days would be liable to be declared terrorists. They also delivered GM plants to ministers and senior civil servants, and, in an historic move, talked to the press.

webTitle: Malcolm Dean: Making patients' views count

fields.headline: Making patients' views count
fields.trailText: Malcolm Dean: Abolition of community health councils is a political mistake, which although not on the scale of the 75p pension rise, is in the same league: a ministerial misreading of public attitudes.
fields.body:
Who says this government does not listen? Last week, ministers accepted two important changes to the health and care bill, which will strengthen the influence of NHS users and the populations that local health units serve. But the concessions were only made after fierce protests by patient and medical pressure groups; a courageous stand by David Hinchliffe, Labour chairman of the Commons health committee; and a mass lobby.

Abolition of community health councils (CHCs) is a political mistake, which although not on the scale of the 75p pension rise, is in the same league: a ministerial misreading of public attitudes. No one saw the nationwide support CHCs have built up resisting hospital closures - which, as last week's hospital building programme signalled, were often over zealous.

Closure of CHCs is still going ahead in England, but not in Scotland or Wales. It was always a "back of the envelope" plan. No consultations were carried out. Two explanations were produced post publication of the NHS plan: first, CHCs, which can enter and inspect all NHS premises, played no part in exposing the three biggest NHS scandals - Alder Hey's organ removals, Bristol Royal Infirmary's failure to control incompetent heart surgeons, or Kent's failure to stop the butchery of Rodney Ledward, the rogue gynaecologist; second, the wide variations in CHC effectiveness.

Both are true. But once scandals were exposed, CHCs played a key role in supporting the victims or the relatives of victims. And if wide variations is a valid criterion, most NHS services would be shut.

What happens now? It is all to play for in the Lords. Ministers have accepted Hinchliffe's proposal that patients' forums, one for each health unit, should have patients' councils, acting as umbrella groups, above them. Second, there will be some form of independent advocacy for patients.

The concessions are crucial. CHCs have built up a large reservoir of 5,000 experienced volunteers, who know their way round the NHS. The national commission, which will be making appointments to the government's multiple new patient bodies - forums, councils, health authority advisory boards - will need to draw on this experience.

Another reform needed is to strengthen Your Guide to the NHS, the new substitute for the patient's charter. Two years ago, the talk was about strengthening the charter. Instead, it was abolished last month, ending the important right to a second opinion. It was never a legal right, but it established an important principle: patients' views count. They were meant to be a pillar of a new modernised NHS.

webTitle: Portugal's plans to sacrifice valley ecosystem to build new lake

fields.headline: Death of a valley
fields.standfirst: Is the Portuguese government sacrificing a treasure trove of wildlife to help its tourist industry?  Eduardo Goncalves  on a controversial dam project
fields.trailText: Is the Portuguese government sacrificing a treasure trove of wildlife to help its tourist industry? Eduardo Goncalves on a controversial dam project
fields.body:
From the top of the hill, the oak forests and rolling grasslands stretch as far as the eye can see. Cows sit under the canopies of the twisted, gnarled trees, and charcoal black pigs feast on their sweet acorns. Sheep wander through shimmering yellow and purple pastureland which hums with bees and other insects, while high above, an eagle circles in search of prey.

Alqueva is in the heart of "montado" country, the forest-pasture landscape that dominates the huge Alentejo region of Portugal which stretches from Lisbon to the Algarve. Here, in the basin of the Guadiana river, some of the country's best smoked hams, cured cheeses, olive oil and corks are produced.

The regular stripping of bark from the cork oak tree is the most profitable part of this traditional farming system, helping to preserve a treasure trove of wildlife. The lack of interference with the natural landscape means that rare birds and mammals - including the Iberian lynx, the most endangered big cat in the world - still inhabit this region.

However, the tranquillity of these hills is to be cruelly shattered. In a few days time, bulldozers will begin clearing tens of thousands of acres of these woodlands. The government, funded by the European Union, has been building a new dam here since 1993 to create a 160 square mile water reservoir, the biggest artificial lake in Europe. More than one million trees will be felled, most of them old-growth holm and cork oaks. The idea is to start flooding the land by the end of the year.

"The clearances will be a veritable nuclear bomb," says Miguel Pais, of the Iberian Birdlife Study Centre. "A lot of animals will die, and others will be left without their territory."

The nesting trees and hunting grounds of Portugal's only pair of golden eagles will vanish, as will that of two pairs of the threatened Bonelli's eagle. Ten per cent of the country's black stork population will be left homeless. These are all rare or endangered birds, and - in theory - protected by law. But earlier plans to rescue their young and eggs have now been dropped.

Once the bulldozers have finished and the dam wall is complete, the valley will fill up with water. The region to be submerged includes a 40 square mile area, which - according to a little-publicised report by the government's own conservation agency, ICN - is inhabited by the lynx.

When the dam was originally envisaged by President Antonio de Oliveira Salazar in 1957, it was to create water for a new industrial city. In the early 1990s it was for hydro-electricity. Now the official purpose is to supply water to the semi-arid fields of this region. Critics say that the area's thin soils and the cost of pumping water make a nonsense of any attempt to convert it to intensive agriculture. Others say that the water will end up irrigating golf courses and supplying hotels on exclusive resorts around the lake and on the 460 new islands it will create.

Miguel Sousa Tavares, commentator of O Publico newspaper, is one such sceptic. "Just close your eyes and imagine: private islands with jetties and heliports, 'traditional' local villages for tourists, rural condominiums, themed hotels, water sports centres, adventure and safari ventures, and everywhere a profusion of golf courses irrigated by the Guadiana river and 'harmoniously integrated' into the surrounding countryside."

The Portuguese government rejects the suggestion, and has promised to plant new areas with cork woodlands to compensate for trees felled. However, it will be more than 40 years before they are big enough to produce quality cork or provide a habitat for endangered wildlife. And some experts say that the lynx may become extinct in as little as 10 years.

The government has also rejected a compromise to lower the height of the dam. This would allow large areas of natural vegetation to survive along with much of the wildlife.

Dr Helena Freitas, president of Portugal's League for the Protection of Nature, says international pressure is urgently needed to save the destruction of further lynx habitats. "If a decision is taken to fill the Alqueva dam to 139 metres, instead of the planned 152 metres, then more than half a million trees and important wildlife habitats could still be saved."

The row comes at a time of mounting concern in Portugal that montado areas are being sacrificed for what are seen as more lucrative ventures. In the Sado peninsula south of Lisbon, a number of an cient cork woodlands - including the home of the world's largest cork oak, the Whistler tree - have been felled to make way for holiday villages, apartments and water sports facilities.

In the last four years, there has been a six-fold increase in prosecutions of such fellings. But developers of the new complex at the Whistler tree site were ordered to pay a fine of £100,000 - the cost of just one of the apartments soon to go on sale there. The Sado area was once home to a thriving lynx population. Now there are thought to be just five left.

Conservationists and the cork industry argue that it opens loopholes for legal clearances when a significant "economic interest" can be shown.

There are also plans to reduce funds for native oak woodlands, while increasing subsidies for cork's principal enemy, eucalyptus plantations. The massive growth of such plantations in recent years has been highlighted as a principal cause of the lynx's regression. Logging companies are quietly confident that they can increase the area covered by these fast-growing trees to 10m acres - five times the area covered by the cork oak. This could cause serious problems for this unique eco-system.

webTitle: New plans to extend credit union membership

fields.headline: Pay as you go
fields.standfirst: Alison Benjamin on attempts to extend credit union membership to the well-heeled
fields.trailText: Alison Benjamin on attempts to extend credit union membership to the well-heeled
fields.body:
Sally Hall drives a BMW. She has a well-paid job and her husband is an IT consultant. They own a four-bedroom house and take overseas holidays with their children. In short, they are financially secure - not the sort you expect to be members of a credit union.

Yet involvement of people like Hall is crucial to credit unions as they edge their way out of the community centres and church halls, where they have been developed but also stereotyped, and look to play a serious role in the government's drive to tackle financial exclusion.

Hall joined her employers' credit union three years ago. She had just received a pay rise from Telford & Wrekin council and did not want it swallowed up in the joint current account. "All decisions in our family about expenditure are made jointly; I liked the idea of having some money of my own and being able to choose how to spend it," she says. Small monthly payroll deductions followed, coupled with further pay reviews. "Before I knew it, I had enough money saved for a £700 loan for a matching bedspread and curtains."

Husband Bill calls his own credit union account his "treat fund" for city breaks and meals out. What triggered his decision to join his local community scheme, the Oak in Telford, was "a little bit of social consciousness and banks getting on my wick".

According to a 1999 report by the credit union taskforce, the credit union movement will have to attract a lot more like Sally and Bill if they are to come anywhere near helping the estimated 3.5m adults without a bank account to access affordable borrowing. "Sustainability will only be achieved by community credit unions if they have an appropriate mix of people in work, providing savings needed to ensure adequate services to less well-off people," the report said. Schemes needed to be "developed as broader-based community institutions with a wider appeal, to comple ment the established banking sector". Since the report, proposals for a universal bank have stolen the political thunder and banks themselves have introduced a number of basic accounts. Yet neither will provide loans for those on low income. For credit unions to take centre stage, they have to throw off their image as the poor man's bank.

There are some signs that this may be happening. From this month, loan repayment periods will be extended and junior credit union members will be able to save as much as an adult. Then, in July 2002, credit unions will come under the regulation of the financial services authority, alongside mainstream financial institutions. The authority's new requirements on capital and liquidity are designed to allay any fears over members' savings. And limits on the size of loans and the number of members will be removed.

Credit unions are already extending their membership criteria, known as a common bond, beyond a small catchment area or workplace, or association. As a result, all 33 credit unions which joined the Association of British Credit Unions Ltd (Abcul) last year had adopted a new type of "live or work" bond. Others are transferring to it in a bid to attract new blood.

Research by John Moores University, Liverpool, has flagged other reasons why many of the 670 credit unions in Britain have never grown beyond 200 members, totalling a meagre 300,000 nationwide. In essence, the research suggests, the schemes operate out of rundown community centres and are run by committed but unprofessional volunteers.

As Bill Hall complains: "The Oak was never open at convenient times, so it was difficult to arrange a loan. When I did make it into the office, I only had a short amount of time and they seemed to be operating as a social club. It was very frustrating."

Telford is pioneering a new approach for credit unions, balancing the needs of busy people like the Halls and those who want a friendly face and somewhere to chat. Launched last November, Fairshare has brought together the Oak and two other Telford-based community credit unions with the council credit union, and drawing in the local NHS and housing trusts as well as a private sector employer, Ricoh. The council is pumping £360,000 into Fairshare over the next three years to make it the model for sustainable credit unions across Britain. Similar schemes are planned in Leeds and Rochdale.

Putting into practice the taskforce's ingredients for success, Fairshare has paid staff, sensible opening hours - including evenings - and premises located in high streets. It is developing business management skills and it is networking the branches' computers, recruiting volunteers, and opening its doors to anyone living or working in Telford or Wrekin.

Mark Donovan, who chairs Fairshare and is the Local Government Association's credit union adviser, says the council's economic development unit pushed the change under the best value regime. "To seriously tackle financial exclusion in a town once known as the debt capital of the world, we had to take steps to promote the growth of credit unions and make them attractive enough to achieve a balance of industrial and community members."

Don Ball, who chaired the Oak, was initially at loggerheads with Donovan, fearing the closure of branches and that industrial members' wishes for higher dividends (interest) would take precedence over the needs of community members for a friendly, approachable people's bank. Now Ball sits on the Fairshare board.

Sally Hall was seconded from the council's financial management team to head the project. Her task: to make Fairshare sustainable within three years. It's a tall order that entails recruiting a 6,000-strong membership - a three-fold increase on current numbers - and building assets of £4.4m. Following a marketing blitz, more than 100 new members came through the door before Christmas. But to keep the momentum alive there will need to be new marketing ideas and new products, such as car and household insurance.

The government acknowledges that credit unions cannot grow in isolation. Key to their success in other countries, such as Ireland where more than half the population are members, or the US where one in four belongs, has been a central services organisation (CSO).

This acts as a central finance facility, pooling and investing credit unions' reserves, recycling surpluses from credit unions with an excess of savings to those with an excess of borrowers and providing administrative support, business planning and marketing. In the US, the CSO has helped set up a network of cash machines.

Abcul has drawn up a CSO business plan calling on banks and government to come up with £20m set-up costs over six years. With the Treasury still wrangling with the big six banks over the £125m a year it wants them to contribute to fund universal bank accounts in post offices by late 2002, are the high street clearers likely to cough up for a CSO as well?

Shaun Spiers, Abcul chief executive, says he remains "hopeful" that they will honour what was a recommendation of the credit union taskforce - on which banks and building societies were heavily represented - as long as the government also chips in. Without the backing, only he warns that initiatives like Fairshare will have only limited success.

Birth of a banking alternative

Credit unions are non-profit making financial cooperatives offering savings and loans to their members. The first was formed in Germany in 1849. Canada and the US followed in the early part of the 19th century, with Ireland and Britain catching on in the 1960s.

Worldwide, there are 100m credit union members. Just 300,000 of them are in Britain. Members save through payroll deductions, direct debits, cheques or cash.

Interest varies from 3% to a maximum 8%. Currently members cannot save more than £5,000, or 1.5% of total members' shareholdings (savings), and loans cannot exceed £5,000 more than an individual's shareholding.

Credit unions charge a small joining fee.

For details of your local credit union contact Abcul on 0161-832 3694 or visit: www.abcul.org

webTitle: Helping Polish exiles in Britain cope with the trauma of the past

fields.headline: Facing up to the past
fields.standfirst: The horrors of persecution and gulags still haunt many Polish exiles in Britain. Could a new book help social services be sensitive to that trauma? Chris Arnot reports
fields.trailText: The horrors of persecution and gulags still haunt many Polish exiles in Britain. Could a new book help social services be sensitive to that trauma? Chris Arnot reports
fields.body:
Stanislaw Stepien looks slightly surprised when I turn down his offer of another glass of vodka. It is late on a dark winter's afternoon and I have already accepted a good slug on top of a cup of tea and a ham sandwich. Politely, I hope, I have declined further offers of cake and apple pie. Even by Polish standards, the Stepiens are generous and hospitable people. Stanislaw tops up his own glass. Then, eyes twinkling mischievously beneath bushy eyebrows, he leans forward and says: "In moderation, I can take plenty."

He is a powerful-looking man with a military bearing. In his 89th year, he is still tilling a fertile acre of garden behind a semi on the edge of Bradford. His wife, Leonia, is 84 and slightly stooped, but just as full of fun. "You can laugh; you can cry," she says at one point. And in the course of nearly three hours of conversation, she does both, occasionally dabbing her eyes with a neatly folded handkerchief.

She talks with measured composure about wartime experiences of unimaginable cruelty and deprivation. Along with her first husband and his family, she was rounded up by Soviet troops and transported to Siberia in cattle-truck trains soon after Stanislaw and his comrades had fought a brave but doomed battle against the Nazi invaders from the west. Having survived the packed, freezing, insanitary trucks, she was put to work helping to fell trees in a forest. She worked for 12 hours at a time, up to her chest in snow. "If you cried, the tears would freeze on your cheeks," she recalls. She drank melted snow. The brick-like bread she was given to sustain her had to be melted over pieces of burning wood.

Leonia was freed after Hitler's armies invaded the Soviet Union in 1941. So began an epic journey, all the way down to the Caspian Sea, across to Tehran and then on to Palestine. From there, she was flown to Britain. Her first husband, Romuald, was killed in 1945 while flying a Lancaster bomber over German cities. She met Stanislaw after the war, in the Leicestershire town of Melton Mowbray.

The remarkable thing about the Stepiens' story is that, in Polish terms, it is not particularly remarkable. Almost as remarkable is how little most of the indigenous British know about these stories. Large numbers of Poles have been living among us since the second world war. Over 160,000-strong at the time, they made up the biggest group of political exiles to settle here since 1918. Yet sometimes it seems that not much has changed since the 1950s when Leonia revealed to workmates at a Bradford textile mill a little about the appalling conditions she had endured in Siberia, and somebody asked her: "Why didn't you write and complain to Stalin?"

Forty years on, the first generation of settlers are reaching an age when many of them need help from the caring services. Are those services geared up to cope with their special needs? They will be in Bradford, if Barbara Stepien-Foad, daughter of Stanislaw and Leonia, has anything to do with it. As social services development manager in the city's Shipley area, she is well aware that there are elderly Poles who are more isolated and more mentally scarred than her own sprightly parents.

"Yet our home-care people providing services in eastern European homes were finding clients very reluctant to ask for help," she says. "They have always been self-reliant survivors. But they've carried what happened to them between 1939 and '45 into old age. In retirement they have more time to dwell on the past. Too often we are reaching them at a crisis point when what we really need is more preventative work. To give them appropriate help, though, we have to understand what they have lived through."

Accordingly, she has set up a course to educate social workers and others on the culture and wartime history of Poles and other eastern Europeans. "I'm not aware that other areas are doing what Bradford is doing, apart from Reading where Age Concern set up a similar scheme that has since collapsed because of lack of funding," says Michelle Winslow, co-author of a new book which should prove invaluable for those who want to know more. The book, Keeping the Faith: the Polish Community in Britain, provides an outline of how their country was carved up by invaders from the west and east, coupled with extracts from the personal stories of elderly Poles.

Winslow took her tape recorder to centres all around the country. But many interviews were done in Bradford and her native Sheffield where she was, until comparatively recently, a state enrolled nurse. A career break led her to a history degree and a PhD on Polish migration to Britain. In the course of it, she became aware of the high incidence of mental health problems among immigrants from eastern Europe. As long ago as 1956, the rate was identified as four times higher than that of the indigenous population.

The reasons are not difficult to discern, as Winslow points out. "Apart from all the trauma they went through during the war, at the end of it they faced the crushing blow that they couldn't go back without risking death or arrest. They'd lost their families and their homeland. Meanwhile, Soviet propaganda had got through to some people here who were shouting 'fascist' at them in the street."

The post-war Labour government was evidently not immune to Soviet propaganda either. Foreign secretary Ernest Bevin urged the Poles to return to their "liberated country" and, in order to appease Stalin, Polish servicemen were excluded from the London victory parade in 1946. Never mind that one in eight of the pilots who fought against the Luftwaffe in the Battle of Britain had been a Pole.

It's hardly surprising that many survivors remain obsessed with the Second World War. It was that obsession that intrigued Tim Smith, a photographer with an interest in oral history, who provided the pictures for Winslow's book (of which he is the co-author) and carried out a few of the interviews. "Many British people went through awful things during the war," he says, "but at the end at least they knew they were on the winning side and they still had a homeland. The Poles had lost everything and had nowhere to go. No wonder they see it as the pivotal event of their lives."

And no wonder it still haunts them in old age. "I wanted to go back," says Stanislaw, "but I knew friends who did and finished up in Siberia. I stayed in England because here I was free," he says, hammering the table with a heavy forefinger. "I try to look forward rather than back," he goes on. "Tomorrow is more important to me than yesterday - tomorrow when I know which seeds are going to come through in my garden."

But he also knows that for himself, his wife and other elderly Poles, the horrors of yesterday retain an all too powerful grip on today.

Keeping the Faith, The Polish Community in Britain, is published by the Bradford Heritage Recording Unit in association with the University of Sheffield at £9.95.

Solid sense of community and pride

The vast majority of Poles who were to settle in Britain had already arrived by 1949. A Home Office report estimated the numbers to be some 162,000, the majority being former deportees to the Soviet Union.

Most of those who settled in Britain were members of the Roman Catholic church, which, in many ways, has provided the background of the organised Polish community. Only 2% were Jewish and they tended to identify with Jewish organisations in this country.

By 1960, there were about 150 Polish schools in Britain. The community also produced a wealth of publications. In the 1940s, the Dziennik Polski (Polish Daily) had a circulation of 35,000; today, the figure is nearer 7,000.

Among the early settlers, men outnumbered women by a ratio of three to one, so there was a search for wives outside the community. Marriages between Polish and Italian immigrants were quite common.

The election of the first Polish pope, the rise of Solidarity (driving force behind the independence movement in Poland) and the downfall of communism all played a part in reviving a sense of pride in Polish roots among the second and third generations.

The original settlers kept alive the belief that one day they would return to an independent Poland. But relatively few lived long enough to see the collapse of communism and the election of Lech Walesa (left) as president in 1990.

Many of those who did outlive communist rule have returned on nostalgic and often painful journeys. For the majority, their former homes now lie in Ukraine, Belarus or Lithuania, and the Poland of a new millennium is not the place of idealised childhood memories. Few have gone back to live there permanently.

In his 89th year, he is still tilling a fertile acre of garden behind a semi on the edge of Bradford. His wife, Leonia, is 84 and slightly stooped, but just as full of fun. "You can laugh; you can cry," she says at one point. And in the course of nearly three hours of conversation, she does both, occasionally dabbing her eyes with a neatly folded handkerchief. She talks with measured composure about wartime experiences of unimaginable cruelty and deprivation. Along with her first husband and his family, she was rounded up by Soviet troops and transported to Siberia in cattle-truck trains soon after Stanislaw and his comrades had fought a brave but doomed battle against the Nazi invaders from the west. Having survived the packed, freezing, insanitary trucks, she was put to work helping to fell trees in a forest. She worked for 12 hours at a time, up to her chest in snow. "If you cried, the tears would freeze on your cheeks," she recalls. She drank melted snow. The brick-like bread she was given to sustain her had to be melted over pieces of burning wood. Leonia was freed after Hitler's armies invaded the Soviet Union in 1941. So began an epic journey, all the way down to the Caspian Sea, across to Tehran and then on to Palestine. From there, she was flown to Britain. Her first husband, Romuald, was killed in 1945 while flying a Lancaster bomber over German cities. She met Stanislaw after the war, in the Leicestershire town of Melton Mowbray. The remarkable thing about the Stepiens' story is that, in Polish terms, it is not particularly remarkable. Almost as remarkable is how little most of the indigenous British know about these stories. Large numbers of Poles have been living among us since the second world war. Over 160,000-strong at the time, they made up the biggest group of political exiles to settle here since 1918. Yet sometimes it seems that not much has changed since the 1950s when Leonia revealed to workmates at a Bradford textile mill a little about the appalling conditions she had endured in Siberia, and somebody asked her: "Why didn't you write and complain to Stalin?" Forty years on, the first generation of settlers are reaching an age when many of them need help from the caring services. Are those services geared up to cope with their special needs? They will be in Bradford, if Barbara Stepien-Foad, daughter of Stanislaw and Leonia, has anything to do with it. As social services development manager in the city's Shipley area, she is well aware that there are elderly Poles who are more isolated and more mentally scarred than her own sprightly parents. "Yet our home-care people providing services in eastern European homes were finding clients very reluctant to ask for help," she says. "They have always been self-reliant survivors. But they've carried what happened to them between 1939 and '45 into old age. In retirement they have more time to dwell on the past. Too often we are reaching them at a crisis point when what we really need is more preventative work. To give them appropriate help, though, we have to understand what they have lived through." Accordingly, she has set up a course to educate social workers and others on the culture and wartime history of Poles and other eastern Europeans. "I'm not aware that other areas are doing what Bradford is doing, apart from Reading where Age Concern set up a similar scheme that has since collapsed because of lack of funding," says Michelle Winslow, co-author of a new book which should prove invaluable for those who want to know more. The book, Keeping the Faith: the Polish Community in Britain, provides an outline of how their country was carved up by invaders from the west and east, coupled with extracts from the personal stories of elderly Poles. Winslow took her tape recorder to centres all around the country. But many interviews were done in Bradford and her native Sheffield where she was, until comparatively recently, a state enrolled nurse. A career break led her to a history degree and a PhD on Polish migration to Britain. In the course of it, she became aware of the high incidence of mental health problems among immigrants from eastern Europe. As long ago as 1956, the rate was identified as four times higher than that of the indigenous population. The reasons are not difficult to discern, as Winslow points out. "Apart from all the trauma they went through during the war, at the end of it they faced the crushing blow that they couldn't go back without risking death or arrest. They'd lost their families and their homeland. Meanwhile, Soviet propaganda had got through to some people here who were shouting 'fascist' at them in the street." The post-war Labour government was evidently not immune to Soviet propaganda either. Foreign secretary Ernest Bevin urged the Poles to return to their "liberated country" and, in order to appease Stalin, Polish servicemen were excluded from the London victory parade in 1946. Never mind that one in eight of the pilots who fought against the Luftwaffe in the Battle of Britain had been a Pole. It's hardly surprising that many survivors remain obsessed with the Second World War. It was that obsession that intrigued Tim Smith, a photographer with an interest in oral history, who provided the pictures for Winslow's book (of which he is the co-author) and carried out a few of the interviews. "Many British people went through awful things during the war," he says, "but at the end at least they knew they were on the winning side and they still had a homeland. The Poles had lost everything and had nowhere to go. No wonder they see it as the pivotal event of their lives." And no wonder it still haunts them in old age. "I wanted to go back," says Stanislaw, "but I knew friends who did and finished up in Siberia. I stayed in England because here I was free," he says, hammering the table with a heavy forefinger. "I try to look forward rather than back," he goes on. "Tomorrow is more important to me than yesterday - tomorrow when I know which seeds are going to come through in my garden." But he also knows that for himself, his wife and other elderly Poles, the horrors of yesterday retain an all too powerful grip on today. Keeping the Faith, The Polish Community in Britain, is published by the Bradford Heritage Recording Unit in association with the University of Sheffield at £9.95. Solid sense of community and pride The vast majority of Poles who were to settle in Britain had already arrived by 1949. A Home Office report estimated the numbers to be some 162,000, the majority being former deportees to the Soviet Union. Most of those who settled in Britain were members of the Roman Catholic church, which, in many ways, has provided the background of the organised Polish community. Only 2% were Jewish and they tended to identify with Jewish organisations in this country. By 1960, there were about 150 Polish schools in Britain. The community also produced a wealth of publications. In the 1940s, the Dziennik Polski (Polish Daily) had a circulation of 35,000; today, the figure is nearer 7,000. Among the early settlers, men outnumbered women by a ratio of three to one, so there was a search for wives outside the community. Marriages between Polish and Italian immigrants were quite common. The election of the first Polish pope, the rise of Solidarity (driving force behind the independence movement in Poland) and the downfall of communism all played a part in reviving a sense of pride in Polish roots among the second and third generations. The original settlers kept alive the belief that one day they would return to an independent Poland. But relatively few lived long enough to see the collapse of communism and the election of Lech Walesa (left) as president in 1990. Many of those who did outlive communist rule have returned on nostalgic and often painful journeys. For the majority, their former homes now lie in Ukraine, Belarus or Lithuania, and the Poland of a new millennium is not the place of idealised childhood memories. Few have gone back to live there permanently.

webTitle: Blackpool's bid to prosper as an American-style casino resort

fields.headline: Turning the tables
fields.standfirst: John Cunningham on Blackpool's bid to prosper as an American-style casino resort
fields.trailText: John Cunningham on Blackpool's bid to prosper as an American-style casino resort
fields.body:
Desperate to halt its decline as a traditional seaside town, and beset by social problems visitors rarely see, Blackpool is pondering a unique plan that would turn it into an American-style gambling resort and provide a new source of funds to tackle local deprivation.

Residents are this month being asked if they could literally live with a fantasy which is being touted as the town's economic salvation. Pharaoh's Palace, a casino with 2,500 slot machines, 70 gaming tables and a 500 bed hotel, designed on an Egyptian theme complete with kitsch sphinxes, is planned to occupy the site of the former Central railway station. If it goes ahead, it would be the first of possibly six giant gambling centres, open for 24 hours with no limits on stakes or prizes.

At present, Blackpool has just two casinos, and gambling - as in all of Britain's 120 casinos - is tightly regulated by law. Pharaoh's, and the other mega-casinos, would lift it out of the parochial league of British gambling, and make it a player on the international circuit. It is easy to see why the proposals - tabled by Leisure Parcs, the company which owns and runs Blackpool's landmark attractions of the Tower, the Winter Garden and the piers, and backed by Blackpool challenge partnership - are being advanced as the resort's best chance of an assured prosperous future. For while the town is still the top seaside resort, with 12m visitors annually, this has dropped 30% since the mid-90s. The borough has the 12th lowest GDP in the UK; out of season, unemployment is up to 50% in some areas.

"Everyone realises that something needs to happen," says Alan Cavill, director of the challenge partnership. "The bald figures from visitors don't reveal the true picture; people aren't staying as long or spending as much." A massive transformation is the answer. "We need a new economic driver, but one resort hotel won't be enough to turn us around."

The consultation is meant to make locals aware of what becoming a casino resort would involve. Opinion is divided: many hoteliers and owners of small guesthouses have angrily protested that resort hotels with 500 bedrooms would kill their trade. Other critics say that Blackpool would lose its family appeal; that the rich pickings of gambling on such an unprecedented scale would attract criminal elements and bring more social problems.

Peter Callow, leader of the Conservative opposition on Blackpool council, says that while he supports the plans, the town should not see resort casinos as "the be-all and the end-all". Also, he doubts it would be easy to get a share of the revenue for regeneration purposes.

Still other doubters point out that seaside towns are notorious for attracting grand, half-baked schemes that either fail to get off the ground or flop. Such scepticism is right to the extent that the plan is based on a triple wager - the first being that residents and businesses will be sufficiently positive in their responses to questionnaires and surveys. Their views will be fed into a submission that challenge partnership will make to the government's gambling review body. This was set up by home secretary, Jack Straw, under the chairmanship of Sir Alan Budd, to make recommendations on future regulation of the industry. It is expected to report to Straw in the summer.

The second bet is that the review body will back an easing of the rules (at present, only 10 slot machines per casino, with a maximum £10,000 jackpot, are allowed), thereby opening the door for resort hotels.

The third (where the odds are trickiest to call) is that the government, aware of the problems of struggling seaside towns, would be willing to reform the law so that part of the tax on casinos could be earmarked for a regeneration fund.

This radical element has been included in Leisure Parcs' plans by its director, Marc Etches. He has borrowed the idea from Atlantic City, the US resort which he sees as a paradigm for Blackpool. Both have had the same sort of bad luck: the Democratic party voted not to return there after cockroaches were found by delegates in hotel rooms at its 1964 convention; while the Labour party has indicated that next year's annual gathering could be its last at Blackpool if facilities are not upgraded.

The New Jersey resort really began to reverse its long decline in 1990, when the state remitted to it a small fixed percentage of gambling tax. This was ring-fenced for urban renewal, with the funds since used to improve transport and social housing and to provide new facilities for elderly and disabled people.

Although he is optimistic, Etches admits the path ahead is daunting. It would mean getting ministers to change primary legislation and to put into practice the controversial idea of hypothecation of taxes. There is a precedent, he points out, as ground improvements at soccer clubs are in part financed from tax on football pools. The change would involve getting other casino operators interested in big schemes, since Leisure Parcs does not want to be the only licence holder. And it would mean avoiding the mistakes which Atlantic City now admits to.

"If they were starting again, they said they'd create a master plan at the beginning that would involve the whole community," says Etches, who has taken a party of officials and councillors to New Jersey. Cavill concurs: "To start with, they built a fortress which didn't have any spin-off for the community, apart from jobs."

Atlantic City's line of baronial casinos along its fabled boardwalk has created 45,000 jobs, with even hotel room staff currently getting the equivalent of £10-£12 an hour. Blackpool is not turning its nose up at that - nor at the prospect that six resort hotels could create more than 20,000 jobs. "But we want a structure to benefit Blackpool long term," says Cavill.

A share of the gambling revenue, guaranteed year in, year out, is what he has in mind. No one can estimate how much it would be. In 1998, the Atlantic City casinos paid about £200m to the New Jersey special revenue fund. Blackpool's tax bonanza would certainly have to be huge if it was to float the resort on a new tide of affluence. "We've managed to get £20m from the SRB [single regeneration budget] over seven years, starting in April," says Cavill. "But it isn't much, given the way Blackpool is going at the moment."

There would be plenty of projects to which gambling revenue could be allocated, says Sue Wright, council social services chair. There is a shortage of affordable housing, pressure on services for children and the elderly and a need to improve local transport.

The most optimistic forecast by Leisure Parcs is that the first resort hotel could open in four or five years, if all obstacles are overcome. Wright isn't holding her breath waiting for the first annual payout. "There's still a long way to go," she says.

Perhaps the biggest hurdle will be one mentioned in a survey of public attitudes, commissioned by Leisure Parcs. In this country, casinos are regarded as exclusive, up-market, members-only places. So even if the home secretary and the chancellor accept the Blackpool plan, the era of the American-style, family-friendly gaming palace could take a long time to find favour with British trippers.

webTitle: Phone line offers support for carers of bereaved children

fields.headline: One call away from help
fields.standfirst: Phone line offers support for carers of bereaved children
fields.trailText: Phone line offers support for carers of bereaved children
fields.body:
A charity which gained national recognition when it won a Guardian-supported award has launched the first nationwide helpline for carers of bereaved children.

Winston's Wish, which provides support for bereaved children and their families, jointly won the 1999 Guardian Jerwood prize for excellence and innovation among smaller charities.

Children often have difficulty talking to adults close to them about death in the family. Winston's Wish provides a grief support programme for children who have experienced the death of a parent or guardian. It includes a residential camp for children aged between four and 18 where they can mix with others who are bereaved, camps for parents, work with individuals and a programme for schools.

With funding of £500,000 over the next five years from life assurance company Swiss Life, the charity has added the family line to its range of services.

Intended for people supporting bereaved children and for the medical professionals, calls are answered by staff who have training and experience in supporting bereaved families.

Based at Gloucestershire Royal hospital, Winston's Wish was launched nine years ago by the palliative team, which felt the busy acute unit was not doing enough to support children whose parents or siblings had died in hospital.

A Winston's Wish spokeswoman says that the phone line is intended to answer specific questions, such as 'Should I let the kids go to the funeral?' and 'Should I let them see me cry?' There are also issues of whether to allow children to view a body, and how to talk to them about a suicide in the family.

Call Winston's Wish family line on 0845 2030405 or find out more at www.winstonswish.org.uk

webTitle: Cancer screening advice for people with learning disabilities

fields.headline: Pictures of health
fields.standfirst: Cancer screening advice for people with learning disabilities
fields.trailText: Cancer screening advice for people with learning disabilities
fields.body:
Women with learning disabilities are being given the chance to decide whether they want cancer screening, with the launch of literature specifically designed to explain the process to them.

All women over 20 are invited for a smear test and all those aged 50-64 are invited for breast screening. However, only 8% of women with learning disabilities take up the invitations, compared to 80% of other women. Often their relatives and carers are embarrassed to broach the subject.

Julietta Patnick, national coordinator of NHS screening pro grammes, says: "Screening can't guarantee that you won't get cancer, but it can reduce your risk of dying from it if you do."

To help women with learning disabilities understand the issue, and therefore enable them to give informed consent to smear tests and mammograms, NHS cancer screening programmes has developed simple leaflets and guidebooks using clear illustrations for women and their carers.

The approach was developed by a group chaired by Sheila Hollins, professor and specialist in learning disabilities at St George's hospital medical school in London. Two women with learning difficulties, Wendy Perez and Jackie Downer, worked with Hollins to produce the materials. "This is about having the same rights as other women and having control over the situation and your own health," says Downer.

Perez presented the leaflet and picture book about cervical cancer to a women's group she belongs to. She received positive feedback.

None of the women, in their late 20s and early 30s, knew about cervical screening.

webTitle: New AIDS campaign targeted at black African community

fields.headline: Facts of life
fields.standfirst: Misconceptions surrounding HIV are putting black Africans at risk.  Nicola Hill  on a campaign set to challenge prejudice
fields.trailText: Misconceptions surrounding HIV are putting black Africans at risk. Nicola Hill on a campaign set to challenge prejudice
fields.body:
Black Africans living in Britain are the target of a new campaign launched today by a leading HIV/Aids charity. Terrence Higgins Trust Lighthouse is seeking to curb the rapid increase in HIV infection in the African community, which has emerged as the most pressing concern among those working to combat the disease.

The charity is holding a conference in London to address issues of prevention and is due to start a three-month poster campaign. The key aim is to tackle the stigma surrounding HIV, which hinders black Africans from seeking advice on prevention or coming forward for testing.

The number of new reports of HIV infection is now higher among heterosexuals than gays or bisexuals. In 1996, heterosexual sex accounted for 29% of new reported infections; by 1999, it accounted for 49% of new reports. The increase is attributed largely to a growing number of reported cases among black Africans.

The majority of HIV transmissions during pregnancy also occur among black African women. And most black Africans seek treatment only once they have symptoms of the disease.

Pat Nair, consultant in communicable disease control with Bedfordshire health authority, will report to today's conference on a 200% increase in reports of HIV in Luton. Just over half of those affected were born in Zimbabwe and 86% had arrived in Britain since 1998.

A representative from the Public Health Laboratory Service will highlight a study in Camden and Islington, north London, which found that 70% of 748 black African respondents did not use condoms with new sexual partners.

Liza Kawonza, a Zimbabwean health promotion manager in Terrence Higgins Trust Lighthouse's African team, says: "Within our community, because of religious and cultural beliefs, once you are known to be HIV positive you are no longer considered a human being."

Themba (not his real name), a 40-year-old black African who is HIV positive, confirms this. "I have lost most of my friends and my life has become much more narrow," he says. "People still think they can be infected by coughing or sharing cutlery." He adds: "There is a sense of shame around sex, and a belief that if you catch a disease it is from your own evil doings and you don't deserve support."

Kawonza maintains that HIV is often associated by black Africans with promiscuity and homosexuality. "This prejudice is based on ignorance which, through the campaign, we are hoping to show has parallels with racism," she says.

The poster campaign will use familiar images of segregation in Africa to challenge black people's own prejudice towards HIV. Kawonza says the campaign is not concerned with talking about safe sex, or apportioning blame, but is about changing attitudes to make it more acceptable for people to talk about HIV and come forward for tests. If people could seek help earlier, she argues, they would be better able to take control of their treatment and live longer.

The charity hopes its message will spread across Europe and Africa. It has been shown to African people at various stages of its development and the response is said to have been "overwhelming". Posters will be displayed in community centres, hairdressers, churches, bars and taxi offices.

Themba, however, is sceptical about the campaign. He says: "The stigma will not go away for a long time. The posters are about encouraging people not to be afraid to talk about HIV. People are not ready to do that. The few people who have come out as HIV positive have become superstars, and this deters other people from disclosing their status."

He argues that the campaign should be about encouraging people to take diagnostic tests and assuring them of confidentiality. He is, however, more hopeful of a research forum which is also being launched at the conference.

Ade Fakoya, a consultant specialising in HIV, will introduce the African research forum to delegates. Based at Newham General hospital, east London, he wants to draw together specialists and involve the black African community in planning research.

Fayoka, who runs a family clinic and offers pre-natal testing, says the issues among the black African community are different from those in the gay community, and one of the key problems is transmission of HIV from mother to child.

Kawonza says: "Black African schoolchildren who contracted the disease at birth are now facing the stigma of HIV and being teased in the playground. They are terrified of talking to their friends."

Themba agrees that answers need to come from within the black African community. "We need an African solution to this problem," he says. "By drawing together the most knowledgeable black African specialists, we can formulate a plan to approach our own people. We need to get the message across that the spread of HIV is a reality and we need to concentrate our efforts on prevention."

A representative from the Public Health Laboratory Service will highlight a study in Camden and Islington, north London, which found that 70% of 748 black African respondents did not use condoms with new sexual partners. Liza Kawonza, a Zimbabwean health promotion manager in Terrence Higgins Trust Lighthouse's African team, says: "Within our community, because of religious and cultural beliefs, once you are known to be HIV positive you are no longer considered a human being." Themba (not his real name), a 40-year-old black African who is HIV positive, confirms this. "I have lost most of my friends and my life has become much more narrow," he says. "People still think they can be infected by coughing or sharing cutlery." He adds: "There is a sense of shame around sex, and a belief that if you catch a disease it is from your own evil doings and you don't deserve support." Kawonza maintains that HIV is often associated by black Africans with promiscuity and homosexuality. "This prejudice is based on ignorance which, through the campaign, we are hoping to show has parallels with racism," she says. The poster campaign will use familiar images of segregation in Africa to challenge black people's own prejudice towards HIV. Kawonza says the campaign is not concerned with talking about safe sex, or apportioning blame, but is about changing attitudes to make it more acceptable for people to talk about HIV and come forward for tests. If people could seek help earlier, she argues, they would be better able to take control of their treatment and live longer. The charity hopes its message will spread across Europe and Africa. It has been shown to African people at various stages of its development and the response is said to have been "overwhelming". Posters will be displayed in community centres, hairdressers, churches, bars and taxi offices. Themba, however, is sceptical about the campaign. He says: "The stigma will not go away for a long time. He argues that the campaign should be about encouraging people to take diagnostic tests and assuring them of confidentiality. Based at Newham General hospital, east London, he wants to draw together specialists and involve the black African community in planning research. Themba agrees that answers need to come from within the black African community. "We need an African solution to this problem," he says. "By drawing together the most knowledgeable black African specialists, we can formulate a plan to approach our own people. We need to get the message across that the spread of HIV is a reality and we need to concentrate our efforts on prevention."

webTitle: Phone line offers support for carers of bereaved children

fields.headline: One call away from help
fields.standfirst: Phone line offers support for carers of bereaved children
fields.trailText: Phone line offers support for carers of bereaved children
fields.body:
A charity which gained national recognition when it won a Guardian-supported award has launched the first nationwide helpline for carers of bereaved children.

Winston's Wish, which provides support for bereaved children and their families, jointly won the 1999 Guardian Jerwood prize for excellence and innovation among smaller charities.

Children often have difficulty talking to adults close to them about death in the family. Winston's Wish provides a grief support programme for children who have experienced the death of a parent or guardian. It includes a residential camp for children aged between four and 18 where they can mix with others who are bereaved, camps for parents, work with individuals and a programme for schools.

With funding of £500,000 over the next five years from life assurance company Swiss Life, the charity has added the family line to its range of services.

Intended for people supporting bereaved children and for the medical professionals, calls are answered by staff who have training and experience in supporting bereaved families.

Based at Gloucestershire Royal hospital, Winston's Wish was launched nine years ago by the palliative team, which felt the busy acute unit was not doing enough to support children whose parents or siblings had died in hospital.

A Winston's Wish spokeswoman says that the phone line is intended to answer specific questions, such as 'Should I let the kids go to the funeral?' and 'Should I let them see me cry?' There are also issues of whether to allow children to view a body, and how to talk to them about a suicide in the family.

fields.headline: Profile: Daphne Obang
fields.trailText: Bracknell Forest, seen by some as the belly button of the south-east's own silicon valley, has not had much in the way of celebrity status to cheer about. It may be home to IT giants Panasonic, Dell computers and 3M, but most people would be hard-pressed to point out the unitary council on a map. Yet it has made history by appointing Britain's first black woman social services director, Daphne Obang.
fields.body:
Bracknell Forest, seen by some as the belly button of the south-east's own silicon valley, has not had much in the way of celebrity status to cheer about. It may be home to IT giants Panasonic, Dell computers and 3M, but most people would be hard-pressed to point out the unitary council on a map. Yet it has made history by appointing Britain's first black woman social services director, Daphne Obang.

Ms Obang, whose brief also includes housing, will be expected to sort out the council's social services department, which, just days before her appointment, was severely criticised for failing local people in a joint review report from the social services inspectorate and Audit Commission.

It is a challenge she relishes. Ms Obang, currently assistant director for community care at Camden council, north London, said: "I'm fascinated with what goes wrong and with what goes on inside people's thinking - the little glitches that can happen in people's communication between the internal and external world."

An avid Ruth Rendell fan, Ms Obang is expecting to take an analytical approach of the "whydunnit" variety, rather than the "whodunnit", to address the problems highlighted in the joint review. "It's the social and economic factors which have created a dysfunctional situation," she insisted. "And the 'why' is just fascinating."

There have been only four black directors of social services in the past - all men and none still in post - and one Asian director still serving. So why would a Conservative-run borough, with an ethnic minority population of just 2.7%, want to employ a black woman director? And why would an up-and-coming professional with a history of working in complex London boroughs - assistant area team manager in Croydon, resource manager at Tower Hamlets and head of adult services for Newham - want to work there? Simple, said Bracknell Forest chief executive Gordon Mitchell: Ms Obang is the best person for the job. "Her personal qualities include the fact that she is someone who can pull people together and encourage people to work better together and handle change sensitively and effectively," he explained.

For her part, Ms Obang said she was taken with the common ground she shared with council leaders in the borough's plan of the way forward. "I was really impressed when I met the recruitment panel and they seemed to me to have their hearts and heads in the right places in terms of delivering good social health care for their area," she said.

Bracknell, then in Berkshire, was built in 1949 as one of the last new towns. Together with its surrounding area, it has grown from some 30,000 people in the 1950s to 111,500 today. As the region has matured - it became Bracknell Forest in 1988 - so have its people; a 20% surge in the number of older people is expected in the next 10 to 15 years.

Voters twice returned a full house of 40 Conservative councillors, in 1983 and 1987, and the Tories account for 30 of the 40 seats. But council leaders have accepted radical change is necessary since the first warning signs of poor social services, from an internal review, prompted the resignation last August of the former director, Trevor Farmer.

When she takes up her post in May, Ms Obang will inherit a department with staff vacancy rates of 16%, a perceived lack of direction and huge challenges in terms of commissioning services and inter-agency partnerships, particularly with the voluntary sector.

Multi-partnership working is the future for social care, said Ms Obang, who credits herself with having helped set up one of the earliest community mental health teams in London's east end, while at Newham. A student of the government's modernisation agenda, she professes herself to have been thrilled on first reading the NHS plan, which she took to the top of a famous landmark near her home to pore over on a sunny Sunday.

"It was very exciting - almost as exciting as reading one of my thrillers," she said. "It's a plan which tries to give a lot of control and power back to people when they are using public services, and that can only be right . We really have to get shot forever of the notion that people who make you better are somehow from a different stratosphere than the patient."

Ms Obang trained as a psychiatric nurse; her first job was as a mental health social worker in Lewisham, south London, and she has had close links with health throughout her career - she is currently a non-executive director of her local community health trust. "I'm passionate about public service and the social health care system, just wanting to make things better," she said.

She admits there are problems with the image of social work and would like to see the Association of Directors of Social Services take more of a lead role in repackaging the profession's image to tackle long-running staff recruitment and retention difficulties. She is adamant that frontline staff can, with proper training and support, be empowered to be full partners in the brave new world of social care.

But Mr Farmer's early departure was a salutary lesson. And with a chill wind gusting across the social care sector, Ms Obang's view of the meteorological office headquarters from her new Bracknell base could prove a useful reminder of how the political climate can blow hot and cold.

webTitle: Private sector fails to support affordable housing scheme

fields.headline: Key workers in the cold
fields.standfirst: Private sector fails to support affordable housing scheme
fields.trailText: Private sector fails to support affordable housing scheme
fields.body:
Lenders and private sector developers have shied away from government plans to provide affordable homes for teachers, nurses and police officers in London and the south-east. And the Department for Education and Employment (DfEE) and the Home Office have failed to stump up any extra cash for the £250m starter homes initiative.

In spite of hopes that interest-free loans and cash deposits of up to £25,000 to help key workers purchase homes would be available from building societies, developers and employers under the initiative, there was little expectation that lenders would be among those who submitted bids this week to the Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions (DETR), and the Housing Corporation.

Peter Williams, deputy director general of the Council of Mortgage Lenders, says that routing the scheme through local authorities has deterred members from participating. "Two or three major lenders were very keen to participate. One option was to run the Homebuy scheme [providing interest free equity loans] through lenders rather than registered social landlords. After all, if someone wants to buy a home they are more likely to approach a bank or building society. But it's not feasible under local authority control."

Another option to provide lower rate mortgages to key workers was also ruled out as non-viable. This could be done only under a national scheme, says Williams; not by a one limited to helping only 10,000 employees get a foot on the housing ladder.

Richard McCarthy, chief executive of the Peabody Trust, which has submitted a bid in partnership with the NHS to provide equity loans on 100 homes for NHS employees, agrees that the heavy focus on local authorities was a problem. "They see the programme as theirs to control, and a way to house their own teachers and social workers."

The House Builders Federation criticised the initiative for failing to tackle the cause of the problem: too many people chasing too few properties. "The reason why too few homes are built is because under-funded LAs are pushing for more and more planning gain requirements, including affordable homes, from developers, in exchange for planning permission.

"It would be fine if there was sufficient public subsidy to make this economically viable. But developers cannot be expected to take on loss-making projects," says an HBF spokesman.

Public sector employers are thought to have steered clear of giving workers top-ups in their pay packets to cover housing costs, fearing that the cash would be clawed back by the Inland Revenue.

The majority of the bids were submitted by councils and housing associations. They are an extension of shared ownership schemes that allow house buyers to purchase part of a property, and rent the rest from a social landlord.

Others, such as the Peabody scheme, and a plan to provide flats for teachers and police above a Sainsbury's supermarket in Lambeth, propose interest-free equity loans - covering a percentage of a property's value - which are repaid when the home owner moves on.

Launching the scheme last December, housing minister Nick Raynsford said its success might depend on private companies providing subsidies to match government cash. A DETR spokeswoman says the tight bidding period, coupled with social landlords' experience in this field, was the reason why they had submitted the majority of the bids. "It is important that bids have the support of local authorities because the homes provided have to be an integral part of their strategies to meet housing need."

The Greater London Authority acknowledges that low wages price people out of the capital's housing market. It called for London weighting to be reviewed, for the first time in 27 years, in its report on key workers launched yesterday. The GLA report, which extends the definition of key workers to include bus drivers, also recommends partnerships between housing associations, lenders and employers. It suggests employers do more to recruit older people, people from ethnic minority backgrounds, non-working parents and skilled refugees already living in London.

It says the starter homes initiative provides an "important, if limited funding contribution", but it wants public subsidy - currently limited to £25,000 per property - to be relaxed so that family-sized homes could be included.

A national website, www.keyworker-homes.co.uk, is being launched this month by Fasttrack Homes Ltd. It will allow key workers to find out what affordable housing options are available, including shared ownership and homebuy schemes.

webTitle: Teen advice schemes earn praise for partnership

fields.headline: Teen advice schemes earn praise for partnership
fields.trailText: Pilot schemes linking up local projects to offer teenagers advice about education, training and employment, have been praised for achievements in partnership working.
fields.body:
Pilot schemes linking up local projects to offer teenagers advice primarily about education, training and employment, have made "substantial achievements" in partnership working, according to a survey published this week.

A Local Government Association (LGA) survey suggests that Connexions service partnerships between local authorities, charities and the private sector are producing an integrated approach to helping teenagers.

The survey looked at 10 projects from the government's pilot Connexions service. The service comprises "personal advisers" in schools and colleges who offer 13- to 19-year-olds information on education, training and careers; and on health, housing, leisure, culture and volunteering activities. Advisers should also help young people secure other services.

All the pilots reported better use of local resources and good partnership working, especially between the statutory and charitable sectors, as well as between social services, education services, and youth and careers services. (Education tended to be the lead local authority department.) Many of the pilots emphasised the need to listen to young people's views and incorporate those in developing the service.

A lack of funds, scepticism among some agencies and "unreasonable" government timescales were cited as problems. Integrated and inclusive partnership working was time-consuming, the survey underlined.

Anne Weinstock, Connexions chief executive, denied that "pulling services together into a pool of advisers" would lead to cuts in other services, such as youth work. "We have made it clear that local authorities cannot reduce spending on youth services and expect Connexions to mop it up," she told an LGA conference at which the survey was launched.

She also acknowledged that "joined-up work" on the ground was not aided by a lack - "encouraged by civil servants" - of joined-up thinking at a ministerial and departmental level.

The LGA says that lessons to be learnt from the pilots include:
 each project needing a full-time co-ordinator and a strategic coordinator;
 having a representative management committee, chaired by a senior member of staff (possibly the council chief executive);
 finding "friendly, appropriate" ways of involving young people in consultation, planning and service delivery.

Chris Clarke, LGA social inclusion chairperson, said: "I am extremely pleased to note the success of rural authorities in developing Connexions.

"These communities have limited resources for facilities for youngsters and face difficulties with disaffection. Outreach workers in rural areas have made great progress in identifying and helping teenagers in difficulty."

The 10 pilots were Coventry and Warwickshire, Devon, East Riding of Yorkshire, Hampshire, Kingston-upon-Hull, Lewisham (in south-east London), North Lincolnshire, North-East Lincolnshire, Portsmouth, and Torbay.

The Connexions service was launched in February and will "go live" in 16 areas from this April. It will be phased in across England over the next two years and should then be open to every teenager.

The service is a key part of the government's flagship Connexions strategy, which aims to draw existing and new programmes and services for teenagers, across the statutory and independent sectors, into a coherent whole.
