webTitle: Cloak and dagger era lives on, despite demise of cold war

fields.headline: Cloak and dagger era lives on, despite demise of cold war
fields.trailText: The cold war may be over and Russia may have overhauled the Soviet-era KGB, but Moscow has shown no inclination to rein in its foreign intelligence activities.
fields.body:
The cold war may be over and Russia may have overhauled the Soviet-era KGB, but Moscow has shown no inclination to rein in its foreign intelligence activities.

The fall of European communism and the collapse of the Soviet Union led to hopes of an end to the cloak-and-dagger era, but Russia remains suspicious about an array of security issues.

The US and Russia have taken the occasional spy scandal in their stride. However, the Hanssen spy scandal comes at a particularly low point in relations between Washington and Moscow.

President Bush has come to power with an entourage of veteran cold warriors who believe Russia should be treated as a strategic rival rather than a partner.

The new defence secretary, Donald Rumsfeld, in particular, believes the US should pursue its plans to construct a missile shield system, NMD, irrespective of Russian concerns.

The new administration is also strongly in favour of Nato expansion into the Baltic states, Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia, a move which Russia views with considerable alarm.

The Russian president, Vladimir Putin, a KGB veteran, is campaigning hard against NMD, which he portrays as a destabilising and hostile development, and the Russian military has threatened to equip its upgraded Topol intercontinental ballistic missile with multiple warheads designed to confuse the NMD's anti-ballistic system.

"Espionage didn't fall with the [Berlin] Wall," said security expert Frank Cilluffo of the Centre for Strategic and International Studies in Washington.

The US maintains its interest in keeping tabs on the military, political and economic activities of other nations.

"Russia still has the capacity to destroy the United States in 30 minutes, so that focuses the attention, even though the prospects of that are minimal in the near term," said Loch Johnson, a professor of political science at the University of Georgia.

Foreign intelligence activities never seem to have flagged under former President Boris Yeltsin, and some analysts have predicted they would increase under his successor Vladimir Putin. Mr Yeltsin split the KGB into several smaller agencies, but the security apparatus seems to have remained mighty.

Russia's intense interest in learning the secrets of the wealthy and technically sophisticated west were underlined by the arrest of Robert Hanssen on charges of spying for Russia, the latest in an unusually heavy flurry of espionage cases over the past year and a half.

Russia, once proud of how it sped from the serf age to the space age in less than a century, now appears to feel vulnerable because it is behind the technological wave. Hanssen was reportedly passing on unspecified information about US electronic surveillance techniques.

Western technological sophistication has made many other countries besides Russia nervous, particularly over the Echelon surveillance network, allegedly run by the US National Security Agency, which reportedly intercepts telephone calls, fax transmissions and private emails.

Moscow, meanwhile, says foreign intelligence agents have stepped up their work in Russia.

Spy wars

1994 Aldrich Ames, a CIA officer, is jailed for life after admitting spying for Moscow. He revealed names of western agents working during the cold war. About a dozen double agents were executed by Moscow as a result

1997 Harold James Nicholson is jailed for 23 years for selling secrets to Russia. Moses Finkel, a Russian citizen, is jailed for 12 years for selling secrets to the US. Richard Bliss, an American technician, is held on spying charges in Russia. He is released, but charges remain

1999 Russian Igor Sutyagin accused of handing over secrets information on new Russian submarines.

Russian embassy second secretary Stanislav Borisovich Gusev is ordered to leave the US after bugging the state department.

2000 Moscow sentences US citizen Edmond Pope to 20 years' hard labour on charges of spying for US. He is pardoned by President Vladimir Putin. A retired US army military intelligence officer George Trofimoff, 73, is accused of spying for the USSR and later for Russia.

fields.headline: Brown slip-up stalls United
fields.standfirst:
David Lacey sees late own-goal keep Ferguson waiting for a quarter-final place
Minute-by-minute match report
Richard Williams
fields.trailText: David Lacey sees a late own-goal by Wes Brown keep Sir Alex Ferguson waiting for a quarter-final place.
fields.body:
For the moment Manchester United's advance to the quarter-finals of the Champions League for a fifth successive season is on hold. And the moment that put it on hold came three minutes from the end of an absorbing match at Old Trafford last night, when Wes Brown put through his own goal to give Valencia the draw their football deserved.

United should still make the knockout stage, but having failed to gain the victory that would have guaranteed Sir Alex Ferguson's side a place in the last eight they still have some work to do, starting with a potentially awkward encounter against Panathinaikos in Athens in a fortnight's time.

Even the visit of Sturm Graz to Old Trafford in United's closing fixture of the second group phase no longer looks an easy thing, now the Austrians have beaten the Greeks twice to join Valencia on six points, two behind United. How glad United must be to have already won in Graz.

"It's a difficult one to call," Ferguson admitted after last night's game, "and clearly it's important we get the right result in Athens."

For a short while last night United seemed to have called it right. When Andy Cole breached one of this season's tightest Champions League defences in the 12th minute, any doubts Old Trafford might have harboured about a home victory evaporated.

But within six minutes Ryan Giggs was forced off with a recurrence of a hamstring injury that had prevented his participation in the warm-up but held off just long enough for the Welshman to play a crucial part in the goal. The loss of Giggs threw United's attack off balance and though Ferguson replaced Teddy Sheringham with Ole Gunnar Solskjaer for the last 27 minutes in an attempt to restore some pace on the left, his attack never regained its momentum.

Valencia, on the other hand, blossomed as they had never done in the Mestalla Stadium six days earlier, when Hector Cuper's attack was frustrated by outstanding defending from Jaap Stam and Brown. This time Gaizka Mendieta and the hugely talented young Argentine, Pablo Cesar Aimar, took United on in a battle of wits to which they knew too many answers for the comfort of Ferguson's team.

In some ways Valencia's readiness to take on United in an open passing game echoed the pattern of the victories achieved at Old Trafford this season by Liverpool in the Premiership and West Ham in the FA Cup. Aimar caused Ferguson's team problems similar to those posed by Steven Gerrard, Michael Carrick and Joe Cole.

David Beckham became a peripheral figure as Roy Keane, Paul Scholes and Nicky Butt, who had replaced Giggs, strove to contain Valencia and restore United's grip on the match. From an England point of view Beckham's inability over the two Valencia games to overcome the cloying attentions of Amedeo Carboni has not been encouraging. All the United player did last night was get himself booked for a series of fouls on his jailer.

The initial pattern of the game picked up the mutually cautious thread from the scoreless encounter at the Mestalla Stadium. Yet Valencia might so easily have scored in the seventh minute when Aimar flicked the ball over the United defence to find Kily Gonzalez clear and onside. Kily wasted the chance with a hasty shot over the crossbar, but United had been warned all the same.

Clearly Valencia had not come to Old Trafford merely to sit in their own half. But the first time their defence was exposed, United scored.

Giggs had been United's principal threat in Spain and now, gathering a pass from Cole, he again took on Valencia's defence for pace. As Jocelyn Angloma lost his footing Giggs took a rebound off Ruben Baraja before playing a return ball to Cole. A firm shot past Santiago Canizares and United were on their way - or so it seemed.

Not surprisingly Valencia took heart from Giggs's departure, and with Mendieta and Aimar still probing away, continued to achieve more in attack than they had done at home. In the 25th minute Mendieta's pass combined with the timing of Aimar's run to outwit Stam and saw the Argentine break clear.

The angle was tight and Aimar dragged his shot wide of the far post. But when the second half began with Aimar again setting up Kily for a shot, which Fabien Barthez saved untidily, it was obvious Valencia were scenting salvation.

When Scholes cleared a shot from Baraja off the goalline with four minutes remaining United sensed survival, but in the next instant Gary Neville failed to close down Vicente Rodriguez, who had replaced Kily on the left, and in lunging for a low cross Brown deflected the ball past Barthez.

"Valencia didn't look as though they were going to open us up," said Ferguson, "but they played some nice football and deserved to draw." Nobody could argue with that.

 Sturm Graz's 2-1 win at Panathinaikos came thanks to goals from Markus Schopp and Mario Haas. Ioannis Goumas replied.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Rovers and Rideout ride the crest of a wave
fields.trailText: Trailing by three goals at the interval, Tranmere produced the most astonishing of comebacks to set a dream showdown with near-neighbours Liverpool.
fields.body:
Even by Tranmere Rovers' standards this was utterly remarkable. Trailing by three goals at the interval, John Aldridge's team of journeymen and honest triers produced the most astonishing of comebacks to move into the quarter-finals ofthe FA Cup where they will play host to their near-neighbours, Liverpool.

The heroes were discarded Evertonians Paul Rideout, who claimed a sublime hat-trick, and Stuart Barlow, who scrambled home the winning goal with just seven minutes of the match remaining.

Southampton became the seventh Premiership club in 18 months to be bundled out of one of the major cup tournaments by the Wirral club.

When artisan and aristocrat stand toe to toe, there is little or no room for football's niceties. If ever a side was designed to strip an occasion bare of its formality, its sense of order and its decorum, it is Aldridge's Tranmere, a robust outfit very much hewn in the image of its creator and mentor.

They took to the field last night, statistically at least, as the poorest side in the First Division and Southampton were so vastly superior in the early stages that, had their finishing matched their highly diligent approach play, the game, as a competition, would have been pronounced dead long before the interval.

With the Tranmere defence shredded often and with astonishing ease, Southampton poured forward and their opening goal was an absolute gem, Hassan Kachloul collecting a Chris Marsden pass before rifling the ball home from around 25 yards.

Tranmere held out until the 26th minute but then capitulated, Jo Tessem steering in from all of 18 inches after Kachloul's cross had trundled across the face of a largely unprotected goalmouth.

As the interval beckoned, Southampton struck for a third time, the centre-back Dean Richards scrambling the ball over the line after Tessem's header had evaded countless free-swinging boots.

Tranmere played with a good deal more enthusiasm as the evening wore on, suggesting that Aldridge had expressed - presumably in an indelicate fashion - his sense of displeasure during the recess.

Their reward came just ahead of the hour when Paul Rideout stuck out a foot to deflect home an Andy Parkinson drive from distance.

Astonishingly, that goal was to spark a most remarkable fightback. With 19 minutes remaining Rideout rose to head in a Jason Koumas corner and with 10 minutes left he repeated the trick, turning home an Andy Parkinson cross.

fields.headline: Pre-school fees
fields.trailText: In theory, every four-year old has a right to free pre-school education, even though in practice your local authority may not have enough places for your child. In these circumstances, try applying to the Early Years Development Plan for a grant of up to £366.67 per term for a private place. For more information, visit the Department for Education and Employment's website.
fields.body:
In theory, every four-year old has a right to free pre-school education, even though in practice your local authority may not have enough places for your child. In these circumstances, try applying to the Early Years Development Plan for a grant of up to £366.67 per term for a private place. For more information, visit the Department for Education and Employment's website.

The Working Families' Tax Credit allows parents who qualify to claim up to £70 per week for the cost of childcare for one child or more, or if you work less than 16 hours per week. For more information, visit the Department of Social Security's website. Application packs are available from the Inland Revenue and social security offices.

fields.headline: Bent cracks riddle of beating nine men
fields.trailText:
Watford 0 - 0 Backburn
After a long wait Marcus Bent cracks the riddle of beating nine men.
fields.body:
A finely balanced match that teetered on the edge of madness slipped over the edge towards the end of the first half last night as two red cards in quick succession left Watford with nine men and Blackburn with nobody but themselves to beat. They only just made it.

The home side had dominated early possession but the visitors always carried the greater threat, with the cunning Matt Jansen combining well with the quicksilver Marcus Bent up front. Jansen had missed two superb chances in the first five minutes, heading Bent's low cross wide before turning on to Garry Flitcroft's prodded pass to shoot against an upright. Bent, played through by another astute ball from Flitcroft, could have scored but for Robert Page's telling tackle.

The next time the two came together, however, was to prove more significant. In the 40th minute Watford's Paul Robinson gifted the ball to Bent, who sprinted forward, with only Page blocking his path, before collapsing as he passed the Hornets' captain. The linesman signalled a foul.

Replays indicated minimal contact. Three defenders were closing in but, once the foul was given, Rob Styles had little option but to raise the red card. Watford protested and Heidar Helguson was booked for going too far.

Four minutes later Helguson joined his captain in the dressing room. This time there could be no argument: the striker's misjudged tackle on John Curtis merited no less than a yellow card.

For nearly half an hour of the second period Watford delayed the inevitable, largely because Rovers over-indulged on their excessive possession. When they did create chances, Jansen tended to waste them.

"The sendings-off didn't make for a great game of football," said Graeme Souness. "Watford just dug in and held on, though Jansen could have scored four or five with different luck and better finishing."

It took Eyal Berkovic, a second-half substitute, to fashion the winning chance, running down the unguarded right before crossing for Bent to convert.

Blackburn's renewed promotion chase continues against Bolton on Friday. Watford, meanwhile, as they pursue a play-off position, will not be looking forward to the next time Styles comes to call. On his last visit, in January, he also sent two players off.

fields.headline: Hulse stalls Albion's promotion drive
fields.trailText: West Bromwich Albion's promotion prospects are fast beginning to resemble what was once the Rainbow Stand at the Hawthorns: a pile of rubble. Their failure to defeat Crewe means they have not won anywhere in four games.
fields.body:
West Bromwich Albion's promotion prospects are fast beginning to resemble what was once the Rainbow Stand at the Hawthorns: a pile of rubble. Their failure to defeat Crewe means they have not won anywhere in four games.

The prognosis did not look encouraging because of the absence of their leading scorer Lee Hughes. But in the 24th minute the striker's tweaked hamstring blew Albion some good in the form of his replacement Bob Taylor. In a move fashioned by the 30-something midfielders Richard Sneekes and Ruel Fox, the 34-year-old veteran of more than 300 appearances swept home Fox's cross.

Crewe's equaliser also followed a cross, but the contrast between scorers could not have been more vivid. Heading Kenny Lunt's ball home was the 17-year-old Dean Ashton.

It was the teenager's second league goal in only his second start and his header was dispatched with the aplomb of a master of the goalscoring art. After springing Albion's offside trap and finding himself one on one with Brian Jensen, Ashton headed the ball beyond the unprotected keeper.

Ashton did not appear for the second half; Taylor did. And it was Taylor who provided the diagonal pass for Jason Roberts to round David Waltham before restoring the Albion lead.

Waltham had had a header ruled out but his frustrations were soothed when Ashton's replacement, Rob Hulse, equalised 14 minutes from time.

fields.headline: Little's late solace for Burnley
fields.trailText: Burnley, as befits a Lancashire cotton town, began last night to stitch together a season that had been falling apart. In free-fall since early December, they toppled the leaders Fulham with a late goal from Glen Little and on spirit alone they just about deserved it.
fields.body:
Burnley, as befits a Lancashire cotton town, began last night to stitch together a season that had been falling apart. In free-fall since early December, they toppled the leaders Fulham with a late goal from Glen Little and on spirit alone they just about deserved it.

Fulham had not won here for half a century and in contrast to many sinew-toughening experiences in those 24 games, this was a benign night with the pitch cloying and conducive to the good footballing habits which have won Fulham considerable favour.

The Burnley fans, though, remain implacably hostile, still wedded to the delight of the clumping tackle and for which Gordon Armstrong and Paul Weller were booked before half-time, and for which Mitchell Thomas should have been.

There was no doubt though that Burnley, unfazed by a run of eight league defeats in 10, were uplifted by Fulham's presence. Gareth Taylor rammed in a low shot from 20 yards which Maik Taylor did well to push round the post, Weller's cross-shot skidded wide, and all Fulham had to show were a few bruises.

That only served to emphasise the ridiculous ease with which Fulham took the lead. Steve Finnan crept into the right of the area and his chip provided a simple far-post header for Barry Hayles.

Finnan then escaped again to strike the outside of the post from Bjarne Goldbaek's pass and when Burnley threatened through Ian Moore, Taylor's near-post save intervened.

When Bertie Bee the Burnley mascot was banished from the touchline it seemed the final ignominy but instead Burnley fashioned an equaliser, Weller's right-wing cross, Taylor's far-post header, and Moore stooping to head the final few inches.

fields.headline: Grainger takes lead in dress rehearsal
fields.trailText: The Worthington Cup Final meeting with Liverpool may beckon but Birmingham City answered the order by manager Trevor Francis to concentrate on promotion matters in emphatic fashion last night.
fields.body:
The Worthington Cup Final meeting with Liverpool may beckon but Birmingham City answered the order by manager Trevor Francis to concentrate on promotion matters in emphatic fashion last night.

Privately, thoughts of the Millennium Stadium could not have been far from the minds of Francis' players last night but Andrew Johnson, for one, did not show it.

The energetic Birmingham forward's performance was neatly capped by an important 71st minute goal, played beneath the body of Teuvo Moilanen after a run that left three defenders in his wake.

The usefulness of scouting missions in such circumstances is debatable, particularly given the inevitable changes that Francis will make before Sunday's Final. But Gérard Houllier's assistant Phil Thompson must have returned to Liverpool with some relevant notes.

Defensive walls at free-kicks on the edge of the penalty box, for example. This was the area that let Preston down as Birmingham's left-back Martin Grainger, recalled after an injury lay-off to gain match practice for the final, shot City into an 11th minute lead. Mark Rankine conceded a free-kick for a foul from behind on Johnson but Grainger's left-foot shot, crisp and precise though it was, should still not have beaten both the wall and Moilanen.

The goal came in the middle of a bright opening 15 minutes for the home side. Seeking a fourth consecutive victory, they opened with an attack featuring clever interplay between Paul McKenna and Colin Murdock for Rankine to curl a neat shot narrowly wide.

There was also a header from David Healy that Bryan Hughes cleared off the line and a finger-tip save by Ian Bennett to divert Brian McBride's header over the bar.

But Birmingham always showed enough composure and tenacity at both ends of the pitch to reflect their slightly superior league standing, even allowing for the absence of four players - Geoff Horsfield, Stan Laziridis, Dele Adebola and Nicky Eaden - likely to start on Sunday.

Johnson continued in the same vein after the interval, weaving his way into a shooting position only to over- elaborate. Then Hughes chipped the ball over Moilanen but hit a post.

fields.headline: Ehiogu banned until Easter Saturday
fields.trailText: The FA's disciplinary committee reverted to its hardline approach yesterday when it suspended Middlesbrough's Ugo Ehiogu for four matches.
fields.body:
The FA's disciplinary committee reverted to its hardline approach yesterday, suspending Middlesbrough's Ugo Ehiogu for four matches for a second sending-off of the season.

The £8m former Aston Villa defender was always looking at a three-match ban for punching Wimbledon's Mark Williams during last week's FA Cup fourth-round replay, but he incurred an extra game as he was also sent off nine weeks ago.

Ehiogu can play against Southampton on Saturday but will not be available for selection again until April 14. "It's bad enough losing players through suspension, but this makes it even worse," said Boro's head coach Terry Venables. "It is something we could have done without."

Celtic's £1.5m-rated Mark Burchill has joined Ipswich on a three-month loan deal with a view to a permanent move. The 20-year-old striker had an extended loan spell at Birmingham earlier in the season but could not agree personal terms with the club.

Fulham have been granted planning permission for a 30,000-seat development of Craven Cottage, though local councillors still have to meet to discuss the recommendation next week.

Most local residents oppose the club's £70m development plans, but unless they can force a public inquiry from the Secretary of State for the Environment John Prescott the stadium should be completed in time for the 2003-04 season.

A council statement read: "Officers have carefully considered the issues raised by objectors and reached the clear conclusion that the key benefits of the proposal outweigh its harms. The very high quality of the new buildings and the advice of English Heritage weigh heavily in this balance."

Pakistan will face Coventry City and Second Division Bury on their first tour to Britain. They will play at Gigg Lane on March 21 and Highfield Road four days later in preparation for World Cup qualifiers against Thailand, Sri Lanka and Lebanon in May.

Bury's chairman Terry Robinson said: "Bury and its surrounding towns and cities have a large Pakistani community who I'm sure will come to the match."

 The Scottish Football League said yesterday that it will look at any postponement requests from Airdrie's provisional liquidators sympathetically. But the league warned that it could follow the precedent it set with Hamilton last season if the club fail to fulfil a fixture without permission. The Accies had 15 points deducted, which saw them relegated to the Third Division, after the players went on strike over a pay dispute.

Airdrie were expelled from the Scottish Cup last week after KPMG claimed that the club could not fulfil a fixture against Peterhead.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: School fees
fields.trailText: If you plan to send your children to public school, you will probably have to pay a minimum of £1,500 a term for non-boarders. Borders will cost more and the more prestigious the school, the higher the fees, for example a single term at Eton costs £5,496.
fields.body:
If you plan to send your children to public school, you will probably have to pay a minimum of £1,500 a term for non-boarders. Borders will cost more and the more prestigious the school, the higher the fees, for example a single term at Eton costs £5,496.

If you're saving for school fees, consider setting up a trust or looking into the school composition fee schemes offered by some public schools. In addition, the school might offer scholarships and bursaries, so it's worth finding out if your child qualifies. Just remember that your children will start school long before they go to university, so the sooner you start saving the better. It's also worth remembering that school fees tend to rise faster than inflation.

fields.headline: Other investment options
fields.trailText: Setting up a trust can be another way of providing for your child's education. The downside is that they can be expensive to set up and manage, and are therefore only really suitable for people making large investments for their children.
fields.body:
Setting up a trust can be another way of providing for your child's education. The downside is that they can be expensive to set up and manage, and are therefore only really suitable for people making large investments for their children.

Another option is to investigate the school composition fee schemes which some public schools offer.

Parents can be liable for tax on gifts of over £100 to any child under 18. Grandparents, however, are not and their contribution can be a welcome boost to the child's education, as well as being a tax-efficient one. If a grandparent wishes to contribute a larger amount of money to a grandchild's education, it may be a better idea to investigate setting up a trust.

Remember that your child is likely to be in full-time education for a minimum of 10 years, regardless of whether he or she decides to go to university, so he sooner you start saving the better.

fields.headline: University and higher education costs
fields.trailText: University students have two costs to meet: tuition fees and living expenses. Most students are entitled to some financial help from their local authority with tuition fees, but living costs will have to be met entirely through student loans and parental contributions.
fields.body:
University students have two costs to meet: tuition fees and living expenses. Most students are entitled to some financial help from their local authority with tuition fees, but living costs will have to be met entirely through student loans and parental contributions.

The Universities and Colleges Admissions Services says most students will pay around £1,050 in tuition fees for the 2000/2001 academic year. Unfortunately, this figure is likely to increase by about £25 a year. And some universities charge more - Oxford's current top-up rate is £1,075 a year.

Local authorities assess parental income when determining how much help a student is entitled to receive towards tuition fees. Of those who apply for help, approximately a third of students will not have to pay fees, due to parental income being lower than the threshold.

For living costs, many students take out a student loan, and top up their income by working part-time or during the holidays, although parental contributions can help to ease the financial pressure on students. For the current financial year, the maximum loans available are £4,590 for those studying in London, £3,725 for those studying outside London and £2,950 for those living at home. Contact the Student Loans Company for details.

The loans do not have to be repaid until the student leaves university and starts earning over a certain amount (currently £10,000 per year). Interest on the loan is linked to inflation, and is therefore much lower than commercial rates.

However, the National Union of Students estimates that living costs are actually much higher than the maximum loans. They estimate it costs £6,636 each year to be a student in London, and £5,268 a year outside London. And this is even before tuition fees are taken into account.

fields.headline: Invest in an Isa
fields.trailText: Saving towards the cost of university education can be very simple. One of the most tax-efficient ways to save long-term is to open an Individual Savings Account (Isa). These allow you to save or invest up to £7,000 each year without paying tax on the interest earned. Many financial advisers recommend Isas because they are flexible and allow you to invest as little or as much (up to the government-imposed limit) as you like each year and you can cash them when you like, without incurring any penalties.
fields.body:
Saving towards the cost of university education can be very simple. One of the most tax-efficient ways to save long-term is to open an Individual Savings Account (Isa). These allow you to save or invest up to £7,000 each year without paying tax on the interest earned. Many financial advisers recommend Isas because they are flexible and allow you to invest as little or as much (up to the government-imposed limit) as you like each year and you can cash them when you like, without incurring any penalties.

Do remember that a stocks and shares Isa is based on the stock market so fluctuations in the market will reflect in your fund value. Do bear in mind that a stock market crash just before your child starts university could mean your fund falling to half its intended value. To avoid such a scenario, consider putting the money into a more stable savings vehicle as the time for university approaches.

If you are already putting the maximum annual investment into an Isa, high interest savings accounts with the major banks and building societies are an alternative. However, these are less tax efficient and will probably be paying a lower rate of interest than an Isa, but they are a safe and flexible option.

fields.headline: Set up an endowment policy
fields.trailText: Endowment policies can be set up to provide a lump sum for when your child starts university. Some people set up a string of policies to mature in successive years. However, you need to be sure you are able to make the regular payments and will not need to cash in the policy before it matures.

Surrendering a policy early can mean a much lower rate of return, and could be subject to high administrative charges. It's also worth remembering that endowment policies are not very flexible and some financial advisers are wary of them for this reason.

fields.headline: Why save for education?
fields.trailText: Education is likely to put a financial strain on many families, from nursery costs to the cost of sending your child to university. While many nursery places are free, parents who want their children to go to a special school will have to pay. Three sessions a week at a Montessori school could set you back £30 per week, with many other nurseries charge around £3 an hour.
fields.body:
Education is likely to put a financial strain on many families, from nursery costs to the cost of sending your child to university. While many nursery places are free, parents who want their children to go to a special school will have to pay. Three sessions a week at a Montessori school could set you back £30 per week, with many other nurseries charge around £3 an hour.

And if schools in your area aren't up to scratch you might want to think about sending your children to a public school. Even the cheapest public schools are expensive; day student fees start at around £1,500 a term but the fees rise swiftly for borders. And of course the more children you have the more you are paying out.

If your children go to university, you can expect to pay several thousand pounds a year in fees and/or maintenance. One estimate put the figure at £6,500 per child per year for a middle income family.

Further qualifications such as postgraduate degrees or professional training will cost even more. Your child will almost certainly be liable to pay the full fees, and all maintenance costs, so if you want to contribute to this stage of their education, you'll need to have a nest egg at hand.

Of course, it may be you who wants to return to education. Although you're unlikely to get any help for postgraduate or professional qualifications, the government is keen to promote 'lifelong learning' and is offering help with a variety of course fees. It is also paying for people to train for understaffed professions, including nursing and teaching. Contact the Department for Education and Employment for more information.

In short, the cost of education is high, so start saving early if you do not want to struggle. Assess your current income and financial commitments to determine how much you can save each month and try to estimate how much you will need to accumulate. Think about some of the potential problems - a drop in income or divorce, and make sure you choose a savings strategy that is flexible enough to cope.

Evan Dando
Manchester University
****
fields.body:
Generally speaking, fans like their idols wild. Tonight, however, when Evan Dando shows off his nicotine patch, it's a wonder the crowd doesn't let out a loud sigh of relief. If Dando is kicking the fags, then surely he's got a grip on his more dangerous habits.

Dando is deceptively sweet and hippyish, but when he parties, it isn't pretty. In the mid-1990s, when his former band the Lemonheads were at their peak, Dando cut his hair short and became a tambourine-bashing gonk-cum-groupie for Oasis. Soon after, his hedonistic tendencies took a life-threatening turn, and since 1996's Car Button Cloth he has been largely silent.

Tonight, however, Dando seems rejuvenated - scatty, charming, his still-dreamy surf-dude features again framed by floppy hair. A new song, All My Life, a moody future classic, augmented by support acts Ben Kweller and Ben Lee (co-writer of Dando's planned solo album, In the Grass All Wine Coloured), hints at a new self-awareness: "All my life I thought I wanted all the things I didn't want at all."

Dando is a natural crowd-pleaser, and the 25-song set leans heavily on It's a Shame About Ray and Come On Feel..., the Lemonheads albums packed with folky punk-pop songs that marked Dando out as a supremely gifted songwriter. Accompanied only by a semi-acoustic guitar and a fuzz-box, the odd song does suffer in translation, and the switch from plaintive strumming to attack-guitar is occasionally clumsy. Dando apologises. "You're shit," a punter heckles jovially. "I know," smiles Dando, "but thanks for coming anyway."

For the most part, though, the delivery is sensitive and passionate; Dando's voice rich and weary. A trembling Buddy is sublime, as is a fulsome Into Your Arms, the compact Alison's Starting To Happen and even whimsical gems such as Frank Mills. Simple songs of love and friends, they're timeless and sometimes very funny evocations of feckless youth and freedom, saved from sentimentality by Dando's frequently troubled, restless presence. The couplet "Tired of getting high, guess I don't want to die" in Rudderless is more poignant than ever.

The audience sings the Juliana Hatfield parts of Rudderless, and almost every other word too, some even whistling the solo to If I Could Talk I'd Tell You. Amused, touched, Dando plays along with it all. And new songs such as Hard Drive suggest his future could still eclipse his past.

 At ULU, London WC2 (020-7344 4444), on Monday.

fields.headline: Rorem Triple Bill
fields.standfirst:
Bridewell Theatre, London
**
fields.trailText:
Bridewell Theatre, London
**
fields.body:
The reputation of the American Ned Rorem rests on his vast output of songs, unashamedly lyrical settings that are a continuation of the French tradition. His orchestral works are hardly ever heard, and his operas even less frequently, so there is at least curiosity value in this triple bill of one-act works (all receiving their first performances in Britain) that the New World Opera Company has brought to the Bridewell's Opera Bites season.

Rorem has written just one other opera, a full-length work, and these three short pieces, from the late 1960s, are modest - no more than 25 minutes long, with a handful of singers and a piano rather than an orchestral accompaniment. But none of them reveals the instincts of a born opera composer. There is no dramatic intensity, no sign of an ability to respond to a text in a way that brings characters or situations to life.

The first, Fables, is a sequence of five of Aesop's stories in verse retellings by Marianne Moore. This piece, at least, gives occasional glimpses of Rorem's gift for melody and his instinctive understanding of voices, but it never really gets anywhere.

Bertha, a setting of a Shakespearean parody by Kenneth Koch, is a disaster, simply because Rorem is incapable of matching the (admittedly heavy-handed) humour of the text with music that has any kind of edge.

Three Sisters Who Are Not Sisters, with a text by Gertrude Stein, is the most successful of the trilogy, though that is not saying much. Even here, Rorem does not really get to grips with Stein's verbal tricksiness, and his music remains po-faced throughout.

How anyone could make a convincing staging from this ramshackle collection is beyond me. Alison Brown does a decent enough job with Fables and especially with Three Sisters, but cannot deal with the inanity of Bertha. The singing varies from the barely adequate to the impressive; Moira Young copes valiantly with the role of Bertha - a deranged hybrid of Boudicca, Lear and Margaret Thatcher - while Sarah Moule is excellent as Jenny in Three Sisters. The enthusiasm of Anthony Davie's piano-playing makes up for what it lacks in subtlety.

 Tonight and tomorrow. Box office: 020-7936 3456.

fields.headline: Rap Eire
fields.standfirst:
Project Arts Centre, Dublin
***
fields.trailText:
Project Arts Centre, Dublin
***
fields.body:
Actor-satirist Arthur Riordan delivered a masterstroke some years back with his absurd hip-hop impersonation of Eamon de Valera, who presided over Ireland between the Easter Rising of 1916 and his death in 1975. Now Riordan is back, de Valera-rapping again, in a sharp 75-minute show. This time he's joined by stand-up comic Des Bishop and a supporting cast, and backed by a loud, sumptuous hip-hop groove from live mixer DJ Lee.

In between the choreographed rap numbers, there's a comic-book plot. A young American visits a small, hokey Irish town called Cadgemore (geddit?), is lured into an election race and liberally dumped on by all the "cute hoors" around him.

Riordan's caricature of the Ghost of de Valera lacks the daft bite it had a decade ago, before Neil Jordan fingered de Valera as the Sinn Fein leader who ordered the assassination of Michael Collins. But he is still very, very funny, in his stovepipe hat and mortician's weeds, as the rosary-beads revolutionary beholding the moral vacuum of the Celtic Tiger and the ingrained corruption of the Fianna Fail party (still in coalition government) he founded in the 1920s.

There is plenty of topical material: the endless scandals being uncovered by the state tribunals; the seriously dodgy pronouncements on asylum seekers by Taoiseach Bertie Aherne and other Fianna Fail ministers; the EU hand-outs; the triumph of PR and Riverdance over substance; the corruption in the Irish beef industry in the BSE age; and the social amnesia, accentuated by the economic boom.

The Bickerstaffe company, which also runs the Cat Laughs comedy festival, has ploughed rock'n'roll production values into the show - video projections of once-sacrosanct footage of the War of Independence; DJ Lee's big mini-rig - and, for a honky, Bishop gets some admirable kick-ass into his rapping. Co-star Joe Hanley produces some very queasy caricatures, including the Greencorpse Meats boss.

Jimmy Fay puts some knuckles into the direction, but there is no energising the come-down from hard technological hip-hop into comedy drama, which is often uneven. Still, this production is full of belly laughs and lots of fun, although it will neither travel nor age terribly well.

 Ends Saturday. Box office: 00 353 1 679 6622.

fields.headline: The strange case of bondage and buttocks
fields.standfirst:
Jekyll and Hyde
Grand Theatre, Leeds
**
fields.trailText:
Jekyll and Hyde
Grand Theatre, Leeds
**
fields.body:
Appropriately, Northern Ballet Theatre's latest page-to-stage adaptation - of Robert Louis Stevenson's The Strange Case of Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde - prompts a split reaction. You like it; you like it not. It looks sensational; it looks tacky. It's strong in parts; yet weak. It's hugely atmospheric; it's light on dance.

The staging is spectacular: Italian choreographer Massimo Moricone focuses on the tale's erotic, dark side, and here are more bare buttocks, PVC, whips and bondage gear than you'd find in an S&M catalogue. So what it lacks in action (and there's an overall feel of ennui and time dragging) it makes up for visually. Designer Alessandro Ciammarughi has created a ravishing art deco set, which doubles as lab and salon, with soaring silver tubes like organ pipes, and sinister gantries along which the predatory Hyde prowls.

The costumes for Hyde's Red Court - his weird assemblage of hangers-on, including bandaged girls straight from the operating theatre and faceless men who are trussed up in black PVC with peek-a-boo backsides (thankfully clad in sheer Lycra) - are pure homo-erotic fetishism. In complete contrast, for the engagement party scene, he turns to slithering satins - a monochrome whirl of wonderful gowns.

Moricone's physical vocabulary is either brutal (for Hyde) or staccato and mannered, especially for the butler, Poole, an excellent vignette from Jeremy Kerridge. Philip Wilby's score moves from the nails-down-a-blackboard discord conjured for Hyde to snatches of jazz and a darkly manic tango. Video projections deal with the transformations, bodies writhing and dividing, arms cruciform. But it doesn't quite come off, and you feel time weighing heavy.

As the tale is devoid of women, Moricone has invented fiancée Lucille, elegantly danced by Charlotte Talbot, and here at least we get some ballet, in the pas de deux. Uncharacteristically, Daniel de Andrade seems ill at ease as Jekyll, and although he partners Talbot well, there's little to employ his talents.

Moricone said he wanted Hyde to dominate, and he does. Jonathan Ollivier, with his long red gloves, veined bald head, black cod-piece and strangely textured pants, looks like a cross between a satyr and a skinhead and commands the action. He pounces on the waiting victim, flings her into corkscrew spins, then tramples her. But his fight scenes, even the final tussle between good and evil, are disappointing choreographically, and he fails to put the boot in. When Jekyll feels a Hyde coming on, he plunges through a red plush door to emerge a monster. At one point the doorway revolves like something from a kitsch quiz show. And the final denouement, with Hyde's posse staggering up the stairs, is just a mess.

Moricone has centred on one mind in two bodies, but maybe a dual role for one would have been more effective. Jekyll said his devil came out roaring. This, I'm afraid, is more of a whimper.

webTitle: Business: Halifax goes all out for home loan dominance

fields.headline: Halifax goes all out for home loan dominance
fields.trailText: The battle for Britain's mortgage customers intensified yesterday as Halifax announced what it claimed was the most competitive range of products on the market and published plans to grab 15% of all new home loans in 2001.
fields.body:
The battle for Britain's mortgage customers intensified yesterday as Halifax announced what it claimed was the most competitive range of products on the market and published plans to grab 15% of all new home loans in 2001.

The country's biggest mortgage lender also pledged to win the "hearts and the minds of the consumer" as it confirmed the reduction in its standard variable mortgage rate to 6.75% from 7.5%. The move came a day after Britain's largest building society, Nationwide, cut its rate to 6.49% from 7.09%.

Because only 400,000 of Halifax's 2.5m mortgage customers have standard variable rate loans, a small proportion of its existing customers stand to receive any immediate benefit from the initiative. These customers will have to apply for the new rates, which will be advertised from today.

Despite reporting a 7% rise in pre-tax profits to £1.7bn, the bank's shares fell 28p to 680p, along with some of its rivals amid concerns that competition for mortgages would reduce profits.

Halifax said that it was beating targets to double its share of current accounts, a sector in which it has just a 5% share. Its high-profile advertising campaign featuring Howard Brown, the singing bank cashier, had helped it to sign up 100,000 new current account customers last month alone.

"Even at this stage, customer inertia is on the way out," James Crosby, Halifax's chief executive, said.

The bank is raising its target for new mortgages from last year's 10%. Halifax has had a 19% share of mortgages for some time but lost new business as a result of its customers "remortgaging" to cheaper rates offered by its rivals. Yesterday's reductions are intended to end this practice.

Other lenders, such as Abbey National and Cheltenham & Gloucester, the mortgage arm of Lloyds TSB, showed little sign of following suit yesterday, leaving their rates as much as one percentage point higher. HSBC last year made its pledge to keep loan rates down.

Halifax said the move would hit its profit margins by no more than the 10% that the bank forecast six months ago. It expects that erosion rate to be reduced to 3% in 2002 although this failed to convince some City analysts who were concerned that a fresh out break of competition next year would bring further pressure on Halifax's profits.

Halifax aims to remain independent despite the unwanted advances being faced by its closest competitor, Abbey National, from Lloyds TSB. Mr Crosby warned that takeovers and mergers were not good for customers. "No matter how big the bank or the franchise, if the value isn't there the customer will walk away."

The bank, with 50% of its shares owned by retail investors, will pay a total dividend of 26.5p. It also confirmed plans to give its 36,000 employees share options worth 20% of their salaries, redeemable after three years. Mr Crosby dismissed options to chief executives as "fat, easy cheques".

fields.headline: A lightweight Lear
fields.standfirst:
King Lear
Clwyd Theatr Cymru, Mold
***
fields.trailText:
King Lear
Clwyd Theatr Cymru, Mold
***
fields.body:
Nicol Williamson was once a powerfully rebarbative presence in Shakespeare, Osborne and Beckett. Terry Hands is a world-class director. Put the two together, and you expect something memorable. But, although this Lear has a stunning visual clarity, Williamson's performance as yet lacks definition; at the late preview I saw, he was too busy searching for the lines to be fully inside the character.

Williamson has one quality vital for Lear: authority. He has height, presence, an explosive unpredictability. In the first scene, things look promising as he treats the division of the kingdom as a mad, capricious game. But we are told that Lear "hath ever but slenderly known himself", and here the same applies to his lines.

Williamson is marvellous at moments: he is vindictively ironic at learning of the "fiery" quality of the Duke of Cornwall and, when he tells his daughters "I gave you all", he invests the lines with a heartbroken disbelief at filial ingratitude. But, as Hazlitt said of Edmund Kean's Lear, "he chips a bit off the character here and there". When it comes to the great tirades, such as the curse of sterility on Goneril, Williamson runs out of verbal and emotional steam.

The pity of it is that Hands has created a framework for a great performance that never quite arrives. Indeed, in terms of staging, this is one of the best Lears in years. The opening, in particular, is mesmerising: Siwan Morris's Cordelia enters alone in a spirit of serene happiness and greets the arriving courtiers with an unaffected gaiety, soon to be fractured.

The storm scene is also a visual coup, with stair-rod rain falling through a swirling orange mist. And Mark Bailey's design, with its jagged cyclorama and torn stage-cloth, gives Hands a Brook- like empty space in which to evoke the world of the play.

Hands has always been a master of grouping and lighting; here, he uses both to great effect. There is something wild and feral about both Jayne McKenna's Goneril and Jenny Livesey's Regan, who prowl round Bradley Freegard's Edmund like predatory animals on heat. Goneril also, at one point, slaps Albany smartingly across the face, while Regan is sexually aroused by the prospect of blinding Gloucester.

Hands presents us with a moral jungle in which the laws of kindness are in abeyance. More than ever, you feel that Richard Moore's perplexed Gloucester and Julian Lewis-Jones's sturdy Kent are struggling unavailingly against an inversion of the natural order.

A predominantly Welsh cast gives strong performances, testifying to Hands's success in creating a Shakespearean ensemble. But Lear rests upon the king, and at the moment, Williamson resembles a former heavyweight champ who scores any number of small points but lacks the knockout blow. One only hopes it returns in the course of the run.

 Until March 10. Box office: 01352 755114.

fields.headline: Shockheaded Peter
fields.standfirst:
Piccadilly Theatre, London
*****
fields.trailText:
Piccadilly Theatre, London
*****
fields.body:
"Anything to me is sweeter/ Than to see Shockheaded Peter" wrote the asylum doctor Heinrich Hoffman when he penned his mock-cautionary tales for children in the mid-19th century. One hundred and fifty years later there has seldom been an evening in the theatre so sweet as Cultural Industry's junk-opera version of these poems about foolish Harriet who plays with matches, Augustus who will not eat his soup, and cruel Frederick who finds that the dog bites back.

Since this show first hit the boards in 1998, its mixture of the macabre, malevolent and monstrously funny, combined with the weird, compelling hurdy-gurdy music of the Tiger Lilies, has won it a cult following. But this is much more than just a new Rocky Horror-type show. For a start, it is inclusive: a bright, not-too-easily frightened eight-year-old would enjoy it as much as a 21-year-old dripping tongue studs and irony.

It revels in the myriad possibilities of theatre, harking back to the plush curtains of Victorian pop-up theatre but simultaneously nudging at the boundaries of dramatic practice. It uses the simplest of techniques (puppetry, cardboard cutout sets) in the most sophisticated manner. It constantly reminds you that theatre is theatrical - something you can all too easily forget if you spend too much time in the dark watching Yasmina Reza plays.

And the content bears repeated viewings. On the one hand, it is about how much we British hate our children; but on other levels, it explores the terrible pain of parenting and the murderous impulses when we discover the pink, perfect, chubbybaby growing into an individual with a mind and traits of its own. One of the things the show does marvellously is to use the Home, Sweet Home motif to remind us that the very place where children should be safest is often the most dangerous environment for them.

There is something for everyone in a show that swings wildly between farce and tragedy, the most delightful of dreams and the nastiest of nightmares. By daring not to take itself too seriously, this 90 minutes offers some seriously good entertainment that gives the West End a welcome kick up the bum.

 Until April 28. Box office: 020-7369 1734.

fields.headline: Brown's embarrassment of riches
fields.standfirst:
Cash surplus needs spending

Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Cash surplus needs spending.
fields.body:
The news that the government has chalked up the largest public sector cash surplus so far this financial year, some £40bn worth - would probably please most chancellors. But not Gordon Brown. He would rather people just did not mention the size of his war-chest. It's embarrassing for the government after the promises it made to renew Britain's crumbling public sector and it certainly doesn't improve the mood among the underpaid army of teachers and nurses.

With an election probably just months away, Whitehall departments are doing their best to reduce the surplus, so Mr Brown can boast that this year at least he has met his spending targets. Core departmental outlays rose by 16% year on year in January - an... extraordinary jump in just one month. Debt interest payments and social security payments are undershooting, but it never harmed a chancellor to stand up on Budget day and announce that because unemployment is lower than forecast, there is more money for health and education.

The embarrassing statistics are the figures for investment. With just two months of the fiscal year to go, the government has spent only £2.2bn renewing the public infrastructure - more than last year's miserly £1.4bn - but well short of Mr Brown's aim of £7bn. In three months of the financial year, the public sector disinvested - it spent less than the depreciation costs.

The trouble is that the last time the public sector was allowed to spend anything like £7bn on investment was 1995-96. After four years on short rations it's not surprising that the patient has trouble absorbing a richer diet.

Cold steel

Earlier this week three companies reshuffled Europe's steel industry. Coincidentally as Usinor, Arbed and Aceralia were announcing their merger Vodafone was losing its "Britain's most valuable company" tag to BP. The reason behind Vodafone's (probably temporary) loss of pole position was that the terms of its sale of Infostrada - a clutch of Italian telephone and internet assets - might have to be renegotiated.

What is striking is that the value put on Infostrada - £7.7bn - is rather more than the combined market capitalisa tion of what will be the world's largest steel company. Yet NewCo, as the steel group will be called, employs more than 100,000 people and (on a pro forma basis) will have revenues of €30bn. That, by the way, is more than 30 times last year's revenues from Infostrada.

Such comparisons might be thought invidious. Despite recent reservations the internet is all about future prospects and companies are priced accordingly. The steel industry, especially in Europe, comes heavily burdened by a past where the politics of employment have often diluted the disciplines of the market. Such excitement as the merger generated came from the likelihood of further cuts in Europe's steel making capacity with a (hoped-for) knock on effect on prices.

Yet, whatever the promise of the internet and the problems of the steel industry, it is surely a matter of concern that the value investors attach to an enter prise which represents the livelihoods of more than 100,000 people is, in stock market terms, not that much more than loose change.

Byers beware

Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, is due to rule on whether Lloyds TSB's £19bn bid for Abbey National should be subjected to a competition inquiry by the end of the week. Indeed he could put the City out of its misery and let it be known whether he believes there is enough competition around to let the black horse trample over its smaller rival as early as today.

Taken in isolation yesterday's moves by another leading player, Halifax, suggest we need have no fears.

On the one hand Halifax is trying to rebalance the re-mortgaging market, which for the past five years has led to attractive rates for new customers and poorer ones for existing customers and which has also seen Halifax, the biggest lender, lose market share. On the other it is trying to instill the competition in the current account market that it has endured in the mortgage market.

What remains to be seen is how fast and how effectively the big four will be able to fight back. If they decide to react, their combined actions could have the impact that Halifax is hoping to have on the mortgage market where it would like a 15% share of all new home loans.

This is a factor that Mr Byers might like to take into account when deciding whether to give Lloyds the all clear to take over Abbey. Its combined strength in current accounts would give it even more muscle - market share of almost 30% - to see off competitors.

He must be clear customers as well as shareholders would share in the benefits of a takeover.

fields.headline: Adult and continuing education
fields.trailText: Having the same job for your entire life is fast becoming a thing of the past and many people are now retraining or going back to college in order to embark upon a second, or even third career.
fields.body:
Having the same job for your entire life is fast becoming a thing of the past and many people are now retraining or going back to college in order to embark upon a second, or even third career.

The government has recognised the need for ongoing training and is working on a number of schemes through its Lifelong Learning programme. Government funding may be available, but this largely depends upon what, and where you plan to study. For more information, go to the Department for Education and Employment's website.

Social welfare benefits are sometimes available to those on low income who wish to go into higher education. Many colleges provide free or cheap childcare and bursaries are available for certain residential colleges. Career development loans, provided through a partnership between the Department for Education and Employment and four major banks, provide funding for students on vocational courses. The loans are designed for those on two-year courses, but they may also be available to help towards to cost of longer courses.

Students on their first course at further education colleges or universities can apply for local authority help with tuition fees. Students up to the age of 55 may also apply for a student loan from the Student Loans Company. However, if you have previously had funding from UK or EU public funds for previous study at a further education level, you may be excluded.

For post-graduate courses, grants are occasionally available through the relevant research councils, or boards such as the Arts and Humanities Research Board, depending on the subject you intend to study. Some banks offer loans at preferential rates to students entering postgraduate study, but many are restricted to certain subjects, such as law or business.

Special government assistance is available to those who wish to train for a career in teaching, nursing or medicine.

People with disabilities are also being encouraged to train or study, and a number of bursaries, scholarships and grants are reserved for the disabled. More information is available from the National Bureau for Students with Disabilities.

To promote lifelong learning, the government is currently setting up Individual Learning Accounts which will replace the current Vocational Training Relief. The new accounts are to be run by Training and Enterprise Councils and Chambers of Commerce and Training and Enterprise, and will be a way for both employees and employers to contribute to the costs of training. Both parties will be able to pay into the accounts, and will receive good tax breaks as an incentive to do so.

If all else fails, try applying for a scholarship or sponsorship from a commercial organisation. These schemes usually require the student to work for the organisation during holidays or a sandwich year, and competition for such schemes can be tough.

webTitle: Bank lays a ghost to rest

fields.headline: Bank lays a ghost to rest
fields.standfirst:
Does strong growth bring higher inflation? A day in Bath might offer the answer

Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Does strong growth bring higher inflation? A day in Bath might offer the answer.
fields.body:
The scene is the Royal Crescent Hotel in Bath, one of Britain's more familiar frontages. It is lunchtime and Ian Plenderleith is explaining how the Bank of England has become the bank that loves to listen. As the coffee cups clink, the intricacies of monetary policy are revealed to the Bath chamber of commerce.

For Plenderleith, it is the chance both to take the pulse of the regions and to lay an old ghost to rest. While the main purpose of his visit is to gather information first-hand, it is hard for a lifelong Bank official to forget that it was behind the elegant frontage of the Royal Crescent hotel that one of the more inglorious episodes in Britain's recent economic history was played out. The "forces of darkness", as Plenderleith calls them, were gathering over sterling in early September 1992 when Europe's finance ministers and central bank governors convened at the hotel and rejected Norman Lamont's plea to save John Major's government from a humiliating devaluation. It was in Bath that the clock started ticking down remorselessly towards Black Wednesday four days later.

Sign of the times

Times have changed. Today the Bank will release minutes of its meeting earlier this month at which interest rates were cut from 6% to 5.75%. On September 16 1992, they were raised twice, to 15%, even though Plenderleith, along with every other official at the Bank, knew that the game was up.

As the official who called Denis Healey back from Heathrow airport during the sterling crisis in 1976, he had been there before. But today, Bath's prosperity is evidence of almost nine years of uninterrupted growth. The days of full employment are back and Plenderleith wants to know whether strong growth means higher inflation.

As the Bank official in charge of foreign exchange markets at the time of Black Wednesday, Plenderleith is aware of the change in the economic weather. Not that he was actually in Bath for Lamont's last stand. As a cricket fanatic, he was at Lord's watching the NatWest final and trying to avoid catching the eye of one of the other guests in the executive box, one John Major.

Today, the Bank's director in charge of markets can joke that Black Wednesday witnessed "one of the least appreciated pieces of financial diplomacy", but that was not how it seemed at the time.

Moreover, without the activities of George Soros and his speculator chums, Plenderleith would almost certainly not be on a whistle-stop overnight tour of Bristol and Bath, chewing the fat with the area's business elite, but back in his office in Threadneedle Street sizing up the impact of the likely cut in US interest rates. A new monetary framework was hurriedly put into place following Britain's departure from the exchange rate mechanism, and this structure was refined in 1997 when the newly elected Labour government gave the Bank the freedom to set interest rates. Under the new arrangement, Gordon Brown set up a nine-strong monetary policy committee, consisting of five full-time Bank officials - including Plenderleith - and four outside experts.

As part of the process, MPC members make regular visits to explain their thinking and find out what is going on outside the M25. There are times when this can backfire. Sir Eddie George, the Bank's governor, was once sandbagged on a visit to the north, but the Bank is anxious to tackle head-on the idea that the MPC takes no heed of the needs of the regions, particularly the impact of the strong pound on manufacturing. At each MPC meeting one of the Bank's agents gives a presentation on how life looks from the regions.

Plenderleith explains to his dinner guests at the Bank's office in Bristol: "We have a mandate to hit the government's inflation target of 2.5%. But as part of that we have a duty to take account of regional variations. That's important. There are differences across the country. We can't juggle all of those, but we need to get a picture of the UK as a whole." He says that the MPC has three main sources of information - hard economic data, the signals from the financial markets and the direct evidence it receives from business surveys, reports from Bank agents and personal visits by committee members.

According to Plenderleith, his visit is a two-way process - he explains what the Bank is up to and businesses explain what life is like for them.

The message from the west country is upbeat, although some firms complain of "profitless prosperity", where intense competition means that increased activity is not showing up in the bottom line. Almost universally, firms are looking for ways to cope with a shortage of labour - either through automation or by increasing output per worker.

But as Plenderleith readily admits, it is a moot point whether Bristol and Bath are really part of the south-west or part of an outpost of the booming south-east. Prosperity has travelled westwards down the hi-tech M4 corridor, so that neither city is typical of the south-west.

Bristol has a pocket of high unemployment in the south of the city, but the fact that BAE Systems is employing engineers from China tells its own story. There is no shortage of jobs and the Bank's agent for the region, John Beverly, says that more and more of the 500 firms he is in regular contact with are starting to report skill shortages.

Tough call

The next meeting of the MPC is a week away, and Plenderleith tells the Bath chamber that the decision on rates will be a tough call, with the strength of the domestic economy counter-balanced by the gloomy news from overseas. "It is the story of two shifting scenes superimposed on each other. In the UK the picture is of reasonably steady growth; in the US the economy slowed rapidly in the final quarter of last year. The MPC has shifted. There has been a sensible shift in the balance of risks from the possibility that we might need to restrain the economy a bit more to the possibility that we are going to get a weaker performance than we would like. I have only one vote and I have no idea how I am going to cast it."

Asked what he has learnt from 24 hours in Bristol and Bath, Plenderleith says: "It is interesting how they are dealing with supply constraints and focusing on efficiency gains. Businesses were not thinking of bidding up the price of labour. It is the first time I have heard people say that the exchange rate has ceased to be an issue for them. That is partly because it has come back from its previous levels, but also because firms have adjusted. It's not universal but if you are getting it here [in Bristol and Bath], it may be true elsewhere."

And what does the Bath chamber of commerce make of the man from the MPC? Hard to say. By the time Plenderleith is preparing to depart for a firm making hi-tech valves, the chairman is already on to the next business - the forthcoming pub triathlon of darts, skittles and shove ha'penny.
